# 道德真经集义（元刘惟永）

**The Collected Meanings of the Dao/Way and Virtue/Power**

**Title:** *The Collected Meanings of the Dao/Way and Virtue/Power*
**Compiled by:** Yuan Dynasty Liu Weiyong
**Volume:** Seventeen
**Source of the base text:** *The Zhengheng Daoist Canon* (洞神部), *Jade Precepts Category* (玉诀类)

---

**Volume One: Master Ningyuan’s Dao/Way and Virtue/Power at Xuanmiao Guan on the Changde Path**
**Compiled by:** Liu Weiyong, with guidance from Master Ningyuan
**Corrected by:** Former imperial official Ding Yidong, who served as *Taifu Temple Clerk* (太府寺簿) and *Editor at the Secretariat* (枢密院编修)

**The Dao/Way and Virtue/Power (Dao De Jing) – Critical Examination of Variations**
**Note on textual differences:** *He Shang Gong’s* edition divides *The Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* into two sections; this follows *Wang Fushi’s* edition instead.

**The Sage of the Dao/Way says:**
The Dao/Way is the path all share in common;
Virtue/Power is what the heart universally attains.
The Dao/Way endures through all ages without decay,
Virtue/Power fills the nature and remains forever.

At the close of the Zhou Dynasty,
the Dao/Way descended while Virtue/Power waned,
thus the sage composed ninety-nine chapters to elucidate the eternal principles of Dao/Way and Virtue/Power,
and called it *The Dao/Way and Virtue/Power Scripture*.
Its words are concise, its meaning profound—
scholars must discern and delve deeply into it.

**Huang Maocai said:**
The Dao/Way is what all must pass through to be born;
Virtue/Power is what all must attain to be nourished.
The heavens and earth use this to give birth and sustain all things,
thus they are inexhaustible;
The perfected sage uses this to give birth and sustain the self,
thus they do not die.

Though the Dao/Way and Virtue/Power have two names,
in truth they serve as one—
they cannot be separated.
In the present age, scholars divide the upper chapters as *The Dao/Way*
and the lower chapters as *Virtue/Power*,
which is far from the original intent of the work.
It would be better to call it *The Dao/Way and Virtue/Power Scripture* in its entirety.

**Shi Tan said:**
There are many interpretations of *The Laozi*,
but those by Confucian scholars—
such as Cheng Tai’s and Lin Zhuhan’s—
often explain the Dao/Way in terms of Confucian *dao*,
as if it were the principle guiding daily conduct.
Those by Buddhist scholars—
such as Su Yingbin’s and Benlai Zi’s—
often explain it in terms of Buddhist *xing* (性),
as if it were the bare, naked nature of beings.
Neither approach captures the original meaning,
for Confucian *dao* refers to the principle within ordinary affairs,
while Laozi’s *dao* is the voidless, natural Way.
How can one forcefully align Laozi’s *dao* with Confucianism?
Buddhist *xing* (性) refers to the pure emptiness untainted by form or *qi*,
while Laozi’s *dao* encompasses the harmonious interplay of form and spirit.
How can one forcefully align Laozi’s *dao* with Buddhism?

Though it is said that "under heaven there is no second Dao/Way"
and "the sage has no dual heart,"
yet the benevolent see it as benevolence,
and the wise see it as wisdom—
their distinctions must be clearly understood.

Confucian scholars explain *dao* as the principle beyond form,
yet they hold that it does not depart from the instruments of the lower realm.
Buddhist scholars explain *xing* (性) as pure emptiness,
yet they exclude form and *qi*.
Laozi, however, seeks the marvelous unity of form and spirit,
so that they may align with the true Dao/Way.
This is why their interpretations differ.

If each adheres strictly to their own teaching,
not only will they fail to grasp Laozi’s core intent,
but they will also lose sight of their own true teachings.

As for Daoist interpretations—
such as those by Bai Yuxian—
they are indeed faithful to the original,
but they tend to favor lofty abstractions and oversimplification,
making the text obscure and rendering it akin to Guo Xiang’s commentary on *The Zhuangzi*.
Thus, this present commentary
adheres strictly to Laozi’s original teaching,
so as not to stray from his true intent,
yet it avoids the lofty obscurity of Bai Yuxian’s style.

Scholars should examine this carefully.

---

**Chapter: "The Dao/Way That Can Be Spoken Of"**
**Note on textual differences:** *He Shang Gong* titled this chapter *"The Chapter of Embodiment"* (体道章),
and Zhao Shixian titled it *"The Chapter of Illuminating Principles and True Meanings"* (显理会真义章).
This follows the *Ming Huang* (Tang Emperor) edition.

**Tang Emperor’s commentary on this chapter:**
At the origin of all marvelous transformations and the source of ten thousand changes,
the chapter first marks the Dao/Way as *the void’s utmost* (虚极),
to reveal where all marvels converge.
Thus, "the Dao/Way that can be spoken of" and "the name that can be given"
clarify the substance and function of the Dao/Way;
"without name, yet with name" reveals the essence and its traces;
"without desire, yet with desire" distinguishes two perspectives;
"the same origin, yet different names" shows how the undifferentiated gives rise to all things;
"the same name, yet called the mysterious" shows how all things return to the undifferentiated.
"Mysterious again, mysterious again" elucidates the interplay of unity and forgetfulness.
"The gateway of all marvels" indicates the path by which one attains enlightenment and exits.

These are the stages of progress and refinement,
the gradual path to enlightenment and true understanding.

**Du Guangting’s *Broad Commentary on the Daoist Canon* (广圣义) explaining the Emperor’s commentary:**
*"Ming"* (明) means luminous and pure—
to reveal openly.
*"Miao ben"* (妙本) refers to the Dao/Way.
At the beginning of the Scripture,
it clarifies the Dao/Way’s origin.
*"You"* (由) means to follow;
*"Qi"* (起) means to arise.
*"Wan"* (万) signifies the vastness of numbers.
*"Hua"* (化) means transformation and adaptation—
it speaks of all things arising from the Dao/Way through transformation.
*"Zong"* (宗) means master;
*"yuan"* (源) means origin.
Since all transformations arise from the Dao/Way,
then knowing the Dao/Way is the master and origin of all transformations.

From this chapter, all principles emerge,
like the ceaseless flow of water from its source.
*"Xu ji"* (虚极) is the Dao/Way’s marvelous origin,
the Dao/Way being its ultimate designation.

This chapter first marks the Dao/Way that can be spoken of as its substance,
and the name that can be given as its function.
The final chapter returns to the gateway of all marvels,
where all traces converge toward the Dao/Way’s origin,
and once again directs us toward the Dao/Way’s true essence.

Within this gateway, seven distinctions are made:
1. *"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of"* and *"the name that can be given"* clarify its substance and function.
2. *"Substance and function"* (体用) means mutual reliance.
   Substance has no fixed form, function has no fixed application—
   without function, substance cannot be displayed;
   without substance, function cannot be established.
   Sometimes there is substance, sometimes function;
   sometimes both are real, sometimes provisional;
   sometimes manifest, sometimes symbolic;
   sometimes named, sometimes represented—
   they mutually define each other,
   alternating to reveal their nature.
   Thus, substance and function are understood as interdependent clarifications.

3. *"Without name, yet with name"* reveals the Dao/Way’s essence and its traces.
   Essence and traces are mutually generative.
   There is essence, then traces arise;
   traces lead us to the essence.
   Without essence, traces cannot appear;
   without traces, essence cannot be sought—
   traces emerge with each event,
   serving as the essence’s manifestation.

The root is the **origin**—
the traces, the **manifestation**.
Traces are the footprints left behind,
yet are they truly the foot?
Traces arise from the foot,
but to take traces as the foot
and then command others to walk upon them—
this only further distances one from the Dao.

Thus, traces are the **end**.

3. *"With desire and without desire"*—
the two perspectives differ.
**Observation** is the **practice** itself.
One observes with the **self’s perception**,
another with the **spirit’s discernment**.
To still the sight externally,
to concentrate the spirit internally,
to illuminate the single mind within,
to forget the myriad forms without—
this is called **observation**.

It serves as the **stage for Daoist practice**,
the **gradual path to veracity**,
first relying on observation and practice,
entering the **Gate of the Mysterious**.

The Dao cannot be attained by name,
nor sought through form—
thus, observation and practice become the **path of cultivation**.
For those with desire, it leads to **death**;
for those without desire, it aligns with **life**.
Thus, one observes **life and death**,
their paths diverging.

4. *"Same origin, different names"*—
the **Uncarved Block** disperses into **vessels**.
The **Great Uncarved Block** is the **Dao**.
The Dao disperses as **spiritual luminosity**,
flows as **sun and moon**,
divides into **the Five Phases**,
gives birth to **all things**.
**Vessels** are **formed with function**.
The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"What is above form is called the Dao;
what is below form is called vessels."*

5. *"Called the Mysterious"*—
the **return to the Uncarved Block after formation**.
Spiritual luminosity, sun and moon,
the Five Phases, all things—
though formed and vessel-like,
they all conform to the Dao,
hence, **"return to the Uncarved Block."**

6. *"The Mysterious beyond the Mysterious"*—
discerning **dual forgetting**.
When forming vessels,
one must remain in the Uncarved Block.
After returning to the Uncarved Block,
this Uncarved Block is also forgotten—
only then does one **harmonize with the Dao**.
Thus, it is called *"the Mysterious beyond the Mysterious."*
**Dual forgetting** means
forgetting both vessel and Uncarved Block.

7. *"The Gate of All Mysteries"*—
showing the **path of transcendence**.
When vessel and Uncarved Block are both forgotten,
one clearly harmonizes with the Dao,
returning to the **beginning of transformation**—
the **Gate of All Mysteries**.
Humans and all things equally receive from the Dao;
with **action and desire**, one loses the Dao and harms life.
By **abandoning desire and preserving harmony**, one returns to the root—
this is called the **essential gateway of the Dao**.
**Transcendence** is **leaving the world**.

Zhang Chong replied:
The **Dao** is the **natural Way**—
heaven, though highest, does not know what it covers;
this is the **naturalness of Heaven’s Dao**.
Earth, though vast, does not know what it bears;
this is the **naturalness of Earth’s Dao**.
Humans, standing between heaven and earth,
have eyes to see, like heaven’s sun and moon;
have mouths to speak, like heaven’s thunder.
Breathing brings wind, exhaling brings mist,
spittle and coughs like rain and dew—
their **hearing and awareness** mirror **spiritual luminosity**,
all the **naturalness of Heaven’s Dao**, which I possess.

As for the four limbs complete,
like the four **directions** steadfastly grounded,
the **sacred bone** at the crown,
like **Mount Sumeru** towering—
blood flowing through the vessels,
like rivers encircling—
this is the **naturalness of Earth’s Dao**, which I also possess.

If one truly embodies the **natural Dao of heaven and earth**
and cultivates it further,
the turbid becomes clear,
the ordinary attains immortality,
and the virtuous becomes sage.
Thus, **"Embodying the Dao"** is the first chapter of *The Daoist Classic*.

The Dao that can be spoken is **not the eternal Dao**.
The name that can be named is **not the eternal name**.
**Nameless**, it is the **beginning of heaven and earth**.
**Named**, it is the **mother of all things**.
Thus, one must **constantly observe without desire** to see its **mystery**,
and **constantly observe with desire** to see its **outcome**.

These two, though of the same origin, bear different names—
both called the **Mysterious**,
the **Mysterious beyond the Mysterious**,
the **Gate of All Mysteries**.

**Annotations from the Emperor’s Edition** omit the *"without"* character;
here, following the **River Upper Master’s** version.

The **River Upper Master** said:
*"The Dao that can be spoken"* refers to **doctrine, governance, and teaching**.
*"Not the eternal Dao"* means it is **not the natural, long-life Dao**.
The **eternal Dao** constantly **nurtures the spirit with non-action**,
**governs without interference**, **conceals light and hides brilliance**,
**erases traces and obscures origins**—
it cannot be named as the Dao.

*"The name that can be named"* refers to **wealth, nobility, and eternal honor**.
*"Not the eternal name"* means it is **not the natural, enduring name**.
The **eternal name** is like an **infant before speech**,
an **egg before hatching**,
a **pearl within the shell**,
a **jewel in stone**—
though internally luminous,
externally it appears **foolish and crude**.

**Nameless** is the **beginning of heaven and earth**.
**Nameless** refers to the **Dao**.
The Dao is formless, hence **unnamable**.
**Beginning** is the **origin of the Dao**.
It exhales *qi* and spreads transformation,
emerging from **emptiness and non-being**,
as the **origin of heaven and earth**.

**Named** is the **mother of all things**.
**Named** refers to **heaven and earth**.
Heaven and earth have **form, position, yin, and yang**,
**hardness and softness**—this is their **named** quality.
**Mother of all things**—heaven and earth contain *qi* and give birth to all things,
nurturing them to maturity, like a mother rearing her child.

Thus, one must **constantly observe without desire** to grasp its **essence**.
**Essence** is the **key**.
If one constantly **abandons desire**, they can observe the **core of the Dao**.
**Core** means **unity**.
Unity issues forth, spreading **named principles**,
clarifying **right and wrong**.

One must **constantly observe with desire** to see its **outcome**.
**Outcome** means **return**.
Those who constantly **hold desire** can observe the **trends of the world**.

These two, though of the same origin, bear different names—
the two refer to **with and without desire**,
same origin means **both arise from human nature**,
yet different names refer to their **distinct outcomes**.
The name **"without desire"** leads to **eternal life**,
the name **"with desire"** leads to **self-destruction**.

Both are called the **Mysterious**.
**Mysterious** means **heaven**.
It speaks of those with and without desire **both receiving *qi* from heaven**.

**The Mysterious beyond the Mysterious**—
within heaven, there is another heaven.
The **thickness of received *qi*** varies—
those who obtain **central harmony and nourishment** become **sage and virtuous**,
those who receive **disorder and corruption** become **greedy and lustful**.

**The Gate of All Mysteries**—
to know that within heaven there is another heaven,
that received *qi* varies in thickness,
and to **eliminate emotions, abandon desire**,
**preserving central harmony**—
this is called knowing the **essential gateway of the Dao**.

**Wang Fu-si** said:
*"The Dao that can be spoken, until it reaches the eternal name."*

The Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao;
The name that can be named is not the constant name.
To point to things and shape forms is not its eternal essence—
Thus, it cannot be spoken, cannot be named.

The **Nameless** is the mother of all things.
All that exists begins from the **Nameless**—
Thus, before form and name arise,
It is the origin of all things.

When form and name appear,
It nurtures, sustains, and guides them—
It is their mother.

It speaks of the Dao:
Beginning from formless, nameless,
It gives rise to all things,
Yet its origin and completion are unknown—
**Mysterious beyond the Mysterious**.

Thus, one must **constantly be without desire** to perceive its subtlety.
**Subtlety** is the utmost refinement.
All things begin from the subtle and then take form,
From the **Nameless** and then come to life—
Thus, one must **constantly be without desire**,
Empty and void within,
To perceive the subtlety of their origin.

One must **constantly have desire** to perceive its **boundaries**.
**Boundaries** mean **completion**.
All that exists, for its utility,
Must rely on the **Nameless** for its use.
The root of desire,
When aligned with the Dao, finds fulfillment.

Thus, one must **constantly have desire**,
To perceive the completion of all things’ boundaries.
These two are the **Gate of All Mysteries**.

Both originate from the **Mother**,
Emerging together from the **Mysterious**—
Though their names differ in application,
At the beginning, it is called **Origin**,
At the end, it is called **Mother**.

The **Mysterious** is the **Dark**—
Silent, without form.
The **Origin** and **Mother** arise from it,
Yet cannot be named—
Thus, it cannot be spoken.
The same is called **Mysterious**,
And when spoken of, it is called **Mysterious**,
Taken from what cannot be grasped and thus named so.

To call it so,
Is to say it cannot be confined to a single **Mysterious**—
To name it thus is to stray far.

Thus, it is said: **Mysterious beyond the Mysterious**.
All subtleties arise from the same source—
Thus, it is called the **Gate of All Mysteries**.

Emperor Tang Minghuang said:
*The Dao that can be spoken reaches the point of no name.*

The **Dao** is the **uttermost subtlety in action**;
The **name** is the designation given to things as they receive its use.
Its use applies to things—
Thus, it is called *speakable Dao*.
Names arise from use—
Thus, it is called *nameable name*.

If its application is boundless and without fixed form,
Then it transcends a single Dao;
If things differ and names vary,
Then it transcends a single name.

Thus, it is forcibly named **Dao**,
Yet the Dao is always **Nameless**.

**Commentary:**
The **Dao** is the **forcible name** for the **uttermost subtlety of origin**.
*Training* (通训) and *direct instruction* (径首一字) mark the essence.
That which can be spoken of is this **subtle origin**,
The pathway through which all things arise—
Thus, it is called *speakable Dao*.
That which is **not the constant Dao** is the **subtle origin** in transformation,
Its use without fixed direction—
Forcibly named, yet not confined to one Dao—
Thus, it is called *not the constant Dao*.

The **name** is the designation given to things as they receive the Dao’s use.
The first character marks the essence.
That which can be named is because names arise from use—
Thus, it is called *nameable name*.
That which is **not the constant name**—
In Heaven, it is called *Clear*,
On Earth, it is called *Tranquil*,
In the Spirit, it is called *Numinous*,
In the Valley, it is called *Full*—
Though one, their applications differ—
Thus, it is called *not the constant name*.

The **Nameless** is the mother of all things.
The **Nameless** is the **subtle origin**.
The **subtle origin**, manifesting as *qi*,
Supports Heaven and Earth—
Heaven and Earth rely on it for their beginning—
Thus, it is called the **Nameless**.

The **Named** is its application.
Its application, skillfully applied,
Nurtures all things—
Things receive their nourishment,
Thus, they have names.

**Commentary:**
The **Nameless** is before transformations arise,
Without forcible naming.
The **subtle origin** at its beginning,
Before the **Nameless** descends as *qi*,
Opens and establishes Heaven and Earth.
Heaven and Earth mutually support each other as their origin—
Thus, it is called the **Nameless**, the origin of Heaven and Earth.
This is the *Taiji* generating the *Two Principles* in the *Yijing*.

*Powering and supporting* (权舆) means *beginning* (as in the *Er Ya*).
The **Named** is its skillful application,
With forcible naming.
When transformations arise and all things are formed,
The **subtle origin** branches outward,
Providing for human use—
Through its abundant nourishment,
It is called the **Mother**.

The **Mother** is defined by its abundant nourishment—
Yet the **Nameless** and **Named** are distinctions made by the Sage
To clarify the unity and difference of origin and trace,
While the Dao does not depend on having or lacking names.

**Constantly without desire** to perceive its subtlety,
**Constantly with desire** to perceive its boundaries.

Humans are born in stillness—
This is Heaven’s nature;
When moved by things, they act—
This is the nature of desire.
If one constantly guards purity and clarity,
Releases the mind and frees the spirit,
Returns to reflect the true nature,
Then one perceives the **subtle origin**.

If one does not govern one’s emotions,
Chases desires and moves,
The nature is lost to desire,
Lost to the Dao’s source—
To perceive the **subtle origin**,
One only sees its **boundaries**.

**Desire** is the movement of nature—
To say it is to establish teaching through thought.
**Constantly without desire** means
The nature is pure and clear,
Without attachment to speech or thought,
Then one sees the Dao’s utmost subtlety.

**Constantly with desire** means
From the origin, action arises,
Teaching follows speech,
Responding to things and communicating effortlessly,
Transforming the world—
Then one sees where all people converge.

**Boundaries** mean **convergence**.
These two arise together yet differ in name—
As above, both originate from the Dao—
Thus, they are the same.
Action emerges from application,
Names are established by use—
Thus, their names differ.

This refers to the matters above:
The two—**speakable/unspeakable Dao**, **named/nameless**, **with/without desire**—
Each has its pair—
Thus, they are called the two.

「Both share the wondrous origin,
Thus, they are called the same.

From the origin descending,
Names are established by application—
Thus, their names differ.

The same is called **Dao/Way**,
When it manifests, names differ—
The same is called **Dao/Way**.

**Dao/Way** is profound and wondrous.
When it is spoken of as manifest,
Names differ—
This is descending from the origin to describe its traces.

When it is spoken of as the same,
It is profound and wondrous—
This is gathering traces to return to the origin.

Returning to the origin is profound and wondrous,
Thus, it is called **Dao/Way**.

The **Dao/Way** again profound,
Is the gateway to all wondrous things.
When the **intention-root** does not arise,
It aligns with the profound and wondrous—
Yet still, one may cling to **Dao/Way** as stagnation,
Failing to achieve dual forgetfulness—
Thus, it is entrusted with **Dao/Way** again profound,
To dispel **Dao/Way** itself.

To **illuminate the Dao/Way of non-desire in non-desire**—
If one can do this,
All dharmas emerge through it—
Thus, it is called the gateway to all wondrous things.

Gathering traces and returning to the origin is called profound and wondrous.
If one dwells in this wondrous state,
Further progress remains—
Though differing in name,
It is equal without distinction—
Thus, it is entrusted with **Dao/Way** again profound,
To dispel **Dao/Way**,
Lest one become stagnant in **Dao/Way**,
And achieve dual forgetfulness—
This is called **non-abiding**.

**Non-abiding** then reveals all.

The **intention-root** is annotated in the *Sutra of the Western Ascension* as:
*"Same origin, differing names—
Each thing generates its own intention-root."*

Now, when the **intention-root** does not arise,
It aligns with the profound and wondrous.

To **illuminate the Dao/Way of non-desire in non-desire**—
This is the desire to eliminate desire,
Thus, seeking non-desire;
Desire to seek non-desire,
Its origin is already detached from desire.

When desire is truly absent,
Non-desire is also absent—
Dispelling again and again,
This is called **total forgetfulness**.

Observing thus directly,
This is called all wondrous things.

Though their wondrousness is manifold,
All emerge from this gateway—
Thus, it is called the gateway to all wondrous things.

Du Guangting’s *Expanded Explanation of the Sacred Meaning* states:
**"The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao/Way."**

The **Dao/Way** is the utmost emptiness and extremity,
Neither form nor sound,
Enduring through later kalpas yet not ceasing,
Preceding heaven and earth yet not beginning.
Roundly permeating, serene and tranquil,
Neither beginning nor ceasing—
Sages, through the **virtue/power** of **permeating transformation**,
Can trace its manifestations,
Yet its origin can be **awakened**—
Thus, they name the **virtue/power** of **permeating transformation** as **Dao/Way**.

The **principle** is marked by the single character,
Which is **non-action and formless**—
The **substance** of **Dao/Way**.
The two characters **"can be spoken of"**—
Are **manifestation and transformation**—
The **functions** of **Dao/Way**.

Within these three characters,
The **substance** and **functions** are established.
The **substance** is wondrous beyond measure,
The **functions** are vast beyond reckoning—
Thus, it is the wondrous origin of **emptiness to the extreme**.

Dispersed, it becomes all things,
Unconstrained by a single direction—
Thus, it is called **without fixed direction**.

But adhering to the single **Dao/Way**,
It clarifies that all things rely on **Dao/Way** for transformation—
Thus, it does not favor partiality.

Lofty yet without limit,
It contains all without exclusion—
This is **greatness**.

Lofty yet without limit,
It does not cling to the lofty—
Great yet without bounds,
It does not cling to the outer—
This is **transience**.

**Transience**, meaning to go forth,
Penetrates the boundless,
Reaching all without obstruction—
This is **distant**.

Empty-hearted, abiding in the single **Dao/Way**,
This is the **return and restoration**.
**Return**, meaning to revert—
Thus, it is called the **return and restoration**.

This draws from Chapter Twenty-Five of the *Dao De Jing*:
*"From the origin, all things arise—
Thus, it is called the constant Dao/Way."*

From this, one may infer:
That which does not constantly abide in its place
Is called the **non-constant Dao/Way**.

Names that can be named are **non-constant names**.
Names are true speech.
The single character **"principle"** is the origin of names,
The two characters **"can be named"** are its traces.

Traces disperse in things,
Called the **ten thousand particulars**—
From traces to the origin,
They merge with **Dao/Way**—
Thus, **Dao/Way** is the origin of names,
Names are the end of **Dao/Way**.

Origin and end mutually generate,
To complete transformation.
Without function, **Dao/Way** congeals;
With function, names are established.

Heaven, obtaining **Dao/Way**, manifests the clear and bright forms,
Earth, obtaining **Dao/Way**, is solid and tranquil,
The **spiritual** obtains **Dao/Way**, transformation ceaselessly,
The **valleys** obtain **Dao/Way**, fullness without deficiency.

This draws from Chapter Two of the *Dao De Jing* to clarify its meaning.

Names dispersed without limit,
This is called the **non-constant Dao/Way of Luo**.

The **nameless** is the beginning of heaven and earth.
The **nameless** is the **emptiness to the extreme**, the wondrous origin,
Before the **virtue/power** of **Dao/Way** is established.
The beginning of the wondrous origin,
There is no **nameless**—
From origin descending to traces,
Generating heaven and generating earth—
Heaven and earth rely on the beginning,
Thus, it is said: the **nameless** is the beginning of heaven and earth.

The **great Dao/Way** exhales **qi** and spreads it across the void,
Becoming the origin of heaven and earth.

From the beginning, there is no **nameless**—
As the *Zhuangzi*’s **"Heaven and Earth"** chapter says:
*"At the dawn of creation, there was the **non-being**,
And the **non-being** had no name."*

The **non-being** already without name,
Cannot be questioned with **Dao/Way**,
Cannot be elucidated with names—
Mingled and indistinct, tranquil and vast,
Enduring as the **master of transformation**—
The **original qi** relies on it to begin.

The **profound transformation** receives it and attains life—
Thus, it is said: the **nameless** is the beginning of heaven and earth.

The **nameless** has no lineage,
Then descending and advancing,
Gradually forming signs and shapes—
Thus, heaven and earth are born,
And the **forms of qi** are established.

The **Great Ultimate** is when form and substance are complete.
Form and substance complete,
Then the **two principles** are divided—
Humans are born within them,
Thus forming the **three talents**.

The **named** is the mother of all things.
**All transformations** refer to their multiplicity.
**All things**—
Within all things, **Dao/Way** is nowhere absent.
Even the finest hair of autumn,
**Dao/Way** dwells within it—
Thus, it can generate the **three talents**,
And be the mother of all things.

All things—
**Dao/Way** exists, they are born;
**Dao/Way** departs, they perish.
The utmost **nourishment and containment**,
Is it not called the mother?

The **great Dao/Way** is without difference or sameness,
Without origin or traces—
Yet through the **virtue/power** of **Dao/Way** and teaching,
Its origin and traces are revealed.

**Constantly without desire** reaches its limit,
To observe its **convergence**.

The **mechanical mind** lodged in the chest,
Is pure white yet not perfected in **spiritual virtue**—
One who **abides in the body** is not harmonious,
This is **desire**.
If the **mind of harming** is forgotten within,
Even a tiger’s tail can be trodden—
What more of humans?

This is **non-desire**.
The **desiring** cling to ears and eyes for seeing and hearing,
Exhaust the mind and thoughts for reasoning—
Seeing and hearing grow more confused,
Reasoning grows more disordered—
This can be called observing the **boundaries of convergence**.

The **non-desiring** merge their **spirit** with the void,
Their **qi** with the **non-being**—
Reaching all without obstruction,
Penetrating all without hindrance—
Aligning with the function of heaven and earth,
They merge with the **great Dao/Way**,
This can be called observing its **wondrousness**.

The observer, externally surveys with the eyes,
Internally illuminates with the spirit—
The eyes discern the presence and absence,
The spirit resonates with the silent void.

Humans are born in stillness—
This is the nature of Heaven, as spoken in *The Record of Music*.
It speaks of nature being inherently pure and tranquil,
Without desire or striving.
When moved by things, stirred by circumstances,
Sensations arise from without and stir within—
How can one be cautious of what one is moved by?

Thus, the Sage establishes laws to curb their wickedness,
Institutes rites to curb their chaos,
Enacts punishments to curb their excesses,
Creates music to curb their licentiousness.
By the Dao restraining desire,
This is how the people are taught to revere virtue and pursue goodness.

These two [paths] arise from the same source but differ in name.

From the One Qi, myriad transformations arise;
From the emergence of forms, myriad things manifest.
The three transformations vary, yet twofold—
From non-being, being emerges—
This is what is meant.

When the Dao is manifest, names are established;
When names are established, desire arises—
This is where the Dao can be spoken of,
Where names can be named,
Where the mechanism of desire is ignited.
This is how traces arise from their roots.

To **shelter the traces** is to abandon desire, forget names,
And return to the wondrous root of the Dao—
To forget the Dao in names,
To forget names is to return to the root.

Those who follow their emotions chase desire and forget the root,
Descending into slipperiness—
Only those who return to the origin of things
Can speak of the utmost Dao.

Both are called **mysterious**.

Those with desire and those without desire
Receive qi from Heaven and Earth.
If they receive the balanced, harmonious essence,
They become virtuous and sage, acting without doing.
If they receive turbid, chaotic qi,
They become dull and foolish, with many desires.

If one can purify the heart, transform thoughts,
Clarify desire and contain emptiness,
Then they are those who shelter the traces and return to the root.

When all cultivate and refine themselves,
And customs return to simplicity and harmony,
The wind of returning to simplicity
Can reach the ancient past.

Mysterious beyond mysterious—
The gateway to all wonders.

To shelter the traces and forget names
Already grasps its wonder—
Yet fearing stagnation in wonder,
One forgets it again—
Thus, both root and trace are forgotten.
Again forgetting this intention,
The spirit merges with the Dao.

Having dispelled desire,
Even non-desire is forgotten—
Not clinging to being or non-being,
Not fixating on the middle path—
This is the complete forgetting.

The gateway to all wonders is the Heavenly Gate.
The Heavenly Gate is the total name for the origin of all dharma.
Without being—
It speaks of all things emerging from non-being,
Returning to non-being—
Gathering and dispersing, concealing and revealing—
Thus, they are transient guests of coming and going.

Empty in name, yet no true gate exists—
Thus, it is called the gate of non-doing.

Then, there is no gate—
No gate means no sides—
Four-way openness, vast and boundless—
This is returning to the wondrous Dao.

**True observation** is the gradual path of cultivation,
The stages of verifying the Dao.

The earlier "seen with the eyes" is the observation of surveying.
The "illuminated by the spirit" is the observation of practice.

The Dao also employs the Three Vehicles’ methods to transform people,
From initial awakening to ultimate attainment—
Abandoning the mundane to realize the sacred—
Thus, there are fourteen stages of observation and practice.

The Small Vehicle’s initial gate has three observations:
First, the **observation of provisional dharma**—oppositional discernment.
Second, the **observation of true dharma**—illumination of the mind.
Third, the **observation of pervasive emptiness**—entering non-doing.

The Middle Vehicle’s gate of observation and practice has four:
First, the observation of **impermanence**,
Second, the observation of **eternity**,
Third, the observation of **non-impermanence**,
Fourth, the observation of **non-eternity**.

The Great Vehicle’s gate of observation and practice also has four:
First, the **observation of wondrous being**,
Second, the **observation of wondrous non-being**,
Third, the **observation of profound mystery**,
Fourth, the **observation of non-profound mystery**.

The Sacred Practice gate further has three observations:
First, the **observation of true emptiness**,
Second, the **observation of true penetration**,
Third, the **observation of true non-being**.

Through these observations and practices,
One refines the mind—
From being to non-being,
From coarse to wondrous—
Attaining wonder and forgetting it,
Thus resonating with the gate of non-doing.

Non-doing and doing—
The Dao can be spoken of as constant Dao,
Body and function held together—
Its principle is clear.

Now, within the gate of body and function,
It is divided into five distinctions:
First, **non-doing as body, doing as function**—
The Dao as body is without,
Names as function are with.
Second, **doing as body, non-doing as function**—
Houses, carriages, tools—
Their doing is body,
Their non-doing is function—
Utilizing their non-being.
Third, **non-doing as body, non-doing as function**—
Naturalness as body,
Conditional relations as function—
All are non-being.
Fourth, **doing as body, doing as function**—
Heaven and Earth as body,
All things as function—
All are being.
Fifth, **neither being nor non-being as body,
Neither being nor non-being as function**—
The Dao as body,
Virtue/power as function.

Again, within the gate of root and trace,
It is divided into two distinctions:
**Non-being as root, being as trace**—
Non-naming and naming.
**Being as root, non-being as trace**—
Mutual illumination.

All things originate from being yet ultimately return to non-being.

From the mysterious source, pure and silent,
The wondrous root, distant and obscure—
Not sought through words or symbols,
Not verified through being or non-being—
Indeed, debate on principles is exhausted,
Speculation on the Dao is at its end—
Yet teachings are set forth to guide the mundane,
Demonstrating these stages.
Yet it lies in the silent heart’s resonance,
Gradual or sudden, adapting to each case—
Do not cling to teachings or fixate on words,
Be not bound by scholarly conventions.
Those who bathe their hearts in virtue and power,
Strive diligently.

The Lord of the Dao says:
*The Dao that can be spoken of is not the eternal Dao.*

Without beginning, it is called the Dao—
Unspeakable, yet to speak of it is false.
Again it says:
*The Dao should not be named,*
*Yet the speakable and nameable Dao*
*Is like things, like the four seasons—*
*Appropriate when it should be.*

Rising and declining in succession,
This is not true constancy.
Constant Dao, constant name—
From its own root, its own foundation—
Before Heaven and Earth existed,
It has eternally endured.

Fu Xi obtained it to inherit the **Qi of the Mother**,
The Western Queen Mother attained it and sat in **Minor Broadness**—
No one knows its beginning,
No one knows its end.

The Nameless is the Mother of ten thousand things.
The Dao is ever nameless—
Heaven and Earth await it to give birth,
As Zhuangzi says: *"It gives birth to Heaven and Earth."*

Before Heaven and Earth existed,
Who could name it?
Thus, it is nameless—
The beginning of Heaven and Earth.

Only after Heaven and Earth came into being
Did ten thousand things arise,
Thus it is named—
The Mother of ten thousand things.

Constantly without desire,
One observes its limits.

Zhuangzi says:
*"Establish it with constant non-being.*
*Not establishing any thing—*
This is called constant non-being;
*Not abandoning any thing—*
This is called constant being.

Constant non-being is in principle—
Its upper reaches are unfathomable,
The utmost subtlety under Heaven,
Thus one observes its marvel.

Constant being in the world—
Its lower reaches are not obscured,
The utmost transformation under Heaven,
Thus one observes its limits.

The two realms of being and non-being,
Within them lies subtle mystery.
Great wisdom observes both together,
And thus nothing is unattainable.

Within vague and indistinct,
There are forms and things.
Small wisdom is self-serving,
Obscured by one-sidedness,
Clinging to being while rejecting emptiness,
Pursuing the superficial while forgetting the root—
Thus Dao/Way and its arts are shattered for all under Heaven.

These two—when most alike—are called *Xuan* (the Mysterious).
The Dao originally has no form—
Who would speak of its marvels?
Things and I share the same root—
This is called *one qi*,
Thus it is called *Xuan*.

The confused of the world
Abandon illusion to seek truth,
Yet the farther they stray from truth,
Not knowing that what is called "thing"
Is merely a difference in names.

*Xuan* again *Xuan*—
The gate of all marvels.

*The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon* says:
*"Xuan gives birth to spirit."*
*The I Ching* says:
*"Spirit—*
*This is the subtle speech of all things."*

Small yet marvelous—this is *Xuan*.
*Xuan*—the color of Heaven.
Though the colored is manifest,
The coloring itself never reaches completion.

*Xuan* again *Xuan*—
This is called "coloring."

The subtle principle of *Xuan*
Is possessed by all things.
Heaven’s movement,
Earth’s resting,
Human aliveness,
The flourishing of ages—
All are marvels,
Yet all emerge from *Xuan*,
Thus it is called the gate of all marvels.

Confucius composed the *I Ching* down to *The Sayings on the Trigrams*
Before speaking of marvels.
While Laozi begins with this in his first chapter.
The words of the sages complement each other’s end and beginning.

Wang Anshi said:
*"The Dao that can be spoken of is not the eternal Dao."*
Constant—Zhuangzi says—
Is without past or future,
Without end or beginning.
The Dao originally cannot be spoken of,
Yet if it can be spoken of,
Then it is its progression.
If it has boundaries,
Then it is not my eternal Dao.

The name that can be named is not the eternal name.
The Dao originally has no name,
Yet if it has a name,
Then it is not my eternal name.
Names arise from meaning,
Thus there are names.

The Nameless is the Mother of ten thousand things.
Non-being names the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
Being names its end.
Thus it is called the Mother of ten thousand things.

*The Complete Meaning* says:
Non-being is above form.
From the Great Beginning to the Great Initiation,
From the Great Initiation to the Great Polarity,
The Great Initiation gives birth to Heaven and Earth—
This is named the beginning of Heaven and Earth.

Being is below form.
Only after Heaven and Earth did ten thousand things arise—
This is named the Mother of ten thousand things,
For *mother* means *to give birth*.

*The Main Explanation* says:
The Nameless is the Great Initiation,
Thus it is the Father of Heaven and Earth.
The Named is the Great Polarity,
Thus it is the Mother of ten thousand things.

Heaven and Earth are the union of ten thousand things;
Ten thousand things are the separation of Heaven and Earth.
Speaking of the Father as Heaven and Earth,
Then ten thousand things become known.
Speaking of the Mother as ten thousand things,
Then Heaven and Earth also become known.

Constantly without desire,
One observes its limits.

The origin of the Dao lies in non-being,
Thus constant non-being observes its marvel.
The function of the Dao returns to being,
Thus constant being observes its limits.

These two are called *Xuan*.
*Xuan* again *Xuan*—
The gate of all marvels.

For one cannot constantly remain in non-being,
Without which one cannot observe its marvel.
One cannot constantly remain in being,
Without which one cannot observe its limits.
To observe its marvel and its limits,
One knows that being and non-being
Emerge from the same *Xuan*.

*The Complete Meaning* says:
The Dao is one,
Yet its explanations are two.
What are these two?
Being and non-being.
Non-being is the origin of the Dao,
And what is called *marvel*.
Being is the end of the Dao,
And what is called *limits*.

Thus the origin of the Dao lies in the boundless and obscure,
While its end disperses into forms, names, and measurements.
These two—though one Dao—
The confused of the world often regard as separate.
Why?
Boundless and obscure constantly abide in non-being,
While forms, names, and measurements constantly abide in being.
Being and non-being cannot coexist.
This is why they are obscured and cannot preserve themselves.

Non-being names the beginning of Heaven and Earth,
While being names the Mother of ten thousand things—
Though their names differ,
They never fail to serve each other.
Being and non-being,
Like east and west in opposition,
Yet cannot negate each other.
Without being, there is no way to perceive non-being,
And without non-being, there is no way to produce being.
The transformations of being and non-being
Alternate and interweave,
Yet never depart from the Dao.
This is what the sages call *spirit*.

*The I Ching* says:
*"Without thought,
Without action,
Silent and unmoving,
Yet responding and thus communicating*
*the principles of all under Heaven."*

This is what is spoken of.

Truly, the sages of old would always observe its subtlety through their *wu si wu wei* [non-thinking, non-action],
and always perceive its manifestations through *gan er sui tong tianxia zhi gu* [responding and thus communicating the principles of all under Heaven].
When both subtlety and manifestations are attained without partiality,
who but the most divine could partake in this?

Thus, the Dao of the sages is now evident.
To observe its subtlety is to exhaust the divine;
to observe its manifestations is to know transformation.
When the divine is exhausted and transformation is known,
what more can be added to the Dao of Heaven and Earth?
These two are called *xuan* [profound] when brought to their utmost.

These two—
the Dao of being and non-being—
both originate from the Dao.
It speaks of how the essence and function of being and non-being
all emerge from the Dao.
Scholars of the world often regard non-being as refined and being as coarse,
yet they do not know that both arise from the Dao,
hence they are called *xuan* when spoken of together.

These two, though differing in name,
originate from the same source—*shen* [divine]—
yet differ in their names: being and non-being.
The sage embodies this,
thus manifesting divine virtue.
Hence, abiding in non-being suffices to perceive its subtlety;
abiding in being suffices to know its manifestations.
Yet ultimately, it transcends the names of being and non-being.

The highest insight knows the origin of Heaven and Earth,
while the lowest suffices to govern the order of all things—
all through this.

*The Zishuo* [Explanation of Characters] says:
*"Covered and entering—this is *xuan* [profound].*
Thus, *xuan* is composed of *xu* [cover] and *ru* [enter].
These two are called *xuan* together.
These two refer to being and non-being.

*Xuan* is also black, yet bears a red hue.
The north is black as yin, yet *xuan* is yang.
Thus, the *I Ching* says:
*'Kun on Earth is black.'*
And again:
*'Heaven is *xuan*, Earth is yellow.'*
Shun spoke of *xuan de* [profound virtue],
referring to its depth in the sage below.

Su Yingbin said:
*'The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.
Yet all that can be spoken of is not the Dao—
only what cannot be spoken of can be constant.*
Now, *ren* [benevolence], *yi* [righteousness], *li* [rites], and *zhi* [wisdom]
are the Dao that can be spoken of.
Yet benevolence cannot be made righteousness,
nor rites made wisdom.
What can be spoken of cannot be constant in this way.
Only what cannot be spoken of
allows *ren* to remain *ren*,
*yi* to remain *yi*,
*li* to remain *li*,
and *zhi* to remain *zhi*—
though all these are not constant,
the Dao remains unchanging and unalterable.
What cannot be spoken of alone can be constant in this way.

What can be named is not the constant name.
The Dao cannot be spoken of—
how much less can it be named?
All names are of what can be spoken of.
Once names are established,
the distinctions of round and square, curved and straight
cannot remain constant.

Non-being names the beginning of Heaven and Earth,
until one observes its *jiao* [manifestations].
From its nameless form, Heaven and Earth arise,
and once positioned, names begin to establish themselves.
From its named propagation, ten thousand things emerge,
and as they flourish, names become innumerable.
Thus, the nameless is the essence of the Dao,
while the named is its function.

The sage embodies the Dao for the world’s use,
entering all things while remaining constantly non-being,
to observe its subtlety;
embodying the utmost non-being while remaining constantly being,
to observe its manifestations.
If one acts only in its manifestations without knowing its subtlety,
it is coarse and not divine.
If one lingers only in its subtlety without knowing its manifestations,
it is refined yet not comprehensive.

These two, when brought to their utmost, are called *xuan*.
Speaking in terms of form,
being and non-being are indeed two—
how can one know that non-being transforms into being,
and being returns to non-being,
yet they are never separate?
Though their names differ,
their origin is one.
Knowing their origin as one,
this is *xuan*.

All that is distant without limit
must be of a *xuan* hue,
thus Laozi often used *xuan* to convey the extreme.
*Xuan* beyond *xuan*—
the gateway to all subtleties.
Speaking of *xuan* is to reach it,
yet still the mind of *xuan* remains.
*Xuan* beyond *xuan* is exhausted—
nothing more can be added—
the source from which all subtleties emerge.

Lü Jifu said:
*The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.*
All the Dao under Heaven that can be spoken of
is not the Dao—
yet at times it is perilous, hence not the constant Dao.
All names under Heaven that can be named
are not the constant name—
ten thousand things, each returning to their root,
returning to the root is called *jing* [stillness],
stillness is called *fu ming* [restoring life],
restoring life is called *chang* [constant].
When the Dao reaches constancy,
the mind solidifies, the form relaxes,
and self and objects are forgotten.
Who can know the Dao that can be spoken of,
or the names that can be named?

Thus, the constant Dao is indeed unspeakable.
Hence it is said: *The Dao endures long, yet does not perish with life.*
The constant name is indeed unnameable.
Hence it is said: *From ancient times to today, its name does not fade.*

Not perishing, not fading—
this is called the constant Dao.
Non-being is the Mother of ten thousand things.
Constant non-being is the Dao itself,
and the origin from which Heaven and Earth begin,
hence it is said: *Non-being names the beginning of Heaven and Earth.*

At the *Tai Chu* [Great Origin], there was being and non-being,
yet non-being had no name.
Being and non-being—
even one cannot be named with being and non-being,
for the origin of one, though not yet formed, already exists.
Once called *one*,
though not yet formed, it already has a name.
The name *one* is one,
yet the one who names is two—
two and one make three,
and from here ten thousand things arise in confusion.
Thus it is said: *The named is the Mother of ten thousand things.*

Constant non-being reaches the observation of its manifestations.
Knowing constancy is called *ming* [clarity],
and clarity sees all things.
Thus, only constancy can be observed—
when desireless, it purifies and gazes profoundly,
with no flaw in observing its subtlety,
hence it is said: *Constant non-desire can be named as small.*
When desire arises,
ten thousand things act together,
and all things return to it,
yet the master remains unknown—
this can be named as great.

The two, when most harmonized, are called *Xuan* [Mysterious].
Only the small reveals its subtlety (*miao*), only the great reveals its manifestations (*jiao*).
Though their origins are the same, their names differ—
and though their names differ, their essence never truly does.
For whether with desire or without, seeking their origin,
one finds nothing—
nothing to find means their origin is the same,
thus they are called *Xuan*.

As to *Xuan*’s hue,
black and red are one in unity.
The sky’s hue is *Xuan*—
yin and yang are one in unity.
Unity in oneness is indeed subtle.
Yet subtle in oneness is not yet subtle in multiplicity;
subtle in self is not yet subtle in things.
The gate to *Xuan*’s utmost.

*Xuan* again *Xuan*—
then even the same is unattainable.
If the same is unattainable,
then oneness and multiplicity, self and things—
all are without fail subtle.
The subtlety of ten thousand things arises from this alone.

Master Lu said:
*The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.*
The constant name has *wu-fang* [boundlessness] as its essence,
the constant Dao has *wu-ti* [formlessness] as its function.
Boundlessness is nowhere absent,
formlessness does nothing it omits—
if there is anything that can be spoken of, it is not boundlessness;
if there is anything that can be named, it is not formlessness.
The unnamed is the Mother of ten thousand things.
At the *Tai-ch’i* [Supreme Polarity], there is *wu* [non-being],
and *wu* has no name.
The unnamed is *Tai-shih* [Great Beginning],
the Great Beginning is the parent of heaven and earth.
Thus it is said: *The unnamed is the beginning of heaven and earth.*
Heaven and earth are the Mother of ten thousand things.
Thus it is said: *The named is the Mother of ten thousand things.*
Speak of Mother and you know the Beginning as Father;
speak of Beginning and you know the Mother as Sovereign.
Thus above it speaks of the beginning of heaven and earth,
below it speaks of the Mother of ten thousand things.
Constant non-desire reaches the observation of its manifestations.
*Miao* is the origin of the Dao,
*Jiao* is the end of the Dao.
The Sage, regarding *miao*, observes with constant non-desire;
the Sage, regarding *jiao*, observes with constant having.
*Miao* lies within, *su* [coarse] lies at the end—
speak of *miao* and you know *jiao* as coarse,
speak of *jiao* and you know *miao* as central.
Thus above it speaks of desire to observe *miao*,
below it speaks of desire to observe *jiao*.
The two, when most harmonized, are *Xuan*.

The *wu* [non-being] that opposes *you* [being] is not the *wu* of constant non-being,
and constant non-being is not the *wu* that opposes *you*.
The *you* that opposes *wu* is not the *you* of constant having,
and constant having is not the *you* that opposes *wu*.
That which does not oppose *wu* is not *you*,
that which does not oppose *you* is not *wu*.
Thus constant non-being is true non-being, yet not *wu*;
constant having is subtle being, yet not *you*.
Hence the two arise from the same source,
and thus they are called *Xuan*.
The gate to *Xuan*’s utmost.

*Xuan* is the essence of subtlety,
subtlety is the function of *Xuan*.
When the Dao reaches *Xuan*’s utmost,
humans become the gate to all subtleties,
entering and exiting between them.
Zhuangzi said:
*The sky’s opening is not the opening of human sky.*
The sky’s opening is natural;
the human sky is contrived.
*Xuan* again *Xuan*—
this is Zhuangzi’s *precise of the precise*.
The gate to all subtleties—
this is Zhuangzi’s *divine of the divine*.

Master Wang Yuanze said:
*The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao.*
The Dao is the path of ten thousand things—
in essence, it is essence;
in function, it is function.
Without name, without progression,
it is nowhere absent.
Thus the Sage’s words always dwell in one aspect,
though dwelling in one aspect,
they differ from the myriad schools of thought,
yet do not lose principle or conform to the times.
The Dao that can be spoken of adapts to the times and acts accordingly;
times shift without pause,
and the Dao responds to change.
For creation subtly moves,
never ceasing for an instant—
thus today is not yesterday.
Yet petty scholars grasp brilliance as the Dao’s root,
pointing to the *Zhun Lu* [a legendary dwelling] as the Sage’s abode.
Laozi was about to loosen their obstructions,
and questioned them with ultimate truth.
Thus this opening chapter clarifies this,
so that even today’s words are not constant.

The name that can be named is not the constant name.
Names arise from reality,
and reality has form and number—
once form and number are complete,
decay follows inevitably.
How can it be constant?
Only by embodying the unconstant is true constancy attained.
The unnamed is the Mother of the utmost.

Receiving command from non-being,
it takes form in being—
thus it is said: *the beginning of heaven and earth, the Mother of ten thousand things.*
The *Yijing* says:
*Only after heaven and earth did ten thousand things arise.*
This aligns with the *Yijing*’s sequence.
Between the covering and the loading,
life emerges—
thus heaven and earth are spoken of first.
Things and heaven and earth originally have no precedence,
pushed to their extreme, being and non-being are one essence—
the speech of Beginning and Mother is also a metaphor.

Though heaven and earth are vast,
they receive command and take form,
never truly separate from being and non-being.
Yet it speaks solely of the Mother of ten thousand things—
thus Laozi’s words merely exhaust nature’s essence.

Constant non-desire reaches the observation of its manifestations.
The *Yijing*’s yin and yang,
Laozi’s being and non-being,
even to the Buddha’s *color and emptiness*—
their essence is one, differing only in exposition.
Those who speak of non-being,
abandoning being to seek non-being,
are but adding another being beyond being—
how can this be non-being?
Thus when there is a time of reality,
it is not truly non-being—
this is true non-being.
The essence of being and non-being is always one,
but when observing with being,
one only sees its surface—
to observe its subtlety,
one must know its original non-being,
yet the non-being of non-being never truly departs from being.
Speaking of constant non-being and constant having,
it is because the names of being and non-being do not succeed one another—
non-being is true being,
being is true non-being.
Speak of *jiao* and you know *miao* as profound,
speak of *miao* and you know *jiao* as coarse.
This is the essence of the law’s speech.
Called *Xuan* because they are one.
Being and non-being originally are one,
before the two names arose.
Learners, if they rush in,
will find non-being not as precise as being.

Once the Dao is attained,
both being and non-being become perfect truths,
with no distinction between them.

This is the gateway to all subtleties.
The Dao contains two essences:
when descending to form, Yang is exalted while Yin is humble;
when ascending beyond form, Yin precedes while Yang follows.

Thus, when the Dao reaches its utmost, it is called *miao* and *xuan*.
*Miao* refers to **virtue/power**,
*Xuan* to **essence/color**.
Speaking of essence, one attains the Dao.
Yet there remains what essence cannot encompass,
hence it is also called *xuan*.
All things possess their subtleties,
all arising from this,
so it is called the **gateway to all subtleties**.

The Dao is one,
yet is spoken of as two.
What is meant by these two?
It is being and non-being.
Non-being is the Dao’s origin,
while *miao* is the subtlety.
Being is the Dao’s culmination,
while *jiao* is the coarse.
Thus, the Dao’s origin emerges from the **boundless void**,
while its culmination disperses among forms, names, and measures.

These two, though one in Dao,
are often mistaken as separate by the world.
Why?
Because the **boundless void** abides in non-being,
while forms, names, and measures dwell in being.
Being and non-being cannot coexist,
and this is why they are obscured and not fully grasped.

The unnamed is the beginning of Heaven and Earth,
while the named is the mother of all things.
Though they differ in name,
they never fail to serve one another.

Being and non-being, like east and west,
are opposites yet cannot negate one another.
Thus, without being, there is no way to perceive non-being,
and without non-being, there is no way to manifest being.
The transformations of being and non-being
alternate and interweave without ever departing from the Dao—
this is what the sages call **divine**.

The *Yijing* says:
*"No thought, no action—*
*still and motionless,*
*yet responsive and thus harmonizing*
*with the workings of Heaven and Earth."*

This is what is meant.

The sages of old
observed the **constant subtlety** through their **thoughtless stillness**,
and the **coarse transformations** through their **responsive harmony**.
When both the coarse and the subtle are attained without preference,
who else but the divine could achieve this?

Thus, the sages’ Dao is also evident.
Observing the subtle exhausts the divine,
while observing the coarse reveals its **manifestations**.
To exhaust the divine and know its manifestations,
what more could be added to the Dao of Heaven and Earth?

Still, observing the subtle is only to exhaust the divine,
not to define it.
For the divine never departs from these two,
yet these two cannot fully name it.
Hence it is said:
*"Both arise from the same source yet differ in name.
The same is that they arise from the divine;
the different is that being and non-being have distinct names."*

The sage
embodies this and manifests its divine virtue,
so abiding in non-being reveals the subtle,
while dwelling in being discerns the coarse.
Yet ultimately, they transcend the names of being and non-being.

Below the sage, some grasp Heaven and Earth’s origin,
while others apply themselves to governing all things—
all rely on this.

Ah! The words of Laozi can be said to accord with the *Yijing*.
Yet they ultimately do not align with Confucius and Mencius.
Why?
For the sage never sought to speak of the Dao.
All speech arises from responding to the world’s transformations,
and is meant for those of middling talent who cannot fathom it on their own.

Though the Dao encompasses both being and non-being,
when spoken of, it elaborates on being while neglecting non-being.
The texts of *Shijing*, *Shujing*, *Liji*, *Yuelü*, and *Chunqiu*
all serve to clarify being,
while regarding non-being, only the *Yijing* speaks of it.

Yet even its discourse
must be embedded in the **hexagrams, trigrams, symbols, and systems**,
in **auspicious and inauspicious**,
**regret and blame**,
so that scholars, when observing from above, see its meticulous attention to affairs and things,
and grasp its **manifested being**;
when observing from below, they perceive its transcendence of instruments and utility,
and attain its **original non-being**.

Thus, the worthy study it and grow ever more confident,
while the foolish glance at it and are not led to doubt or lose their way.

For their minds ponder:
*"That Dao of subtlety—*
*the middling talents cannot reach it,*
*and those who can reach it*
*would not need words to explain it.*
If one does not measure it thus,
and insists on speaking only of subtlety,
then one leaves learners seated in confusion."*

Laozi understood the interplay of being and non-being,
and thus regarded non-being as the origin,
so his words elaborate on non-being while neglecting being.
Non-being requires no words,
yet he could speak elaborately of it.

Laozi, differing from Confucius and Mencius,
and Wang Bi losing the intent of Confucius—
for his teaching holds that the **unnamed** is the beginning of Heaven and Earth,
yet the **divine** is what Heaven and Earth most struggle to name.
Once the world has named it as divine,
how could there be anything unnamed?

Again, Wang Bi asserts that one must observe through **constant desire** to see the coarse.
But desire is the **harm to nature**—
the *Yijing* says: *"Restrain anger, suppress desire,"*
and Laozi says: *"Do not see what can be desired,
so the heart remains undisturbed."*
If desire exists,
how much more will one be **drowned in it, turned aside, lose oneself in pursuit of things,**
and fail to know what to hold fast to?
Then how could one observe the coarse?

This failure to discern
leads him to say, *"I know the fullness of Heaven and Earth,
the great framework of the ancients."*
Alas, how laughable!

Liu Zhongping said:
*"The Dao that can be spoken of is the mother of the Dao that cannot be spoken of."*

The **Taiji** depends upon the Dao.
Heaven and Earth depend upon the myriad things.
The myriad things depend upon Heaven and Earth.

What depends upon something is not the Dao itself—
it is the accumulation of the Dao.

The Dao is **absolute non-being**, yet nameless.
**Taiji** is **non-being**, yet nameless when detached from it.
Heaven and Earth are **being**, yet named when entered.

**Taiji** is obscure and divine—
its name cannot be grasped—
this is the subtlety of the Dao.

Heaven and Earth manifest in forms—
their names can be carried—
this is the coarse of the Dao.

Both arise from speech.
The one who is **constantly without desire** observes it and sees only its subtlety.
The one who is **constantly with desire** observes it and sees only its coarse.

Only the one who is constantly without desire
can penetrate to the **mystic**.

Some say: *"This is not what is meant."*
They say that **non-being** names the beginning of Heaven and Earth,
while **being** names the mother of the myriad things.
They say that **constant non-being** is to observe its subtlety,
while **constant being** is to observe its coarse.

I say: *"No. The reader errs."*
If **being** can name the mother of the myriad things,
how can **non-being** name the beginning of Heaven and Earth?
If **constant being** can observe its coarse,
how can **constant non-being** merely observe its subtlety?

For there is a beginning, there is an end—
yet it cannot be called **non-being**.
**Constant non-being** reaches **absolute non-being**—
yet it cannot be called **being**.

Ah! To know this is to know the **mystic**.

**Constant non-desire** is the gateway to the Dao.
**Constant non-being, constant being**—
speaking of **being** and **non-being** in interplay,
one cannot take one side without the other.

**Constant non-being** seeks to observe the Dao’s subtlety,
**constant being** seeks to observe its coarse.
Subtlety speaks of the root; coarse speaks of the branch.
Only when both root and branch are observed
does one see the Dao.

The **constant name** has **no form** as its essence,
the **constant Dao** has **no essence** as its function.
**No form** means it is nowhere absent,
**no essence** means it does nothing absent.
If **no form** had anything that could be spoken of,
it would not be **no form**.
If **no essence** had anything that could be named,
it would not be **no essence**.
Thus it is said:
*The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao,*
*The name that can be named is not the constant name.*

**Tai’chu** has **being** and **non-being**—
**non-being** has **non-being**, yet is nameless.
**Non-being** that is nameless—this is **Taishǐ**.

**Taishǐ** is the father of Heaven and Earth,
thus it is called the **nameless beginning of Heaven and Earth**.
Heaven and Earth are the mother of the myriad things,
thus it is called the **named mother of the myriad things**.

Speaking of the mother, one knows the beginning as father;
speaking of the beginning, one knows the mother as origin.
Thus it is said above: *"the beginning of Heaven and Earth,"*
and below: *"the mother of the myriad things."*

Yet the principles of the world have
the Dao and the **constant Dao**,
names and the **constant name**.

What is called **Tai’chu** having **being** and **non-being**—
it is **non-being** alone.
What is called **non-being** that is nameless—
it is **name** alone.
For **being** and **non-being** give rise to the **name of name**,
thus the **nameless** is only the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
And above this, there is the **Ancestor**.

Subtlety is the root of the Dao;
coarse is the branch of the Dao.
The sage’s subtlety is observed through **constant non-being**.
The sage’s coarse is observed through **constant being**.
Thus it is said:
*"Observe its subtlety with constant non-desire,
observe its coarse with constant desire."*

Subtlety lies within; coarse lies in the branch.
Speaking of subtlety reveals the coarse as coarse,
speaking of the coarse reveals the subtlety as central.
Thus it is said above: *"observe its subtlety,"*
and below: *"observe its coarse."*

For **non-being** is **non-being** opposed to **being**,
while **constant non-being** is not **non-being** opposed to **being**,
nor is it opposed to **being**.

**Being** is **being** opposed to **non-being**,
while **constant being** is not **being** opposed to **non-being**,
nor is it opposed to **non-being**.

What is not opposed to **non-being** is not **being**,
what is not opposed to **being** is not **non-being**.
Thus **constant being** is **true non-being**—
yet not **non-being**.
**Constant being** is **subtle being**—
yet not **being**.

Thus these two arise together and return to the **mystic**.

Zhuangzi said:
*"Establish it with **constant non-being**,
speak of it with **Tai’yi**."*

This is read as **constant non-being, constant being**.
**Constant non-being** seeks to observe its subtlety,
**constant being** seeks to observe its coarse.
Because it seeks to observe its subtlety,
it is established with **constant non-being**.
Because it seeks to observe its coarse,
it is established with **constant being**.

If both coarse and subtlety are forgotten,
and there is no desire to observe,
then what is called *"established with constant non-being"*
is simply **obscured**.

This is called **the mystic again**—
not merely the same as the **mystic**.
*The mystic, the mystic again*—
the gateway of all subtleties.

The **mystic** is the essence of subtlety;
subtlety is the function of the **mystic**.
Subtlety arises from what is not the **mystic**.

Liu Jujie said:
*"The Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao."*
The Dao meets speech—
then its being the Dao is enough, yet it is not the **constant Dao**.
The **constant Dao** has no limits—
this is what is called **constant non-desire**.
The Dao has no limits—
this is what is called **constant desire**.

When the world’s Dao is lost,
Laozi governs the One to save it—
its adaptation to things is appropriate,
not clinging to the old,
to harmonize the world’s transformations.

The name that can be named is not the **constant name**—
if forced to name it, call it **Great**,
then this name is **Great**.
**Great** is a name; **Dao** is a character.
The **constant name** has no limits—
no limits mean no name.
The name that can be named has no limits—
no limits mean it has a name.

The **mystic** of name and character—
is it not here?

The **nameless** is the mother of the **Dao that cannot be spoken of**.
This speaks only of name, not of Dao.
Since name extends to character,
the **nameless** is also seen.

Heaven and Earth’s beginning—
vastly obscure and unified—
then where are the so-called name and character?

Once names and characters exist,
then adaptation to things is appropriate—
things arise from what is appropriate,
and from what is appropriate comes what is possible,
until what is possible becomes what is actual.
Thus, the Dao is the mother of all things.

**Constantly without desire**, one observes its **boundaries**.
**Constantly without desire** is the same as the **constant Dao**;
**constantly with desire** is the same as the **possible Dao**.

When one is in **constant impossibility**, it is called **constant without desire**;
when one is in **constant possibility**, it is called **constant with desire**.

For the text below speaks of **constant without name** but not **constant without desire**,
speaks of **my without desire** but not **desire without desire**—
desire, if it exists, is never **constant**.

To observe the **mystic** through **constant without desire**,
that is the beginning of Heaven and Earth;
to observe the **boundaries** through **constant with desire**,
that is the mother of all things.

What is called **observation** is the mind’s eye,
not merely the force of sight.

These two are called **mystic**.
**Without desire** and **with desire**—
though their names differ,
their essence arises from the same Dao.
For **impossibility** and **constant** are both the Dao.

**Mystic**—
obscure, dim, profound, and boundless—
is the hue of the Dao.
The Yellow Emperor said:
In Heaven, it is **mystic**; in humans, it is **Dao**.

The Dao, when seen, is unseen yet has hue—
the Sage observes its **mystic** and its **boundaries**,
and thus speaks of it.

When called the same, it is **mystic**;
**mystic**, it can be spoken of—
the **constant Dao** and the **possible Dao** depend on each other.

**Mystic beyond mystic**—
the gateway to all **wonders**.

Again, **mystic**—
form and hue are not hue;
nothing can be observed of it.

**Mystic of mystic** and **again mystic of mystic**—
not hue, yet they depend on each other,
not discarding the earlier **mystic** as a burden.

**All wonders**—
the **wonders** of all things.
All things possess **wonders**, all arising from the Dao—
thus, the Dao is the **wonder** of all things.

Here, **boundaries** are not mentioned,
for **wonders** and **boundaries** are not discarded as burdens.

Liu Ji said:
The Dao that can be spoken of is the gateway to what can be attained.
**Dao** speaks of its **body**; **name** speaks of its **function**.

What can be spoken of and named
is like the myriad schools and arts—
each has its strengths, its uses in time,
yet does not encompass all;
it is not the **true constant**.

Speaking of **constant Dao** and **constant name**—
self-originating, self-rooted—
before Heaven and Earth existed,
it has eternally endured.
The divine and spirits, the divine and emperors,
those who give birth to Heaven and Earth—
who can know the **Dao that can be spoken of**,
the **name that can be named**?

The Classic says:
The Great Dao is formless,
giving birth to Heaven and Earth.
Before Heaven and Earth existed,
who could name it?
Thus, it is **nameless**, the beginning of Heaven and Earth.

The Classic says:
The Great Dao is **nameless**, yet nourishes all things.
When all things exist,
there are forms that can be named—
thus, there is **name**, the mother of all things.

**Nameless** is the **mystic** of the Dao—
without action, without form,
thus **constant without desire** to observe its **mystic**.

**Named** is the **boundaries** of the Dao—
with emotion, with sincerity,
thus **constant with desire** to observe its **boundaries**.

The scholar must enter **without** from **with**,
unwinding to reach **mystic**,
seeking origin and end—
never truly different.

Thus, emerging with different names,
yet called the same—**mystic**.

**Mystic**—
the hue of Heaven,
that which is distant without limit.

**Mystic beyond mystic**—
then the divine beyond the divine,
profound beyond the profound,
entering the gate of the boundless,
wandering in the wild of the limitless,
matching the function of the void—
all **wonders** arise from this.

Thus, it is called the **gateway to all wonders**,
the source of all things,
the dependence of transformation.

Who can exit without passing through the door?
How could one not pass through this Dao?

The people can be led by it,
but cannot be made to know it.
Knowledge is shallow;
ignorance is profound.
Knowledge is external;
ignorance is internal—
thus, it follows with *all under Heaven know*.

---
*End of Volume One of the Collected Meanings of the Dao-De Jing*
*Beginning of Volume Two of the Collected Meanings of the Dao-De Jing*

**The Dao That Can Be Spoken of**

Master Zhi of the Concentrated Dao declares:
*"The Way of Eternal Virtue is a Mystic Vision."*

**Chapter on the Dao That Can Be Spoken of**
Zhao Shizhan says:

1. **Transcending Form to Manifest the True**
   The Dao that can be spoken of is not the Eternal Dao.
   The Dao that can be spoken of is the realm of *form and lower things*.
   The Eternal Dao is the realm of *formless and higher things*.

   In the realm of *form and lower things*, the Dao is dispersed among shapes, names, measures, and calculations.
   In the realm of *formless and higher things*, the Dao is concealed in the void, emptiness, stillness, and boundlessness.

   If one seeks the Dao through objects, the Dao cannot be grasped—
   for its inability to be grasped, forms and instruments are not the Dao.
   If one observes the Dao apart from objects, the Dao has no fixed attributes—
   for its lack of fixed attributes, its divine mysteries are boundless.

   The heart is the substance of the Dao;
   the Dao and the heart are not distinct.
   Nature is the origin of the heart;
   the heart and nature are not different.
   The heart and nature—
   the formless in form.
   The Dao and the heart—
   the formless yet manifest.

   The heart, nature, and Dao—
   though spoken as three, they are one.
   Being, non-being, and unity—
   though divided into three, they converge as one.

   One is said to be *numbers*—
   yet the Dao is not *numbers*!
   One is said to be *mystery*—
   yet the Dao is not separate from *numbers*!
   Mystery is formless—
   yet the Dao cannot be confined by words!

   Its manifestation is clarity;
   all things are without exception in the Dao.
   Thus, even the Dao that can be spoken of,
   though it may be spoken of, still holds the Eternal Dao within it.
   The Eternal Dao, though it transcends what can be spoken of,
   yet the Dao that can be spoken of is rooted in it.

   If one distinguishes between true and false in form,
   the true is the Eternal Dao,
   while the false is the Dao that can be spoken of.
   If one distinguishes between emptiness and reality,
   the Dao is the substance of true nature,
   while things are illusory manifestations.

   Let us illustrate with practical principles,
   perhaps this will yield some understanding.

   Though called *eternal*, change is inherent.
   Thus, when we speak of *eternal*,
   it refers to the realm of nature,
   the heart to the function of the Dao—
   together, they are called *eternal*.
   The substance of *eternal* is taken from its unchanging aspect;
   for its unchanging aspect, it is called *eternal*.
   From the Eternal Dao flow all things.

   Again, *eternal* is great—
   thus, when viewed from this perspective, is it not great?
   *Eternal* is the radiant function of the Sage.
   To speak of *eternal* is not to exclude the Dao;
   to speak of the Dao is not to exclude *eternal*—
   what is called *eternal* is the Dao,
   and the Dao is *eternal*.
   If one must speak of the Dao without mentioning *eternal*,
   how can the Eternal Dao be fixed as one?
   If one must speak of *eternal* without mentioning the Dao,
   how can the Dao be displayed in its fullness?

   *Eternal* abides eternally;
   the eternal abides in unchanging constancy.
   *Communicating* flows through all things;
   the communicating flows without end.

   One substance, two functions—
   yet one substance encompasses both change and constancy.
   Heaven is not eternal?
   The Nine Heavens reach their limit, yet Heaven sometimes alters.
   Earth is not eternal?
   The Six Directions reach their limit, yet Earth sometimes emerges.
   The sun is not eternal?
   It sometimes wanes.
   The moon is not eternal?
   It sometimes eclipses.

   The *Qian* (Heaven) above the Nine Heavens has no head,
   the *Peng* (Great Bird) rests only at the Sixth Month—
   thus, those who cling to form and *numbers* must have limits.
   Only the *eternal* has no form,
   no form means no *numbers*,
   no *numbers* means no generation,
   no generation means no annihilation.

   From Heaven and Earth down to all things,
   they are all of *form and numbers*—
   how could they be the same as my True Eternal Dao?

   Thus, it is said:
   The Dao that can be spoken of is not my Eternal Dao.

   Is *eternal* not change?
   To call it *eternal* without change—is that possible?
   Is change not *eternal*?
   To call it change without constancy—is that possible?

   When things are born,
   *eternal* is with them in their birth.
   When things transform,
   *eternal* is with them in their transformation.
   Born yet not born,
   *eternal* flows without obstruction.
   Transformed yet not transformed,
   *eternal* remains as it is.

   Self-born, self-transformed—
   without the True Eternal Dao, how could birth and transformation occur?
   Eternally born, eternally transformed—
   this is the True Eternal Dao, which ceaselessly generates and transforms.

   Flowing, dispersing, shifting—
   it does not cling to any fixed *eternal* state.
   Waning and waxing, full and empty—
   it does not adhere to any fixed principle,
   yet it encompasses all forms without being seen,
   abides in one nature eternally.
   Exhausted, it transforms;
   transformed, it flows.
   The great person adapts to the times through this.

   If useful, then follow;
   if not, then abandon—
   the Sage knows transformation through this.

   When applied to the world,
   it is called the *divine instrument*.
   When practiced for the benefit of all things,
   it is called *enlightened authority*.
   When pondered to its utmost elemental principle,
   it is called *subtle mystery*.
   When wielded in accordance with yin-yang,
   it is called *divine mechanism*.

   As for Yao’s use of it—*benevolence*;
   Shun’s use of it—*filial piety*;
   Yu’s use of it—*channeling the rivers and streams*;
   Tang’s use of it—*ascending to sage-like reverence*.
   Though their uses differ,
   their essence is one.
