   Only those virtuous rulers who do not share the Sage’s concerns
   can truly embody the *eternal*—
   for they alone understand its substance.

2. **Transcending Names to Manifest Reality**
   Names can be named,
   yet they are not the Eternal Names.
   What can be named with names
   still has form.
   The Dao being formless,
   how could it be named?

   The *Classic* says: *Not the Eternal Name*.
   What can be named is not my Eternal Name—
   yet the Eternal also has a name.

   The Eternal is without generation;
   generation is matter—
   all matter can be named.
   The Eternal is without use;
   use is action—
   all actions can be named.
   Yet to investigate the origin of generation,
   the ancestor of all actions,
   one finds it cannot be seen.

   Liezi says:
   *"When the Dao is fully applied, it fills the six voids;
   when it is discarded, no one knows its whereabouts."*

   The Dao has unity and dispersion,
   nature has interaction and distinction—
   the formless unites with the formless,
   the formless enters the formless without obstruction.
   Its spirit soars like lightning,
   its motion is swift as a drawn arrow—
   how could one trace its path?

   This is the Dao that cannot be named.
   Thus, unity is oneness of substance.
   This unity is unity with the Great Void.

   Dispersion is the origin of all things;
   from the formless arises the form.
   The ungenerated can generate all things—
   vital essence contains *qi*, nurtures life—
   how could one be ignorant of this?

This dispersion is dispersion into myriad things to form shape—this can be named.
The Dao generates yang in the child [position], the child’s beauty appears in the southeast—thus the Dao emerges and interacts with things.
The Dao generates yin in the noon [position], the noon’s beauty exhausts in the northwest—this is the Dao’s return and its distinction of things.
When interacting with things, its manifestation is manifest—then the names of myriad things are naturally bestowed.
When distinguishing things, its concealment is concealed—then the origin of the One Truth is unseen.

To name the unseeable as the constant name, the nameable yet cannot be unified;
To name the seen as nameable, then the constant name also cannot be pursued.
Emerging from darkness and entering darkness—this supreme Dao is indeed mysterious.
Who names it? Who does not name it?

Next, dividing the two: having and not having.

**One: The Great Void originates One.**
Without name, the beginning of heaven and earth—with the Dao residing in the utmost void and profound obscurity,
deep as if eternally existing, not entangled with any thing.
All that has form are not the Dao’s constant Way.
Next, speaking of the non-constant name—since names exist between form, substance, and measure,
according to their beauty or ugliness, no thing lacks a name.
All that can be named are not the Dao’s constant name.
Without name, the beginning of heaven and earth.
With name, the mother of myriad things.
Earlier, speaking of the non-constant name—this means the constant has not departed from name.
Now speaking of the without-name—using the character *wu* (無) to break the constant character.
Without name, the beginning of heaven and earth.
The without-name is the constant Dao.
The constant Dao is the without-name.
Why speak of one principle in two ways?
Because the Dao cannot be spoken—those who speak of it never truly reach it.
The Dao originally has no name; those who name it never fully grasp its essence.
It must be spoken of as the non-constant constant—indeed, twofold speech.
The constant Dao and constant name—speaking of its ineffable without-name,
and speaking of its nameable use.

The without-name generates heaven and earth; the nameable begets myriad things—
all to display its function.
The essence of the supreme Dao is deep as the Great Void,
no thing generated, no name obtained—
at the utmost stillness, stillness generates motion,
thus the One *qi* unfurls like a brushstroke as the origin of things—
called "touching" yet not touching, called "responding" yet not responding,
rooted in void transformation, spirit generating *qi*.
The principle of generation unfolds here.
The Dao generates One; One is the beginning—
the spirit of myriad forms is thus evenly bestowed.
The "having" is not truly having—this is One yet unformed;
the "not having" is not truly not having—this is the initial form,
like the moon’s shadow in *guàn* (艮).
Like a trickle’s source, gradually forming heaven and earth—
who embodies transformation? This is the non-doing that does.
Now, the without-form is the marvelous—all laws return to rest;
the with-form is false—ordinary people taste it.
The Dao hidden is without use yet achieves use—
achieving use, *qi* comes first.
The law arises, using the law yet never exhausted—
the Original Beginning is boundless.
One, though falling into numbers, harmonizes with numbers—then eternal life.
The beginning has form; refining the form, one does not die.
Water one, fire two, wood three, metal four, earth five—
these are the generating numbers of the Five Phases.
Nine wood, three fire, seven metal, five water, ten earth—
these are the initial numbers of the Five Phases.
If one obtains their initial state, then knows the metal-wood inheriting the Original,
merging their completion reveals the life-death of water-fire.
Wood follows the child’s return to *shēn* (申), thus beginning to dwell in the womb.
*Qián* (乾) heaven belongs to metal, the east, and its governing function—
thus all six lines are nine, aligning with wood’s shared origin,
lodging in the metal direction, embodying a family’s marvelous function.
When metal comes to invade and occupy the *yín* (寅) position,
with the seven *qi* of *yīn-yūn* (氤氲) heaven,
dwelling in the three yang and receiving conception—
until fire, emerging from *duì* (兑) in the *hài* (亥) position,
obtaining three water, earth, and *guàn* (艮),
arising in the *xùn* (巽) direction—
its omens then appear in *yín-shēn-wèi-hài* (寅申巳亥).
The *Nǚtái* says: "This is the beginning," yet the *qi* does not congeal—
form and substance are fully refined here,
generating without interruption—thus differing from the *Hong Fan*.
Generation has conflict, yet also harmonious principle.
From the *Xian Jing*.

One follows the Original and does not terminate—thus called "beginning," emerging from the without-name.

**Two: The Great Ultimate generates Three.**
With name, the mother of myriad things.
The beginning is the origin—
before its generation is seen.
The generating is the mother—
things generate, then forms appear;
forms appear, then nourishment arises;
nourishment arises, then numbers emerge—this is the nameable.
The Classic begins with the without-name as the origin,
and the nameable as the generating—thus the non-existent becomes existent.
*The Er Ya* says: *Zhào* (肇), *zǔ* (祖), *yuán* (元), *tāi* (胎)—these are "beginning."
The *Kūn* hexagram embodies earth’s Dao, wife’s Dao, subject’s Dao—mother’s Dao.
*Qián* begins it; *kūn* generates it—
thus, pairing husband and wife brings forth male and female;
with male and female, the name of mother first becomes clear.
Thus, first speaking of beginning, then speaking of mother—
fourfold explanations arise:
One through yin-yang, two through heaven-earth,
three through father-mother, four through having-not-having.
Yin-yang is *qi*; *qi* is the division of yin-yang.
Initially, one *qi* unfurls—originally without yin-yang.
When the Great Ultimate generates one *qi*,
the light and clear ascend to form heaven,
the heavy and turbid descend to form earth.
Again, the *Kāi Tiān Jīng* says: "When heaven’s *qi* is sufficient, the surplus becomes earth."
Speaking of sufficiency reveals yin-yang has fixed numbers—
numbers are complete, then divided.
In the *Hun Yuan* era, though yin-yang existed,
refinement was not yet extreme, mixed yet undivided—
thus *Liezi* says: "The *qi* and form are complete yet not separated"—
this is the "mixed and turbid."
Again, the Original Beginning, with the Primordial Three *qi*,
generates thirty-six heavens above and thirty-six earths below—
above and below merge their virtue to form yin-yang.

「Again, the clear is the source of the turbid—this is seen in the *Qīng Jìng Jīng* ["Scripture of Pure Stillness"];
the yin is the nourishment of the yang—this is seen in the *Shēng Shén Zhāng* ["Chapter on the Spirit of Birth"].

From this, it may be observed that yin-yang originates from one *qi* yet divides itself into two,
hence the saying: *"Merge and then divide"*—the beginning of heaven and earth.
Originally, there are no parents;
they are born within the Great Emptiness (*Tàixū*), void and boundless,
conceived within the Primordial Chaos (*Hùndùn*), one *qi* undivided—
their form is like a chicken’s egg: yellow within, white without.
Before their division, heaven and earth are nurtured in the Soul’s Source (*Língyuán*).
When they divide, above and below are distinguished as heaven and earth.

Three *qi* merge to form *virtue* (*dé*), accumulating to nine for the yang.
Once the nine yang *qi* ascend, the surplus becomes earth.
Thus, heaven has nine heavens, earth has nine earths—
the Great Luo (*Dàluó*) forms the thirty-six heavens,
the three palaces of Metal, Fire, and Earth complete the merged numbers.

The Middle Luo (*Zhōngluó*) forms thirty-six heavens,
combining with thirty-two heavens—
the numbers of the Four Beginnings (*Sìshǐ*) arise.

The *Jiùkǔ Jīng* ["Scripture of Saving Suffering"] states:
*"Thirty-six above, thirty-six below—
this is heaven’s birth and earth’s completion,
uniting heaven and earth’s numbers,
totaling seventy-two as the seasonal markers,
fulfilling the beginning and the end."*

Heaven and earth are the manifested symbols (*chéngxiàng*) of the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way has no abode, yet it abides in heaven and earth.
Heaven and earth have no abode, yet they abide in the *Kàn* ["Receptive"] and *Kūn* ["Comprehensive"].
Thus, heaven is called father, earth is called mother—
heaven and earth merge from one *qi* to give birth to all things,
acting as father and mother.

The *Kàn* aspect pertains to the beginning (*shǐ*),
the *Kūn* aspect pertains to birth (*shēng*),
for the Dao/Way of beginning and birth is one.
Is it not that the form of heaven is male and the form of earth is female?

Those who grasp the meaning forget the symbols,
those who grasp the symbols forget the words—
if one has not yet grasped the meaning and symbols,
how can one exhaust their truth?

Thus, when discussing heaven and earth through one *qi*,
it is akin to the *Kàn* aspect dividing into spirit and matter—
this is the *"merge and then divide."*

From this, it may be observed that the Dao/Way is the mother of heaven and earth,
and heaven and earth are the mothers of all things—
thus it may be understood.

This is the *"divide and then merge"*—
the *Kàn* aspect as heaven and father,
the *Kūn* aspect as earth and mother.
From heaven to earth, eighty-four thousand *lǐ* [leagues],
and from earth to heaven, likewise.

When discussing the trigrams’ symbols (*guàxiàng*),
the *Fù* ["Return"] to *Tài* ["Great"] is three yin and three yang—
the *Kàn* below and *Kūn* above is the time of heaven and earth’s harmonious exchange (*jiāotài*).
The *Yì* ["Changes"] says: *"When male and female merge their essence, all things transform and are born"*—
this is the *Tài* ["Great"].

The *Tài* ["Great"] is the *Zhōnghé* ["Central Harmony"].
Within this, there is a *chōngqì* ["colliding/central *qi*"].
Dark and obscure, vague and indistinct—
here, the utmost truth (*Zhìzhēn*) converges,
this being the intent of all things containing life.

Yet, when heaven and earth are measured by eighty-four thousand *lǐ*,
the half-yin within yang is the spring equinox (*Chūnfēn*),
the half-yang within yin is the autumn equinox (*Qiūfēn*—
this too is the symbol of male and female union.

Though heaven is distant from earth and earth from heaven,
without the *qi*’s exchange and harmony (*jiāohé*),
how could they be called parents?
How could there be the principle of life and birth?

Thus, before division, it is called Primordial Chaos (*Hùndùn*),
after division, it is distinguished as yin-yang,
differing essences merge as male and female,
and marriage unites them as husband and wife.
The *Yì* ["Changes"] says: *"Only after male and female does husband and wife exist."*

Thus, the mother is taken to speak of birth.
The *virtue* (*dé*) that exists yet is empty—
this is the reverse of things;
the *power* (*shén*) that exists yet is none—
this is the origin of truth.

The nameless is the origin of true emptiness (*Zhēnkōng*),
the named is the wondrous application of things (*Miàoyǒng*).
Yet if the truth is without form (*wú*),
why wait for form to display its wonder?

One *qi* divides itself, the Three Powers (*Sāncái*) distinguish themselves,
all things take root naturally—
who directs this? Who sustains this?
This is called *Zìrán* ["Self-So/Naturalness"].

If discussing the *Shǐ* ["Making"] that causes this,
the *virtue* (*dé*) that has its own source is so,
the *power* (*shén*) that lacks its own source is not—
how could one escape heaven’s unfolding and earth’s completion,
yin’s merging and yang’s interfacing?

Without the mother, how could birth be displayed?
Without birth, how could one be called mother?
The *Scripture* says: *"The Dao/Way gives birth to it"*—
thus the Dao/Way is the mother of all things.

Entering without exit, existing without form—
as if there were a mechanism yet unable to act on its own.
The duality of having and not having,
if not the Dao/Way, then who?

Establishing the name "mother," the void emerges as reality (*shí*),
establishing the beginning (*shǐ*), reality returns to the void.
One having, one not having—
the Dao/Way’s wondrous application.
The origin of the none—
one must recognize the Great Emptiness (*Tàixū*),
the function of returning—
its essence lies within the mother.

The numbers of heaven and earth,
five *Kàn* and ten *Lí* ["Fire"]—
five times five is the mother,
scattering to give birth to all things—
this is called *Miàoyǒu* ["Wondrous Possession"].

As in the case of six *Wù* ["Not Yet"] added to *Kàn*,
six *Jǐ* ["Already"] added to *Lí* ["Fire"]—
the principle of life and birth is thus revealed.

Three distinctions (*Sānbàn*) manifest two bodies (*tǐ*).
First: **Stillness and Reflection (*Jìngzhào*) as the constant form (*Chángtǐ*)**.
Constantly without desire to observe its wonder—
the Dao/Way that may be spoken of is not the constant Dao/Way,
the name that may be named is not the constant name—
pointing to the constant Dao/Way and constant name is to exhaust the wonder.

It cannot be seen, cannot be heard—
it causes people to abandon sight and sound beyond names and words,
this being not attainable by those with intent.
Only those without intent may comprehend it—
thus it is called the *constant Dao/Way*.

Next: **The nameless beginning of heaven and earth, the named mother of all things—**
speaking of the Dao/Way’s wondrous application.
The first four sentences speak of wonder (*miào*),
the last two reveal its application (*yòng*).

To speak of wonder yet not of application,
the Dao/Way has no display.
To speak of application yet not of wonder,
affairs may obstruct the principle.

Moreover, all things receive their mandate from the none (*wú*),
yet take form in the having (*yǒu*).
The principle is thus again confirmed,
and the sages perceive it—
this lies in the seen and the seeing.

The Dao/Way has no color or form (*sèxiàng*),
the truth transcends names and words (*Míngyán*).
Delving deeply, one’s essence is perfected beyond the heart (*wúxīn*),
one’s destination is exhausted in reality (*shíqù*).
Since the void and none (*Xūwú*) is the Dao/Way,
why cling to things’ forms and appearances (*xiàngyīn*)?
To not abandon perception and hearing,
how could one return to purity and stillness?

Purity and stillness (*Qīngjìng*) are the root of nature (*xìng*),
color and form (*sèxiàng*) are the cause of names (*míng*).
Nature’s root is serene and pure (*zhànrán*),
neither name nor form.
Separating from nature while forms arise—
this is delusion, this is emptiness (*wàngwú*).
Thus names arise from the body and form,
forms arise from the mind’s perception (*niànxīn*),
truth and falsehood stand opposed—
the Dao/Way’s origin is difficult to trace.»

The **Dao/Way** (*Zhuāngzǐ*) speaks of the **Mystery of Mysteries** (*Xuánxuán*): since all things arise from the void and none (*Xūwú*), yet take form in the manifest (*yǒuxiàng*), the **Mystery** (*Lǐ*) is thus established, and the **Sage** (*Shèngrén*) perceives it, abiding in perception and awareness (*cúnxū jiànjiàn*). The **Dao/Way** is without color and form (*wú sèxiàng*), true beyond names and words (*zhēn jué míngyán*), its essence exhausted in the heartless (*wúxīn*), its destination fulfilled in the real (*shíqù*). Since the void and none is the **Dao/Way**, why cling to things’ forms and appearances (*xiàngyīn*)? To not abandon perception and hearing (*bù jué jiànwén*), how could one return to purity and stillness (*Qīngjìng*)?

Purity and stillness (*Qīngjìng*) are the root of nature (*xìng*), color and form (*sèxiàng*) the cause of names (*míng*). Nature’s root is serene and pure (*zhànrán*), neither name nor form. When form arises without nature—this is delusion, this is emptiness (*wàngwú*). Thus names arise from the body and form, forms from the mind’s perception (*niànxīn*), truth and falsehood stand opposed—yet the **Dao/Way**’s origin remains unfathomable (*nán yuán*).

---

**Thus**, the one who composes the **Scriptures** (*Jīng*) must uphold the void and none (*Xūwú*), while the seeker of **Mystery** (*Lǐ*) must observe color and form (*sèxiàng*). Through the void, one perceives reality (*jiàn shí*), from delusion and illusion (*huànwàng*), one knows the return (*zhī guī*). From none (*wú*) comes the having (*yǒu*), refined thought coalescing with dust to achieve completion (*jīng xiǎng chén ér chéngjiù*). Things lack inherent nature (*wú zìxìng*), hence the saying of the void (*yú wú yǒu yán*). The **Dao/Way** is nameless (*wú míng*), for it is not color. This is **Zhuāngzi**’s teaching: **"Before the having (*yǒu*), there was the none (*wú*), and before the none, there was the none"** (*Wèi shǐ yǒu fū, wèi shǐ yǒu wú yě zhě*).

**Second**, the **Way**’s constant and transformative application (*Cháng*). The **Sage** seeks its subtle essence (*miào*) through desireless observation (*wúyù guān qù*). The **Dao/Way** itself does not generate, nor is its none (*wú*) not the **Dao/Way**. The **Dao/Way** descends into things (*wù*), yet things are never not true (*wù wú fēi zhēn*). When things return to the **Dao/Way**, the **Dao/Way** does not claim dominion over them. The **Dao/Way**’s true constancy (*Zhēncháng*) is effortlessly free (*tuōrán wú lèi*), yet how can one speak of the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) as a mere sweeping vision (*fànjǐng*), a single *qi* spontaneously arising (*yī qì zì shēng*)?

The **Mystery** (*Xuán*) coalesces with true essence (*Zhēn*), and the **Three Powers** (*Sāncái*—Heaven, Earth, and Man) manifest their concrete forms and symbols (*xìngxiàng*) in Heaven. Then the **Six Qi** (*Liùqì*—Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water, and Void) circulate and gather to form shapes (*huí bóbó chéngxíng*) upon Earth. The **Five Phases** (*Wǔxíng*—Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water) generate and transform, while **Yin** and **Yang** govern their grand cycles (*Yīnyáng zǒng qí dàshù*). The **Eight Trigrams** (*Bāguà*) are fixed by the **Four Seasons** (*Sìshí*), with standards both constant (*yǒucháng*) and ever-changing (*biànhuà bùyǐ*), in life and death (*yī shēng yī miè*), as the **Mystery** (*Lǐ*) of things inherently is (*zài wù lǐ zhī gùrán*).

The **Dao/Way**’s **Mystery** (*Xuán*) is undying and unborn (*bùsǐ bùshēng*), its governance refined through **Yin** and **Yang** (*yīnyáng zhī zhèngmiào*). Those who grasp this **Dao/Way** belong to the **Perfect Ones** (*Zhìrén*). To fail in understanding the origin of life (*wèi dá shēngyuán*), yet to cling to illusion and extinction (*tú guī huànmiè*), is to not exhaust the **Mystery** (*Bù qióng zàohuà*)—this is the **Way**’s direct pointing to **Rest** (*Xiū*) and **Floating** (*Fú*), unaware of the **Mystery** (*Shù*) in death. When things lose their **Spirit** (*Shén*), their forms are not burdened by the **Mystery** (*Shù*). Those who exhaust the **Mystery** (*Shù*) recognize that **Void** (*Kōng*) is not truly void, nor **Form** (*Sè*) truly form. This is the work of the **Inverted Observer** (*Nì guān zhě*).

**Void** (*Xuán*) is the **Mystery** (*Xuán*). Earlier, it was said that having and none arise from the same **Mystery** (*Tǐ*), so one cannot distinguish them as having and none (*bù dé yǐ yǒu wú ér shū guān*). Later, the teaching is strictly sealed, hence the saying: **"Void is the **Mystery**"** (*Tóng wèi zhī xuán*). The character *tóng* (同) is composed of *yī* (一, "one") and *kǒu* (口, "mouth"), yet both are one in right and wrong (*yī zhě shìfēi, yī zhě shìfēi*). Thus, if they do not share the same *kǒu*, then right and wrong are the same. Hence, the **Great Unity** (*Dàtóng*) transcends humanity (*lí rén*).

To transcend humanity is to enter Heaven (*rù tiān*), and to enter Heaven is to align with the **Dao/Way** (*tóng dào*), which is called the **Mystery** (*Xuán*). This is the **Great Unity** (*Dàtóng*). The **Mystery** (*Xuán*) of having and none (*Yǒu wú èr lǐ*) is the same, yet the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) is spoken of as void (*wú*), making it subtle yet unseen (*miào ér bù kě jiàn*). Thus, the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) is also seen through having (*yǒu*), how could it be said that the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) is not the same? All things arise from having within none (*wú zhōng chū yǒu*), and none is contained within having (*yǒu zhōng hán wú*), rooted in the same nature (*bēn yī xìng*). Why then distinguish them as different?

「Yet the nature of the **Great Unity** (*Dàtóng*) is first revealed through the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) of transcending form and emptiness (*bèi sèkōng*), and further through the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) of surpassing having and none (*lí yǒuwú*). Thus, its meaning becomes gradually clear.

To awaken is to perceive the **Dao/Way** in every aspect (*tóutóu shì dào*), while to be deluded is to see distinctions in all phenomena (*mí shì jiànjiàn jiē shū*). To regard death and life as one thread (*yī tiáo*), and to treat the acceptable and unacceptable as a single passage (*yī guàn*), only then can one attain **equality and wisdom** (*píngděng xìngzhì*) to enter it.

**Yuè Jiě** says: *"Subtle yet minute is called the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)."*
The **Mystery** (*Xuán*) is the essence of Heaven (*tiān zhī sè*).
The *Book of Meaning* (*Shūyì*) states: *"Subtle yet minute is called the **Mystery** (*Xuán*), vast yet responsive is called **exalted** (*jùn*)."*
When **virtue/power** (*dé*) is concealed, it is subtle yet minute—this is the **Mystery** (*Xuán*).
When **virtue/power** (*dé*) is manifested, it becomes vast yet responsive—this is **exalted** (*jùn*).
Thus, among the **Sages** (*shèngrén*), when **virtue/power** (*dé*) is in the lower realm, it is called the **Mystery** (*Xuán*), and when in the higher realm, it is called **exalted** (*jùn*).
*"Subtle yet minute"* is indeed the **Mystery** (*Xuán*), yet it is difficult to speak of.

The **Dao/Way** has no form or appearance (*wú xíngxiàng*), so who can distinguish its vastness and minuteness?
The **Dao/Way** is vast as Heaven is vast (*dào dà tiān dà*), how could it be said to be minute?
In its relation to things (*qí zài wù*), how can minuteness be divided?
It is called *"hidden"* (*yǐn*) because it lacks form (*wú xíng*).
It is called *"profound"* (*ào*) because it is unfathomable (*wú cè*).
Indeed, the **Sage’s** heart (*shèngrén zhī xīn*), in harmony with the **Dao/Way**, is subtle.
When it emerges to respond to things (*chū ér yìng wù*), in principle it is hidden (*zài lǐ yǐn*), in practice it is manifest (*zài shì xiǎn*).
Though the practice is minute, it reveals itself as vast—this is the **Dao/Way** entering the ears and eyes of mortals (*zhù rén zhī ěrmù*).
The **Dao/Way** is vast yet dwells in minuteness—this is the profound depths of the heart’s abode (*chǔ xīn zhī yuānměi*).
Minuteness is the right (*yòu*), the right is the **yin** (*yīn*).
Through its hidden nature, the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) is subtle yet does not conceal its application (*ér bù cáng yòng*).
Vastness is the left (*zuǒ*), the left is the **prince** (*jūn*).
Through its manifest nature, it reveals the practice yet does not display the principle (*ér bù xiǎn lǐ*).
Thus it is said: *"Subtle yet minute is called the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)."*

Five praises of the **Mystery** (*Xuán*).
First, all **dharma** (*zhūfǎ*) possess subtle essence.
The **Mystery** (*Xuán*) scripture observes its subtlety through constant non-desire (*wú yù*), and its profundity through constant desire (*yǒu yù*).
Again, the same origin yet different names is called the **Mystery** (*Xuán*).
This binds the meaning of the first two sentences, unifying having and none into one principle (*yī zhèng*).
It is also said: *"The **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)."*
Initially, it refers to direct perception of the **Dao/Way**’s illumination (*jiànjué xiàngzhào*), awakening to this having and none (*wù yǒuwú*), where the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) is unified in essence (*yīn shì yǒuwú*), and thus deep insight is attained (*shēn shí zhī*).
Yet the meaning of *"the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)"* transcends the former principle (*yòu fēi qián lǐ kě bì*).
The scripture’s intent proceeds step by step (*cìdì shì yǒuwú*).
Having and none arise from the **Dao/Way** (*yǒuwú shēng yú dào*), and the **Dao/Way** governs having and none (*dào suǒyǐ sī yǒuwú*).
Yet having is inherently having (*yǒu zì yǒu*), not the **Dao/Way**’s having (*fēi dào zhī yǒu*).
None is inherently none (*wú zì wú*), not the **Dao/Way**’s none (*fēi dào zhī wú*).
This is the **Dao/Way**’s sovereign yet non-sovereign nature (*zhī dào zhǔ zhī ér bù zhǔ*).
Yet none also emerges from the **Dao/Way** (*rán wú yì chū yú dào*), and having also emerges from the **Dao/Way** (*yǒu yì chū yú dào*).
Since none’s essence is the **Mystery** (*Xuán*), having’s essence cannot but also be the **Mystery** (*Xuán*).
None manifests as images and patterns (*xiàngshù*), and images and patterns return to annihilation and none (*xiàngshù rù wú*).
The *Listed Master* (*Lièzǐ*) says: *"Self-generated, self-transformed"* is this.
Thus, having and none are not entangled with the **Dao/Way** (*yǒuwú bù gān yú dào*), and it is clear.
Yet having and none both emerge from the **Dao/Way** (*yǒuwú jiē zì dào chū*), and thus each attains the **Mystery** (*Xuán*).
It is like one father with two sons—father and sons share the same surname (*xìng*).
How could the father’s surname be given to the elder son yet not to the younger?
This illustrates the **Dao/Way**’s **Mystery** (*Xuán*), and having and none cannot but share the same **Mystery** (*Xuán*).

When applied in humanity (*qí yòng zài rén*), the **Dao/Way** generates from **Oneness** (*yī*).
**Oneness** is number (*shù*), the beginning (*shǐ*), and the meaning of *"embracing the beginning as one"* (*bàoshǐ yī*) returns to the **Great None** (*Tàiwú*).
Then, the body’s use and practice (*shēnzhōng yòngshì*) are revealed.
How could it be merely carried by empty words (*qǐ zhí yǐ xūyán zàizhī*)?
When the **Dragon** (*lóng*) and **Tiger** (*hǔ*) intermingle, the **Sage’s embryo** (*shèngtāi*) is formed.
The **Sage’s embryo** is refined and reveals the **True Person** (*zhēnrén*).
The **True Person** emerges and rides upon the **Divine Light** (*shén guāng*).
**Zhuangzi** says: *"Ascending upon the **Divine Light** (*shén guāng*) with form’s annihilation."*

Second, the subtlety precedes all **dharma** (*zhūfǎ*).
Again, the **Mystery** (*Xuán*): all **dharma** arise from the **Dao/Way** (*cóng dào ér shēng*).
The coarse and refined—each possesses the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)’s principle (*yīyī jiē yǒu Xuánlǐ*), called *"the essence of the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)"* (*tǐ Xuán*).
The **Mystery** (*Xuán*) of essence has not yet escaped traces (*wú tuō yú jì*).
To transcend the essence’s **Mystery** (*Xuán*), to depart from the essence’s application (*zhuàngxíng ér shàng*), and to ascend beyond form (*chéng shén guāng*), this is *"the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)"* (*shì yòu Xuán*).
The *Sutra of Strict Adherence* (*Léngyán*) says: *"Subtle yet constant is tranquil, having and none are both none, none and none are also annihilated."*
This speaks of **nature** (*xìng*).
Earlier, it was said that the scripture proceeds step by step (*cìdì*).
*"Step by step"* refers to distinguishing **sudden** (*dùn*) and **gradual** (*jiàn*), and **sudden** (*dùn*) and **gradual** (*jiàn*) refer to dividing **Great Vehicle** (*dàchéng*) and **Small Vehicle** (*xiǎochéng*).
The **Great Vehicle** (*dàchéng*) and **Small Vehicle** (*xiǎochéng*) are arranged in stages of fruition (*jiēguǒ*).
As in the *Ocean of the Void and Wisdom Storehouse* (*Hǎikōng Zhìcáng*) discourse on having and none (*yǒuwú zhī yì*), the **ultimate subtlety** (*miàoyǒu*) and **ultimate none** (*miàowú*) are the consummation (*jiūjìng*).
As in the **Nature School** (*Xìngzōng*) discourse on **inner void** (*nèikōng*), **outer void** (*wàikōng*), **inner-outer void** (*nèiwài kōng*), **void of void** (*kōngkōng*), **great void** (*dàkōng*), **ultimate void** (*shèngyì kōng*), **void of conditioned dharma** (*yǒuwú kōng*), **void of unconditioned dharma** (*wúwéi kōng*), **ultimate void** (*jìngyì kōng*), **void without bounds** (*wújì kōng*), **scattered void** (*sǎnkōng*), **void without change** (*wúbiàn yì kōng*), **void of inherent nature** (*běnxìng kōng*), **void of self-nature** (*zìxiàng kōng*), **void of shared nature** (*gòngxìng kōng*), **void of all dharma** (*yīqiè fǎ kōng*), **void of attainability** (*bùkědé kōng*), **void of inherent nature and self-nature** (*wúxìng zìxìng kōng*), the principle has not yet reached its limit (*lǐ yóu wèi jí*).
Only *"void of attainability"* (*bùkědé kōng*) is the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*).

The term *"the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)"* sighs at the **Dao/Way**’s profound and distant nature (*dào zhī shēnyuǎn*).
No extremes are established (*èrbiān bù lì*), nor is the middle **Dao/Way** (*zhōngdào*) secured.
Speech and silence are inexhaustible (*yánmò fěi qióng*), yet it is called *"the actual"** (*shìshí*).
Thus, one does not tread upon emptiness (*bù shǐ bù jiè xū*), and this is the true **Oneness** (*zhēnyī*).
This is the attainment of having (*suǒwéi yǒudé*), the so-called *"profound subtlety"* (*wēimiào*).

Now, we divide the gates of **sudden** (*dùn*) and **gradual** (*jiàn*), the stages of the three **Vehicles** (*sānchéng*), to verify the meaning of *"the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)"*.

Before the **Mixed Primordial** (*Hùnyuán*), there was no name nor image (*wú míng wú xiàng*).
Once the **Mixed Primordial** (*Hùnyuán*) is distinguished (*bìpàn*), there are images and names (*yǒu xiàng yǔ míng*).
From the time before namelessness (*zì wú míng yǐqián*), direct insight into its principle (*zhí wù qí lǐ*) is called **sudden** (*dùn*).
If from the time after having names (*cóng yǒu míng zhī hòu*), to subdue having and return to none (*shè yǒu guī wú*), this is called **gradual** (*jiàn*).
**Sudden** (*dùn*) does not establish a single **dharma** (*bù lì yī fǎ*), while **gradual** (*jiàn*) begins with cultivation and practice (*shǐ yú xiūwéi*).
The gate of cultivation and practice (*xiūwéi zhī mén*) is inherently attained through teaching (*zì yánjiào dé*).
This is the so-called *"daily progress"* (*rìyì*).
Progress yet capable of decline (*yì ér néng sǔn*), until *"again decline"* (*yòu sǔn*), one attains *"the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)"* (*zhèng yòu Xuán*).
In **nature** (*xìng*) it is so, and in **command** (*mìng*) it is also so.
The **Canon of Vitality and Health** (*Wèishēng zhī jīng*) begins with nurturing life (*yǎngshēng*), proceeds to prolonged life (*chángshēng*), and culminates in ascension to immortality (*fēixiān*).
The principle of **sudden** (*dùn*) and **gradual** (*jiàn*) each has its own tendency (*yǒu yóu qù*).
The meaning of *"the **Mystery** (*Xuán*) within the **Mystery** (*Xuán*)"* is not the ultimate scope of the **middle** (*zhōng*) and **small** (*xiǎo*) **Vehicles** (*chéng*).

The **Supreme Lord of the Dao** (*Tàishàng Dàojūn*) says:
*"Neither void nor non-void, nor void of void,
Neither **dharma** nor non-**dharma**, nor neither **dharma** nor non-**dharma**,
Neither thing nor non-thing, nor neither thing nor non-thing,
Neither person nor non-person, nor neither person nor non-person,
Neither cause nor non-cause, nor neither cause nor non-cause,
Neither fruit nor non-fruit, nor neither fruit nor non-fruit,
Neither beginning nor non-beginning, nor neither beginning nor non-beginning,
Neither end nor non-end, nor neither end nor non-end,
Neither end nor non-end, nor neither end nor non-end,
Yet as the root and foundation of all **dharma** (*yīqiè zhūfǎ gēnběn*).
Without contrivance nor action (*wú zào wú zuò*), it is called **natural** (*zìrán*)."*

The **Dao/Way** unfolds naturally, yet cannot be compelled to act nor prevented from acting.
Again it is said: The **Dao/Way** referred to as *playen* (玄), when rooted in the boundless four directions, exhausts the meaning of *playen*.

From this, the practitioner, neither clinging to void nor to existence, is called *playen*.
Yet this *playen* transcends all attainment, thus it is named **Double-Playen** (*Chóng Playen*), the gateway to all marvels.
Now we establish the **Sudden Teaching** (*Dùn Jiào*), naming it **Yet-Playen** (*Yòu Playen*), its meaning radiant.

Again, speaking of the **Great Vehicle** (*Dà Playen*) and the **Supreme Vehicle** (*Wúshàng Playen*), the **Teaching of Jade Purity** (*Yùqīng Jiào*) is the **Great Vehicle**, while the **Supreme Vehicle** is the **extinction of traces** (*Mǐn jì*) in the Three Purity Ones (*Sānqīng*).
Even as the **Supreme Lord of the Dao** (*Tàishàng Dàojūn*) in the **Nine Grades of Great Purity** (*Tàiqīng Jiǔpǐn*), one enters the realm of *playen*.
The **Nine Grades of Great Truth** (*Shàngzhēn Jiǔpǐn*), one attains the utmost *playen*.
The **Nine Grades of Great Sagehood** (*Shàngshèng Jiǔpǐn*), one reaches **Yet-Playen**.
When the Three Purity Ones are all extinguished, there is boundless **Yet-Playen** (*Wúliàng yòu Playen*).

All this is revealed through **nature** (*xìng*) and illuminated by the **Dao/Way** (*dào*), the grand essence of the scriptures resides here.
Thus, it is called the **Round Teaching** (*Yuán Jiào*), encompassing **nature** and **life** (*xìngmìng*).

When **virtue/power** (*dé*) enters, it becomes the **Dao/Way** (*dào*); when **nature** (*xìng*) merges, it becomes **life** (*mìng*).
This **life** (*mìng*), the culmination of **nature** (*xìng*), differs from the **life** of longevity (*chángshēng*).

The **life** of nurturing vitality (*yǎngshēng*) is not merely the fulfillment of **nature** (*xìng*), but also requires the preservation of deep roots and firm foundations.

Again, following the **Longevity School** (*Chángshēng zōng*), the **Yet-Playen** of the **Double-Playen** (*Chóng Playen*) is divided into two gates.
*Playen* is the inherent principle of all ten thousand things, manifesting in form and perception, revealing marvels in action, and transcending marvels to commune with the divine—all these are called *playen*.
*Playen* is ever concealed.
With concealment as **mystery** (*mì*), and **mystery** not transmitted, thus the **Forbidden Texts of the Flower Hall** (*Huā Táng nèijìn zhī shū*) are sealed, and their penetration lies in **entry** (*rù*).

Those who can penetrate are called **Seeing the Mechanism** (*jiàn jī*).
The *Yì* says: *"Delve into the profound and explore the hidden, hook the depths and reach the distant."* (*tàn zé shì suǒ yǐn, gōu shēn zhì yuǎn*)

Yet the hidden *playen* of things cannot compare to the hidden *playen* of the human body.
The hidden *playen* of the human body is the **Heavenly Mechanism** (*Tiānjī*).

**Laozi** says: *"The human body is subtle and marvelous, the worldly cannot speak of it."* (*rén shēn wēimiào, fán shì nán yán*)
Meaning all people value the distant and despise the near, unaware of the *playen* within their own bodies, yet only seeking to exhaust the mysteries of external things.

The *playen* within the body—sages discern the subtleties of yin and yang, and thus establish the **Law-Image of Heaven and Earth** (*fǎ xiàng guànkūn*), forming the **Nine Elixir Secrets** (*Jiǔdān zhī jué*), the **Longevity Doctrine** (*Chángshēng zhī zōng*).
They say the **Dao/Way**’s essence lies in the profound and subtle, the **Heavenly Mechanism** is deep and distant, and only the most profound cannot speak of it.

This method originates from the **Three Sovereigns** (*Sān Huáng*), and is transmitted to **Yellow Emperor** (*Huángdì*).
Later, those who succeeded the sages were many, yet their recorded teachings are sparse.
Only **Wei Boyang** (*Wèi Bóyáng*) composed the *Parameters of the Triple Concord* (*Shēntóng Qì*), correctly taking the **hexagrams and trigrams** (*yáo xiàng*) and **systematic words** (*xì yán*) of the *Zhou Yì* (周易), harmonizing them with the **Six Celestial Children** (*Liù Tiānzǐ*), moving the **Heavenly Mechanism** of Earth and Heaven, and unfolding its profound mysteries.
His words say: *"To refine the **Golden Elixir** (*Jīnyè*) and **Great Elixir** (*Tàidān*), one must first seek the **mixed origins** (*hùnyuán*) of Heaven and Earth, investigate the **foundations of yin and yang transformation** (*yīnyáng zàohuà zhī běn*), understand that **water and fire** (*shuǐhuǒ*) **subdue and restore** (*kèfù*) each other as husband and wife, and recognize that **metal and water** (*jīnshuǐ*) **emerge and nourish** (*xiàngshēng*) each other as child and mother.
Thus, when the male contains the female form, **lead** (*qiān*) within produces **sand** (*shā*).
When the female merges with the male form, **sand** (*shā*) within produces **mercury** (*gǒng*)."*

The Sun is **yang**. Within the Sun lies the **crow**—**yin** containing **yang**. The Moon is **yin**. Within the Moon lies the **rabbit**—**yang** containing **yin**. Thus, there exists the **Dao/Way** of **yin** and **yang** reversing, the principle of **water** and **fire** requiring each other. The **Dao/Way** of **creation and transformation** is now clear.

Having known their positions, one must also know their **roots**—these are the **mixed origins** (*hùnyuán*) of Heaven and Earth. Having taken their **roots**, one must also take their **symbols**—these are the **paired symbols** of **yin** and **yang**. Having obtained their **symbols**, one must inquire into **movement and stillness**; when **movement and stillness** are clear, one must know their **numbers**; having known their **numbers**, one must follow the **water clock**; when the **water clock** is divided, one must clarify **advance and retreat**; when **advance and retreat** are clear, one must then **separate the Dragon and Tiger**.

Then the boundaries of **south and north** are divided, and the forms of **metal and water** are united. Thus, the **Great Elixir** (*Dàdān*) may be refined.

There are also **internal and external methods and symbols**: **water** and **fire** have **dryness and moisture**; there are **cauldrons and chambers**; there are **fetal sacs**; there are **advance and retreat**; there are **hexagram symbols**; there are **omens of water and fire**; there are **rules for extraction and addition**; there are **patterns of the trigrams**; there are **forms of separation and union**. As mentioned above, each contains hidden profundity and mystery.

One must exhaust one’s wisdom and still seek instruction from a teacher. If one claims that the **mysterious pass** is a secret and leaves it unsaid, then where is the **doctrine of longevity**?

Previously, it was said: *"The **nameless** is the beginning of Heaven and Earth; the **named** is the mother of ten thousand things."* Speaking of **beginning** and **mother**, yet not speaking of **end**, one must infer the intent—this is called **grasping it**.

As for the **completion of the method** and the **principle of threefold perfection**, the **golden edicts and jade inscriptions** are recorded, the **Dao/Way** is transmitted, and the **doctrine of the Five Immortals** is elucidated. The **essentials of nine returns and seven transformations** are distinguished—this is the gathering of the **most profound mysteries**.

As for those of **minor attainment**, they are **initial profundity**; those of **medium attainment** are **ultimate profundity**; those of **great attainment** are **profoundest profundity**. This is seen in **cultivating the body and nurturing life**, **ingesting qi** and **refining the elixir**, ultimately achieving **transcendence and ascension**, ascending to the **ultimate profundity**—all of this has stages.

Like their **nature**, from **empty delusion** to **true emptiness**; like their **life**, from **cultivated vitality** to **ascending to the True**—profound beyond profundity, its meaning is thus.

To **be able to be without** is not yet to **be able to be without without**; thus, one cannot yet be the **gate of all mysteries**. To **be able to nurture qi** is not yet to **be able to refine the spirit**; thus, one cannot yet grasp the **logic of profoundest profundity**. **Nature exists in emptiness**, **life exists in reality**—only then does the **gate of mysteries** appear, not inherently mysterious, but **mysterious in multitude**.

The **Six Canons** symbolize **virtue**. The **gate of all mysteries**—as the *Explanation of Characters* says—**three persons** constitute a **multitude**; this is not limited to three. From **Heaven and Earth** to **all things**, from **sentient beings** to **insentient things**, all are encompassed by it. Thus, it is called the **gate of all mysteries**.

Truly reaching **profundity** is **exhausting one’s nature**; exhausting one’s nature is **oneness alone**. **Profoundest profundity** is **ultimate life**. Ultimate life enters **neither death nor birth**; thus, the **Dao/Way** has **no gate, no side paths**—it is the **vast and boundless sovereign**.

If one speaks of it as a **gate**, then the **Dao/Way** indeed has a **location**—this is incorrect. Speaking of it as a **gate** means it is not in any **location**; speaking of it as the **Dao/Way**, **nature has a returning movement**. Because of this returning movement, it is spoken of in terms of **entering and exiting**; yet speaking of **entering and exiting**, one has not yet seen **perfected nature**. When **nature is perfected**, there is nothing to perfect. Who exits? Who enters? Only then can one **gather all things** in the **ultimate void**, making the **mysterious oneness** an **unfathomable spirit**.

The *Classic of Change* says: *"Perfected nature, abiding, abiding—this is the gate of Dao/Way and virtue."* Thus, **birth and death**, as the *Secret of the Dark* says, **"Heaven gives life, Heaven takes life"**—this is the **principle of the Dao/Way**. **Exiting mechanisms, entering mechanisms**—as the **Gèn** trigram says, **"When the time to stop arrives, stop; when the time to move arrives, move."**

Those who **exit without fear** have **embodied the Dao/Way**; those who **enter without delight** have **penetrated profundity**; and those who **exit and enter without knowing why they exit and enter** have **exhausted the mysteries**. Thus, knowing the **gate** means **penetrating the principles of life and death for all things**, revealing the **doctrine of the return of all things**, and indeed, all things **receive their mandate from the **nameless**—this is **emerging from the **nameless** to the **named****.

Those who receive their mandate from the **Dao/Way** are all **mysterious**; thus, it is called **all mysteries**. How mysterious is it? Like **water**—those who **transgress** are **drowned**; all who are **born from the Dao/Way** possess **mystery**.

Next, it is said: *"I emerge from the **gate of all mysteries** and obtain **oneness**; **oneness** is within me. I shall carry this mystery and return, restoring my **root** and **command**, embodying **profoundest profundity**, and also being able to **master all mysteries**."* Like **fire**—**illuminating from myself**, all things are illuminated; **transforming from myself**, all things are transformed. Initially, the **Dao/Way’s mystery** is **me**; ultimately, **I** am also the **mystery of all things**. When one reaches this point, does the **Dao/Way** truly **mystify me**, or do **I** truly **mystify all things**? Ultimately, it advances to **unknowing**.

Shào Ruòyú says: *"The **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of is the **gate of all mysteries**."* The **Great Dao/Way** is **utter void and utter stillness**, **formless and nameless**; it cannot be sought through **sight or hearing**, cannot be known through **thought or reasoning**, cannot be attained through **speech or language**. This is the **Dao/Way** of **no beginning and no end**, **constantly existing and unchanging**. From **primordial void**, it **transforms into one qi**; because there is a **trace of one qi**, it is thus **speakable**.

Since it is said to be **speakable**, it is not the **constantly existing Dao/Way**; since there is a **name of qi**, it is not the **constantly existing name**. Before **one qi** manifested, in the **formless and nameless** time, this was the **beginning of Heaven and Earth**. This is the **Dao/Way** that cannot be spoken of. When there is the **name of one qi**, it is the **mother of ten thousand things**—this is the **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of.

Thus, one knows that **my body** emerges from **oneness**, and **human ability** can take **oneness** as **law**. Upon **awakening and entering**, one sees the **Great Dao/Way**. The **Great Dao/Way** is **human true heart**; **one qi** is the **desire born from the heart**.

The true heart is originally empty and tranquil, without birth or annihilation. When the true heart moves, it becomes manifest, and its names are desire-thought, wisdom, intuition, and cognition. Because the heart gives rise to desire, one follows desire and receives birth. After birth, one accepts and rejects pleasures and evils, clings endlessly to the five colors and five sounds, relies on strength and arrogance to dwell in honor or humiliation, and is deluded by false thoughts. Clinging to this false heart, one covers the true heart, failing to comprehend the Dao/Way of **one qi**.

If one abandons falsehood and desire, then one attains **oneness**. This heart, when held, is upright; when obtained, it is luminous. As the mother of ten thousand things, it is also the root of birth and death. Desire covers the true heart, hence there is birth and death.

If one can be without desire, then being without desire is empty and tranquil, returning to the formless beginning. Thus, one can transcend birth and death.

Hence, Laozi says: *"Constantly without desire, one observes the beginning of Heaven and Earth."* This is the subtle mystery of transcending birth and death. Again, he says: *"Constantly with desire, one observes the Dao/Way of one qi."* This is the perilous edge.

Shallow understanding cannot seek the heart with the heart—this is having desire. It cannot annihilate the heart with the heart—this is being without desire. These two—having and not having—are both encompassed as one principle. When spoken of as teaching, they are distinguished by the names "having" and "not having."

When having and not having merge, it is called **Xuan** (the Mysterious). The Buddhist School calls it the **"Non-dual Dharma Gate"** or the **"Middle Way."** The gate of **Xuan** takes the Middle as its law, like a net analogy. Yet since the law arises from the heart, and once it arises in the heart, it clings to the Middle—this is not empty and tranquil.

Laozi feared the Middle Way’s law would bind, preventing one from abandoning the net. Thus, he further explained with **Xuan**, teaching that the student should neither cling to having or not having nor dwell in the Middle Way of **Xuan**. In actual practice, the ground of reality is untouched by even a speck of dust, and the heart becomes empty and tranquil—this is **wuwei** (non-action), so no need for contemplation.

Because there is no attainment, this is being without desire. Hence, no dust arises, and it is called **clearing and tranquility**; there is no action, so it is called **wuwei**; there is no cultivation or realization, so it is called **natural**; there is nothing at all, so it is called **empty and tranquil**; it is unrestrained and free, so it is called **soaring**; it is uniformly ordinary, so it is called **serene and simple**.

Thus, when the heart is without desire, it departs from all distinctions. Departing from distinctions, there is no affliction. When the heart is without desire, encountering things there is no self. Without self, there is no conflict, hence no blame.

When the heart is without desire, it departs from all good and evil. Departing from good and evil, it is not bound by cause and effect. When the heart is without desire, it does not cling to all things, hence there is no birth, and without birth, there is no death.

The heart that is constantly without desire is the gate of all mysteries. King Zhi-ran says: *"The Dao that can be spoken of reaches the gate of all mysteries."* The Dao that cannot be spoken of—when spoken of, it is not so. The Dao that cannot be named—when named, it is not so. Calling it the Dao, can it not be spoken of? The Dao that can be spoken of is not the naturally constant Dao. The name that can be named is not the naturally arising name.

The constantly constant Dao and constantly constant name, like a ring without end, like the four seasons in their course—never beginning, never ending, yet arising and vanishing in turn, decaying and reviving, are not what I call the truly constant.

Constantly without desire, one observes its mystery—this is the substance of the Dao. Constantly with desire, one observes its perilous edge—this is the function of the Dao. Yet substance and function are always concealed in **huanghu** (obscurity and confusion). Between the subtle and coarse, the profound and the obscure, it cannot be known by wisdom, cannot be perceived by cognition, nor can it be attained through sight, hearing, or response.

How then does one attain it? There are those who learn and know it; there are none who know it without learning.

The *Yijing* says: *"Without thought, without action, silently unmoving, yet responding and thus communicating with all under Heaven."*

Yangzi says: *"Plow the Dao and obtain the Dao; hunt virtue and obtain virtue."*

Mencius says: *"Self-obtained."*

When self-obtained, one encounters the source on all sides. When study reaches the point of encountering the source on all sides, then where does one go without carrying it?

The so-called "obtaining" refers to obtaining this.

Ah! The mystery of the Dao suffices to exhaust the nature of all things. The subtlety of the Dao suffices to fathom the principles of all things. Nature and mystery are one in profundity, and the so-called having and not having—can they not be observed together and dualistically extinguished?

Some say: *"Having having, not having not having—what does this mean?"* This speaks of how having and not having alternate thus: not having is true having, having is true not having. Having and not having interdependently arise, never differing.

The Classic says: *"These two emerge together but have different names. They are called **Xuan** because its color is dark and faint, red and black, yin and yang mingling in steam—all unified."*

The *Yijing* says: *"One yin and one yang is called the Dao; the unfathomable yin and yang is called the Spirit."* Yin and yang, having and not having, are all unified.

Unified in one, yet not yet mysterious in one; mysterious in one, yet not yet mysterious in multiplicity; mysterious in multiplicity, yet not yet mysterious in self and things. Hence, it is said: *"Spirit is the mysterious speech of all things."*

**Xuan** beyond **Xuan**, then one and multiplicity, self and things—all are mysteriously unified. This is the so-called gate of all mysteries.

Thus, Laozi begins his first chapter with the profound meaning of **repeated Xuan**, reaching the most profound and distant principles, which cannot be exceeded. This is what students should devote their hearts to.

Program Tai-zhi says: *"The Dao that can be spoken of reaches the unnameable."* Without distinctions of self/other, past/future, always thus—this is its constancy. If it can do this but not that, if it was once thus but is not now, then it cannot be called constant.

Before the Dao becomes virtue, it is indistinct and boundless, encompassing all things in one. Within it, it can be firm or yielding, real or empty, short or long, responding to all stimuli with countless differences, yet not adhering to any particular thing or event—so what can it not respond to, what can it not accomplish?

---
*(Note: "重玄" [chóng xuán] is rendered as "repeated Xuan" to preserve the layered profundity, though "double mystery" or "ultimate mystery" could also serve. "恍惚" [huanghu] is "obscurity and confusion," a Daoist term for the ineffable state beyond duality.)*

The absence of distinctions between self and other, past and future—this is its constancy. Those who grasp the Dao understand its boundless essence and thus speak clearly of its unchanging nature, calling it *constant*.

When the Dao manifests as virtue, virtue solidifies into principles—*ren* (benevolence), *yi* (righteousness), *li* (ritual), *zhi* (wisdom)—all dwelling within the Dao yet unfolding into specific deeds. Once named and defined, they adhere to particular forms and limits. Thus, this virtue cannot encompass other virtues, nor can its name serve as another’s. Therefore, what can be spoken of as the Dao is no longer the *constant Dao*, and what can be named is not the *constant Name*.

The unnamed is the origin of heaven and earth.
Heaven and earth—governing all creation, opening and closing, generating and transforming—are already vast within their domain. Yet Laozi further ascends beyond them, establishing another category and naming it *Wu* (the Non-being). He declares that this *Wu* is what can be called the origin of heaven and earth. Such claims, the Confucian scholars doubt as empty boasts.

Yet the *Yijing*’s two principles (*yin* and *yang*) are heaven and earth, but what gives rise to them is truly the *Taiji* (Supreme Ultimate). The *Taiji* is neither heaven nor earth, yet it encompasses both, standing supreme. At that stage, no forms exist to be cast aside, no numbers to be counted—thus Laozi renames it *Wu*. Though their names differ, their essence is the same. His disciples knew later ages would doubt this, so Zhuangzi framed a question and answered it himself:

*"If form arises from the formless, how did heaven and earth come to be?"*
Thus, it is said that *Wu* gives rise to heaven and earth.
Even Zhuangzi knew people would doubt, so he clarified: Before heaven and earth formed, within the formless there were four stages: *Taiyi* (Great Unity), *Taichu* (Great Commencement), *Taishi* (Great Beginning), *Taosu* (Great Primordial)—this is their order. Though their *qi*, form, and substance were present yet undivided, they could only be called *hunlun* (indistinct chaos).

Only when movement and transformation occurred did the light and clear rise as heaven, the heavy and turbid settle as earth. Thus, the *Taiji* is precisely that which dwells in emptiness, embracing both purity and turbidity, establishing itself in an unmatched state of non-action. Is this not the indistinct yet formless?

Laozi names it *Wu*, preceding heaven and earth—this aligns with the *Yijing*’s logic.

The named is the mother of all things.
A later passage states: *"All things under heaven arise from the having; having arises from the non-being."* When it is *Wu*, it is simply vast and boundless. Yet all things emerge from it, so calling *Wu* the origin of heaven and earth is still plausible. But once it enters *You* (the having), how does it differ from other things, yet still generate them?

It is the *Wu* that has stirred yet not yet solidified into things. Examining its boundaries, it is the *hunlun*—about to move but not yet manifest. On the verge of being named *Wu*, it already differs from *Wu*; on the verge of being called *wu* (thing), it lacks defined form. Thus, studying its core, it is named *You*.

When it fully takes shape and is called *wanwu* (ten thousand things), they are all fixed in form and substance: heaven and earth, sun and moon, rain and dew, mountains and rivers, grasses and trees, humans and beasts, tools and vessels—all clearly defined, not merely *You*.

Laozi describes this *You* in three shifting names, yet they share one essence. Numerically, it is *One*—capable of generating all yet not yet all. Figuratively, it is *Xiang* (image); practically, it is *Pu* (uncarved block). *Xiang* and *Pu* can both become form and vessel, yet their form and vessel remain uncoagulated. Thus, above it is not yet *Wu*, below it is not yet *wu*—this *You* transcends past and future, self and other, as the eternal progenitor of all things. Hence, a later passage declares: *"All things under heaven have a beginning, which is the mother of all things under heaven."* Zhuangzi’s theory of origins stems from this.

Laozi himself knew this truth would be hard to grasp at once, so he further explained, moving from the whole to the particular: *"There is a thing, indistinctly formed, existing before heaven and earth. Silent and boundless, it stands alone yet never changes, revolves eternally yet leaves no trace—it can be the mother of all things under heaven. I do not know its name; I call it the Dao, forcefully name it the Great."*

*Mixing and forming*—this is the undivided state. It is the indistinct unity of *Wu* and *You* before differentiation. Existing before heaven and earth, it is where they truly originate. Standing alone, revolving eternally, it is the mother of all things under heaven—truly without a child, yet the source of all.

These three aspects encompass the origin of all things and phenomena under heaven. Laozi’s text omits what the *Six Classics* already elaborate, yet delves deeply into what they leave unexplored. The *Six Classics* exhaust the discussion of governance when reaching the Dao, but Laozi ascends beyond the Dao’s mother—heaven and earth—to higher realms: *Wu*, *Xuan*, and *repeated Xuan*—these are its domains.

Yet once the distinctions lie beyond these three aspects, they become beyond what can be spoken of as the Dao or named at all.

Since there is no name to invoke, yet one must speak from this realm to awaken the unenlightened—where then shall words be anchored?

Thus, transcending what can be spoken of or named, he establishes the dual categories of *You* and *Wu*, to convey his intent.

This is the overarching principle of his teaching.

Once these two categories are named, the scope of his discourse becomes accessible to all, allowing each to follow and infer its meaning.

When speaking of *Wu*, one knows his intent must lie before heaven and earth.
When speaking of *You*, one knows his intent must lie beyond all things.

Thus, though his text meanders in intricate ways, its myriad passages never stray from the dual principles of *You* and *Wu*.

Yet *You* and *Wu* were already discussed in the *Six Classics*, differing only in that the *Six Classics* never spoke of them in isolation.

The *Yijing*’s references to "without thought, without action, without form, without substance" indeed speak of *Wu*, yet thought, action, form, and substance are merely adjuncts—never wholly abandoned to stand alone as *Wu*.

Laozi’s innovation here lies in addressing the moment before creation had any manifestation, where even thought, action, form, and substance had not yet taken shape.

His intent, it seems, is to position himself within *Wu*, placing the *Six Classics* in the realm of already-formed things.

His aspirations are indeed lofty and distant, yet his words imply what may not exist.

Yet his distinctions are clear, his principles consistent throughout, and all may be examined and verified.

Confucian scholars also draw from this lineage, though many misinterpret his text by conflating *Dao* and *qi*, forcing shallow reasoning into profound mysteries—thus distorting and confusing it.

Why not test his teachings with concrete examples? Zhang Liang’s tranquility, Cao Parameter’s serenity, and Emperor Wen’s silent governance—these are instances where Laozi’s teachings, though not fully implemented in the Zhou, bore fruit in the Han.

In applying Laozi’s principles, they stand as the foremost models across the ages.

Yet did these rulers ever truly withdraw from worldly affairs? They simply refused to burden themselves with personal desires, so their reverence for *Wu*’s power—though not fully realizing the Dao—sufficed to cultivate emptiness and still chaos, never entangling themselves in worldly matters.

By the time of the Western Jin, however, rituals, music, laws, and governance were abandoned in favor of absolute *Wu*, leaving no structure or order, and the Jin dynasty collapsed in chaos. Thus, those who study Laozi must recognize that within *wuwei* lies *wu buwei*—what is not done—and only then can they understand how Han and Jin governance, though rooted in the same source, produced such divergent outcomes.

As for those who falsely claim *wuwei* as their practice, naming themselves Daoists while fabricating absurd tales of transcendence, fortune, and misfortune, these are not Laozi’s words.

Tracing their origins, tales of immortality arose in the Warring States, while prayers for retribution and responses flourished in the Han—yet none of this appears in the *Eighty-One Chapters*.

Should students of Laozi adhere to the original eighty-one chapters, or to the later embellishments of fantastical speech?

Should rulers and ministers emulate Zhang Liang, Cao Parameter, and Emperor Wen, or the reckless excesses of the Jin and the bizarre later traditions?

These are clear lessons—easy to discern, yet essential to heed.

Ever without desire, one may observe its boundaries.

The capacity to generate the **Having** from the **Non-Having**, yet not claiming itself as the **Having**, is how one may perpetually abide in the **Non-Having**.

The capacity to generate **Things** from the **Having**, yet not claiming itself as **Things**, is how one may perpetually abide in the **Having**.

How so? Before form and substance take root, within there is no separation or interruption, hence it may be perpetuated. But when one derives form and substance from **Creation-Transformation** (造化), and emerges from the **Dao/Way** to manifest as **virtue/power** (德), **benevolence**, **righteousness**, **propriety**, and **ritual**, these are all **Things**.

When these **Things** are perpetually congealed without dispersion, they may be named. If the **Having** is dispersed, then there is **Non-Having**. Thus, once the **Having** has become **Things**, all that has ever taken form cannot master its own **Having**.

When myriad **Things** arise together in their **keynote** (芸芸) state, and those that return to their root and wither become **bare** (枯秃), they may be awaited. For those who already possess the **Having**, since it cannot be retained, they revert to **command** (复命), and when the **stillness** (静) of the **Non-Having** once more overflows like spring’s nourishment, all that emerges in **keynote** cannot restrain itself, and thus retreats into the **Non-Having**.

The **Dao/Way’s** attainment or loss, along with the **spokes-and-hub** (辐毂) and **door-and-window** (户牖) of its implements—all are governed by a single principle. Thus, the **Having** and **Non-Having** of the world are insufficient to trace the **outer and inner** (表里) of the **Great Dao/Way**.

Those who perpetually abide in **Non-Having** are the **Dao/Way’s** essence yet to emerge. Those who perpetually abide in the **Having** are the **Dao/Way’s** movement already tending toward emergence.

These are all **Things** yet not ensnared by **Things**, hence they may encompass all **Creation-Transformation** without being consumed by it. With their dwelling in totality and their substance embracing all, the beginning and end of the **Great Dao/Way** may be sought within them.

That which is called **Mysterious** (妙) dwells in the depths of **Creation-Transformation**, where all **Having** originates. This is the **Non-Having** yet to be encompassed by totality.

That which is called **Boundary** (徼) is the **edge**, like the four corners of a frontier marking the boundaries of a central kingdom. It is the **Non-Having** that has emerged as **Having**, yet has not yet fully become **Things**. Hence it cannot be called **Mysterious** and is perpetually the **Boundary**.

With these two distinctions established, the **outer and inner** (表里) of the **Dao/Way** may be measured. To attain **Non-Having** and dwell within it is to explore the origin of all **Having** and perceive its **inner**; to attain the **Having** and dwell within it is to exhaust the production of all **Things** and perceive their **outer**.

Thus, Laozi esteems the perpetuation of **Non-Having** and **Having**, for within them the **outer and inner** of the **Dao/Way** may be imagined.

Zhuangzi said: *"Those who perceive the **Having** are the virtuous gentlemen of old; those who perceive the **Non-Having** are the friends of Heaven and Earth."* This aligns with the principle.

The *Book of Changes* (《易》) states: *"That which is above form is called the **Dao/Way**; that which is below form is called the **instrument** (器)."* The **Dao/Way** is the **instrument**, and the **instrument** is the **Dao/Way**. It is merely that their forms are above or below, not that they are two distinct entities.

This **Mysterious** and **Boundary** are the *Book of Changes*’s **above** and **below**. Those who abandon the **above** and **below** yet name it **Mysterious** and **Boundary** seek only to establish their own school, though their ultimate intent is not fundamentally different.

In the world, how could there be anything below that lacks support and yet stands empty above? Or anything **inner** without its **outer**?

This is the mutual reliance of **Dao/Way** and **instrument**, **Having** and **Non-Having**, clearly evident and easily understood. Hence, they are borrowed to illustrate that within the discourse on **Mysterious**, **Boundary** is never neglected.

These two are of the same origin yet bear different names. The **Having** is **Boundary** to the **Non-Having**, while the **Non-Having** is **Mysterious** to the **Having**. When they have already emerged, the **Having** and **Non-Having** may indeed be divided. But before emergence, they are indistinguishably merged, hence it is said they are the same.

The same is **One**. **One** is not yet **One**, for from it the **Three** may generate the **Myriad**, yet it has not yet reached the **Myriad**.

The *Book of Changes* and the Five Classics, as well as the *Discourses* (《论》) and *Mencius* (《孟》), have all spoken of **One**, yet none have explained how it is **One**.

Laozi’s disciples, however, have elaborately expounded upon this. They speak of **"indistinct unity"** (混成), **"indistinctly merged"** (浑沦), and **"indistinct chaos"** (浑沌)—all describing its undivided state.

From its emergence before division, it is named **"same"** (同); from its **Non-Having** and **matching"** (匹) not yet being so, it is named **"alone"** (独); and from its **Non-Having** not being otherwise, it is named **"perpetual"** (常). All these terms emphasize its totality and clarify its essence.

When the **Non-Having** has emerged as **Having** yet not fully become **Things**, it is again given distinctions—named **"One"** (一), **"Uncarved"** (朴), or **"Form"** (象)—all taken from its capacity to encompass the **Myriad** in unity, for the names arise from what it contains.

Thus, Laozi’s discourse on the **Dao/Way** is particularly detailed here. Though its branches and leaves may greatly diverge from Confucian teachings, even Confucians cannot help but draw upon its **Mysterious** insights.

Hence, the profound in **Dao/Way** can still align the disparate to serve the unified; while the shallow in **Dao/Way**, to the point of declaring that Confucius does not belong to a single school, are like those who pass through a doorway yet fail to recognize the halls and chambers within.

The unified is called **Dark** (玄). Five colors find **black** as their **Dark**, Heaven’s color is **Dark** in its boundless expanse, the **Great Dark** (太玄) of the **Vague** (罔) is direct, and in winter, all **Things** return to their root, **revert to command** (复命), without visible boundaries—this is named **Dark**.

Thus, **Dark** refers to the **profound and distant**. The *Liezi*’s statement that *"the **Dao/Way** is formless and ends in the **Dark**"* is precisely this teaching.

The unified is called **Dark**, for **Having** and **Non-Having** merge, indistinctly merged without separation, hence it may be called **profound and distant**.

If their traces are faintly discernible, then the **Non-Having** is truly hidden within the **Non-Having**, while the **Having** is truly formed within the **Having**. Once distinctions begin to emerge, it cannot again be called **Dark**.

The **Dark** beyond **Dark**, is the gateway to myriad **Mysterious** insights. When all **Having** is indistinctly merged into **Non-Having**, it has reached its extreme.

Now, advancing further upward, there is yet another **Dark**. The **Non-Having** advancing into **Dark** becomes ever more profound. And beyond the **Dark**, there is yet another **Dark**, its principle being what?

Zhuangzi and Liezi have indeed illuminated this.

「In Liezi’s discourse, there are **Too-Easy** (*Tà Yì*), **Too-Primordial** (*Tà Chū*), **Too-Beginning** (*Tà Shǐ*), and **Too-Substantial** (*Tà Sù*), all of which are the **Qi** (*Qi*) and form’s foundation for the myriad.

When descending through these four stages in sequence, and reaching the **Light and Pure** Heaven (*Qīng Qīng zhī Tiān*) and the **Heavy and Impure** Earth (*Zhòng Zhuó zhī Dì*), one may observe their order: **Having** advances to **Non-Having**, **Non-Having** further advances to **Dark**, and **Dark** advances yet again to **Darkness**—their successive ranks are clearly discernible.

Liezi says: *“There is **Having**, and there is **Non-Having**,”*—this aligns with Laozi’s **constant Non-constant Having** (*Cháng Wúcháng Yǒu*).

Again, *“There is **Having** before **Having** and **Non-Having**,”*—this is Laozi’s **Dark**.

Again, *“There is **Having** before **Having** and **Non-Having**, before **Having** and **Non-Having**,”*—this is the **Dark** beyond **Dark**.

All are insights perceived by the mind yet unnamed by the world, expressed through thought and forced into speech.

Laozi’s words—**“stillness, emptiness, profound and distant”** (*Jìliáo Yǎomiǎo*)—truly describe the state of **Dark** and **Dark** beyond **Dark**, while Zhuangzi further expands them as **“dim and silent, murky and obscure”** (*Hūn Mò Qí Jīn*).

Only **constant Non-Having** (*Cháng Wú*), which can encompass the **Mysterious** essence of all **Having**, is the true source from which the **Dark** beyond **Dark** emerges.

In later chapters, the **multitude of myriad** (*Zhòng Fǔ*) and **Zhuangzi’s hundred transformations** (*Bǎi Chāng*), along with the myriad beauties, all follow this same **Mysterious** principle, yet are clarified in their own terms.

Since the advent of written records, the **Dao/Way** of sages’ wisdom, virtue, and righteousness has been revealed in the *Yì* and confirmed by the governance of the **Five Three** (*Wǔ Sān*)—the **Six Classics**. From ancient times to the present, the world relies on them for sustenance, like the **Five Grains** and **Cloth of Raw Silk** (*Bùmáo*), without which life cannot thrive, and with which it flourishes. None can replace them, nor is there another principle as profound.

Yet Laozi establishes a teaching that seeks to utterly abandon sages’ wisdom, virtue, and righteousness, and revert to the **beginning of knotted cords** (*Jiégǒu*).

Those who take the **Six Classics** as their profession collectively uphold and reject this teaching, even labeling his work as a **heretical doctrine**. Yet the **Ten Thousand Words** (*Wàn Yī Yán*) persist alongside the **Six Classics**, never truly discarded—why is this?

The **Six Classics** elucidate **rites and laws**, so their texts are all about **instruments** (*Qì*). Yet regarding the **Dao/Way**, they offer only a brief outline.

Laozi exhausts the **Dao/Way** in its **constant Non-Having** (*Cháng Wú*), yet omits mention of **instruments** (*Qì*).

Though their focus differs—one detailed, the other sparse—**instruments** (*Qì*) bear the **Dao/Way**, and the **Dao/Way** generates **instruments** (*Qì*). They cannot be separated into two distinct paths.

Seeking the **Dao/Way**, one must ascend from lower learning to higher attainment, yet the **Six Classics** do not fully explore its depths.

Laozi, however, has fully expounded its profound essence.

Thus, those who study the **Dao/Way** and glimpse its truth find no language in the **Six Classics** to verify it, and so they align with Laozi’s words to elucidate its **virtue/power** (*Dé*).

Hence, though his teaching appears contradictory to theirs, the **Dao/Way** remains concurrent—there is good reason for this.

Ah! This principle is subtle indeed, too profound to be grasped in a single utterance.

Now, let me take the most accessible yet closest examples from ancient times to clarify it, so all may understand.

**Agriculture** is the foundation of civilization, yet its practice is the most coarse.

The teachings of the **Six Classics** speak of the timing for plowing, sowing, harvesting, and storing—of the tools before the **plow** (*Sì*), **hoe** (*Chuán*), **weeder** (*Zhì*), and **reaper** (*Zhì*). These are the most **concrete** (*Xíng*) and **lowly** (*Yuè*) of all **instruments** (*Qì*).

Yet the transformations of the four seasons depend on these **instruments** for their manifestation, and the seeds of a hundred grains achieve their fullness through them.

Even if the **original Qi** of Heaven and Earth is beyond naming, it still relies on these **instruments** to manifest its functions—how can one claim the **Dao/Way** is absent simply because its tools are present?

As for Laozi’s **Dao/Way**, he exhausts its utmost **Mysterious** essence.

He rejects the governance of **eastern labor and western harvest** (*Dōng Zuò Xī Chéng*), yet even in his texts, though he speaks of all things arising and returning to their roots—too numerous to enumerate—he still provides tools for **planting** (*Zhòng*), **harvesting** (*Shuō*), **nurturing** (*Yǎng*), and **pruning** (*Fá*).

Yet Laozi never utters a word on these matters.

When discussing the **subtle** and **Mysterious**, he still considers the **hinge of Heaven and Earth’s transformations** (*Tiān Dì Shēnghuà zhī Shuā*) and the **beginning of virtue and Dao** (*Dé Dào Yǔncáng zhī Shǐ*) as shallow, directly probing the origins of Heaven and Earth—**“how did Heaven and Earth come to be Heaven and Earth?”**—and the **Dark Non-Having**—**“how could the **Dark Non-Having** be **Dark Non-Having**?”**—only to name them in accordance with his intent.

Thus, his teaching seems entirely distinct from the **Six Classics**.

Yet, by examining his spoken words to infer what he does not say, and by seeking what he cannot help but imply despite his reluctance to speak openly, one finds that **virtue** (*Dé*), **righteousness** (*Rén*), and **rites** (*Yì*) are never truly absent, nor are **taxes** (*Shuì*), **punishments** (*Xíng*), **military force** (*Bīng*), **criminal law** (*Xíng*), and the **practical tools of daily life**—**chickens, dogs, boats, and carts** (*Jī Quǎn Zhōuchē*).

Though his words often exalt **Non-Having**, they never truly abandon **Having**.

In the first chapter, he reaches the extreme of **Dark** beyond **Dark**, yet he transcends the myriad **Mysterious** and governs their emergence.

When observing **Having**, it frequently appears in contrast with the **Mysterious** and **Non-Having**, standing parallel yet distinct—this **Having** and these **instruments** (*Qì*) are never truly separate.

Sages’ wisdom, virtue, and righteousness are never truly discarded.

Thus, when reading Laozi’s words, within the utmost **Non-Having**, one finds the **virtue/power** (*Dé*) of all **Having** and **Mysterious**—it must originate from **tracing** (*Jiànjì*).

Huang Maocai says: *“The **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of is not the **constant Non-Having**.”*

**Constant** (*Cháng*) here means **enduring** and **permanent**.

The **Dao/Way** begins and ends with Heaven and Earth—how could it be anything but enduring and permanent? Who could truly speak of it?

If the **Dao/Way** could be spoken of and named, then the world’s understanding would suffice as **constant**.

The Classics say: *“I do not know its name, so I call it **Dao/Way**.”*

The **Dao/Way** is singular and absolute—why then does it oppose **name** (*Míng*)?

Laozi’s intent is to reveal the **enduring and permanent** **Dao/Way** to people, is it not?

**Non-Having** is the **mother of myriad things**.

At the **beginning of Heaven and Earth**, was there truly **Non-Having**?

If there was indeed **Non-Having**, who then gave rise to it?

**Non-Having** is **Non-Naming**—**Non-Naming** is **Non-Having**—it cannot be named, so it is called thus.»

「When it has already come into existence, does it truly have something? It is only named thus to emphasize its power.

The Classics say: *“Vague and indistinct, yet within it there is form; indistinct and vague, yet within it there are things.”*
And again: *“Things are formed in a chaotic unity.”*
All these are forced names.

The term **"Non-Having"** (母) refers to its capacity to generate things.
Only after Heaven and Earth came into being did myriad things arise—thus, the sequence is first Heaven and Earth, then myriad things. His words follow this order.

**"Non-Having"** (无) and **"Non-Wanting"** (无欲) are said to reach the same state, called **"Mysterious"** (玄).
The Classics speak of **"Not Wanting"** (不欲), **"Few Wants"** (寡欲), and **"Desires Abundant"** (可欲多矣). Now, if one says **"Non-Wanting"** (无欲) and **"Having Wants"** (有欲), then it aligns with the Classics’ words.

Yet, **"Non-Wanting"** (无欲) may be called **"constant"** (常), but can **"Having Wants"** (有欲) also be called **"constant"** (常)?
One replies: Since things came into existence, those with **nine orifices** (*jiǔqiào*) are born from the womb, and those with **eight orifices** (*bāqiào*) are born from eggs—all due to desire.
