Doing nothing, yet the people till and eat,
Weave and clothe themselves,
Content with suckling, joyful with full bellies,
Playing without aim—
Delighting in their natural endowments,
All movements virtuous, the transformation of *non-action*.

Thus, the Sage entrusts them without interference.
The people can be led but not made to understand—
This is the wind of the Supreme Virtue’s *non-virtue*.

Born yet not possessing, achieving yet not dwelling.
All things generate spontaneously, each in its own transformation,
Not claimed as one’s own, yet all striving fulfills its nature,
Not relying on personal merit—
When deeds are complete and affairs settled,
The Way is realized in things,
The mind wanders at Maoshu’s peaks,
Not lording over the people—
This is the Sage’s complete virtue.

Only by not dwelling does one not depart.
The Sage’s deeds align with Nature’s creation,
Ensuring all things reach their utmost,
Yet forgets name and self.

*Not dwelling* means not claiming rank or treasure as one’s own,
So the people remain unaware, unknowing—
Thus, the Way does not perish, virtue does not fade.

*The Honglie Explanation* says:
When Chu’s General Zi Fa attacked Cai Yu, King Xuan of Qin welcomed him at the capital,
Granting him a hundred *mu* of land and the ceremonial jade tablet of a high official.
Zi Fa declined, saying:
*"To govern a state and establish policies, to receive visiting lords—
This is the king’s virtue.
To issue commands and the enemy flees before battle—
This is the general’s might.
To array troops and defeat the foe—
This is the common soldier’s strength.
To ride upon the people’s labor and take their rewards—
This is not the Way of Ren and Yi."*
Thus, he declined and did not accept.

Hence, *"achieving yet not dwelling"*—
Only by not dwelling does one not depart.

Xie Tusou said:
All under Heaven know what is supremely good.
When the Sage governs the world,
Good governance and fine transformations penetrate the hearts of the people,
Yet they do not recognize them as such.
Later generations implement a policy or decree, and the people call it good;
They establish a benefit or remove a harm, and the people praise it—
This is not impossible,
Yet what is manifest to all may not touch their hearts.

Thus, the unknowing are deeply moved,
While the knowing barely acknowledge it—
The profound is hard to exhaust, the shallow easily exposed.
If it is easily exposed,
Then the shift from good to evil, from virtue to vice,
Is but a turn of the hand—
Hence the warning against *having* and *not having*, *difficulty* and *ease*—
Its meaning is profound.

Thus, *having* and *not having* are inseparably linked.
Without level, there is no slope;
Without forward, there is no return.
The Sage alone ensures that what is called *good* is not evil,
That what is called *virtue* is not vice.

Without life, there is no death;
Death gives rise to life again.
Difficulty becomes ease, ease becomes difficulty;
Length and shortness, height and low—
Mutually contrasted, tilted, reversing, ever-changing,
With no fixed beginning.

Like sounds moving to tones’ harmony,
Or what precedes guiding what follows—
This is the necessary logic, the inevitable course.

Thus, the Sage’s virtue is never lost.
The Sage knows the world’s nature is ever-shifting,
So he follows Nature’s spontaneous order,
Acts without contrivance,
Teaches without speech—
Yet when called *good* or *beautiful*,
Who can truly know?

When things must act, the Sage does not shirk responsibility;
When things must be born, the Sage does not claim the benefit;
Doing without doing, yet not relying on ability;
Achieving without achieving, yet not dwelling on success—
All under Heaven find their proper place,
While the Sage seems uninvolved.

Yet though he does not dwell on his deeds,
Where would the world turn without the Sage?
The Sage has no designs on the world,
Yet the world cannot be without the Sage.

This is why it was the age of ancient Sage-Kings.
Indeed, examining it:
The rise and fall of ages, the waxing and waning of human nature and things—
How unequal they are!

The *Tai* yielding to *Pi*, *Yi* to *Sun*,
*Sue* to *Jian*, *Ji* to *Wei*—
The *Yi* has already spoken of this.
Yet the Sage comprehends these transformations,
Divinizes their changes,
Ever guiding the people through tireless motion,
Moving them in the realm of the unknown—
Thus, the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun
Governed with effortless ease,
Yet the world was in harmony,
And all things flourished without decree.

「Later generations adorned their actions as achievements,
And twisted their ways to display their abilities,
Boasting virtues and flaunting beauty—
Yet how could they fail to unsettle the people’s ears and eyes?
It is like cutting colored silk to claim elegance,
Or drawing water to feign depth.
The intent of nurturing and propagating life does not dwell within them,
And their downfall comes swiftly and surely.
How could they ever be considered models of perfect virtue and beauty?

Lin Yongzai remarked: *All under Heaven knows the utmost, yet does not cling to it.*
This chapter embodies the principle of *having while not possessing*.

Where there is beauty, there is ugliness;
Where there is virtue, there is vice.
Beauty unknown as beauty,
Virtue unknown as virtue—
Then there is no ugliness, no vice.

For all things in the world,
There is presence and absence,
Difficulty and ease,
Length and brevity,
Height and low,
Sound and voice,
Front and back.
The six lines of *mutual generation and completion*
All metaphorically illustrate the paired opposites of beauty and ugliness,
Virtue and vice.

Thus, the Sage acts without action,
Speaks without words—
Never shirking emptiness as idle,
Nor fearing excess as laborious,
But simply completing the task without claiming it.

Like the heavens and earth nurturing myriad things,
Through endless transformations and changes,
Pursuing one another without end—
Did they ever cease their toil?
All things flourish under heaven and earth,
Yet heaven and earth never claim them as their own.
Like spring and summer, life and death,
Creation’s work never relies on them as proof of its power.
Thus, they give birth without possession,
Act without reliance—
Their intent lies solely in *completing the task without claiming it*.

Hence, the three lines: *All things act, yet they do not claim to be the originators.*
*—作* (zuò) is akin to the *Yijing*’s *Kūn* (坤), which "acts to complete things."*
This reflects Shun and Yu’s *receiving the Mandate of Heaven yet not taking it as their own*.

From ancient times, all Sages were thus—
Why single out Laozi?

Only by *not claiming* does one *not lose*.
Those who possess what they have cannot truly have it,
While those who do not claim what they possess can truly have it.
These eight characters hold profound meaning.
The *Shū* (书) says: *He who has virtue yet loses virtue*—
This is its very essence.

When sound harmonizes with form, it is called *music*—
Hence, *sound and voice in accord*.

Fan Yingyuan noted: *All under Heaven knows the utmost, yet does not cling to it.*
*—至* (zhì) is pronounced *yǐ* (以), a grammatical particle.
Since ancient times, Sages have embodied this Dao in their dealings with affairs—
Their way of attaining perfect beauty and virtue,
Yet people unaware of their true beauty and virtue,
Is that affairs unfold naturally,
Each with its proper course.

Thus, the Sage follows nature’s logic,
Acts with measured harmony,
Never boasting or claiming credit for beauty or virtue.
If one boasts of beauty or claims virtue,
And makes all under Heaven aware of it—
Then ugliness and vice must surely follow.
Hence, *presence and absence generate and follow one another.*

This further confirms the opposites of beauty and ugliness,
Virtue and vice.
Therefore, the Sage’s *uttermost teaching*.

The Sage’s *uttermost teaching*—
This is the meaning of *continuing from above to below*.
The Sage, pure in the Dao,
Also called *the great and transformative*—
All that follows does likewise.

To dwell in *non-action* is to embody the Dao—
The Dao is ever *non-acting* yet never *not acting*,
And the Sage remains empty-hearted while responding to things.

To practice *unsaid teaching* is to align with Heaven—
Heaven speaks not, yet
The four seasons pass in its course,
And myriad creatures flourish in its embrace.
The Sage follows principle to benefit all,
Nothing left unaligned—
This is the *unsaid teaching*.

*All things act, yet they do not claim to be the originators*—
The ancient texts, as per Wang Bi and Yang Xu, agree.

*—作* (zuò) is motion.
Silent and still, yet sensing and thus fully responsive—
This is the Dao.
The Sage embodies the Dao in establishing things,
Responds only after being moved,
Thus, *they do not claim to be the originators*.

From *giving birth without possession* to *All under Heaven knows the utmost, yet does not cling*—
Fu Yi remarked: *The ancient texts all read "dwell" (处).*
All things’ generation, propagation, and movement
Arise from the Dao.
Yet the Dao never claims them as its own,
Nor relies on them for its power—
Until the task is complete, it never dwells on it.
Only by *not dwelling on the task’s completion*
Does one ensure that things do not resist.

The Sage embodies the Dao in standing,
Thus also *they give birth without possession*—
How could ugliness and vice follow?

Xue Yongzai said: *All under Heaven knows the utmost, yet does not cling*—
*To the paired opposites of front and back.*

Where there is beauty, there is ugliness;
Where there is virtue, there is vice—
No affair in the world lacks its counterpart.
These six are but one corner of the whole.

Yanzi’s *"As if standing firm upon something"*—
Surely there are opposites to it.

Therefore, the Sage’s *uttermost teaching*.
*—作而不为* (zuò ér bù wéi) is the affair of *non-action*,
*—言而不言* (yán ér bù yán) is the teaching of *no words*—
The Sage thus transcends all opposites.

Heaven and earth are *unbenevolent*,
Treating myriad things as *straw dogs*.
The Sage conforms to and mirrors them.
Only by *not claiming* does one *not lose*—
In their lack of dwelling, they also lack nothing to abandon.

Resting in the *Resting Pavilion* (休休庵) remarked:
*All under Heaven knows the utmost, yet does not cling*—
*To the paired opposites of front and back.*

The Three Powers established,
Myriad things born,
Radiance and luster flourish,
Names and forms appear.
Common folk know myriad things’ beauty,
Their utility in sustaining life—
Yet those who prize it fail to recognize the nurturing grace,
This is called *ugliness*.

Even if all know that creation’s movement,
Life and death’s unfolding,
Is virtue—
Those who take this as virtue
Only see the Three Powers’ *virtue/power*,
Yet fail to grasp the great Dao,
This is called *vice*.

Alas! To be blind to the Dao and lost in virtue,
To chase superficial ends while forgetting the root—
Day by day, their corruption deepens.

Though humans are the most enlightened,
They cannot reflect upon their original,
Pure, luminous, and wondrous nature—
Endowed with great *divine penetration*,
Capable of mastering all phenomena,
Possessing *non-action’s wondrous efficacy*—
Yet they pursue illusions and vie in *action*,
Their emotions and perceptions ensnared,
Bound by the Five Desires and Eight Winds,
Their greed, anger, delusion, and attachment wreaking havoc.

The Dao/Way gives rise to existence from non-existence,
Existence gives rise to non-existence,
Non-existence and existence mutually generate endlessly.

What is done in the world,
Some is difficult, some is easy—
Difficult things bring forth suffering,
Easy things bring forth joy,
And suffering and joy, difficulty and ease,
Mutually arise and fulfill one another.

Actions have virtue and vice,
Principles have strengths and weaknesses—
Strengths and weaknesses contrast,
And thus power has highs and lows,
Mutually inclining and countering one another.
Good and bad, sounds and tones,
Intermingle and blend,
Right and wrong,
One has not yet ceased,
The other follows in its wake—
Who would resolutely reflect,
Returning to simplicity,
Restoring to purity?

Thus the Sage dwells in non-action’s Dao/Way,
Yet never departs from it.

The Sage is one who comprehends the great Dao,
And broadens ultimate virtue/power.

The Master [Buddha] said:
*"Sever desire, abandon love,
Know the heart, attain the root,
Awaken to non-action’s dharma,
Internally gain nothing,
Externally seek nothing—
The heart does not cling to the Dao,
Nor does it bind to karma.
Without thought, without action,
Neither practice nor attainment,
Not passing through all stages,
Yet naturally exalted,
This is called the Dao."*

The Dao of non-action
Unites myriad virtues,
Dissolves collective confusion,
Responds to circumstances,
Aids the faltering,
Supports the endangered,
With wondrous natural efficacy.

Like spring moving through all lands,
Wind sweeping the boundless void.

Those who attain the great Dao
Do not boast of action’s achievements,
But trust in non-action’s Dao,
With virtue’s natural harmony,
Equal to all of existence—
Without words, people transform themselves.
Cultivating the self, harmonizing the family,
Govern the state, bring peace to the world—
Never for a moment can one depart from the Dao.

Those who take the Dao as their essence,
Their virtue/power aligns with Heaven and Earth,
Lofty, bright, vast, and profound,
All things arise together yet they do not reject them,
Nurturing all things without claiming ownership,
Mastering all phenomena without relying on their eminence,
Great deeds accomplished yet they do not dwell in their position.

Only those who do not dwell in great deeds,
Nor rule over others,
Are without loss.

Without honor or disgrace,
They transcend right and wrong.

Abandoning is losing.
Chu Bo-xiu said:
*"All know the Dao’s utmost extent,
Yet fail to depart from it."*

Externally in things,
There are beauties and virtues—
All know and delight in them;
Internally in oneself,
There are true beauties and true virtues—
Few know and do not pursue them.

Beauty and virtue arise from human desire,
Yet sometimes they are not beautiful nor virtuous.
True beauty and true virtue root in Heaven’s principle,
Everlasting through ages, ever beautiful and ever virtuous.

What the world calls good or bad,
Right or wrong,
All belong to deluded emotions—
One’s "right" is another’s "wrong."
Who can truly grasp the proper?

Born from the six pairs of opposites,
They spread endlessly—
Like the rise and fall of yin and yang,
Or the waxing and waning of existence and non-existence;
Difficulty and ease, deeds and failures—
The crane’s height reveals the duck’s shortness,
The mountain’s grandeur shows the marsh’s lowliness;
Sound emerges, yet tone arises,
Spring precedes, summer follows—
Even these mutually arising and fulfilling opposites
Cannot forever preserve beauty and virtue,
How much more so when they contrast and incline against one another?

The Sage investigates the origins,
Rescues defects,
Leading by example—
Non-action yet deeds are accomplished,
No words yet teachings are established,
People enjoy their customs,
Things fulfill their nature.

Plowing, digging, sowing—
These are things’ deeds,
I do not reject them,
Nurturing and fostering their growth.

These are things’ births,
I do not claim them,
Letting things act naturally—
What must be done cannot be avoided by me.
Why should I rely on my own efforts?

Only because they do not dwell in great deeds,
Thus their deeds cannot be abandoned.

Zhuangzi said:
*"I forget the world easily,
But making the world forget me is difficult."*
Truly so.

Some may debate:
Why, after naming the Dao as "non-existence,"
Does this chapter suddenly turn to beauty and vice,
And the six pairs of opposites?

For where the Dao exists,
Things arise;
Where things arise,
Names follow.
What is called "non-existence" is hidden,
But beauty and vice are names of things,
And deeds’ traces cannot escape the six pairs.

The Sage does not defy things’ nature,
But lets them flow, rise, and fall—
Sometimes contrary to principle,
Yet adjusts and rectifies accordingly,
Treating ailments with medicine,
Each restored to health.

When the illness departs and the medicine is removed,
The Sage’s heart is also empty.
How can the six pairs of opposites be avoided?

Niu Miao said:
*"All know the Dao’s utmost extent,
Yet fail to depart from it—
Beauty is delight,
Virtue is also delight.
Vice and non-virtue are both spoken of as not delightful."*

Even as in the world a single good deed,
Once fixed, is sure to turn bad—
This is the hidden calamity in prosperity,
The danger in security,
The interplay of fortune and misfortune.

No beauty is more beautiful than serving a lord,
Yet serving too often brings disgrace.
No virtue is more virtuous than friendship,
Yet too many friends bring estrangement.

*The Baopuzi* says:
*"Draped curtains gather mist,
Silken hangings blend with clouds—
Collecting fragrant blossoms in the grove of orchids,
Playing with red flowers in the pool of pearls,
Entering the dim glow of the Eight Gates of Darkness,
Exiting with the splendor of the Vermilion Wheels.
Yet when joy reaches its peak,
Sorrow gathers in its wake;
When fullness is attained,
Deficiency follows inevitably."*

This is the way beauty and vice intertwine—
All people in the world know this principle.

Thus non-existence and existence mutually generate,
From non-existence arises existence,
From existence not ceasing arises non-existence—
Non-existence generates existence,
Existence returns to non-existence,
Existence has form yet generates shadow,
Sound arises yet produces echo—
Non-existence moves yet generates existence,
Existence arises and returns to non-existence’s generation;
Existence has form yet returns to non-form.

Not generating is not the original non-generating,
Not having form is not the original non-form.

Generating is the principle’s inevitable end,
Ending cannot but end,
Just as generating cannot but generate—
This is all the saying of existence and non-existence’s mutual generation.

Difficulty and ease mutually fulfill one another—
Difficulty is the gateway to ease,
Ease is the root of difficulty.

In the world, all things are difficult or easy,
Interdependent in their use—
Even a single difficult deed,
If diligently pursued, though difficult,
Will become easy—
Is this not ease?

*(End of translation.)*

「若以易心临之，则其为难矣。
If one approaches it with a careless heart, then it becomes difficult indeed.

古语有云：世上无难事，只怕有心人。
As the old saying goes: There are no difficult matters in the world—only those who lack resolve.

又曰：有心射山山须透，无心射纸纸难穿。
It is also said: With resolve, one may pierce mountains with an arrow; without it, even paper resists.

洞宾曰：难难十石芝麻树上摊，易易浑似和衣一觉睡。
Zhuangzi’s disciple Dongbin remarked: Difficult tasks weigh like ten stones on a sesame tree—
Effortless ones feel as natural as resting in one’s robes.

老君曰：天下之难事必作於易，天下之大事必作於细。
Laozi said: The world’s difficult matters arise from ease,
And great undertakings begin in the minute.

是以圣人犹难之，故终无难。
Thus, the Sage still regards them as difficult,
And so, in the end, there is no difficulty.

此难易相成之说也。

长短之相形。
The interplay of length and brevity.

夫物之不齐，物之情也。
Things are not uniform—this is their natural state.

是故无长不别短，无短不显长，
长短之势，相形方别。
Hence, there is no length without distinction from brevity,
No brevity without highlighting length—
The very nature of length and brevity reveals their contrast.

且鹤胫虽长，断之则悲，
凫胫虽短，续之则忧。
Even the crane’s long legs, if severed, bring sorrow,
And the short legs of the teal, if lengthened, cause distress.

古人有言曰：青松高百尺，绿穗低数寸。
The ancients said: The green pine soars a hundred feet,
While the humble reed bows but a few inches.

同生大块间，长短各有分。
Both spring from the same earth,
Yet each possesses its own measure.

如人之才性，亦各有长短。
So too with human talent and nature—
Each has its own strengths and weaknesses.

然各长其长，各短其短，
则鸢飞鱼跃，各得其所，
自无长短之非也。
Yet if each fulfills its own strengths,
And accepts its own weaknesses—
Then the falcon soars and the fish leaps,
Each finding its proper place,
And there is no fault in length or brevity.

若稍有片善，寸长自以为能，
则长短必相形而随之也。
But if one has even a shred of virtue,
And deems a single inch of length sufficient—
Then length and brevity will inevitably contrast and follow suit.

非斯之谓欤？

高下之相倾。
The interplay of elevation and humility.

夫高者尊也，下者卑也，
虽尊卑之礼固有定在，
然高而不谦，尊卑而不安分，
则相倾之势由是而生也。
Elevation is nobility, humility is lowliness—
Though the rites of rank have fixed distinctions,
Yet if one is elevated without modesty,
Or ranked without proper humility—
Then the very force of imbalance arises.

盖贵以贱为本，高以下为基，
若好高而不为高，则不高矣。
For nobility is rooted in humility,
And elevation depends on a foundation of lowliness—
If one seeks elevation yet does not act accordingly,
Then one cannot truly be elevated.

古语有云：墙高耶，雨剥而颓之；
渊卑耶，水就而归之。
As the old saying goes: A wall too high will crumble beneath the rain’s relentless assault;
A pool too low will fill with waters that flow toward it.

谚曰：岸上沙，今人担土旧人家；
陌上路，今人来往昔人墓。
A proverb states: Sands on the shore—
Now men carry soil to build homes where once none stood;
Paths through the fields—
Now men tread where once lay ancient graves.

由是观之，海水桑田之变，固有之矣。
Thus observed, the shifting of seas and fields is natural indeed.

此高下相倾之势也。
This is the force of elevation and humility in balance.

若以势而言之，则如王公之子归庶人，
庶人之子为王公。
If spoken of in terms of this force,
Then it is like the son of a noble returning to common birth,
Or the son of a commoner ascending to noble rank.

扬子云曰：朝得权为卿相，夕失势为匹夫。
Yangzi said: One may rise to minister in the morning,
And fall to commoner by evening.

此皆高下相倾之说也。

声音之相和。
The interplay of sound and resonance.

声者鸣也，鸣则有音，
音必有响，响则必应，
故云音声相和也。
Sound is utterance—when uttered, there is tone,
And tone must have echo, which must respond—
Thus it is said that sound and resonance harmonize.

且雷霆有声，不动不闻，
锺鼓有音，不击不鸣。
Even thunder’s sound, if unmovement remains, cannot be heard,
And bells’ tones, if not struck, will not ring.

《诗》云：嘤其鸣矣，犹求友声。
The *Book of Odes* says: *Ming! Ming!*—its call still seeks a harmonizing response.

《易》曰：呜鹤在阴，其子和之。
The *Yijing* says: *The wailing crane is in the shade—its offspring responds in harmony.*

此声响之相随，犹形之於影，
自然而并生，俱出而俱没也。
This is how sound and echo follow one another,
Like form and shadow—
Both arise naturally together,
And vanish as one.

夫音者，本无待於声也，
声发而响随之耳。
For resonance is not dependent on sound—
It is only when sound is emitted that echo follows.

如人言凶则气粗，声和则气悦，
爱人者人常爱之，敬人者人常敬之，
未尝不由己出，其犹音响之於鸣声，
此固然之理也。
When one speaks harshly, their *qi* grows coarse,
And when their voice is harmonious, their *qi* is pleasing—
Those who love others are often loved in return,
And those who honor others are often honored in turn.
This is never otherwise—
Just as echo follows utterance,
So too does this principle hold true.

前后之相随。
The interplay of before and after.

夫身行於前，影必随之后，
阳唱於前，阴必和於后。
For when the body moves forward, the shadow follows behind,
And when the Yang leads, the Yin must harmonize.

此影形相逐，阴阳相和，
前后相随，此则必然之理也。
This is how shadow chases form,
And Yin harmonizes with Yang—
Before and after follow one another—
This is the inevitable principle.

《孔丛子》曰：前譬之古也，后譬之今也。
The *Kong Congzi* says: Before is like the past,
And after is like the present.

古今相继，犹前后之相随，
初无间然也。
Past and present follow one another,
Just as before and after—
There is no separation.

澄明子曰：前者始条理也，后者终条理也。
The Sage Chengming said: Before is the beginning of order,
And after is its completion.

未闻有前而无后也，
亦未见有始而无终也。
I have never heard of a before without an after,
Nor seen a beginning without an end.

前后一理也，始终一贯也。
Before and after are one principle,
And beginning and end are a continuous thread.

不由於前而至於后者，天下无之。
There is nothing in the world that does not arise from before and reach after.

此大修行人初以无为居其前，
无不为必继之於后，
此自然之道也。
Thus, the great cultivator first abides in *wuwei* (non-action),
And *wuwei* must inevitably follow—
This is the Way of Nature.

是以圣人处无为之事。
Therefore, the Sage governs through *wuwei*.

圣人者，天下之至人也。
The Sage is the ultimate person in the world.

而曰处无为之事者，何哉？
Yet why is it said that the Sage governs through *wuwei*?

夫无为者，简易也。
For *wuwei* is simplicity.

盖圣人者德并二仪，
故参乾坤之理，而从於简易也。
The Sage’s virtue encompasses both Yang and Yin,
Thus they grasp the principles of Heaven and Earth,
And follow simplicity.

何以知之？
《易》曰：乾以易知，坤以简能。
How do we know this?
The *Yijing* says: *Heaven is known through ease, Earth through simplicity.*

易则易知，简则易从。
Ease is easy to understand,
And simplicity is easy to follow.

易知则有亲，易从则有功。
Ease to understand brings familiarity,
And simplicity to follow yields effectiveness.

有亲则可久，有功则可大。
Familiarity allows endurance,
And effectiveness allows greatness.

可久则贤人之德，可大则贤人之业。
Endurance is the virtue of the worthy,
And greatness is their accomplishment.

易简而天下之理得矣。
Through ease and simplicity, the world’s principles are attained.

此圣人之所以处无为之事也。

行不言之教。
To practice the teaching that does not speak.

夫不言者，忘言也。
For not speaking is forgetting speech.

盖忘言之中，至理存焉。
Within forgetting speech, the highest principles remain.

谓天下之理尽在不言之中，
故圣人得其奥理，默而行之，
故云行不言之教也。
For the world’s principles are entirely contained in not speaking—
Thus the Sage attains their profound essence,
And acts in silence,
Hence it is said: *To practice the teaching that does not speak.*

然夫不言之教，谓天道也，
盖天道不言而善应也。
Yet the teaching that does not speak refers to the Dao of Heaven—
For Heaven’s Dao does not speak yet responds with goodness.

孔子曰：天何言哉？
四时行焉，百物生焉。
天何言哉？
Is this not what Confucius said?
*Heaven speaks not—*
Yet the four seasons proceed in their order,
And all things flourish in their time.
*Heaven speaks not—*

是以圣人观天之道，执天之行，
故云行不言之教也。
Thus the Sage observes Heaven’s Dao,
And follows its actions,
Hence it is said: *To practice the teaching that does not speak.*

《易》曰：天生神物，圣人则之。
天地变化，圣人效之。
天垂象见吉凶，圣人象之。
河出图洛出书，圣人则之。
The *Yijing* says:
*Heaven births divine things—*
The Sage follows them.
*Heaven and Earth transform—*
The Sage imitates them.
*Heaven displays symbols to show auspiciousness and inauspiciousness—*
The Sage mirrors them.
*The Yellow River reveals its map,*
*The Luo River its script—*
The Sage follows them.

夫神物变化，吉凶图书，
亦未尝有言也，
而圣人则效法象，
斯非行不言之教之谓欤？」
For divine things and transformations,
And symbols of auspiciousness and inauspiciousness,
There is no speech—
Yet the Sage responds by imitating their forms,
Is this not the practice of the teaching that does not speak?

*The myriad things act yet do not claim their deeds.*
The *acting* refers to the creation and flourishing of all things.
The *not claiming* means humility, not self-praising.
The *Zhongyong* says:
*Great indeed is the Sage’s Dao,*
*Vast and towering, reaching to Heaven.*

The *Yijing* says:
*The Sage acts,*
*And all things observe.*

Yet never has it been heard that the Sage boasts of his abilities.
As in the past, when Zongni (Confucius) traced the lineage of Yao and Shun,
And established the constitutional models of Wen and Wu,
He aligned himself above with Heaven’s timing,
And below followed Earth’s nurturing,
Like Heaven and Earth in their boundless sustaining and covering,
Like the four seasons in their orderly succession,
Like the sun and moon in their alternating brilliance,
All things flourishing together yet not harming one another,
The Dao running parallel yet never conflicting.

The lesser virtue flows like a river,
The greater virtue deeply transforms.
Thus his disciples said:
*"Is our Master a Sage?*
*How vast his abilities!"*

Confucius replied:
*"A Sage? That I cannot be."*
This is the humble self-effacement,
The *not claiming* of which we speak.

*He gives birth yet does not possess.*
The *giving birth* is the name of *ren* (virtue).
How so? Does not the *Yijing* say:
*"Endless, ceaseless birth—*
*This is called virtue."*

The *not possessing* means the Sage does not hoard his virtue for himself.
Former scholars said:
*"One may let all under Heaven benefit from the Sage’s virtue,*
*But not let them know of the Sage’s virtue.*
*To let them benefit and know—*
*This is the lesser virtue.*
*To have a method that can be debated—*
*This is the lesser virtue.*
*To let them benefit from the Sage’s sevenfold virtue yet remain unaware,*
*This is the greater virtue."*

*Without trace yet named—*
This is the Sage’s teaching of *giving birth yet not possessing*.

*The Sage does yet does not rely.*
The Sage is one of many talents and arts,
Yet never does he claim them as his own,
Hence it is said: *to do yet not rely*.

In the past, Yangzi (Yang Zhu) asked the Old Master (Laozi) of the Sage’s governance.
The Old Master replied:
*"The Sage’s governance,*
*Its power covers all under Heaven,*
*Yet appears not to act from himself.*
*Its transformation benefits all things,*
*Yet the people do not rely upon it.*
*There is no one to praise its name,*
*Yet things rejoice in their own accord.*
*He stands in the unfathomable,*
*Yet wanders in the boundless.*
*This is the teaching of doing yet not relying."*

Is this not the same principle?
*When deeds are accomplished, he does not dwell upon them—*
Thus it is said: *he does not depart*.

The *not dwelling* means he does not boast of his deeds.
The *not departing* means his name endures.
Again, it is said:
*The not dwelling is self-retreat.*
Indeed, when deeds are accomplished and the body retreats,
Then his virtue is lasting,
And his name is renowned.
Hence it is said: *his name does not depart*.

The Classics state:
*"Deeds accomplished, name secured,*
*Yet the body retreats—*
*This is Heaven’s Dao."*

As in the past, when Yu (the Great) tamed the waters and settled the land,
Shun (the Sage) passed the Mandate of Heaven to him,
Yet Yu declined in favor of Shun’s son, Shangjun (Kang Yu),
And withdrew to Yangcheng (the City of the Sun),
This was *accomplishing deeds yet not dwelling*.
And all under Heaven followed him—
This was *his name not departing*.

Is this not what is meant?

Zhuangzi’s *Inner Chapters* says: *"All under Heaven knows this, yet it does not depart."* Beauty lies within oneself, not in others. Goodness lies within oneself, not in others. Now, if one accumulates a single beauty yet desires all under Heaven to know it, then it is no longer beauty; if one performs a single good deed yet desires all under Heaven to know it, then it is no longer goodness.

The affairs of the world have opposites—what exists has its nonexistent counterpart, what is difficult has its easy counterpart, what is long has its short counterpart, what is high has its low counterpart. They generate and complete each other, contrast and incline toward each other, like echoes responding to sound, shadows following form.

The Sage encompasses all with effortless spontaneity. His actions are without contrivance, his teachings without words. Like Heaven, he nurtures all things without toil, with life’s function yet no trace of creation, with deeds yet no claim to labor. Our Master said: *"Only Heaven is great, only Yao followed it."* Broad and boundless, the people cannot name it.

The Sage follows Heaven’s Way by accomplishing deeds yet not dwelling upon them. At its utmost, goodness accumulates and his name becomes renowned; virtue shines and his person is honored. He does not seek fame, yet fame follows him. Though he wished to depart from it, how could he depart?

The Master of Chu’s Retreat said: *"Those who possess what they possess cannot truly possess it; those who lack what they possess can truly possess it."* This is truly speaking to the heart’s essence.

The character *去* (départ) is read as in *"the noble departs from benevolence."*

The ancient scholars said: *"If one seeks virtue yet avoids fame, then there are no deeds worth doing under Heaven. The Sage has intent in doing good yet no intent in gaining fame, yet fame cannot ultimately be made to depart—just as sound harmonizes with sound, and form follows shadow."*

When read from beginning to end, the entire chapter’s meaning flows together like a pulse, its threads interconnected. It concludes by reiterating: *"Only because he does not dwell upon it, it does not depart."* This is not merely a marvel of composition but a profound teaching for humanity.

Xu Liu said: *"All under Heaven knows this, yet it does not depart"*—the meaning echoes throughout.

Wealth is the root of misfortune, and joy the source of sorrow; this is the natural order. None can perceive it, so the Sage, moved by pity for the world’s ignorance, declares: *"All under Heaven knows beauty and goodness, rushing toward and delighting in them, yet does not know that evil and harm arise from them."*

This principle is like the generation of having and lacking, the completion of difficulty and ease, the contrast of length and shortness, the inclination of high and low, the harmony of sound and echo, the succession of before and after. From ancient times to now, all things and affairs have their opposites, like an endless ring.

Only the Sage stands alone, without counterpart. Thus the Sage dwells in non-action, yet it does not depart.

Only the Sage stands independent, with no opposing counterpart. For he dwells in non-action, practices teaching without words.

Non-action is not inaction—it means following nature’s spontaneity, responding without contrivance, and thus achieving harmony.

Teaching without words is not mere silence—it means sincere inner cultivation and loyal, trustworthy outward conduct. The world follows him without effort or expenditure. Though he daily responds to myriad affairs, he leads yet does not initiate, so he does not weary of labor—hence it is said: *"He acts yet does not claim the deed."* The people are nourished by his care alone, with no personal gain—hence it is said: *"He gives life yet does not possess."* He establishes deeds and fulfills his role, acting only as duty demands, without boasting of his own ability—hence it is said: *"He acts yet does not rely upon it."* When deeds are accomplished and affairs settled, he retreats and yields his position—hence it is said: *"He accomplishes deeds yet does not dwell upon them."*

Only thus, by following Heaven’s Dao, is his person preserved and his deeds enduring. Therefore, his fame is praised across ten thousand generations without ceasing. Hence it is said: *"It does not depart."*

*Zhiyi’s* *Collected Remnants* says: *"Having and lacking generate each other, just as there must be low if there is high. Thus, though having and lacking differ, both ultimately escape the realm of mere possession."* This speaks to the forms of things, borrowing the contrast of having and lacking to illustrate it.

Guang [commentary] says: *"These six pairs are why things are unequal; only those who lose their counterparts can achieve harmony."*

From *Cross-Referencing the Masters*:
*The Master Zhuang* says: *"The Dao can be weak yet strong, soft yet hard, yin yet yang, hidden yet manifest, encompassing Heaven and Earth, responding without measure. To know shallowly is to not know deeply; to know externally is to not know internally; to know coarsely is to not know finely. To know is to not know; to not know is to know. Who knows that knowing is not knowing, and not knowing is knowing? The Dao cannot be heard—hearing it is false. The Dao cannot be seen—seeing it is false. The Dao cannot be spoken—speaking it is false. Who knows the formless form?*

*"Therefore, all under Heaven knows goodness as goodness, yet it is no longer goodness. The wise do not speak; those who speak are not wise."*

Shi Tan said: *"All under Heaven knows beauty as beauty, yet it is already evil. All know goodness as goodness, yet it is no longer goodness."*

Thus, having and lacking generate each other, difficulty and ease complete each other, length and shortness contrast each other, high and low incline toward each other, sound harmonizes with sound, before follows after. Beauty and evil, goodness and harm, having and lacking, difficulty and ease, length and shortness, high and low—all are relative terms without fixed names.

When there is beauty, there is evil in opposition; when there is goodness, there is harm in opposition. Hence it is said: *"All under Heaven knows beauty as beauty, yet it is already evil; all know goodness as goodness, yet it is no longer goodness."*

When it comes to having, there is lacking in opposition; having difficulty, there is ease in opposition; having length, there is shortness in opposition; having height, there is lowliness in opposition. Thus, they generate and complete each other, contrast and incline toward each other.

Yet these are all opposites, but as for sound and sequence, they are not starkly opposed, yet why are they included as well? Truly, the Way in which they generate and complete each other, contrast and incline toward each other, is also like the harmonization of sound and the following of sequence—this is the natural principle.

This further illustrates that even what does not seem opposite is used to describe what must be opposite. Therefore, the Sage handles the affairs of *wuwei* (無為, non-action), and practices the teaching of *busheng* (不言, non-speech).

*Wuwei* and *busheng* are both means to embody the Dao’s *wu ming* (無名, namelessness). With names come action and speech. Since the Dao has no name, what need is there for speech and action?

Thus, it transcends the realm of beauty and evil, goodness and harm. Only in *wuwei* and *busheng* can beauty even be named—what of evil? Only in *wuwei* and *busheng* can goodness be named—what of harm?

All things arise, yet the Sage does not claim them; they are born, yet the Sage does not possess them. Act without relying upon it; when the work is done, do not dwell upon it.

All things arise, yet I do not claim them—let them arise. They are born, yet I do not possess them—I though give birth to them, yet never claim that they are mine to give birth to.

Act without relying upon it—I act through *wuwei* (non-action), yet never rely upon what I have done. When the work is done, I do not dwell upon it—though I give birth to them, it cannot be said that I have no merit, yet I do not dwell upon that merit.

Thus, though I am beautiful, others do not know me as such; though I am good, others do not know me as such.

Only by not dwelling upon it does its essence remain. If one dwells upon it, it departs. If I dwell upon my beauty, when beauty’s name departs, it becomes evil. If I dwell upon my goodness, when goodness’s name departs, it becomes harm.

Only by handling the affairs of *wuwei* (non-action), practicing the teaching of *busheng* (non-speech), acting without claiming, giving birth without possessing, acting without relying upon it, and completing the work without dwelling upon it—thus, its name does not depart.

Its name does not depart, then it is my name. This passage elaborates upon the previous meaning of *wu ming* (namelessness).

*Dao De Jing Ji Yi* (道德真经集义, *The Collected Meanings of the Dao De Jing*) Volume Six concludes. Volume Seven begins.

「Master Yinyuan of the Concentrated Dao/Way’s profound and mysterious *De* (virtue/power) is always present.

*Liu Weiyong*, who oversees the affairs of the *Xuanmiao Guan* (Mysterious Marvels Hall), has compiled this text.

*Ding Yidong*, in his capacity as a *delong* (editor) of the *Jushimi Yuan* (Office of the Imperial Secretariat) and a *taifu shi bu* (official of the Bureau of Finance) in the previous dynasty, has verified it.

**Chapter on Not Esteeming the Virtuous (不尚贤章):**
*Considerations of Differences (考异):* The *Master of the Yellow River* (河上公) composed *The Chapter on the Mysterious Transformation of the Alone-Evolved* (至神独化义章), while *Zhao Shizhu* (赵实庵) authored *The Chapter on the Mysterious Transformation of the Alone-Evolved* (至神独化义章) and *The Chapter on Pacifying the People* (安民章).

*Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang* (唐明皇) expounded: In the previous chapter, it was made clear that the myriad transformations return to the root, and the Dao/Way’s virtuous transformation is illuminated. In this chapter, it is made clear that the noble and esteemed are not to be relied upon, and *wuwei* (non-action) leads to the ultimate principle.

First, it is stated that one should not esteem the virtuous, thereby severing the traces of arrogance and partiality. Next, the *saintly principle* (圣理) is mentioned, demonstrating the method of establishing the teaching, concluding with *wuwei* (non-action) to show that transformation is complete yet returns to simplicity.

*Du Guangting* (杜光庭) said: The great sage establishes the principle, while the virtuous assist it. How can they be like fish and water without relying upon each other? From the sovereign of the Five Phases (二五之主) down to the tyrant-king (霸王之君), those who open states and establish their foundations depend upon the virtuous as their basis.

The phrase "not esteeming" (不尚) refers to the conduct of arrogance and boasting. If the virtuous are employed, the people will naturally govern themselves; if boasting is employed, grievances and conflicts will arise. Not esteeming boasting will naturally eliminate grievances and conflicts, and not valuing rare and precious goods will make the people without covetousness or theft—thus aligning with the saintly, and with the Dao/Way’s *xuzi* (emptiness), *wuzhi* (non-knowing), and *wuyu* (non-desire), fulfilling the principle of not esteeming.

*Zhang Chongying* (张冲应) replied: "Pacifying" (安) means "governing" (治), and "people" (民) refers to "humanity" (人). This chapter speaks of how rulers and great officials reflect upon the Dao/Way, nurturing their own selves, and thus their upright actions and virtuous influence will follow. If the people take *wuwei* (non-action) as their foundation, there will be none who are not governed and pacified.

Not esteeming the virtuous prevents the people from striving in conflict. Not valuing rare and difficult-to-obtain goods prevents the people from becoming thieves.»

If desirable things are unseen, the heart will not be disturbed.
Thus, the saintly governance
empties the heart,
fills the belly,
weakens the will,
strengthens the bones,
ever keeping the people in *wuzhi* (non-knowing) and *wuyu* (non-desire),
so that even the wise dare not act.

To act with *wuwei* (non-action)
is to ensure nothing remains ungoverned.

**Variants:**
*"Heart"* (心) in *"heart will not be disturbed"* (使心不乱) was originally *"people’s heart"* (民心) in ancient texts.
*"Nothing remains ungoverned"* (无不治) was rendered as *"nothing remains undone"* (无不为) by Fu Yue (傅奕) and Sun Deng (孙登), matching the ancient version.

**He Shang Gong (河上公) said:**
*"Not esteeming the virtuous"* (不尚贤) refers to those virtuous in the eyes of the world—
eloquent in speech, skilled in rhetoric, yet detached from the Dao/Way, prioritizing artifice over substance.
*"Not esteeming"* means neither rewarding them with office nor wealth.
Thus, the people will not strive in contention.
*"Not contending"* clarifies the return to natural simplicity.
*"Not valuing rare goods"* means the ruler does not hoard precious treasures—
gold abandoned in mountains, pearls cast into depths.
Thus, the people will not steal.
With the ruler’s purity above, none below will be greedy.

*"Desirable things unseen"* means abandoning licentious music and distant beauties,
so the heart remains undisturbed.
No licentiousness, no confusion.

Thus, the saintly governance—
governing the nation and nurturing the self are one.

*"Empty the heart"* means eliminating cravings, dispelling chaos.
*"Fill the belly"* means embracing the Dao/Way, holding to unity, guarding the Five Spirits.
*"Weaken the will"* means gentle, yielding, and humble—never seizing power.
*"Strengthen the bones"* means cherishing essence, moderating exertion, ensuring marrow fills and bones harden.
Ever keeping the people in *wuzhi* (non-knowing) and *wuyu* (non-desire),
returning to simplicity, guarding purity.

Thus, even the wise dare not act—
for deep thought prevents reckless speech.
To act with *wuwei* (non-action)
is to move without contrivance, following natural course,
and thus nothing remains ungoverned.
With virtue’s influence profound, the people dwell in peace.

**Wang Fu Si (王辅嗣) said:**
From *"not esteeming the virtuous"* to *"the heart will not be disturbed"*—
*"Virtuous"* means capable, *"esteeming"* is praise by name, *"valuing"* is exaltation by title.
If only capability is rewarded, why bestow praise and honor?
Exalting the virtuous for fame alone, their glory exceeding their worth,
the people will rush to compete, their abilities vying in rivalry.
Wealth beyond use will tempt the greedy to steal, risking life for plunder.
Thus, if desirable things are unseen, the heart will not be disturbed.

Therefore, the saintly governance truly *"fills the belly"*—
the heart holds wisdom, the belly sustains life;
empty of wisdom, yet full of nourishment.

*"Weaken the will, strengthen the bones"*—
bones without knowledge remain sturdy,
while the will, when unrestrained, breeds chaos.
Ever keeping the people in *wuzhi* (non-knowing) and *wuyu* (non-desire),
they guard their true nature.

Thus, even the wise dare not act—
*"the wise"* refers to those who act.
And so nothing remains ungoverned.

**Tang Ming Huang (唐明皇) said:**
*"Not esteeming the virtuous"* prevents contention.
Exalting the virtuous leaves traces—
those who follow them will contend.
If the virtuous and unvirtuous each fulfill their roles,
there will be no contention.

**Commentary (疏):**
*"Esteeming"* means elevating in status.
*"Virtuous"* means talent and ability.
The ruler’s exaltation of ability leaves traces;
following these traces loses authenticity,
and losing authenticity is the root of esteeming the virtuous.
Contention arises from clinging to these traces—
better than the Dao’s mysterious transformation,
assigning *wuwei* (non-action),
letting the people follow naturally—
clouds obey the dragon, winds follow the tiger.
Then, even in the reign of Tang Yao (唐尧),
there will be no shortage of worthy ministers like Yuan Kai (元凯);
I Lu (伊吕) ascending to office,
fulfilling the hopes of the people.
Each in their proper place, none coveting more,
and thus there is no contention.

**Original Text Translation:**

Do not esteem rare and difficult-to-obtain goods,
so the people will not become thieves.

Rare and difficult-to-obtain goods refer to what lies beyond one’s natural endowment.
To seek what cannot be had is futile—thus they are called difficult to obtain.
He who does not rest in his natural allotment,
but covets what he lacks,
has already strayed from his nature—
how can this not be theft?

Let things be used according to their nature,
and let actions accord with one’s abilities,
then rare and difficult-to-obtain goods will lose their allure,
and the essence of life will not be stolen.

**Commentary (疏):**
Humans, upon receiving life, are endowed with a natural portion.
The materials and faculties they inherit are their own body and treasure.
To seek beyond one’s allotment is futile—
thus they are called difficult to obtain.

If one does not abide by his nature,
but aspires to brilliance beyond his endowment,
he loses his true essence
and becomes a thief by private inclination.

Now, if the wise and foolish follow their natural inclinations,
and abilities align with their capacities,
with no desire to exceed their portion,
they will naturally disregard rare and difficult-to-obtain goods,
for they are already content with what they possess—
who would then be a thief?

Thus, Zhuangzi said:
*"The unvirtuous steal the essence of life and glut themselves on wealth and honor."*

It is also explained:
If the ruler does not esteem pearls, rhinoceros horn, or precious gems,
his governance will be pure and tranquil,
and the people, transformed by this, will naturally abandon greed.
Each knowing their sufficiency,
they will not become thieves.

Do not present what is desirable,
so the heart remains undisturbed.

Since there is no pursuit of the virtuous nor coveting of rare goods,
there is nothing visibly desirable to incite confusion in the heart.

**Commentary (疏):**
To aspire to brilliance is to see what is desirable—
when desire stirs, how can the heart not be disturbed?
Now, if one neither elevates ability nor seeks beyond his portion,
there will be nothing desirable to provoke confusion in the heart.

Thus, the Sage’s governance.

**Commentary (疏):**
This speaks of the Sage’s governance over the realm and self,
establishing it as the foundation of teaching.
What more is there to governance of the realm?
Only governance of the self.

Thus, empty the heart and fill the belly,
cut off desire and forget knowledge in *wuwei*,
and nothing will remain ungoverned.

Empty the heart.
When the heart is not disturbed by what is desirable, it is empty.

**Commentary (疏):**
To labor the mind after external things is to be obscured by worldly affairs,
but to cultivate stillness and preserve purity is to let desires not arise—
when desires do not arise, the heart is empty.
Zhuangzi said: *"An empty room gives birth to white."*—
meaning that when the heart is empty, pure clarity arises naturally.

Thus it is said:
Empty the heart, fill the belly,
let virtue and power internally suffuse—
then there will be no arrogance or contrivance,
just as one who eats until satisfied will stop,
generating no further greed.

**Commentary (疏):**
The belly, when full, does not crave more;
when virtue and power internally suffuse,
no greed arises—
thus it is said, *fill the belly*.
*"Eating until satisfied and stopping"* comes from the *Spring and Autumn Annals*,
where Yan Mo and Ru Kuang advised Duke Wuzi of Wei:
*"Use the belly of a commoner to govern the heart of a noble—
when satisfied, there will be no further greed."*

Weaken the will.
When the heart is empty, the will grows weak.

**Commentary (疏):**
The will is the mind’s affair—
when the mind has something to act upon, it is called will.
To let the mind adhere to gentleness and weakness is to know
that when the heart is empty, the will weakens.

Strengthen the bones.
When the belly is full, the bones grow strong.

**Commentary (疏):**
The bones are the body’s framework.
Since virtue and power internally suffuse,
and there is no greed,
the belly remains full—
when the belly is full, the bones grow strong.

Always let the people be without knowledge and without desire.
Always let them lack the knowledge of contention and esteem,
and the desire for acquisition.

**Commentary (疏):**
The Sage’s teaching of emptying the heart and filling the belly
seeks to make the people naturally free from the knowledge of contention
and the desire for acquisition,
so they may transform on their own.

Let those who know dare not act.
Through tranquil transformation, when knowledge and desire are exhausted,
even those who possess knowledge will not dare to act.

**Commentary (疏):**
Those without knowledge and desire are already tranquil—
thus, those who possess knowledge will gradually be refined by pure transformation,
daring not to act in pursuit of traces or greed,
but instead practicing *wuwei*.

To act in *wuwei* is to govern perfectly.

To act in *wuwei* while letting people return to their nature,
pure transformation will naturally ensue.

**Commentary (疏):**
To act while abiding in *wuwei*—
even if acting, it is still *wuwei*.
Since the pursuit of the virtuous is abandoned,
and rare goods are not sought,
people follow their natural portions,
and things retain their authenticity—
in *wuwei*, what is there to arrogate or contrive?
Though without fame or repute,
people do not recognize it,
yet who can say the pure wind does not prevail?

Du Guangting said:
*"Not esteeming the virtuous prevents contention.*
*Pursuing traces*—this means artificiality.
Once the principle of esteeming the virtuous arises,
artificial men will inevitably appear.
Why? Because the virtuous are difficult to discern.
The cunning feign trustworthiness,
the flatterers feign loyalty—
how easy is it to distinguish them?

The *Classic* says:
*'Wisdom produces great deceit.'*
Thus, when the ruler values wisdom,
the people respond with deceit;
when the ruler values the virtuous,
the people respond with artificiality.
It is better to rectify oneself and lead by example,
governing through *wuwei*,
nurturing with the Great Harmony,
transforming through tranquility—
then worthy ministers will naturally serve their roles.

This is what is meant by *clouds following the dragon, winds following the tiger*.
Clouds follow the dragon and winds follow the tiger—
this is Confucius’ interpretation of the *Book of Changes*’ *Qian* hexagram,
where the fifth line says: *The flying dragon in the sky.*
Since it can broadly influence all things,
water flows to dampness,
fire turns to dryness,
clouds follow the dragon,
winds follow the tiger.
Each follows its kind, responding naturally—
this illustrates the Son of Heaven ascending to the fifth position,
and all under heaven coming to his court.

The Sage acts, and all things behold him—
those rooted in Heaven turn upward,
those rooted in Earth turn downward.
This speaks of water, which is yin—
when flowing on Earth, it seeks dampness.
Fire, which is yang—
when burning wood, it seeks dryness.
Though these two things lack awareness or sentiment,
they are moved by *qi* and respond thus.
Again, the dragon is a water creature,
and clouds are water *qi*—
when the dragon roars, mist rises.
The tiger is a fierce beast,
and wind is a moving force—
when the tiger howls, valley winds arise.
These two things, though possessing awareness and sentiment,
share the same *qi* and kind as those without—
thus they respond in the same way.

「When the Sage descends into the world, the flying dragon soars through Heaven,
and the worthy and virtuous support one another—
all things respond in harmony, thus expanding their influence.

Emperor Yao of the Tang dynasty, surnamed Yiqi and named Fangxun,
was known as Emperor Tao of the Tang clan.

Emperor Shun of the Yu clan,
a descendant of Zhuanyu, grandson of Qiaoniu,
son of Guying, born to Mother Yuleng at Yaochu,
was thus surnamed Yao and named Zhonghua.

The eight **Yuan** and eight **Kai** were his ministers.
In ancient times, the High Xin (尧) clan had eight talented sons:
Bo Feng, Zhong Kan, Shu Xian, Ji Zhong,
Bo Hu, Zhong Xiong, Shu Bao, Ji Li—
loyal, solemn, reverent, and harmonious,
spreading benevolence and grace—
the people of all under Heaven called them the eight **Yuan**.

The High Yang (舜) clan had eight talented sons:
Cang Shu, Tui Gu, Dao Jie, Dai Lin,
Long Jiang, Ting Jian, Zhong Rong, Shu Da—
virtuous and broad-minded, wise and sincere—
the people of all under Heaven called them the eight **Kai**.

These sixteen clans united in their excellence,
and their renown did not fade.
Yet Yao did not trust them,
and instead raised Shun as his minister,
appointed the eight **Yuan** to propagate the Five Teachings to the four quarters,
and assigned the eight **Kai** to govern the **Hou Tu** (后土, the Earthly Realm).

The **Tai** and **Heng** (台衡) were the expectations of the Son of Heaven—
he established the Three Ministers (三公) to symbolize the Three **Tai** (台, celestial palaces).
He did not value rare and difficult treasures,
so the people did not become thieves.

Human life originates from the vital essence of Heaven and Earth,
and those who receive the clear, bright, and pure *qi* become Sages and worthy ones,
while those who receive the turbid, stagnant, and confused *qi* become foolish and lowly.
The Sages and worthy ones possess vast divine intelligence,
while the foolish and dim-witted are clouded in ignorance.
Thus, there are inherent differences in human nature.

Laozi said to Confucius:
*"The Way generates people and all things,
and birds, beasts, insects, and all creatures have their odd and even—
this refers to differing *qi*.
But common people do not know its nature,
only those who grasp Dao and virtue can trace its origin."*

The *Wenzi* (文子) says:
*"Clear *qi* is Heaven, turbid *qi* is Earth,
harmonious *qi* is humanity.
Within harmonious *qi*, there is brightness and darkness—
thus, there are the worthy and the foolish.
If the foolish seek to emulate the worthy, they exceed their nature—
this is called *yue fen* (越分, transgressing one’s limits).
If the dark seek to replace the bright, they make false demands—
this is called *mang qiu* (妄求, presumptuous desire).
This is the act of stealing the essence of life
and greedily coveting wealth and honor—
words from the *Zhuangzi*’s *‘Pianmu’* (骈拇, ‘Extra Thumbs’) chapter."*

Wealth and honor are coveted because they can be seized,
but when there is no higher path to aspire to,
people accept their lot,
acting according to their ability and receiving tasks accordingly—
how much less would they transgress their limits
to greedily steal what is not their due!

A ruler does not value pearls, rhinoceros horns, or rare treasures—
this prevents the people from becoming thieves.
He does not display what is desirable,
so his heart remains undisturbed.
To covet and admire is to envy brilliance.

Human nature is limited,
yet to envy wisdom is to transgress one’s nature—
this is called *desire* (欲).

Again, those who cultivate the Dao,
in their early stages,
though their practice is incomplete,
their refinement not yet mature,
fear what is desirable,
being drawn by the realm of phenomena—
thus, they retreat into mountains and forests,
avoiding the clamor of the world.
But when their hearts are tranquil and their wills steadfast,
the realm cannot entice them—
they move through the day with ease,
never wearying.
This is the saying:
*"Small retreat in the mountains, great retreat in the marketplace."*

Unable to sever desire,
fearing the pull of phenomena,
they hide in mountains and forests to avoid what they see—
until their hearts are purified and their thoughts still,
their minds dwell on the true and genuine,
free from external disturbances,
preserving inner serenity—
even amidst the bustling markets,
name and gain do not touch their hearts;
even amidst the worldly paths,
controversies do not disrupt their intentions.
Mingling with the city,
how does this harm the cultivation of the genuine?

Thus, the Sage’s principle:
*"The True and Perfect Man said to the Yellow Emperor:
‘I have never heard of a man who cultivates his body
yet fails to bring order to his state.’
The body of one man is a microcosm of his state—
the chest and abdomen are like palaces and halls,
the four limbs like boundaries and territories,
the bones and joints like officials.
The spirit is like the ruler,
the blood like the ministers,
and the *qi* like the people.
To govern the body is to govern the state—
loving the people secures the state,
cherishing the *qi* preserves the body.
If the people scatter, the state falls;
if the *qi* is exhausted, life dies.
What has fallen cannot be restored,
what is dead cannot be revived—
thus, the Perfect Man extinguishes breath before it arises,
and treats ailments before they manifest.
*Qi* is difficult to nurture yet easily corrupted,
the people are hard to gather yet easily dispersed—
governance must begin before chaos arises,
not after it has already passed."*

**Reflect upon this!**

**Empty your heart.**
Only when the Dao gathers in emptiness does emptiness embrace the Dao.
When the Dao gathers in the heart,
the spirit plays with transformation,
the heart communicates with Heaven,
and all things spontaneously transform below—
the Sage rests in harmony above.
This is the ultimate principle of governance.

*"The empty room produces whiteness"*—
words from the *Zhuangzi*’s *‘Renjian Shijie’* (人间世, ‘The World of Man’) chapter.
The room is the heart—
to see what is present as if it were absent is to empty the heart.
When the heart is emptied,
pure whiteness naturally arises.
Pure whiteness is the appearance of great clarity and openness.

The *Inner Observation Scripture* (内观经) says:
*"The heart is neither green nor red,
neither white nor yellow,
neither long nor short,
neither round nor square—
it encompasses Heaven and Earth,
yet enters the finest hairs.
Restrain it, and it ceases;
release it, and it runs wild.
Calmness and stillness bring life,
turbulence and agitation bring death.
It illuminates the eight directions,
or it confuses even one corner.
Humanity’s greatest difficulty lies in the heart—
thus, teaching people to cultivate the Dao is to teach them to cultivate the heart.
Teaching people to cultivate the heart is to teach them the Dao.
The heart cannot be stilled,
but through the Dao it is stilled;
the heart cannot be seen,
but through the Dao it is illuminated.
The dual paths of good and evil,
all worldly laws arise from the heart and perish in the heart—
those who practice the Dao still the heart and attain the Dao,
while the common folk indulge the heart and endanger themselves."*

The heart gives rise to chaos, its extinction brings order—
thus the Son of Heaven establishes officials,
clarifies laws and punishments,
sets rewards and calamities,
and hangs omens of fortune and misfortune,
all to guide humanity—
for these are measures against the heart’s unruliness.

The heartless are without commandments,
the steadfast-hearted are without doubt,
the still-hearted act not at all,
the restrained-hearted are not disordered,
the rectified-hearted are not perverse,
the purified-hearted are not defiled,
the empty-hearted are not attached.

To grasp these seven principles,
one may speak of the Dao,
one may speak of cultivating the heart.

Fill the belly.

The heart’s desires are boundless,
the belly’s capacity is sufficient.
The heart is boundless, so empty it.
The belly is sufficient, so fill it.
An empty heart gives rise to no cravings,
a full belly halts greed of its own accord.

Cherish loyalty and sincerity,
embrace simplicity and purity—
thus virtue is complete within.

*The *Chūnqiū* is the name of the annals of Lǔ.
When Yán Mò and Rǔ Kuān remonstrated,
it was in the twenty-eighth year of Duke Zāo of *Chūnqiū*,
when Wèi Xiànzǐ of Jìn, Shū by name,
held office and appointed his son Wù as Great Officer of Gěngyáng—
now Jìnyáng.
In winter, there was a case in Gěngyáng,
and Wù could not decide it,
so he brought the matter before Xiànzǐ.

The plaintiff’s elder, with female musicians as tribute,
intended to give them to Wèi Zǐ.
Wù said to the two ministers Yán Mò and Rǔ Kuān:
*"Our lord is renowned among the thousand lords for his refusal of bribes—
yet to accept tribute from Gěngyáng would be the height of greed.
My lords must remonstrate!"*
Both agreed.

After the court audience, he awaited them in the hall. The tribute was presented, and Wèi Xiànzǐ summoned the two ministers to dine. When the food was served, he sighed three times. After eating, he had them sit.

Wèi Xiànzǐ said, *"I have heard from my elder kinsmen that there is a saying: 'Only when eating does one forget worries.' When my lords placed the food before me, they sighed three times. Why is this?"*

They answered with identical words: *"When others gave the two lesser men wine, they did not eat at night, and when the wine arrived, they feared it might not be enough—thus the first sigh. In the middle of the meal, they reproached themselves, saying, 'Should the General’s food be deemed insufficient?'—thus the second sigh. When the tribute was fully presented, they wished that their own bellies might serve as the virtuous mind of a noble one, and they prayed earnestly for it to cease—thus the third sigh."*

Wèi Xiànzǐ declined the tribute from Gěngyáng.

*Sprinkled* is the word for posthumous title. The *Chūnqiū* records: *"Wù Zǐ, whose given name was Wèi, was posthumously titled Wù."* The two ministers, Yán Mò and Rǔ Kuān, remonstrated with Wù Zǐ, wishing that their own bellies might serve as the virtuous mind of a noble one. The belly is easily filled, yet the mind is hard to satisfy—this was their desire to curb his greed and not accept the tribute from Gěngyáng. Even when lesser men’s bellies are full, they still know to stop; how much more should a noble one’s mind be content!

The *Chūnqiū* praised this act.

The Wèi clan’s rise was due to their accepting remonstrance. Their resolve was weakened.

The *Shī Xù* states: *"What arises in the heart is called resolve."* What the heart gives rise to is resolve; what it acts upon is deed. If the heart is soft and yielding, then there will be no reckless, hasty, or contentious affairs—all will be in harmony.

Harmony in affairs is the foundation of governance. Strengthen their bones.

If their resolve is weakened, then their virtue and gentleness will not be sullied by external temptations. If their bones are strengthened, then their firmness and preparedness will be rooted within. Those who follow the Dao will have sinews and bones that are strong and resilient—no hundred maladies can invade them.

A full belly strengthens the bones; the harmonious *qi* is abundant. In governing the realm, clear administration brings peace to the people, and frugal expenditures ensure their strength is plentiful.

Peaceful people are those whose resolve is weakened. Abundant strength is those whose bones are strengthened. Always let the people be without knowledge or desire.

Greed and avarice give rise to strife; knowledge sparks action.

The strife and desires being absent, clarity and tranquility will naturally manifest. Let those who possess knowledge dare not act.

When the lower follows the upper, it is like the wind bending the grass—pure and harmonious, universally permeating, all returning to the state of *non-action*. To act in *non-action* is to have nothing left ungoverned.

The principle of *non-action* is vast indeed! *Non-action* does not mean withdrawing so that nothing comes, or pushing so that nothing stays, or forcing so that there is no response, or moving so that nothing shifts, or being rigid and stagnant so that nothing flows, or being coiled and damp so that nothing scatters.

It means that private desires do not intrude upon the public Dao, that appetites do not pervert proper methods. To act in accordance with principle, to establish merit through resources, to complete deeds without self-praise, to achieve feats without claiming renown—this is *non-action*.

If water is used with a boat, sand with a cart, mud with a sled, and mountains with a wheelbarrow, if one cultivates summer fields and winter ponds, follows elevation for tillage and depression for reservoirs, then this is not what I call *action*—it is *non-action*.

The *non-action* of the Sage follows naturally, relies upon the people, demands without toil, plans without error, acts without omission. Their words are refined as writings, their deeds as models, their advancement and retreat suit the times, their movement and stillness follow principle. They neither favor beauty nor detest ugliness, nor do their rewards and punishments stem from personal likes or dislikes. Each has their own appointed name, each fulfills their own proper function. Matters arise from nature itself, without deviation from the self. They conform to Heaven’s timing, adapt to Earth’s traits, and follow humanity’s inclinations.

Thus, ministers gather like spokes to a wheel, the worthy and unworthy each employing their talents. The ruler gains means to govern his ministers, the ministers gain means to serve their ruler—this is the Dao of *non-action* in governing the realm.

The unheard and unscented is the *Shijing* [Book of Songs]—[大雅] [Great Odes]—[文王篇] [Wenwang’s Chapter]. It speaks of Heaven’s Dao being difficult to know: the ears do not hear its sounds, the nose does not perceive its fragrances. If one follows the rituals of Wenwang, then the world will naturally trust and comply.

The unrecognized and unknown is the *Shijing*—[大雅] [Great Odes]—[皇矣篇] [Huangyi’s Chapter]. It speaks of those who do not acknowledge the past nor comprehend the present, yet act in accordance with Heaven’s laws.

This says that Heaven’s Dao values sincerity, esteems nature’s essence, and does not exalt the worthy nor hold wealth in high regard—this aligns with it.

The Song emperor Daozong said: *"Not exalting the worthy leads to the people not becoming thieves."* Exalting the worthy brings many who know, to the point where the world is greatly alarmed, and Confucianists and Mohists all rise up. Valuing wealth brings many desires, to the point where daylight thefts occur, and robbers lurk even at midday.

Not exalting the worthy means the people each settle into their own appointed nature and fate, without striving to surpass others, hence they do not contend.

Not valuing wealth means the people each find contentment in their own natural inclinations and fates, without coveting what they do not possess, hence they do not become thieves.

Zhuangzi said: *"Trim the deeds of the Ru historians, and muzzle the mouths of Yang and Mo."*

The virtue/power of the world thus begins to return to its original unity.

*The Traveling Wolf* says: *"Do not exalt the strange and devalue the useful; only then will the people be content. Do not show them what is desirable, lest their hearts be disordered."*

When people have desires, they will even contest their very nature and fate—plundering, deceiving, and committing every outrage. Boyi, seeing the allure of fame, starved to death beneath Chief Yang’s hill; Zhi, seeing the lure of profit, met his end on Dongling’s heights. Their passions burned like wildfire, their coldness froze like ice, and so their hearts were shattered, reckless, and uncontrollable.

Yet the Sage does not pursue profit, does not shun harm, does not rejoice in longevity, nor lament early death. He does not prize advancement nor despise obscurity. Then what is there to desire? When desires do not arise, my heart is serene. When stirred, it responds; when still, it is unobstructed. In motion, it does not chase; at rest, it does not resist. What can disturb it?

Confucius was forty and free from doubt; Mencius, forty and no longer troubled in heart—both had attained this.

Thus, the Sage’s governance aims to keep the people in a state of *wu zhi* (無知) and *wu yu* (無欲). The valley is empty and thus responsive; the mirror is empty and thus reflective. The gourd is empty and thus can receive; the ear is empty and thus can hear; the eye is empty and thus can see; the nose is empty and thus can smell. If filled, they become obstructed.

The Sage, when compelled to govern the world, treats all with equal benevolence, strengthens the near while uplifting the distant, follows what is natural, and lets things unfold of their own accord—what need for scheming? Yao’s elevation of Shun and execution of Gun nearly achieved this.

When the heart is empty, it listens impartially and observes without bias, free from likes and dislikes. When the belly is full, the mind is content and at ease, free from greed. Why exalt the worthy or blame the unworthy?

The Sage nourishes the belly, not the eyes. The belly, unselective, can contain all. The will is the mind’s knowledge; the bones are the body’s foundation. A strong will may lead one to relentlessly pursue fame or wealth, to boast of one’s abilities or flaunt one’s achievements—ever farther from the Mysterious Dao. Weak bones cause erratic movement, clashing with others until one is exhausted and cannot return.

The Sage’s will is ever humble, yet others exalt him. Ever yielding, yet others honor him first. Knowing strength, he embraces weakness; knowing glory, he embraces disgrace. This is called weakening the will to still it—nothing can then displace it. Firmly grasping it, nothing can overturn it. The unbroken essence, like that of Guangchengzi, lived twelve hundred years without decay—this is called strengthening the bones.

Zhuangzi said: *"In harmony with the unknowing, virtue does not depart. In harmony with desirelessness, this is called pristine simplicity. Pristine simplicity, and the people’s nature is preserved."*

The Sage’s governance seeks only to let the people preserve their nature. Excessive knowledge disrupts the appointed nature and fate; excessive desire drowns their natural inclinations. This is called governance, yet what chaos is greater?

Thus it is said: *"Keep the people in a state of wu zhi and wu yu, so that the learned dare not act, the eloquent dare not speak, the brave dare not display their strength, the capable dare not boast of their talents, the clever dare not scheme, and those who pride themselves on cleverness and cunning dare not multiply laws to exploit the people."* The Sage prohibits and stops all this—this is called *"the learned dare not act."*

When the Nine Virtues are fully cultivated and the talented are in their proper offices, is this not because knowledge is not prized? Simply executing the ruler’s commands and delivering them to the people—then there is nothing that cannot be governed.

The Sage’s governance is not about abandoning people and things, suddenly standing alone in a realm of non-action. It is about acting from non-action.

The transformations of all things occur in the realm of the manifest. The Sage embodies the Dao, standing above all things, unifying their completion, and ordering them. Things arise; follow them to observe their return. Things are born; guide them to their fulfillment. How could there be anything ungoverned?

When governance is supreme, the sun, moon, and stars follow their courses. When governance is supreme below, birds, beasts, grasses, and trees each fulfill their nature.

Wang Anshi said: *"Not exalting the worthy prevents contention among the people."* Discussing what is meant by *"not exalting the worthy"*:

The Sage’s heart has never sought to subdue the world through the worthy, yet the world submits to him—never without the worthy. If the people of the world are made to serve the world’s affairs, and the worthy are not exalted, then what reliance is there for governance?

The people, even in infancy, possess a natural inclination toward goodness. If they are not taught by the worthy, they cannot fully illuminate the world’s goodness. Once goodness is clear within oneself, how could the worthy not be revered? Thus, even if the laws and institutions remain, they are sufficient to restrain later chaos. If the worthy are exalted throughout the world, how could the people contend?

His intent is to make all under heaven clearly understand goodness, yet he does not advocate exalting the worthy. Still, the world is not so uniformly equal, and if the laws of exalting the worthy are abandoned, people may not necessarily understand goodness. Alas, the worthy cannot alone remedy the flaws of the unworthy—who knows the worthy who can make all under heaven sincerely and willingly submit?

Qi Huan Gong asked Guan Zhong: *"If I, alas, reach a point of no return, to whom should I entrust the state?"* Qi Huan Gong favored Yi Ya, but Guan Zhong said that Yi Ya, whom he did not often consult, was not as loyal as Xi Peng. If one elevates those who forget their superiors and rebel below, what greater harm from exalting the worthy could there be?

Some may say: *"Is this not what he means? He merely argues against its drawbacks."*

The Sage above does not prize rare and hard-to-obtain goods to the point of disturbing the heart. To exalt the worthy sparks contention; rare goods provoke theft. Both arise from what the heart desires. Thus, the Sage in governance does not command people to exalt the worthy or prize rare goods. If these two things are unseen, then the heart alone may remain undisturbed.

To exalt the worthy is good, but to prize rare goods invites theft—evil. Why reject both? For good and evil are opposites. Where there is good, there is also its opposite; both must be made to vanish.

There are two kinds of desire in the world: the desirable desire and the undesirable desire. As Mencius says, the desirable is called good—yet the eye’s delight in color, the ear’s in sound, the nose’s in scent—these are undesirable desires.

*The Explanation of Characters* states: *"谷 (gǔ) can receive; 欠 (qiàn) signifies lack."* That which can receive and endure, yet is not full—this is desire. Laozi says: *"Do not exalt the worthy, lest the people contend. Do not prize rare goods, lest the people steal. Do not display the desirable, lest the heart be disturbed."* These are Laozi’s one-sided, unbalanced words.

The ancient kings neither exalted the worthy nor despised it; neither prized rare goods nor rejected them; neither displayed the desirable nor concealed it. Yet Laozi’s words speak of the formless Dao: not exalting the worthy prevents burdening oneself with goodness; not prizing rare goods prevents burdening oneself with profit. Only thus can one remain undisturbed by the desirable.

Mencius said: *"The desirable is called good."* When goodness accumulates and fills to the divine, reaching this divine state, one no longer sees the desirable. Thus, the Sage’s governance strengthens the bones.

To empty the heart is to clarify that the worthy are not exalted; to fill the belly is to show that rare goods are not prized; to strengthen the bones is to demonstrate that the desirable is unseen.

The hearts of people differ in worthiness and unworthiness. If one exalts worthiness and unworthiness, contention arises. Thus, emptying the heart erases the distinction between worthy and unworthy, and so the worthy are not exalted. The belly, which can receive, if filled, makes rare goods mere trifles of food, sound, and color. All that is desirable becomes desire itself. Weakening the will prevents seeking; strengthening the bones ensures stability. Only by having no desires does one not see the desirable, yet remain steadfast. To have no desires yet stand firm—this is what the noble value.

If one constantly makes the people ignorant and desireless, empties their hearts, weakens their wills, and fills their bellies while strengthening their bones, the people will have no knowledge or desires. Even the wise will dare not act. If all the people are without knowledge or desire, even the wise among them will not dare to act. To act without action is to govern without fail. To act yet do nothing, to do nothing yet achieve all—this is the Sage’s way of *wuwei*, and thus nothing remains ungoverned.

Su Yingbin said: *"Not exalting the worthy prevents contention; strengthening the bones is the end."* If the worthy are exalted, the people will shame themselves for not measuring up and thus contend. If rare goods are prized, the people will suffer from lack and thus steal. If the desirable is displayed, the people will suffer from not obtaining it and thus rebel. Yet though the world knows these three as afflictions, if one seeks to abolish them outright, it is delusion.

The Sage does not act thus. Though the worthy are used, they are not exalted; though rare goods exist, they are not prized; though desirable things are present, they are not displayed. Thus, the worthy are employed yet the people do not contend; rare goods and desirable matters are before them, yet theft and chaos do not arise. Is this not the result of emptying the heart yet not filling the belly, weakening the will yet not harming the bones?

Now, if one were to exalt and display the worthy, treasure and prize goods, and flaunt the desirable, then both heart and belly would be filled. If one were to abolish them outright, then will and bones would weaken. When heart and belly are full, the people contend. When will and bones are weak, there is no foundation to stand upon.

If one constantly makes the people ignorant and desireless to the point where they dare not act, and does not flaunt these three things, then the people will know nothing to covet, their desires will be tranquil, and even the clever will have no schemes.
