entering through the mouth, stored in the stomach.
The five natures, coarse and debased,
become the form, flesh, bones, blood, vessels, and six emotions.
Its **ghost** is called the **pò**.
The **pò** is feminine, governing entry and exit through the mouth,
harmonizing with Heaven and Earth—
thus, it is called **Female**.

The **gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **root of Heaven and Earth**.
*Root* means **origin**—
the nose and mouth’s gate
is where Heaven and Earth’s primal **qi** circulates.

Endlessly preserved—
the inhalations, exhalations, and breathing
should be subtly endless,
as if preserved yet nonexistent.
Its use requires no labor—
breathing should always be relaxed,
never hasty or strained.

Master Wáng Fǔsì said:
**The Valley Spirit does not die**—
the **Valley** is the central void, without grain,
without form or shadow,
without resistance or obstruction,
dwelling low yet unmoving,
guarding stillness without decay.
The **Valley** accomplishes its purpose unseen—
this is the utmost substance.
Dwelling low yet unnamed,
it is called the **root of Heaven and Earth**.

Endlessly preserved,
its use requires no labor.
The **gate** is where the Mysterious Female originates.
Tracing its origin to its extreme,
it shares the same body—
thus, it is called the **root of Heaven and Earth**.

If one speaks of its preservation,
its form is unseen.
If one speaks of its absence,
all things arise from it—
thus, it is endlessly preserved.
Without things, nothing is formed;
used yet unlabored—
hence, **"its use requires no labor."**

Emperor Xuānzōng said:
**The Valley Spirit does not die.**
*Valley* is the empty yet responsive.
*Spirit* is the wondrous yet unfathomable.
*Death* means **rest**.
The Valley’s response to sound
is unknown in its mechanism—
when stimulated, it responds like a spirit.
The spirit’s response never rests.
To illuminate the utmost Dao—
emptiness generating things,
wondrous operation beyond words—
thus, the **Valley Spirit** is used as an analogy.

This is called the **Mysterious Female**.
**Mysterious** means **deep**.
**Female** means **mother**.
The Valley Spirit’s response is profound, subtle, and inexhaustible,
capable of mothering all things—
thus, it is named the **Mysterious Female** to illuminate the great Dao’s nurturing power.

**Commentary:**
The **Valley Spirit** clarifies the spirit’s response to sound,
like the Dao’s response to things—
stimulated, it responds like a spirit.
*Spirit* is named for the unfathomable;
*death* is defined by rest.
The unfathomable response never rests—
thus, **"The Valley Spirit does not die."**

**Mysterious** means **deep**.
**Female** means **mother**.
The Valley Spirit’s deep and subtle operation is difficult to explain,
yet all things flourish through its nourishment—
thus, it is called the **Mysterious Female**.
The **gate of the Mysterious Female**—
this is called the **root of Heaven and Earth**.
The deep, subtle, and maternal operation
gives birth to all things—
thus, it is called the **gate**.
Heaven and Earth, having form,
rely on this primal endowment as their foundation.

**Commentary:**
The Mysterious Female’s operation—
when stimulated, it responds, and things emerge—
thus, it is called the **gate**.
Heaven and Earth are the greatest of formed things—
without the Mysterious Female’s operation,
they would disperse and exhaust.
Thus, they rely on this primal endowment as their foundation—
hence, **"this is called the root of Heaven and Earth."**
*Root* means **foundation**.
Endlessly preserved,
its use requires no labor—
the Mysterious Female’s operation is subtly endless,
its application effortless, requiring no exertion.

Master Dù Guāngtíng said:
**The Valley Spirit does not die**—
the meaning of the **Valley Spirit** is **echoing response and nourishing the spirit**,
divided into three distinctions.

The First speaks of the Valley’s embrace of emptiness—
when there is sound, it responds.
The Dao’s essence is formless—
cultivate it, and you attain it.

The Second speaks of the spirit’s formlessness—
when there is invocation, it attends.
The Dao’s manifestation is without image—
cultivate it, and it endures forever.

The Third speaks of the echo in the Valley—
without sound, it does not respond.
The Dao resides in the body—
without cultivation, it does not manifest.

"Not dying" does not mean the death of life and death,
but the death of rest.
If one says it is the cultivation of the body’s dissolution,
then it is the death of life and death.

The first is: nourishing the spirit brings eternal life and non-death,
the second is: echoing response without cessation—
this is the death of rest.

The Mysterious (玄) is Heaven—
in humans, it is the nose.
The Female (牝) is Earth—
in humans, it is the mouth.

The original and harmonious *qi*, the enlightened and luminous spirit,
within the body, entering and exiting through nose and mouth,
breathing in response to nourish the body—
thus, it is called the Valley Spirit.

Again, Heaven’s five *qi* enter through the nose,
their spirit is called *hun*—
ascending, it communicates with Heaven.
Earth’s five flavors enter through the mouth,
their spirit is called *pò*—
descending, it communicates with Earth.

Speaking of nourishing *qi* makes one a companion of Heaven—
practiced endlessly, one may attain eternal life,
refining *yin* with *yang*.

Eating flavors makes one a companion of Earth—
practiced endlessly, it breeds illness and leads to death,
refining *yang* with *yin*.

Master Laozi commands nourishing the spirit and treasuring the form,
abstaining from grains and eating *qi*—
this is the Dao of non-death,
hence, **"the Mysterious Female’s gate, the root of Heaven and Earth."**

The Mysterious Female’s gate—
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.

It is not only that humans rely on the Mysterious Female’s circulation of *qi*
to attain eternal life.
Heaven and Earth, vast as they are,
also require the Dao’s *qi* to circulate and nourish them,
only then can they remain pure and tranquil without change.

As the lower scripture says:
*"Heaven, without purity, would fear cleaving,*
*Earth, without tranquility, would fear dispersing.*
Heaven and Earth losing the Dao
still face the perils of collapse and dissipation—
how much more so for the human body,
if it does not uphold the central and preserve the One!"

Endlessly preserved,
its use requires no labor—
Heaven and Earth rely on *qi* naturally,
thus enduring forever.
Human breathing through nose and mouth
should be endlessly subtle and mysterious—
as if existing yet not existing,
not to be forced with haste or exhaustion.

The Dao of governing the realm,
when laws are enacted,
should balance severity with gentleness,
gentleness with severity—
for if laws are too lenient, the people grow slack,
if too harsh, the people are ruined.
If one governs the world with the Dao of purity and tranquility,
and the people are spared laborious exertion,
then the common folk will be devoted,
their blessings enduring and prolonged,
endlessly preserved like melons, gourds, and *gu* plants—
thus, it is said: *"Endlessly preserved, its use requires no labor."*

Master Song Daojun said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die."*
What has form has flourishing and decline,
what has measure has completion and ruin.
Form and measure together bring life and death—
this is the principle of all things.
The Valley responds to all things yet remains ever empty,
the spirit transcends all things yet remains ever still.
Within the eternal truth,
it is one with the Dao,
not clinging to form,
not falling into measure.
Generating life without end,
like the sun and moon—
eternally unceasing,
like the Great Bear—
eternally unerring.
Thus, it is said: *"It does not die."*
This is called the Mysterious Female.

All things receive their mandate from the formless,
yet take shape in the formed.
The Valley’s operation is without likeness,
the spirit’s essence is without boundary—
this is where all things receive their mandate.
The Mysterious is Heaven’s hue,
the Female is Earth’s kind—
this is where all things take shape.
The Valley Spirit illustrates the eternal Dao,
the Mysterious Female reveals the marvel of creation.
The Mysterious Female’s gate—
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.

Zhuangzi said:
*"All things have their source in birth, yet no one sees their root;
they emerge, yet no one sees their gate.
Only the sage sees them."*
Thus, it is said here:
*"The Mysterious Female’s gate—
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth."*
Heaven and Earth are the above and below of all things.
Things and Heaven and Earth originally have no sequence—
to clarify the great Dao’s order,
Heaven and Earth come first, then all things.
Yet what Heaven and Earth emerge from is the Mysterious Female.
Who before Heaven and Earth could see it?
Endlessly preserved,
its use requires no labor—
from its own root, its own foundation,
eternally established since antiquity,
like fire’s transmission—
one does not know when it will end.
This is called *"endlessly preserved."*
Vastly created by Heaven,
a single *qi* moving on its own,
suddenly transforming itself,
entrusting all forms to proliferate—
*Li* is easily understood,
*Kun* is simply capable,
not achieved by force—
what labor is there?

Master Wang Anshi said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Female."*
The Valley is able to be empty,
able to contain,
able to be full,
able to respond.
With these four virtues,
unknown in their operation,
thus it is called *spirit*.
With its spirit, it does not die—
if it dies, it does not generate,
not generating, yet able to generate,
generating yet unseen in its progress.
The Female takes the meaning of generating things,
generating things yet unseen in its actions—
thus it is called Mysterious.
*The Classic of Changes* says:
*"The Great Polarity generates the Two Principles—
this too is the Mysterious Female."*
The Mysterious Female’s gate—
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
Its gate is the origin from which Heaven and Earth are born.
Speaking of it as existing is like saying it exists—
endlessly preserved,
its use requires no labor.
"Endlessly" refers to distant yet unbroken speech.
Though Heaven’s Dao is endlessly preserved,
the sage employs it without exertion,
all arising naturally.
Truly, the sage uses the formless to govern the world’s forms,
using surplus to supplement the world’s deficiencies.

Master Su Yingbin said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Female."*
The Valley, though empty, still has form and outline,
the spirit is empty and formless.
Empty and formless—
how could there be birth?
How could there be death?
Even calling it the Valley Spirit speaks of its virtue—

This is called the Mysterious Female, speaking of its function.
The Mysterious Female gives birth to all things,
yet it is called Mysterious—
for one sees its birth but not the means by which it births.

The gate of the Mysterious Female,
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
The gate of the Mysterious Female,
speaking of all things arising from it.
The root of Heaven and Earth,
speaking of Heaven and Earth arising from it.

Endlessly preserved, yet used without labor.
"Endlessly" refers to subtlety without cessation;
"as if it exists" refers to existence without visibility.
If one can thus, though used all day,
there is no exhaustion.

Master Lü Jìfǔ said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Female."*
The Valley is the form that can be seen,
yet because it attains Oneness,
it is empty yet able to fill.
The Spirit is formless,
yet because it attains Oneness,
it is tranquil yet able to respond with vitality.
If a person can guard the Center and attain Oneness,
then the form that can be seen—
the body—
can be made empty like the Valley,
and the formless heart
can be made tranquil like the Spirit,
then the form and formless are united without death.

The ancients said:
*"The body unites with the heart,
the heart unites with the qi,
the qi unites with the Spirit,
the Spirit unites with the Formless—
this is their teaching."*
If united, there is no death;
if no death, then no birth;
if no birth yet able to give birth,
this is called the Mysterious Female.

The Formless refers to the union of having and not having;
The Female refers to the ability to give birth endlessly.
The gate of the Mysterious Female,
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
The Dao’s birth of Heaven and Earth
comes from this alone—
thus it is said as such.

Endlessly preserved, yet used without labor.
Is it said to be lost?
Then it is endlessly preserved yet never ceases.
Is it said to exist?
Then how could one see its existence?
As if it exists—
if it is lost yet not ceasing,
if it exists yet not visibly so,
then my use of it
holds no concern for existence or loss—
it is simply applied without reflection.
Where is there labor?

Master Lù Nóngshī said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Female."*
The one who gives birth endlessly does not generate;
the one who kills life does not die.
The Valley Spirit,
Formless yet containing and responding.
The Mysterious Female,
Mysterious yet embodying both female and male.
Thus it is said: The Valley Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Female.

The gate of the Mysterious Female,
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
The Mysterious Female,
this is the birth of Heaven and Earth.
The so-called gate of the Mysterious Female,
its offspring arise from it yet cannot be seen—
thus it is said.

Hence, Zhuangzi said:
*"Though there be birth, one cannot see its gate—
this is what is meant."*

Endlessly preserved, yet used without labor.
It seems to exist yet also seems not to exist,
it seems to be preserved yet also seems not to be preserved—
its operation never ceases,
its use never exerts itself,
thus it is said: Endlessly preserved, yet used without labor.

The *Yijing* says: *"Endless coming and going is called Communion"*;
Zhuangzi says: *"Continuously thus without pause is called Fate"*;
and Laozi says: *"The Spirit’s vitality, if not ceaseless, would fear exhaustion."*

Truly, endless coming and going without pause or exhaustion,
this is the Spirit alone—
thus it is called "endlessly preserved."

The Valley Spirit speaks of its function,
the Mysterious Female speaks of its essence.

Master Wáng Yuànzé said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Female."*
The Valley responds yet never exhausts,
the Spirit transforms yet cannot be measured—
all things receive their mandate from it,
yet it never generates, never dies—
this is the Valley Spirit.
Speaking of the Spirit reaches its peak,
yet adding "Valley" refers to its ability to be empty and full,
and yet to contain and respond—
because it is active yet never worn out,
it is simply called "does not die."

The Valley Spirit receives the mandate while the Mysterious Female embodies form—
it itself becomes yin and yang to complete Heaven and Earth,
yet originally it is one thing.
It begins from its reception of the mandate,
thus called the Valley Spirit.
From its embodiment of form,
thus called the Mysterious Female.

The gate of the Mysterious Female,
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
The Mysterious Female,
its essence is yin yet unified—
within its essence, there are yin and yang called its gate,
different from a door.
All things arise from this gate yet cannot be seen,
thus called the gate of the Mysterious Female.

Endlessly preserved, yet used without labor.
"Endlessly" refers to the Valley drawing and not ceasing—
this is called the Spirit.
The Mysterious Female gives birth endlessly yet is neither fixed as having nor not having—
its use without labor is because movement brings forth more,
where is there labor?

Master Liú Zhòngpíng said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die, to its use without labor."*
The Valley is empty yet able to contain and respond.
The Formless is the gate of the Mysterious.
The Female is gentle, tranquil, and profound,
having receptivity without depletion,
having acceptance without emission.
The Valley and the Spirit never generate,
never die,
yet it is said alone: "The Valley Spirit does not die"—
for if it does not die, then it does not generate,
this is clear.

Endlessly preserved, yet used without labor.
It is said: "Its use is as if it exists."
Its use without labor is the use of non-use.

Master Liú Jùjì said:
*"The Valley Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Female."*
The Spirit as Spirit,
its emptiness is unyielding,
its response is inexhaustible,
yet no trace can be seen—
thus the Valley is used as a symbol,
and it is called the Valley Spirit,
because the Valley is empty yet responds.

Truly, if there is birth, then there is no one who does not die,
yet only the one who does not die can give birth—
giving birth yet never dying,
then it can give birth endlessly.
This is called the constant state of no desire.
No death is called the Spirit.
Giving birth endlessly is called the Female,
its essence is one.
Thus it is called the Mysterious Female.

The Female is the Mother.
Adding the Formless makes it the Dao—
like *Formless Communion*, *Formless Oneness*, or *Formless Virtue*.

The gate of the Mysterious Female,
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
The Mysterious Female,
its birth is its homeland—
like a gate.
Heaven and Earth flow in form,
originating from the Mysterious Female—
like a root.

Only the constant state of no desire
can give birth yet not die,
thus called the Formless Spirit.
If there is birth, there is a Mother,
thus the Spirit is called the Mysterious Female.

Once born, it takes form,
thus called the Mysterious Female as the root of Heaven and Earth.

The Formless is the Dao—
the Dao is Heaven and Earth.

Continuous yet as if existing,
using it without effort.

Continuous—
this describes unending birth.
Unending birth,
its thread of life seems to exist,
yet in truth, it does not truly exist.

*"As if"*—
this is not a proper affirmation of its existence,
like the silkworm becoming its cocoon,
or the spider weaving its web—
separating them is endless,
yet seeking them is fruitless.

Using it without exertion—
this refers to the Spirit’s use,
not the human’s use.
Its reason for not laboring:
emptiness and responsiveness.

Earlier, it was specifically said that responsiveness exists,
so how could there not be exertion?

The previous chapter spoke of the analogy of the *túshuò* [鐙鈐, stirrup-spring],
thus next comes *Gu-Shen* [谷神, Grain-Spirit].

Though this chapter speaks of the Dao’s ultimate principle,
the Spirit’s cultivation for the body is no different.

For when the essence is complete, the *qi* is complete,
when the *qi* is complete, the Spirit is complete,
and when the Spirit is complete,
it neither dies nor is born.

Liu Ji [刘骥] said:
*"Gu-Shen* does not die—
the Dao descends as *qi*,
*qi* settles as the embryo,
the embryo condenses as the Spirit,
and the Spirit ascends daily as the *Xian* [仙, Immortal]—
thus the Dao is the method of cultivating life."

From Formless to Form,
Form is the *qi*-Mother.

The body is the Spirit’s dwelling,
nurturing the body preserves the Spirit.

*Qi* is the Spirit’s Mother,
having *qi* sustains the child.

Thus the term *Qi-Mother*—
this is the true foundation of longevity.

The Classic says: *"Gu-Shen* does not die,
this is called the Mysterious Female."

The Mysterious Female—
this is *Gu-Shen* itself.

*Gu-Shen* draws in *qi*,
which descends to the Mysterious Female.
Examining its origin,
the Mysterious Female precedes *Gu-Shen*,
then *Gu-Shen* follows.

For human life,
from *Ren* [壬] to *Gui* [癸],
the two kidneys mark its beginning and end.

Yet in its function,
*Gu-Shen* precedes the Mysterious Female—
for human breath originates from the two nostrils,
while the *Dan-Tian* [丹田] receives it.

The *qi*, drawn continuously by *Gu-Shen*,
never fully dissipates,
its use lies in the subtlest realm.

When sustained long,
the *qi* rests in the Mysterious Female,
no longer drawn from *Gu-Shen*—
this is *Tái-Xī* [胎息, Embryonic Breath].

The *qi* in the Mysterious Female,
like a child in the womb,
requires no external breathing—
breathing arises from within.

Thus its method begins with *continuous yet as if existing*,
and ends with *breathing not external*—
this is the *Tái-Xian* [胎仙, Embryonic Immortality].

Some say the nostrils are the Mysterious,
the mouth is the Female—
nose inhales the pure,
mouth exhales the impure.

Others say: *"Closing the Earth-House [地户] reveals its presence in the nostrils,
not in the mouth."*

Again: *"The mouth and nostrils are not the Mysterious Female,
for the Mysterious Female lies in the lower field [下田]."*

Indeed, it is not spoken of through its gates of entry and exit,
but divided by force alone.

*Gu-Shen* is also called *Shen-Lú* [神庐, Spirit-Dwelling],
the Mysterious Female is also called *Dan-Tian* [丹田].

The *Huangting* [《黄庭》] says:
*"Breathing enters the Spirit-Dwelling through the field."*

The Classic says: *"Gu-Shen* does not die,
this is called the Mysterious Female."

The gate of the Mysterious Female—
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.

The *Du-Ren Jing* [《度人经》] says:
*"Opening the Three Brightnesses [三景],
this is called the Heavenly Root."*

The Three Brightnesses—
these are the *Xuan-Yuan* [玄元, Dark Primordial] *Shi-Qi* [始气, Originating *Qi*].

This is called *Qi-Mother*—
later giving birth to Heaven and Earth,
arranged as the Three Celestial Marks [三辰],
also called Three Brightnesses,
due to their inner and outer nature.

The Mysterious Female is the inner *Gu-Shen*.

The *Yu* [御] commentary says:
*"Grain responds to all movement while remaining ever empty,
the Spirit marvels at all things while remaining ever still.
This is akin to earlier words on the *túshuò* [鐙鈐],
which stays empty to await the *qi*—
all such analogies illustrate the Dao’s grand essence."*

Its foundation is that *Gu* [谷] contains the Spirit—
this is *emptiness* containing the Spirit,
achieved through nurturing stillness,
not like the emptiness of a hollow grain.

The *Huangting* [《黄庭》] says:
*"Within emptiness, serene and tranquil—
the Spirit arises naturally."*

For the nature is the heart’s function,
the heart is the nature’s Spirit.

Movement lies in the *ji* [机, mechanism],
stillness is held by the *qi*.

The *Xi-Yi* [希夷, Rare and Exalted] symbol—
this is the Dao.

The Dao’s essence—
this is the *one* *qi* of Formless and Emptiness.

The *one* *qi*’s function—
this is nature.

Nature—
this is *Gu-Shen*.

The *one* *qi* at rest—
this is nature.

When nature is still, all transformations are at peace.

The *one* *qi* in motion—
this is emotion.

When nature moves, all transformations arise.
The Sage preserves the Original Spirit in the Celestial *Gu* [谷].

The Celestial *Gu*—
this is the space between emptiness and void,
emptiness and void—
the realm of Formless and Emptiness.

Pure *qi* and pure nature—
the root of all transformations.

The *Zheng Yuan Jun* [正元君, Upright Primordial Lord] speaks in terms of palaces:
the *Gu* is called the Celestial *Gu*.
The Celestial *Gu*—
this is the *Niwan Palace* [泥丸宫].

The *Niwan Palace*—
this is the chamber of Formless and Emptiness.

When a person preserves the Spirit,
the Five *Qi* naturally come to pay homage,
descending through the *Xuanpin* [玄牝, Mysterious Female].

The *Xuanpin*—
this is the path of Heaven and Earth’s ascent and descent.

Thus observed,
one knows that the *one qi* flows upward and downward:
in the Celestial *Gu*, it becomes *jinjing* [金精, Essence of Metal];
in the *Xuanpin*, it becomes *yuye* [玉液, Jade Nectar].

It is also said:
When the *Xuanpin* is firmly established at a hundred breaths,
its *qi* passes through the *Lingguan* [灵关, Spirit Pass],
stirring the *Tianguan* [天门, Heavenly Gate] above,
and descending through the *Dihu* [地户, Earthly Portal] below—
this may be called the *Miaodao* [妙道, Marvelous Way].

The *Lingshu* [《灵枢》] states:
*The Mysterious Female connects above to the Celestial Gu,*
*and descends below to the Earthly Portal.*

From cultivating *qi* to dwelling in *qi*,
when more is taken in than expelled,
this appears in the *Zhen* [☳] hexagram;
when more is expelled than taken in,
this appears in the *Li* [☲] hexagram.
At sunset, it is gathered—
refined by the *Qian* [☰] hexagram.

This is the daily method of scholars for gathering and taking.

When *qi* is held without entering or exiting,
this is called *taixi* [胎息, Womb-Breathing].
One ascent, one descent—
this becomes the *Longhu* [龙虎, Dragon-Tiger].

This is another method of refining the elixir.

*Qi* is one in essence,
yet its methods differ—
thus, the affairs of immortals and transcendent beings
cannot be achieved by a single approach.

The *Taixi* theory relies on dwelling in *qi*;
when the Spirit is present, it becomes the way of immortals and transcendent beings—
this can be verified.

**Second Section: Clarifying the Mysterious Female**

The *Xuanpin* is spoken of:
The nose has two nostrils,
which descend to the kidneys.
The kidneys have two gates—
*Xuan* [玄, Mysterious] is yang,
*Pin* [牝, Female] is yin.
The two kidneys are likewise.

Daily practice lies in alternating left and right.

Next, it returns to the original flow.
The gate of the *Xuanpin*—
this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.

The *Yu Zhu* [御注, Imperial Annotation] cites the *Zhuangzi* [《庄子》]:
*"All things have their source of life, yet no one sees its root;
they have their place of emergence, yet no one sees its gate—
only the Sage can perceive this."*

This is profound speech.

The Dao in relation to Heaven and Earth,
all things in relation to *Kan* [☵] and *Li* [☲]—
life arises on its own, transformations unfold on their own,
nature is its own nature, fate is its own fate.
Who is the root? Who is the gate?
Speaking in terms of *ziran* [自然, Self-So],
one does not know why it is so.
Speaking in terms of the True Sovereign,
is there truly no gate, no root?
Yet only the Sage can perceive this.

Those who do not see cannot enter through the gate,
those without a gate cannot recognize the root of life.
This matter lies in the *tianji* [天机, Heavenly Mechanism]—
who else but the Sage can partake in this?

Thus it is said:
Knowing and refining it makes one a Sage.

The *Xuan* [玄] is the *one*;
the *Pin* [牝] is the *mother*.
The *one* arises from emptiness,
the *mother* unites through movement.
Seeking yin is yang,
receiving yang is the mother.
The *one* does not await birth,
yet birth arises on its own.
The mother does not await union,
yet emotion is naturally stirred.

The *Yijing* [《易》] says:
*"Water flows to dampness,
fire turns toward dryness,
clouds follow the dragon,
wind follows the tiger."*
This is an inevitable principle.

Thus, when *Kan* [☵] and *Li* [☲] unite at *hai* [亥, 11 PM],
one *yang* begins at *ren* [壬] in the northwest.

*Ren* is yang-water,
uniting with *ding* [丁]’s yin-fire to produce *bing* [丙].
*Bing* is yang-fire,
uniting with *xin* [辛]’s yin-metal to produce *geng* [庚].
*Geng* is yang-metal,
uniting with *yi* [乙]’s yin-wood to produce *jia* [甲].
*Jia* is yang-wood,
uniting with *ji* [己]’s yin-earth to produce *wu* [戊].
*Wu* is yang-earth,
uniting with *gui* [癸]’s yin-water to produce *ren* [壬].
This is the principle of husband and wife.

Humans have two kidneys:
left is *chang* [场, field], right is *yin* [阴, darkness].
Left is the kidney, right is the *mingmen* [命门, Gate of Life].
At the inception of *ren* [壬],
the *mingmen* begins to form.

Only with the *mingmen* does the heart arise,
the heart generates blood—
following *ding* [丁] producing *bing* [丙].
The heart generates the lungs,
the lungs generate skin and hair—
following *xin* [辛] producing *geng* [庚].
Only with the lungs does the liver arise,
the liver governs sinews—
following *yi* [乙] producing *jia* [甲].
Only with the liver does the spleen arise,
the spleen generates flesh—
following *ji* [己] producing *wu* [戊].
The spleen generates the kidneys,
the kidneys generate bone marrow—
following *gui* [癸] producing *ren* [壬].
With the kidneys, they unite with the *mingmen* to form two.

Thus observed,
from the *one qi* of Heaven’s Primordium as root,
it is already established as *one*.
How could it lack a name?
The name is the mother of all things.

In *Qian* [☰], it begins and thrives.
The beginning is the *Yuan Shi* [元始, Primordial Origin],
governing Heaven—
thus one knows that *Qian* governs the Original *Qi*.

Exiting, it becomes yang;
entering, it becomes yin.
This is how the *Gu Shen* [谷神] breathes,
how the *Xuanpin* collects and stores—
all things receive their fate from this.

How could there be no root to take hold,
no gate to emerge from?
Those who seek to see it
must perceive it here.

Thus, from the *one qi* dividing into yin and yang,
Heaven and Earth are thereby magnified.
Beginning with *ren* [壬], it generates the Five Organs,
the human body is thereby completed.

In Heaven and Earth, there is something knowable—
in the human body, the two *qi* ascend and descend,
breathing and sighing, merging in harmony.
Only those with profound insight can achieve this.

**Third Section: Clarifying the Methods of Regulation and Mastery**

Soft and enduring, as if preserved,
yet used without exertion.

Those who receive their fate from yin and yang
cannot depart from the numbers of yin and yang,
those who entrust their form to life and death
cannot escape the authority of life and death.

Indeed, human life
is endowed with fixed numbers—
this is the principle of Heaven and Earth.
Using numbers to govern people,
if one uses numbers without knowing their limits,
then those who perish prematurely in mid-course exist.
If one obtains the numbers and transcends them beyond things,
then those who achieve longevity and immortality exist.

What are these numbers?
One, three, five, seven, nine—
two, four, six, eight, ten.

From where do these numbers arise?
They originate from the *one qi* of the Yellow Palace’s Heavenly Primordium.

Thus, the human body follows the *one*;
Heaven and Earth span eighty-four thousand *li* above and below.
At the two solstices’ intersection,
the operations of *Kan* [☵] and *Li* [☲] unfold.
One inhalation, the pulse travels three *cun*;
one exhalation, the pulse travels three *cun*.
Between inhalation and exhalation, the pulse travels six *cun*.
In one day and night, there are thirteen thousand five hundred breaths—
half yin, half yang.
From *hai* [亥] to *si* [巳], the *yingqi* [营气, Nourishing Qi] travels
twenty-five degrees of yang,
twenty-five degrees of yin,
totaling twelve *shi* [时] and one hundred *ke* [刻] of water clock measurements.

The waxing and waning, the full and the empty—
thus completing the yearly function,
harmonizing the Five *Qi* [五气].
Do not precede it with excess,
nor follow it with deficiency,
then yin and yang will be balanced in due measure.

If balance is lost,
the Five *Qi* will stray and conflict,
in Heaven becoming *victory and reversal* [胜复],
in man disrupting the Five *Zàng* [五藏, visceral organs],
and from this all diseases arise.
The art of its application lies in what can and cannot be done.

The Classic says: *"Gentle and enduring as if it exists"* [绵绵若存],
for *gentle and enduring* is the *one qi* [一气].
Draw the *one qi* between the *Gǔshén* [谷神, Grain Spirit] and the *Xīngshén* [神, Vital Spirit],
making it so subtle and weak
that its sound cannot be heard,
its movement cannot be felt—
seemingly nonexistent yet present,
seemingly present yet imperceptible,
thus it appears to exist.

So, the *Yíng* [营, Nourishing] and *Wèi* [卫, Defensive] *Qi* remain ever attuned,
the Six *Mài* [脉, pulses] do not overrun,
the ascent and descent of purity and turbidity
never lose their proper timing,
and panting or breathing
never become violent.

The *Mèngzǐ* [《孟子》] says: *"Hold firm to your resolve and do not exhaust your qi* [持其志无暴其气]."
The *Kāngcāngzǐ* [《亢仓子》] says: *"The body conforms to qi,
qi conforms to the heart,
the heart conforms to the spirit,
the spirit conforms to the formless* [体合於气，气合於心，心合於神，神合於无]."
The *Yùzhù* [御注] says: *"From its own foundation and root,
it has been thus from ancient times.*
As fire spreads,
one does not know its end."

When qi conforms to the spirit,
yin and yang cannot control life.
The *Yì* [《易》] says: *"Yin and yang are unfathomable"* [阴阳不测者是也].
Life and death cannot be manipulated.
The *Zhuāngzǐ* [《庄子》] says: *"This is the 'life and death that are neither life nor death'* [彼为生杀非生杀者是也]."
All this lies in not exerting oneself.

But those who dwell within Heaven and Earth,
yet go against the yin-yang numbers,
are those who cannot master qi.
When external things seduce,
they are instead overtaken by qi—
how much more so by those called *thieves of vital essence* [盗机]?

Thus, Heaven and Earth endure eternally
through this very principle.
Shào Ruòyú [邵若愚] says: *"The Grain Spirit does not die—
this is the Dao of 'use it not to exhaustion'* [谷神不死至用之不勤]."
The Grain is used to illustrate emptiness.
Emptiness is the *Dao* [道].
The Spirit is the *one qi* of Dao’s transformation,
the 'having within the formless' [无中之有].
The formless emptiness has no shape;
it is originally without birth,
yet also without death.
Thus it is said: *"The Grain Spirit does not die."*

Emptiness is the root of all things,
called *Xuan* [玄, Mysterious].
The Spirit is the origin of transformation,
called *Pìn* [牝, Feminine].
The Grain Spirit is thus the *Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝].
All things issue from the *Mysterious Feminine*’s gate,
this is called *the root of life and Earth* [生天地根].
To observe the Grain Spirit as *gentle and enduring as if it exists* [绵绵若存],
those who practice it must make the spirit conform to emptiness,
not through strenuous effort or contrived technique,
nor through cultivated skill or force.

Wáng Zhìrán [王志然] says: *"The Grain Spirit does not die—
this is the Dao of 'use it not to exhaustion'* [谷神不死至用之不勤]."
The *Mysterious Feminine* takes Heaven and Earth as its root,
yet all things are born from it without revealing its root.
The *Yì* [《易》] uses *Qián* [乾, Heavenly] and *Kūn* [坤, Earthly] as its gate,
yet all things emerge from it without revealing its gate.
Those who perceive it must be *sages* [圣人].

The Classic says: *"The Grain Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Feminine* [谷神不死，是谓玄牝]."
The Grain embodies emptiness;
emptiness can nourish the spirit,
and the spirit remains ever-present,
so it does not die.

The Dao of the Grain Spirit is wondrous beyond transmission.
It is explained thus: *"This is the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝]."
*Xuan* [玄] is the gate of the wondrous Dao.

The *Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] is the root of Heaven and Earth,
the *having within the formless* [无中之有],
the *Feminine* [牝] is the embodiment of Earth’s principle.
Penetrating the distinctions of day and night,
exhausting the origins of yin and yang,
fathoming the vital essence of life and death,
comprehending the transformations of birth and death—
following the *one qi* of creation,
ascending and descending without end,
the Grain is ever-emptying and receives its mandate from Heaven,
the Spirit is ever-quiescent and takes form from Earth.
One emergence brings forth life,
one withdrawal brings forth transformation—
all things return to their natural source.

Its source was never born,
yet its means of birth are without origin;
its source was never transformed,
yet its means of transformation reach no destination.
This is what the *Zhuāngzǐ* [《庄子》] calls *"never having died nor ever having been born"* [未尝死而未尝生].

The *Lièzǐ* [《列子》] says:
There is the *born* [生生],
the *formed* [形形],
the *heard* [声声],
the *seen* [色色],
the *tasted* [味味].
The *born* that is born dies,
yet the *born* that is born without end never ceases.
The *formed* that is formed is solid,
yet the *formed* that is formed without substance never exists.
The *heard* that is heard is audible,
yet the *heard* that is heard without sound never emits.
The *seen* that is seen is manifest,
yet the *seen* that is seen without appearance never displays.
The *tasted* that is tasted is savored,
yet the *tasted* that is tasted without flavor never presents.

Without knowing,
without ability,
without not knowing,
without inability—
what I desire to learn
must be the subtlety of *"never ceasing, never existing, never emitting, never displaying, never presenting"* [未尝终、未尝有、未尝发、未尝显、未尝呈].

To embody yin and yang,
ride the transformations,
flank the sun and moon,
embrace the cosmos—
to ascend and play with the Creator,
to descend and befriend the external,
the deathless, the endless—
this is the *Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝],
this is the *Grain Spirit* [谷神].

To seek neither death nor life
from this is impossible.
The *Zhuāngzǐ* [《庄子》] says:
*"When virtue is cultivated and returns to its original,
this is the Primordial True Person* [性修反德，德至同为初真人]."
To rest in this state,
one’s breath becomes profound and deep,
called *gentle and enduring as if it exists* [绵绵若存],
this is the Dao of *"use it not to exhaustion"* [用之不勤].

Ah! This Dao is very easy to know,
very easy to practice,
yet few can know it,
few can practice it—
why is this so?
Because those who study it
have not yet illuminated the profound roots of stillness and extremity,
of entering death and returning to life.

When subtlety is mastered here,
one can govern Heaven and Earth,
store all things,
ascend to the Great Brightness above,
reach the utmost Yang’s origin,
enter the Gate of Obscurity,
attain the utmost Yin’s source.

Obtaining the traces of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang,
one then knows where the *Mysterious Feminine* and *Grain Spirit* reside.

Huáng Màocái [黄茂材] says:
*"The Grain Spirit does not die—
this is called the Mysterious Feminine* [谷神不死，是谓玄牝]."
The Grain embodies emptiness;
emptiness can nourish the spirit,
and the spirit remains ever-present,
so it does not die.

The Dao of the Grain Spirit is wondrous beyond transmission—
it is explained thus: *"This is the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝]."
*Xuan* [玄] is the gate of the wondrous Dao.

The Mysterious Feminine is the origin of all things.
The Gate of the Mysterious Feminine is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
*Xuan* [玄] is the Gate of the wondrous Dao,
*Pin* [牝] is the origin of all things.

Seeking it within myself,
what substance is it, indeed?
Seeking it and finding it impossible,
then seeking what gives birth to my body,
what substance is that, indeed?

Heaven and Earth and I all originate from the Mysterious Feminine;
knowing what gives birth to my body,
one then knows the root of Heaven and Earth.

The Classic says: *"Deep-rooted and firm-founded,
the Dao of long life and enduring vision—
this is it."*

Continuous as if ever-present,
its use requires no effort.
"Continuous" means successive.
"Continuous as if ever-present"
also describes the Dao of the undying.

The superior scholar hears the Dao,
and diligently practices it.
Now, why is its use without effort?
The diligent have moments when they are not diligent,
but those who use it without effort
are never not diligent—
this aligns with the Dao.

There is no greater diligence than this.

Chéng Tàizhī [程泰之] says:
*"The Grain Spirit does not die."*
The Master Lao had many allusions to the Grain,
saying: *"Vast as the Valley, for its breadth,"*
and *"The Valley receives One and is filled,"*
speaking of its capacity to receive.
*"Be the Valley of the world,"*
*"The rivers and seas can be kings of all the Valleys,"*
all praise its virtue of humility.

Yet this chapter uniquely reveals profound truths:
the Spirit, the undying,
the ever-present—
its deepest meaning and practical application
are not the same as other texts that merely liken the Grain.

Other schools offer no further insight,
only saying that the Grain’s emptiness
is indeed the Spirit,
but emptiness alone is insufficient.
Following its undying nature,
its ever-presence,
and contemplating its essence,
one sees that emptiness alone
cannot fully capture its description.

Emperor Xuānzōng of the Tang [唐明皇] explained it thus:
*"It responds to sensation—
its response is like the Spirit,
for it is the very meaning of sound producing echo."*

Other schools, having followed the Emperor’s revelation,
later began to cite his interpretation
as their own insight.
Before this, none had spoken of it.

The echo’s generation with form’s shadow
shares the same principle.
Yet shadows cast by form are not identical—
whether by sun, moon, water, or fire,
all things with light produce shadows.
Thus, if one seeks the origin of shadows,
they look to the sun and moon but find none,
then turn to water and fire,
and the principle can be made clear.

But sound’s emergence differs.
When released into the wild, it disperses;
when striking the mountains, it is muffled.
Only the Grain—
exteriorly curved, interiorly hollow—
when sound enters it,
resonates back and forth,
and thus harmonizes to produce echo.
Therefore, though Heaven is vast
and all things are many,
only this Grain can produce echo from the void,
and thus possess this Spirit.

Swift or fine, long or short,
much or little—
it responds to sensation and generates,
each instance resembling the original.
If not taken from this Grain,
where else could one find the Spirit?

Only when one knows the Spirit belongs to this
does it become undying and ever-present,
and all can be deduced.

It was only when Dàchāng [大昌] grasped this principle
that he felt it was fitting yet dared not assert it deeply,
until he encountered the *Listed Child* [列子] citing the Yellow Emperor’s words
to elucidate the Master Lao’s teachings,
and then he was firmly convinced beyond doubt.

The *Listed Child*’s words on transformation
fully cite the Yellow Emperor’s original discourse on the Grain Spirit,
to prove that the continuous generation and transformation
is the Grain’s ability to be the Spirit,
to be undying,
to be ever-present—
all are named by this.

Further, he explains that all things’ birth and death
come from entering and exiting the mechanism,
and he cites the Yellow Emperor’s words to clarify:
*"Form moves but does not generate form—
it generates shadow.
Sound moves but does not generate sound—
it generates echo.
The Void moves but does not generate the Void—
it generates the Having."*

The principle he aligns with
is perfectly consistent with earlier teachings.
Thus, Dàchāng saw that the Yellow Emperor’s two meanings
were originally one chapter,
but the *Listed Child*’s phrasing
happened to diverge slightly,
so he also split them into two.

The reader must combine their differing expressions
to trace the underlying thread,
and then clarity will emerge.

As for the Grain’s ability to be the Spirit,
it can be deduced.

When it is hollow,
in the Dao it is the Void.
When sound strikes it,
it responds to sensation and thus has substance.
The Having moves and strikes the Void,
the Void receives and thus is hollow,
so the Grain responds to sound and generates echo—
the image of generation without self-generation.

When sound ceases and striking stops,
the Void remains void in perception,
and the Spirit cannot always be the Spirit.
If there is further striking,
its response is as before,
and then one knows that transformation
does not transform itself.

This is why it attains
the undying and the ever-present.

The *Classic of Changes* [《易》] says:
*"Without thought,
without action,
quietly unmoving,
responsive and thus communicating—
this is Heaven’s way."*

Its lack of thought and action,
its quiet stillness,
are the Grain’s image of Void without sensation.
When sensation comes, it immediately responds,
producing echo and answering sound—
this is the unmeasurable Spirit.

The *Classic of Changes* speaks of divination’s Spirit,
saying: *"It is about to act,
it is about to move—
ask it, and it will respond as if receiving a command,
with no distinction between near and far, deep or shallow,
and thus one knows the coming thing."*

Divination’s response as if receiving a command
is the *Classic of Changes*’s sensation and communication.
Thus, it also borrows the metaphor of echo and response.

The Master Lao’s book stands alone,
refusing to be confused with the *Classic of Changes*,
so though he extols this Grain’s Spirit greatly,
he does not directly imitate the *Classic of Changes*’s echo and response.

Yet in seeking its principle,
there is no difference.

The *Listed Child* truly had insight here,
combining the Yellow Emperor’s and Lao’s teachings
to reveal their harmony,
and then the principle became clear.

Thus, the Great Master [参] examined myriad principles [万理] and observed,
yet held firm to his own insight [自主其见].
He said: *"Beyond the Grain’s Spirit [谷], there is no echo [响],
then beyond the echo, there is also no Spirit [神]."*

Those who rigidly uphold a single void [一虚] as its meaning,
when extended to its limit,
Lao’s words then speak of the *Unperishing* [不死],
or of *storage* [若存],
all lacking a final resting place [无归宿].
Therefore, he did not dare to follow blindly.

The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门],
this is called the *Root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根].
All that is termed *Origin* [元],
take the meaning of *profound, dark, and obscure* [窈深暗晦].
*Origin-Virtue* [元德],
*Origin-Sameness* [元同],
*Origin-Viewing* [元览],
and this *Mysterious Female* [玄牝],
all belong to the four categories of *Virtue-Sameness* [德同] and *Viewing-Female* [览牝],
already touching upon the *existent* [有] and thus visible [可见].
Therefore, beyond these four categories [四则之上],
he further deepens into the *obscure* [深晦],
and thus adds *Origin* [元] to explore the *command* [命].
Its *foundation* [宿],
when elevated to its utmost,
the *Miracles of the Nonexistent* [无] are already profound.

Then, discarding the label of *Nonexistent* [无],
and solely designating it as *Mysterious* [玄],
its *image* [象] can be imagined.

The *Female* [牝] is one who *responds without initiating* [应而不唱].
The Grain’s Spirit [谷] that *harbors the echo awaiting sound* [蕴响待声] is exactly this.

If *sound is not stirred* [声苟不感],
then the *echo never emerges* [响终不出],
and thus it can be said to *not act before things* [不为物先].

Only those who are the *mighty and strong of the world* [天下之雄且强],
already knowing this,
and yet can *bow to the Female* [自屈於牝],
have reached the utmost *void* [虚].

Above this *void* [虚],
further adding *Origin* [元],
then the *transformations and changes* [变化] that arise,
are the *source of Heaven and Earth’s birth* [生天生地].

Thus, the previous chapter says: *"The Nameless* [无名] *is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.*
And here, it speaks of the *Root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根].
All this is *probing the ultimate and commanding the initial* [探端命初],
and knowing that the *Nonexistent’s response to stimulation* [无之受感而应]
is the *foundation of all existence* [凡有]—
it *grants the primal command* [命其宗] and *governs their emergence* [司其出].

Continuous yet as if existing [绵绵若存],
its use is not exhausted [用之不勤].
With *form and substance* [有形有质],
it is *visible to the eye* [目可睹] and *graspable by the hand* [手可捉],
so it is called *existing* [存]—
if the Grain’s Spirit [谷] can *respond* [能应],
then it is said to *sequence things* [以为序],
but it is *indistinctly nonexistent* [漠乎其无有],
or if it is said to *not exist* [不存],
then the *echo before ceases* [前响已绝],
and the *sound after strikes* [后声再触],
its response remains unchanged [其应如故].
Therefore, it is spoken of as *existing yet indistinct* [若存].

*Continuous* [绵绵] means merely *holding to connection without cessation* [相属而不绝].
Zhuangzi’s *threshold* [际] is exactly this.
The *threshold* is the *intersection of opposites* [两异之交].
Let us clarify it with the *plainly seen* [易见] four seasons [四序]:
when *spring’s season ends* [春之已季],
it is the *summer’s season about to begin* [夏之欲孟].
The *space between the end and the beginning* [季孟之间] is the *threshold* [际].
There is an *end* [季], then there must be a *beginning* [孟],
but the *Origin-Qi* [元气] never *makes itself into end or beginning* [自为季孟].
Thus, the Listed Child’s words on *eternal return* [命往复]
and saying that its *threshold cannot be exhausted* [际不可终] are correct.

Observing from the *threshold* [际],
what is now called *beginning* [孟]
is the *substitution of what was once called end* [昔名为季].
The *beginning* arises [起], the *end* departs [去],
and thus *summer follows spring’s departure* [夏应春往].

Only those who *establish eternal return to give birth and transform* [制往复以出生化],
have *no threshold and no end* [无际无终],
and this is why they *remain everlasting* [常存].
This *everlasting existence* [存],
though *constant and never perishing* [常不亡],
is *yet unseen* [不可得见],
so it *continuously connects* [绵绵相属],
as if existing yet *no sequence is apparent* [不见其序].
Therefore, it is spoken of as *existing yet indistinct* [若存].

Its *eternal birth and transformation* [生生化化],
never *ceasing or lingering* [无时或息, 无时或留],
as if *laboring greatly* [甚劳],
yet *with sequence in precedence and succession* [先后有序],
though there are *actions and functions* [有作用],
they do not *exhaust movement* [费运动].
*Self-birth, self-transformation* [自生自化],
*self-consumption, self-rest* [自消自息],
there is *no labor at all* [元无劳].

Zhuangzi says:
*"The interplay of yin and yang, the four seasons’ progression,
each attains its order.*
*Awaken! As if perishing yet existing,
effulgent yet formless—its spirit,
all things nurtured yet unaware.*
This is called the *Origin-Root* [本根].
Is this not the *spirit that perishes not* [能神而不亡],
as if *laboring yet truly not exhausted* [若劳而寔不勤]?"

Discussing how the Listed Child’s *birth and transformation* [生化]
originate from Laozi’s *action and return* [作复],
and Laozi’s *action and return*
originate from the *Classic of Changes’* *eclipse and growth* [消息],
yet the *means by which they birth, transform, act, and return* [所以生化作复],
all do not exceed the *advance and retreat of yin and yang* [阴阳之进退].

When *yin retreats and yang advances* [阴退而阳进],
it becomes *birth and action* [为生为作];
when *yin ascends and yang descends* [阴升而阳降],
it becomes *transformation and return* [为化为复].
Speaking of this *gradual advance and retreat* [进退之渐],
it is *eclipse and growth* [消息].

This is what the *Classic of Changes* and Laozi *speak in common* [所同言],
yet Laozi *constantly probes what the Classic does not fully reveal* [探夫《易》之所不肯尽],
and having spoken of it,
he *transcends eclipse and growth to discuss existence and nonexistence* [越消息而言有无].

*Existence and nonexistence* [有无] are again
the *mechanism governing eclipse and growth* [消息之机],
yet not *confined to the cycles of eclipse and growth* [自囿於消息之数].
Thus, the *evidence of action and return* [作复之证] is the *straw-dog* [刍狗];
the *mechanism of eclipse and growth* [消息之机] is the *bellows-key* [橐钥];
and the *source of birth and transformation* [生化之原] is the Grain’s Spirit [谷神].
This is the *distinction between shallow and deep* [浅深之辨].

Zhan Qiu Pu said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit perishes not—its use is not exhausted.*
The *Chapter of the Manifested* [成象] states that all things
are *nurtured by the Grain’s Spirit and Qi* [谷养神气],
thus *eternally born and unperishing* [生生不灭],
this is called *Heaven’s Mysterious Female as Yang* [天主阳为玄],
and *Earth’s Mysterious Female as Yin* [地主阴为牝].
The *Mysterious Female* is the *gate through which all things are born and transformed* [品物生育之门],
this is called the *rooted in Heaven and Earth* [根於天地],
and the *endless generation and manifestation of things* [生物成象无穷]."

Zhang Chong Ying replied:
*"The Grain’s Spirit perishes not—its use is not exhausted.*
I possess this body,
*endowed with Heaven’s Qi* [禀天之气],
and *containing Earth’s essence* [含地之精],
this is the *Spirit of the Five Viscera* [五脏之神].
The *nose* [鼻] is where *Qi’s ascent and descent* [气之升降] are hinged,
the *mouth* [口] is where *essence’s circulation* [精之运行] is linked.
*Qi moves fifty-one times before resting* [气五十一动息],
ascending and descending through the *nose* [鼻].
*Essence circulates seventy-four times in a moment* [精一刻凡七十四运],
circulating through the *mouth* [口].
Thus, the Grain’s Spirit [谷],
*nourished by this essence and Qi* [得此精气所养],
*perishes not* [不死],
this is why it is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝故].

The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门],
is the *nose as Heaven’s Qi’s gate* [鼻为天气之门],
and the *mouth as Earth’s essence’s gate* [口为地精之门].
If *movement is constant* [运动有常],
then the *kidneys do not empty and the seas do not block* [肾不虚海不塞],
and this is the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之所以根].
If one can *rest the essence and Qi* [息其精气],
*continuously as normal* [绵绵如常],
using them *endlessly* [用之无穷],
then *longevity will be without end* [享年为无已].
This is the *law of male and female interplay* [男女通行之法],
and it is imperative to *deliberate and nurture it* [详味而养之],
then one will *attain true humanity and sainthood* [成真入圣],
all through this." [皆以之也。]

「If not so, then *essence will be depleted and Qi will be exhausted* [精耗气亏],
and the *Grain’s Spirit* [谷神] will have no nourishment to sustain it—
then the face will lack luster and vitality [颜无光采],
and *Qi will transform into the Yang Male* [气化雄],
*essence into the Yin Female* [精化雌],
*Spirit into the Ghostly* [神化鬼],
which is called the *Three Corpses* [三尸者也].

Humans live in this world,
possessing this wondrous *essence-Qi-Spirit* [此妙],
yet cannot preserve and nurture it.
Alas.

Zhang Lingying said:
*"Xuan* [玄] is Heaven’s domain, the Yang,
and is the *Primordial Qi* [元气].
*The Female* [牝] is Earth’s domain, the Yin,
and is the *Primordial Essence* [元精].
The *Primordial Qi* [元气] ascends at the *Child Hour* [子时],
this is the *birth of one Yang* [一阳生也].
From the *Kidney Palace* [肾宫], it flows through the *Left Path* [左道] into the *Five Zang Organs* [五脏],
and at the *Maocheng Hour* [卯时] meets with *essence* in the abdomen,
entering the *liver*—this is called the *Spring Yang Division* [春阳分也].
By the *Wucheng Hour* [巳时], it reaches the *Heavenly Gate* [天门],
the *nose as the gate for its entry and exit* [鼻为出入之门],
and ascends to the *crown* [顶],
until the *Wuhou* [午时], when it descends, residing in the *Right Path* [右道],
entering the *bone networks* [骨络], then returning to the *Kidney Palace* [肾宫].

The *Primordial Essence* [元精] ascends and descends at the *Wuhou* [午时],
this is the *birth of one Yin* [一阴生也].
From the *Command Essence* [命元], it flows through the *Right Path* [右道] into the *bone networks* [骨络],
and at the *Yousheng Hour* [酉时] meets with *Qi* in the back,
entering the *lung*—this is called the *Autumn Yin Division* [秋阴分也].
By the *Haicheng Hour* [亥时], it reaches the *Earthly Portal* [地户],
the *mouth as the gate for its entry and exit* [口为出入之门],
and ascends to the *crown* [顶],
until the *Child Hour* [子时], when it descends, residing in the *Left Path* [左道],
entering the *Five Zang Organs* [五脏], then returning to the *Command Essence* [命元].

When *essence ascends and Qi descends* [精与气一升一降],
the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝] interplays,
neither depleted nor excessive [不亏不盈],
then the *Spirit dwells in Heaven’s Grain* [神居天谷],
guarding and sustaining this form [守卫此形],
and only then can one perceive the *method of regulating and attaining non-death* [调理不死之方].

Bai Yushan said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit does not perish"* [谷神不死],
this is because the *heart is originally without aging and death* [此心本无老死].
This is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝],
unified in this *One Dao* [同此一天].
The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门]
lies where the *mind’s movements arise* [念头动处].

This is called the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根],
for it is the *heart* [惟心].
Continuously as if preserved [绵绵若存],
it is simply *this* [只是如此].
Using it without strain [用之不勤],
is to act *without effort* [无为而已].

Liao Cuiran said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit does not perish"* [谷神不死].
*Empty Qi* [空气] within the body is the *mother of Spirit* [神之母],
and the *mother and child mutually nourish* [子母相养],
thus *form and Spirit attain longevity* [形神长生].
This is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝],
the *mother of all things* [万物之母].
The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门]
is the *gate of all transformations and marvels* [生生化化，众妙之门].
This is called the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根],
the *source of all phenomena* [万象之本].
Continuously as if preserved [绵绵若存],
*left and right find their origin* [左右逢原],
this is the *original face of suchness* [本来面目之为].
Using it without exertion [用之不动],
it *circulates endlessly without pause* [周行不殆],
extending through ancient and modern times [绵亘古今],
*requiring no effort to consume* [不消用力].

Chen Biuxu said:
*"The Grain’s Spirit does not perish"* [谷神不死]—this is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝].
The *Great Person* [大人] takes *Great Emptiness* [太虚] as the *Empty Grain* [空谷],
and *Creation* [造化] as the *Supreme Spirit* [至神].
The *Empty Grain* and *Supreme Spirit* [空谷至神]
are the *body and function of the Dao* [道之体用],
how could there be a principle of *perishing or not perishing* [有死乎不死之理]?
Moreover, it is *deep and hidden* [深冥],
and yet can *mother and nourish*—
thus it is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝].
Some say *Grain* [谷] symbolizes *Heaven and Earth* [天地],
and *Spirit* [神] symbolizes the *Great Dao* [大道].
But those who speak of *Grain’s Spirit* as a metaphor for *mountains and valleys echoing in response*—
is this not too trivial?

Furthermore, if humans can *embrace openness without bounds* [怀豁无方],
aligning with the *Great Emptiness’s vastness* [法太虚之广],
and *preserve the true and genuine Spirit* [存任神真],
drawing upon *Creation’s vitality* [资造化之灵],
then *form naturally harmonizes with the Dao* [自然形与道合],
what is there to speak of *death* [何死之谓乎]?
Thus, one *flourishes in hidden cultivation* [冥然茂养],
and *all things receive its blessings* [物受其赐也].」

「Thus it is called the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝]. The *Master of the Yellow River* [河上公] in his *Commentary* [《章句》] explains that *Grain* [谷] refers to the *nourishing sound* [育], meaning *nourishment* [养]. When humans can *nourish their Spirit* [养神], then they do not *perish* [死].

The *Spirit* [神] here refers to the *Spirits of the Five Viscera* [五藏之神]:
- the *Liver Spirit* [肝] harbors the *ethereal soul* [魂],
- the *Lungs Spirit* [肺] harbors the *corporeal soul* [魄],
- the *Heart Spirit* [心] harbors the *Spirit* [神],
- the *Kidneys Spirit* [肾] harbors the *Essence* [精],
- the *Spleen Spirit* [脾] harbors the *Will* [志].

When humans can *cleanse and still their form within the Great Emptiness* [清静虚空], *nourishing their Spirit* [以养其神], and not be *defiled by the myriad desires* [不为诸欲所染], their *form remains whole and their Spirit intact* [使形完神全], and thus they do not *perish* [死]. But if one *entangles with emotions and lingers in indulgence* [触情耽滞], *disturbed by the myriad phenomena* [为诸境所乱], their *form decays and their Spirit departs* [使形残神去], then how can the *Dao* [道] be preserved?

The *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门] is called the *Root of Heaven and Earth* [天地根]. The *Great Emptiness* [太虚] and *Creation* [造化] are the means by which *all things enter and exit* [万类之以出入]. Since there is the name of *entry and exit* [出入], it is called the *Gate* [门]. Moreover, *Root* [根] means *origin* [元], and the *Gate* [之门] refers to the *two nostrils* [两鼻], which serve as the passage for the *Essential Qi of Heaven and Earth* [天地之元气] to circulate within the body.

The earlier statement that *Grain’s Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死] exhorts humans to *the principle of nourishing the Spirit* [养神之理], while this passage on the *Gate of the Mysterious Female* [玄牝之门] illustrates *the technique of refining the form* [炼形之术]. Thus, those who *perfectly nourish both form and Spirit* [形神俱妙] alone may *align with the Dao* [与道同].

Humans possess both *form* [身] and *Spirit* [神], and thus they have *birth and death* [生有死]. With *birth and death* [生有死], one cannot speak of the *Dao* [道]. *Flowing and shifting without constancy* [流动无常], how can it be called *stillness* [静]? If one *empties their form and Spirit* [空其形神], *forgets the distinction between self and things* [忘其物我], then *their exit lacks a root* [出无根], and thus *the Qi does not gather to form life* [气聚不以为生]; *their entry lacks an orifice* [入无窍], and thus *the Qi does not disperse to cause death* [气散不以为死]. Without *life* [生] or *death* [死], this is the *Spirit of Grain* [谷神]. *Birth and death are without constancy* [生死无常], for they are but *floating and shifting things* [浮动之物]. *Deeply hidden and feminine stillness* [幽深雌静], *serene and unmoving* [湛然不动], is what is meant by the *Mysterious Female* [玄牝].

*Continuous as if ever-present* [绵绵若存], yet *its use requires no exertion* [用之不勤]. *Continuous* [绵绵] describes its unending nature—this passage ties together the earlier teachings on *nourishing the Spirit and refining the form* [结上养神炼形之义].

To *nourish the Spirit* [养神] is to attain *profound subtlety and hidden stillness* [深妙冥极], *cleansing and emptiness* [清静虚空], *continuous as if ever-present* [绵绵若存], yet *responding to things without ceasing* [感物而起], *uninterrupted in time* [无有绝时].

To *refine the form* [炼形] is to *breathe in the harmonious Great Emptiness* [呼吸太和], *guide and connect the blood and Qi* [导接血气], *drink the elixir of the endless spring* [饮难终之泉], and *chew the herb of longevity* [咀延年之草], so that *their limbs and joints remain unobstructed* [使其支节通畅] and *they experience no exertion* [而不勤劳]. Only then can they *share the same root as Heaven and Earth* [与天地同根] and *enter the same gate as all marvels* [众妙共门].

*Master Xie Tuonan* [谢图南] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is the *ineffable function’s non-exertion* [至用之不动]. The *Classic* [经] states: *Grain is filled by the One* [谷得一以盈], *Spirit is made agile by the One* [神得一以灵]; *Heaven and Earth possess this* [天地有之], and *humans also possess it* [人亦有之].

*Master Chen Xiyi* [陈希夷] says: *Mountains fall from Heaven’s heights* [山自天之上而坠], so when one *observes the trigram *Kān* [艮] and its lines* [画], one knows *mountains originate from Heaven* [山自天来]. The *human head symbolizes Heaven’s apex* [人之首象天顶], called *Kunlun* [昆仑]. The *nose and mouth are the roots of mountains* [鼻口山根], and the *Spirit dwells between them* [神藏其间], thus it is called *Grain’s Spirit* [谷神], the *master of the body* [一身之主宰]. Indeed, it *never truly perishes* [实未尝死].

The *Mysterious Female* [玄牝] refers to the *Two Primordial Elements* [乾坤二元]. The *head* [首] is *Kān* [乾], the *abdomen* [腹] is *Kūn* [坤]; the *Qi of these two elements ascends and descends, circulating* [二元之气升降往来], called *Mysterious* [玄] when in *Kān* [乾], and *Feminine* [牝] when in *Kūn* [坤]. The *Mysterious Female* [玄牝] is the *Qi of the Two Primordial Elements* [二元之气], and the *Two Primordial Elements* [二元] are the *masters of Grain’s Spirit* [谷神之主].

*Master Shao Kangjie’s* [邵康节] poem states:
*"One thing originally has a body, a body still has a Heaven and Earth"* [一物元来有一身，一身还有一乾坤].
This is precisely what is meant.

The *Gate* [门] refers to the *two nostrils* [两鼻]. The *pure and tranquil Qi of Heaven and Earth* [天地清宁之气] enters through the *human nostrils* [自人之鼻], *circulating and permeating the body* [流布身中]. The *head* [乾首] and *abdomen* [坤腹] are both *nourished by this* [胥此养之], hence it is called the *Root* [根]. The *Qi’s continuous entry* [是气之入], *unending as if ever-present* [绵绵不绝若存], is *preserved by following its natural flow* [顺其自然而存之], requiring *no exertion* [不必劳力].

Thus it is said: *Its use requires no exertion* [用之不勤]. Some may *overclose their Qi* [过於闭其气], which is not only *without benefit* [非徒无益] but also *harmful* [而又害之]. Indeed, it has been discussed: *The Great Ultimate* [太极] *begins to differentiate* [肇分], and humans stand alongside Heaven and Earth as *the Three Talents* [三]. This is the *Dao of the Three Talents* [三才之道].

The *head* [首] is Heaven, the *abdomen* [腹] is Earth, and the *heart* [心] resides between them—*the Three Talents within the human body* [吾身之三才]. *Master Shao Kangjie’s* [康节] poem states:
*"Heaven divides Creation within the One, humans weave the loom from the heart’s apex"* [天向一中分造化，人从心上起经纶].
The *heart* [心] resides between the *head* [首] and *abdomen* [腹], *weaving the threads of the above and below* [以弥纶上下], so that the *Mysterious Female ascends and descends* [使玄牝升降], the *Spirit and Qi circulate* [精神往来], and thus *the body may endure perpetually* [吾身可以常存矣].

When *preservation and nourishment are profound* [存养既深] and *understanding and recognition are mature* [体认既熟], then *it appears vague and indistinct* [惚兮恍兮], yet *therein lies an image* [其中有象], *indistinct and vague* [恍兮惚兮], yet *therein lies a thing* [其中有物], *deep and hidden* [窈兮冥兮], yet *therein lies a precision* [其中有精]. These three may be *perceived* [可识].

*It cannot be seen* [视之不见], thus it is called *Yí* [夷];
*it cannot be heard* [听之不闻], thus it is called *Xī* [希];
*it cannot be grasped* [搏之不得], thus it is called *Wēi* [微].
These three may be *imagined* [可想].

*Know its masculine aspect* [知其雄], yet *hold to its feminine aspect* [守其雌];
*know its white* [知其白], yet *hold to its black* [守其黑];
*know its prosperity* [知其荣], yet *hold to its adversity* [守其辱].
These three may be *preserved* [可存].

When one *reverses their gaze inward and inspects* [反观内察], *Heaven and Earth resemble oneself* [天地与我相似]. Is it not true that *The Spirit of Grain does not perish* [谷神不死], and *Master Lao* [老氏] does not *deceive me* [欺我]?

*Master Lin Yinshi* [林鬳斋] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is the *ineffable function’s non-exertion* [至用之不勤]. This section arises from *one practice of cultivation and nourishment* [修养一项功夫之所自出]. *Master Lao’s* [老子] original intent, however, was not *exclusively for cultivation and nourishment* [却不专为修养].

*Essence* [精] is *substantial* [实], *Spirit* [神] is *ethereal* [虚]. *Grain* [谷] refers to *the ethereal* [虚].」

The *Spirit of Grain* [谷神] is the *divine essence within the void* [虚中之神者也]. It is said that *human spirit emerges from the void* [人之神自虚中而出], hence it *endures perpetually without perishing* [故常存而不死].

*Mysterious* [玄] is that which is *remote and boundless* [远而无极者也]. *Feminine* [牝] is that which is *void and unsubstantial* [虚而不实者也]. These two characters merely describe the *void* [虚].

*Heaven and Earth* [天地] arise from this, hence it is called the *root* [根]. *Continuous* [绵绵] conveys the meaning of *unceasing, unbroken* [不已、不绝]. *As if existing* [若存] means *as if present, as if absent* [若有若无]. When applied within the *void and nothingness* [虚无之中], it *endures without labor* [不劳而常存], thus it is said: *void yet unyielding, in motion yet ever emerging* [虚而不屈，动而愈出].

*Master Huì* [晦翁] says: *The most wondrous principle* [至妙之理] contains the *intent of eternal generation* [有生生之意存焉]. This passage is well-phrased, though its meaning leans toward *theories of nourishing life* [养生之论]. Though this chapter may be applied to *cultivation and nourishment* [修养], its original intent was not *exclusively for this purpose* [实不专主是].

*Master Fàn Yīngyuán* [范应元] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is called *the Mysterious Feminine* [是谓玄牝]. *The Spirit of Grain* [谷神] is akin to *void luminosity* [犹言虚灵也]. *Not perishing* [不死] is akin to *boundlessness* [犹言无极也]. *The Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] speaks of *that which generates all things yet remains unseen in its generation* [言其生物而不见其所以生也]. It is said: *void luminosity, boundlessness*—this is the *feminine principle of generation* [虚灵无极], which is unseen in its generation, hence it is called *mysterious* [玄]. *The Spirit of Grain* [谷神]—*Fù Yì* [傅奕] says it is *profound yet penetrating* [幽而通也].

*Sīmǎ Wēngōng* [司马温公] says: *It is called Grain because it is centrally void* [中虚故曰谷], *it is called Spirit because it is unfathomable* [不测故曰神]. *Sū* [苏] says: *Grain is supremely void yet still retains form* [谷至虚而犹有形], *but the Spirit of Grain is void and formless* [谷神则虚而无形也]. If it is *void and formless*, how could there be *anything to die* [虚而无形尚无有生，安有死邪]? Calling it *the Spirit of Grain* [谷神] speaks of its *virtue* [言其德也]; calling it *the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] speaks of its *function* [言其功也]. The *Mysterious Feminine* generates all things yet *remains unseen in its generation* [牝生万物而谓之玄], how could one see its generation without seeing *how it generates* [焉见其生之而不见其所以生也]?

*The Gate of the Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝之门] is called *the root of Heaven and Earth* [是谓天地根]. *Gate* [门] refers to *yin and yang* [指阴阳也]. It is said that *one opening, one closing*—*endless coming and going* [以其一辟一阖，往来不穷而言也]. *Yin and yang* [阴阳者] are spoken of in terms of *the Dao’s motion and stillness* [以道之动静而言也]. When in motion, it is called *yang* [动而曰阳]; when motion reaches its extreme and stillness ensues, it is called *yin* [动极而静曰阴]. Motion reaching its extreme turns to stillness, stillness reaching its extreme turns back to motion—*opening and closing without error* [动极而静，静极复动，开阖不忒], *generation and nurture without end* [生育无穷]. *Root* [根] means *Heaven and Earth originate from this* [谓天地本於此也].

If a person *first attains this in their heart* [人能於此心之初得之], they will know that *the root of Heaven and Earth is a root without root* [天地之根，无根之根也]; *the Gate of the Mysterious Feminine is a gate without gate* [玄牝之门，无门之门也]; *the Spirit of Grain is a spirit without spirit* [谷神，不神之神也]. How could it ever be exhausted?

*Continuous, as if existing* [绵绵若存], *used without exertion* [用之不勤]. It is said that *the Spirit of Grain in Heaven and Earth is continuous and boundless* [谓谷神之在天地，绵绵密密而无极也]. Yet *it cannot be seen when viewed* [然视之不可见], *cannot be heard when listened to* [听之不得闻], *cannot be exhausted when used* [用之不可既], hence it is said: *as if existing*—*Heaven and Earth use it, and the four seasons proceed, all things flourish, yet they never labor* [故曰若存，天地用之而四时行、百物生，未尝劳也]. The *Spirit of Grain in humans* [谷神在人] is likewise.

*Continuous and boundless* [绵绵密密], *eternally generating* [生生无穷], *as its origin*—who could claim dominion over this body? *As its origin*—where could it ultimately reside? Hence it is said: *as if existing* [故曰若存]. Those who *skillfully use it* [善用之者] *never labor* [未尝劳也], how could it ever be exhausted? This chapter should be *profoundly understood* [宜深体之]. Some may interpret it *exclusively for cultivation and nourishment* [或有专就修养上解者], yet one must *first recognize the Spirit of Grain* [然必须认得谷神方可].

*Xuē Yōngzhāi* [薛庸斋] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—this is called *the root of Heaven and Earth* [至是谓天地根]. *Grain* [谷] is where *the spirit resides* [神所居]. *Spirit* [神] is what *the form carries* [形所载]. *Nourishing the form to vitalize the qi, containing the qi to harbor the spirit*—this is the *Way of non-perishing* [以形养气，以气含神，不死之道也]. *Spirit inherently does not perish* [神本无死], yet when *assigned to form, it has death* [赋于形而有死], though even in death it *has not truly died* [虽死而未尝死也]. The *Spirit of Grain* [谷神] *does not perish because of the Mysterious Feminine* [因玄牝不死], and *Heaven and Earth take the Mysterious Feminine as their root* [天地以玄牝为根].

*The Mysterious Feminine* [玄牝] is *internal* [内焉], yet *harbors essence externally* [而藏精外焉], *adjusting breath*—*one opening, one closing* [而调息一开一阖], *one exhalation, one inhalation* [一呼一吸]. Exhaling reaches *the deep root* [呼则至於深根], inhaling reaches *the firm base* [吸则至於固蒂]. Thus *the spirit enters* [于是有神入焉], *revolving through the Dipper* [离斗辗历天廷], *riding the sun and moon, parting clouds and mists* [骑日月披云雾], *soaring and returning to the Hall of Great Possession* [腾腾乎会归于大有之室], much like the *divine beings dwelling on Mount Gūshè* [亦犹姑射山有神人居焉].

*Continuous, as if existing* [绵绵若存], *used without exertion* [用之不勤]. *Continuous* [绵绵] means *adjusting breath as if present, as if absent* [调息似有若无], *its use requires no labor* [用之要不至勤劳尔].

*Xiū Xiū’ān* [休休庵] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—*used without exertion* [至用之不勤]. *Void and luminous* [虚明] is called *Grain* [谓之谷], *subtle and wondrous* [灵妙] is called *Spirit* [谓之神]. *Void, luminous, subtle, and wondrous without end* [虚明灵妙无穷] is called *not perishing* [谓之不死], which is the *Mysterious Feminine* [即玄牝也]. *Mysterious* [玄] is the *Great Dao* [大道也]. *Feminine* [牝] is the *Mother* [母也]. *One vital breath* [一气] *generates within the void and luminosity* [生於虚明之中], then *clears and turbid divide to establish Heaven and Earth* [然后分清浊立天地], hence it is said: *The Gate of the Mysterious Feminine is the root of Heaven and Earth* [故云玄牝之门，是谓天地根].

*The wondrous Dao acts without action* [妙道无为], *one vital breath runs unceasingly* [一气运行不绝], hence it is called *continuous, as if existing* [是谓绵绵若存]. *Responding to the times, adapting to circumstances* [应时应机], *benefiting life and aiding all things* [利生济物], *accomplished without labor* [不劳而办], hence it is said: *not exerting* [故云不劝].

*Void, luminous, subtle, and wondrous* [虚明灵妙] in humans is called *heart* [在人曰心]. The *heart is sovereign over all phenomena* [心为万法王], capable of *generating Heaven and Earth, running the sun and moon* [能生育天地，运行日月], *wondrous mechanisms and marvelous functions* [玄机妙用], *effortlessly boundless* [任运无穷], *responding to circumstances and sensations* [随缘应感], *accomplished without labor* [不劳而办]. Those who *awaken and clarify* [悟明者] *understand without being told* [不言而知已].

*Zhù Bóxìu* [褚伯秀] says: *The Spirit of Grain does not perish*—*used without exertion* [谷神不死至用之不勤]. *Grain is void yet responsive* [谷虚而善应], *Spirit is luminous yet boundless* [神灵而无方]. If a person *harbors the most luminous essence within the most void place* [人能以至灵之物藏至虚之所], then *they respond to sensations without trace* [则随感而应]. *Response leaves no mark* [应已无迹], *life does not even know its own generation* [生尚不知], *how could death exist* [死乎何有]?

*Mysterious* [玄] refers to *the Dao’s profound, unfathomable nature* [道妙难测], *Feminine* [牝] is *the realm of transformation and nurturing* [化育之地]. Its *function* [其为用也] *is wondrous in generating all things yet eternally generates* [妙万物而能生生], hence it is called *not perishing* [是之谓不死].

This elucidates *the Way of void-hearted spirit-nourishment* [此发明虚心养神之道], borrowing *Heaven and Earth’s creative transformation* [借天地造化为言], beginning with *void-heartedness and yielding to transformation* [始於虚心而任化], ending with *effortless self-transformation* [终於无心而化自己出]. All things’ generation *originates from this* [凡物之生，本莫不由斯], hence it is called *Gate* [故称门焉].

*Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子] says: *The Heavenly Gate* [天门者]—*there is no such thing* [无有也]—*all things emerge from non-being* [二万物出於无有]. In terms of the *Yì* [《易》], this is the *Tàijí* [太极]; in terms of humans, this is *nature* [以人言即性].

The beginning is the *one source* [一化] *awaiting transformation*, the *gathering place of myriad principles and myriad things* [万理众甫之都会].

If each person possesses it fully yet ignores its pursuit, then *the Valley* [谷] *is not truly the Valley*, *the Spirit* [神] *does not manifest itself as Spirit*—how can one relate to Heaven and Earth, to all things?

The *form* [形] *nourishes life*, *the contained qi* [含气] *nourishes life*, and *the primordial spirit* [元神] *nourishes life*.
When these three are regulated and abide, the *Dao flourishes* [生道昌].
Within the body, the *Void-hearted Mother* [身中玄牝] is seen.

Continuously guarding it without loss,
like preserving something in the realm of *faint and elusive* [恍惚],
then what movement could there be?

This chapter’s words are *concise yet profound* [语简意深],
akin to *Mencius* [孟子] discussing the *浩然* [浩然] *qi of righteousness*—
it manifests only after cultivation within the person,
permeating the body as the *Dao itself*.
Those who awaken grasp it naturally;
it cannot be fully exhausted by mere words.

Earlier masters, discussing *Dao* from beyond the orthodox [方外],
often elaborated its *refined essence* [精] yet neglected its *coarse manifestations* [粗],
achieving *transcendence* [上达] but lacking *foundational study* [下学].

*Huǐnyuán* [混元] placed this chapter after *Beauty and Evil, Virtue and Wealth, and the Keys to the Mysteries* [美恶贤货橐钥],
unifying them without separation,
but its language is *profoundly abstruse* [玄奥],
so scholars fear its *height and distance* [高远] and dare not approach it directly.

Now, without heeding my own *shallow inadequacy* [浅陋],
I presume to sketch beyond the shadow—
*the Valley-Spirit* [谷神] *is akin to the Non-ultimate* [无极],
the *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] *is akin to the Tàijí* [太极].
The *continuous method* [绵绵] *mirrors the Tàijí’s* [太极] *pervasive diffusion* [氤氲布化],
giving rise to an unceasing *Dao* [生道不息].

*The Valley* [谷] refers to its *substance* [体],
the *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] to its *transformation* [化],
and *continuous* [绵绵] to its *application* [用].
If one can *inwardly seek it within oneself* [反求诸身],
then self-transformation is achieved.

The *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之根] is *implied without words* [不言而喻].
In the present age, those who practice *life-nourishment* [养生家],
their teachings also center on *Valley-Spirit and Void-hearted Mother* [谷神玄牝],
yet they fixate on *physical form and material essence* [形质],
extracting it from the *kidneys and heart* [心肾], or from *breathing through mouth and nose* [口鼻呼吸].
These are but *later Heaven’s crude residues* [土苴] after all.

As for the *root of Heaven and Earth* [天地之根] and the *origin of myriad things* [万物宗],
they are abandoned and not explored—
how can they illuminate the *wondrous essence of Valley-Spirit* [谷神之妙]?

According to *The Liezi* [《列子》], it cites *The Yellow Emperor’s Book* [《黄帝书》],
which preserves this chapter entirely.
Evidently, these words existed in antiquity,
and *Huǐnyuán* [混元] merely *recounted them without original composition* [述而不作].

*Niú Miào* [牛妙]’s transmission states:
*The Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死], hence it is called *Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝].
*The Valley* [谷] is *nourishment* [养].
*Spirit* [神] is one of the *three highest elixirs* [上药三品] in the *Daoist canon*.
*The Void-hearted Mother* [玄牝] refers to the *two nostrils* [鼻之左右孔].

Thus, *great cultivators* [大修行人] practice the *method of fetal breathing* [胎息法],
from *external Void-hearted Mother* [外玄牝] to *internal Void-hearted Mother* [内玄牝],
guiding and drawing the *true qi of Supreme Harmony* [太和真气],
focusing intent on the *elixir field* [丹田].
With prolonged practice,
their bodies endure eternally—
hence it is said, *the Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死].

*The Jade Purity Fetal Essence Inner Nourishment Classic* [《玉清胎元内养经》] states:
*The wondrous Dao of the Fetal Essence* [胎元妙道],
uniting *external Void-hearted Mother* [外玄牝] with *internal Void-hearted Mother* [内玄牝],
supplementing *external true spirit* [外真神] with *internal true qi* [内真气],
gathering *Heaven’s myriad treasures* [天之万宝] and *my own fetal essence* [我胎之元精],
so that *spirit is born from the fetus* [神生於胎],
*qi clings to the spirit* [气恋於神],
the *heart-sovereign* [心君] *governs in concealment* [潜御],
*breathing is smooth and even* [气息调匀],
*continuous as if preserved yet never ceasing* [绵绵若存而不息],
*endless in its application yet manifesting its efficacy* [用之不穷而见功].
*The Valley-Spirit does not perish* [谷神不死] is the *union with my true origin* [合我真宗].
This is the meaning.

The **Gate of the Mysterious Female**—this is called the **Root of Heaven and Earth**.

Now, the discourse on the Mysterious Female has **inner and outer** aspects. The **outer** has already been explained above; the **inner** is a **mouth-to-mouth transmitted** secret, not recorded in texts. Thus, Zhang Pingzhong’s *Awakening to the True* [《悟真篇》] states:

*The Mysterious Female*—
not the heart, not the kidneys,
not the liver, not the lungs,
not the spleen, not the Triple Burner,
not the bladder, not the elixir field [丹田].

Then what is it?
It is further said:
*The True Mysterious Female, the Mysterious True Female*—
all converge at a single orifice.

Yet this profound principle,
without an enlightened teacher, is difficult to know.

I once read the *Daoist Canon on Cultivation* [《道藏修行论》], which states:
*The Mysterious Female resides between the two kidneys,*
called the **Divine Chamber**—
the **Palace where the Spirit-Sovereigns assemble**,
the **Region where essence and qi intermingle**,
