When the **Buddhist school** reinterpreted them, such language vanished, hence they speak of **true emptiness, real existence**. True emptiness is the meaning of **lack of selfishness**; real existence is the meaning of **fulfilling his own selfishness**. Yet their phrasing, though lofty, is a layer removed.

**Fan Yingyuan** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they attain longevity."* Among formed things, none endure like Heaven and Earth. Both arise from the **Dao**, hence their enduring longevity stems from their **resting in lack of selfishness**, not seeking to benefit themselves, thus they attain eternal life. **Riverbank Master** said: *"This speaks of Heaven and Earth’s eternal life to instruct people."* Therefore, when the Sage arrives, his body is preserved. The Sage is humble and does not contend for precedence, yet people naturally revere him. The Sage does not contend, does not oppose things, yet nothing can harm him. Is it not because of his lack of selfishness? Thus, he fulfills his own selfishness. The Sage fulfills his own selfishness—not in crookedness, not in wickedness—but because common people seek to benefit themselves, hence they cannot attain precedence and preservation, while the Sage’s humility and non-contention alone enable him to attain precedence and preservation.

**Xue Yongqi** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Once form and number are complete, formation and decay are inevitable. Are Heaven and Earth truly enduring? Their enduring longevity comes from **generating without self-generation**, hence their eternal life. Humble yet radiant, low yet uncrossable—placing his body last, yet his body is foremost. Not burdened by death, life, wealth, or nobility, his spirit is whole; externalizing his body, yet his body is preserved. **Emperor Yao** ceded the realm to **Xuyou**, **Emperor Shun** to **Shan Jun**, because of their lack of selfishness, thus they fulfilled their own selfishness.

**Restful Retreat Hermit** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* All formed things escape not the four **kalpas** of arising, dwelling, decay, and emptiness. Only Heaven and Earth endure because they do not self-generate. **Qi** emanates to manifest the **Two Principles**, true **qi** circulating without beginning or end, hence their eternal life. The Sage is the **Three Powers’** manifestation after Heaven and Earth, the world thus formed. **Body foremost**—his luminous true nature precedes the **Great Ultimate** yet is already present. **Externalizing his body, yet his body preserved**—if one establishes the world without clinging, this is called **body beyond things**; though the world decays, true nature does not decay.

「Is it not because of their lack of selfishness? True nature differs from things, thus it can well fulfill its own selfishness.»

**Chu Bo-xiu** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Indeed, since the **cosmic chaos** (*hun-dun*) first divided, the light and clear ascend and float upward, while the heavy and turbid descend and sink downward. The **principle of existence and nonexistence** (*you-wu*) and the **vessel of Dao** (*dao-qi*) rely on each other to stand, spanning the ages without ceasing their transformative and generative processes—thus they endure. Why is this so? It is because they do not self-generate. To self-generate is to cling to self and fail to give birth to things; how could they then endure eternally?

The Sage manifests **body foremost** (*shen-xian*) and **body beyond things** (*wu-wai-shen*), merely abandoning selfishness for the sake of the public, emulating Heaven and following Earth’s ways to nourish the people and cultivate all things. All who practice humility, dwell in lowliness, do not presume to be first, decline merit and yield to ability, and retreat to preserve their whole—these are acts of **body foremost**. Yet when the world joyfully acclaims them, they cannot but assume the lead.

To dwell in humble thatched huts, eat coarse grasses, guard true nature while cherishing self, awaken from the dream of life and death—these are acts of **body beyond things**, yet they surpass the pursuit of noble life, and thus their preservation is inevitable.

The **gentleman** (*jun-zi*) does good, fulfilling what is rightfully his due. Does he seek reward for it? Heaven’s aid to the virtuous is without a shred of private intent; it follows by kindred nature, like an echo answering a call. The Sage embodies Heaven’s impartiality, follows the Dao’s generative virtue, fearing only that one thing might lose its place—thus Heaven’s response and divine blessings are complete. Though human affairs may seem to fulfill selfishness, in truth they arise from Heaven’s utmost impartiality; thus his blessings and rejoicings are without shame.

When the **gentleman** receives blessings, is it not for his own honor? No—it is to extend virtue to the people, broadening Heaven and Earth’s **great virtue** (*da-de*). If one does good while harboring even a trace of selfish gain, then it is not true goodness; its end may even lead to evil. Can one not be cautious at its beginning?

**Niu Miao-zhuan** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Heaven is the accumulation of **yang** (*yang*), thus it can fulfill its function and cover all; it spans the ages without wearing down, hence it is called ‘long.’ Earth is the accumulation of **yin** (*yin*), thus it can fulfill its function and bear all; it endures through the **kalpas** without decay, hence it is called ‘durable.’ Yet why do they endure both long and durable? It is because Heaven and Earth do not presume to be able to endure; thus they endure. They do not presume to be able to fulfill their own selfishness; thus they fulfill it.

**Lie Zi** said: *"There is life that does not generate, and there is non-generation that can generate life. The generating cannot help but generate, thus it is always generating. Always generating is without a time that does not generate, but non-generation is singular. Singular non-generation—its Dao is unfathomable."* Is this not so?

Thus the Sage manifests **body foremost** and **body beyond things**. The Sage is the **humble gentleman** (*qian-qian jun-zi*). Why is this so? Did not Confucius say, *"The Sage—whom I cannot see, but if I see a gentleman, that is enough"*? Those who do not dare to be first, but instead place themselves after others—are they not the **humble gentlemen**?

**Lao Zi** said: *"He who does not dare to be first under Heaven can thus fulfill his function and endure."* Confucius also said: *"First act according to your words, then follow them."* In ancient times, **Hu Qiu Zi Lin** told **Lie Zi**: *"If you know how to hold back, then you can know how to hold yourself."* **Lie Zi** said: *"I wish to hear of holding back."* He replied: *"Look at your shadow, and you will know."* The ancients referred to "you" as "shadow."

**Lie Zi** looked back and observed his shadow: when his form bent, the shadow curved; when his form straightened, the shadow stood upright. Thus, bending and straightening follow his form, not his shadow; yielding and extending follow things, not himself. This is called **holding back while assuming the lead**.

Is this not the saying? **Body beyond things** preserves itself.

The **body** is but the **manifestation** (*wei-xing*) of Heaven and Earth’s entrusted form, thus Dao encompasses the **Four Great Elements** (*si-da*), and **virtue** fulfills the **Five Constants** (*wu-chang*), making it the most **spirited** of all things. Those who value their **body** place merit and fame beyond consideration, store Heaven’s principle within their chests—thus they can preserve their **body**, safeguard their life, and complete their years.

If one flaunts their talents and covets fame, then they cannot escape the afflictions of the **body**. The ancients said: *"Straight wood is felled first; sweet wells run dry first. The elephant loses its life for its tusks; the fragrant pine is burned for its scent."* **Zhuang Zi** said: *"When achievements are complete, the vessel is broken; when fame is attained, the virtue is lost."* Who can abandon fame and achievement, returning to share with the common people?

**Lao Zi** said: *"He who externalizes Heaven and Earth has Heaven and Earth; he who externalizes his body has longevity."* This is the saying.

In the present age, many **gentlemen** endanger their **body** and abandon their life—is this not tragic? Is it not because of their lack of selfishness that they fulfill their own selfishness?

This is truly speaking of the Sage’s **body foremost** and **body beyond things**, not of one who acts without mind. When the Sage assumes **body foremost** and **body beyond things** to fulfill the policies of the Sage, it is indeed due to the operation of selfishness—thus it is called *fulfill their own selfishness*.

The **lack of selfishness** is to say **non-action** (*wu-wei*). *Fulfilling their own selfishness* is **action** (*you-wei*). Moreover, there is no affair under Heaven that can be accomplished without action or achieved without effort. **Non-action** is the Sage’s **true nature** (*ti*); **action** is the Sage’s **application** (*yong*). When **true nature** and **application** are both complete, only then does the Sage’s Dao manifest—how could one cling to **non-action** and hinder *fulfilling their own selfishness*?

If a person lacks selfishness, then how do they differ from **clay and wooden figures** (*tu-mu ou-ren*)? **Lao Zi** said: *"If one speaks of ‘no mind,’ then Dao itself has no mind. It is still one layer of mountain apart."* This is truly speaking of knowing **true nature** but not **application**.

**Yang Zhi-ren** said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Heaven’s **emptiness** (*xu*) reaches its utmost, thus it endures; Earth’s **thick bearing** (*hou-zai*) is vast, thus it is durable. Because they do not self-generate, they rely on the **rotation of the sun and moon** (*ri-yue xuan-zhuan*) to generate, thus they can fulfill their own selfishness. If Heaven did not rotate, the sun and moon would not shine; if Earth were to dry up, all things would not generate.

The **human body**—its **inherent nature** (*ben-xing*) is called Heaven; its **original mandate** (*yuan-ming*) is called Earth.

If **life and nature** are both preserved and cultivated according to the Dao, one may endure as long as Heaven and Earth.

Thus, the virtuous person practices humility, retreat, and self-effacement, placing themselves last, yet others revere them and they lead by example. Those who can cultivate the **outer body** beyond the body, who know the **spirit within the spirit**, the **true nature within nature**, and the **Dao within the Dao**, are those who can transcend the body and attain eternal preservation.

Is it not because the Sage achieves this through their **public virtue and selflessness**? Hence, by being selfless yet abundant, they fulfill their own **selfishness**.

*The Doctrine of the Mean* states:
*"The utmost sincerity knows no exhaustion. Without exhaustion, it endures; enduring, it manifests; manifesting, the heart becomes vast and enduring. Vast and enduring, it becomes lofty and bright. Vast and enduring—this is what bears all things. Lofty and bright—this is what covers all things. Vast and enduring—this is what completes all things. Vast and enduring correspond to Earth; lofty and bright correspond to Heaven; vast and enduring are boundless. Thus, it shines without being seen, transforms without moving, and achieves without action. The Dao of Heaven and Earth can be fully expressed in a single word."*

Yù Qīngzhōng said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Heaven, with its **primordial qi** (*yīyuán zhī qì*), circulates across the **four directions** without interruption or cessation, hence its endurance. Earth, in its **submissive form**, bears all things and remains constant, lacking nothing and leaning on nothing, hence its durability. Yet what enables their eternal endurance?

It is because they generate all things without claiming credit. All things cannot generate themselves; they must rely on Heaven and Earth for their existence. Heaven and Earth do not take credit for generating all things but grow alongside them. Thus, the generator of all things is Heaven and Earth, and their **eternal generation** is what allows all things to thrive. **Eternal life** is spoken of when generation is mentioned, for endurance is inherent within it.

The heart of Heaven and Earth is a heart of **universal impartiality**. The Sage embodies this universal impartiality of Heaven and Earth, placing themselves after Heaven and Earth yet leading in heart. They place themselves last, yet others revere them first.

Not possessing what they have, they preserve it. They transcend the body, yet the body endures. Is this not because selflessness enables such attainment? Selflessness is universality—only the selfless can truly fulfill their own selfishness. Those who embody the **Heavenly Mandate** naturally return to it, without expectation or contrivance. Though it seems selfish, it is truly universal.

Xū Liùxū said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they attain eternal life."* Heaven’s endurance and Earth’s durability—this is the central theme of this passage. What follows is its elucidation. Yet by reasoning that they do not generate themselves, one concludes that Heaven and Earth endure and last because they do not contrive their own existence. If Heaven and Earth had a self-serving intent to prolong their lives, how could they truly endure?

Thus, when the Sage arrives, the body is preserved. The Sage places themselves last, yet others revere them first, following the Dao of Heaven and Earth in not generating themselves. They hold fast to humility and retreat, so the world naturally honors them as first. Those who transcend the body know that the body is not truly theirs; through **non-action, tranquility, and emptiness**, nothing can harm them. The body is naturally transcended—not by deliberate effort, but by natural detachment. Thus, the body is preserved.

Is this not because of their selflessness? Hence, they fulfill their own selfishness.

The Sages attain **leading by example and eternal preservation** because they follow the Dao of Heaven and Earth in not generating themselves, not by selfish intent. Thus, they achieve the fulfillment of **leading by example and eternal preservation**.

Chái Yuángāo said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally—unchangeably."* Heaven and Earth endure because they fulfill their roles of covering and bearing all things, shaping forms naturally without contrivance. Thus, when the Sage arrives, the body is preserved. They diminish themselves to enrich others; others naturally honor them. They abandon self for the benefit of all, yet do not take from others. They do not act selfishly, yet fulfill their own selfishness. They forget their own selfish desires and fulfill the expectations of others. This is how the Sage aligns with the enduring Dao of Heaven and Earth.

Sū Jìngjìng said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* Since ancient times, none have matched Heaven and Earth in endurance. Yet who truly understands why Heaven and Earth endure? The **Supreme Ultimate Dao** truly generates them, yet Heaven and Earth do not generate themselves. If they were to grow alongside all things, they would merely be one thing among many—how could they then attain eternal life?

Heaven and Earth stand above all things, yet do not compete with them, thus they endure eternally. The Sage understands this, always placing the world before themselves and their body last. When the people are hungry, they dare not indulge in satiety while others starve; when the people are cold, they dare not wear heavy garments while others shiver. They treat the people with the intimacy of father and son, yet do not dare to neglect them as distant relatives; they treat them as brothers, yet do not dare to exclude them.

Though the Sage places themselves last, the world reveres them first. Though they transcend the body, the world preserves them. Just as Heaven and Earth, by not generating themselves, endure eternally in their generation, so too does the Sage, by placing themselves last and transcending the body, not dare to act selfishly for their own sake. Yet the people wish to honor the Sage’s body, to preserve the Sage’s life. The Sage wishes to retreat, yet the people honor them first; the Sage wishes to transcend, yet the people preserve them. Is this not fulfilling their own selfishness?

Thus, it is known that those who are not self-serving are truly able to fulfill their selfishness.

Běn Yī’ān Chúshì said: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally, thus they fulfill their own selfishness."* To complete all things is to complete oneself. Common people see the self and others as distinct, thus they eagerly seek to fulfill their selfishness. Yet those who are selfish ultimately gain no benefit, while those who are selfless paradoxically achieve self-fulfillment. This is the natural order.

Now, consider how Heaven and Earth treat all things: they scatter with wind and nourish with rain, stir with thunder and illuminate with sun and moon. All is done solely for the sake of generating all things.

The movement and circulation of all things never cease—
this is how they endure eternally.

The Sage’s governance diminishes the high to benefit the low,
sets aside the self to follow others.
Yet when the people are amply provided for, who is there to suffer want?
There has never been one who, being kind, abandoned their kin,
or who, upholding righteousness, delayed serving their lord—
what greater benefit could there be?

If people understand this, they may broaden their vision beyond the self
and expand their heart toward the great public good.

Stone Pool [said]: *"Heaven and Earth endure eternally.*
The reason Heaven and Earth can endure so long is that they do not generate themselves—
thus they attain eternal life.
Therefore, the Sage places himself last, yet his worth is foremost;
sets himself aside, yet his essence remains.
Is this not because of their lack of selfishness?
Thus they fulfill their own selfishness."

Yet interpretations of this passage differ.
The ancients held that Heaven and Earth’s eternal life was like a person’s longevity—
their enduring existence.
Modern commentators argue that *generating* refers to generating all things,
meaning Heaven and Earth merely generate others without generating themselves—
what is called ‘not generating yet generating generation.’

However, examining the latter passage, both interpretations have merit.
When it speaks of ‘placing himself last’ and ‘setting himself aside,’
this is the generation of all things.
When it speaks of ‘his worth being foremost’ and ‘his essence remaining,’
this is the generation of longevity.
If we speak of their lack of selfishness, it is the generation of all things.
If we speak of fulfilling their selfishness, it is the generation of longevity.

To unify these, the ‘not generating themselves’ refers to generating all things,
while ‘eternal life’ pertains to longevity.
Though Heaven and Earth cannot be spoken of in terms of life and death,
their enduring existence is eternal life itself.

Evaluating thus, Laozi’s intent is precisely that Heaven and Earth,
by generating all things without selfishness, attain eternal endurance.
If people can abandon selfishness to seek life,
they too may endure eternally.

Yet Laozi’s teaching truly seeks eternal life—
why then does he speak thus?
Fundamentally, this passage connects with the later chapter on *Entering and Exiting Life and Death*.
For people’s pursuit of life often harms it—
like trampling seedlings to hasten growth—
leading to self-destruction, as if driving them to their death.
Only by nurturing gently, without excessive effort,
as indicated in the *Spirit of the Upper Valley* chapter,
can one attain eternal life without striving for it.

*(End of Volume Twelve of *Collected Meanings of the Dao De Jing*)
#1 *Wuqi wuqi*: The *Liezi*’s *Heavenly Blessings* chapter reads *"wu chu wu qi"* [without place, without qi].
#2 *"Fei yi qi wu si ye"* [Is this not because of their lack of selfishness?]: *"Ye"* likely replaces *"ji"* [immediately].
#3 *"Zheng ze xin youjiu"* [Then the heart is enduring]: The current *Zhongyong* lacks the character *"xin"* [heart].

「The *Dao De Jing* annotated by Master Liu Weiyong, verified by the former court’s Grandee and Treasurer Ding Yidong, also a Compiler of the Secretariat
**Chapter on the Supreme Virtue of Water** (考异: *He Shang Gong*’s *Chapter on Changing Nature*, Zhao Shixian’s *Chapter on Gentle Compliance and Rectifying Justice*)

**Emperor Xuanzong of Tang’s Commentary:**
The preceding chapter illuminated the Way’s boundless virtue—Heaven and Earth are without selfishness, thus enduring forever.
This chapter clarifies that the Sage, like water in its gentle flow, incurs no blame.
It begins with the metaphor of water, showing how its three virtues approach the Dao.
Next, it states that water dwells in the lowly, embodying the seven supreme qualities in benefiting all.
It concludes with *not contending*, urging adherence to gentleness to preserve ultimate victory.

Du Guangting says:
Water’s virtue is gentle and yielding, serene and harmonious,
dwelling in compliance, flowing downward—
swelling or dispersing with the seasons, adapting to vessels’ shapes,
becoming springs or scattering as mist and dew.
All things lose it and die; gain it and live.
Strike it and it is unharmed; grasp it and it slips away.
Yet it does not fully reach the Dao,
for water has form while the Dao is formless.
Though form may hinder, in its virtue of benefiting all
and its humble use, water nears the Dao.

The *Dao De Jing* uses water as an analogy
to exhort those cultivating the Dao,
urging them to embody the seven virtues and three abilities,
to refine their person and govern the realm,
while preserving the virtue of *not contending*—
thus avoiding blame or fault.

Zhang Chongying responds:
This *nature* refers to the character one cultivates after growth.
Humans inherit the *qi* of Heaven and Earth,
and originally have no vice—
but as they grow, emotions disrupt them,
stirring the five desires,
and their nature becomes mostly unvirtuous.
Thus, people abandon the Dao and ruin themselves,
yet fail to repent.
This chapter admonishes those who let their cultivated nature run wild,
urging them to restrain it
and thereby advance toward the Dao.
For its virtue is like water’s:
Water benefits all things without contending,
dwelling where others abhor.
Thus it nearly attains the Dao.

It dwells in the lowly—
Water’s nature is pure,
flowing over earth’s grass and trees,
then descending—
akin to the receptive yielding of the female.
Its heart is deep—
Water is profound and empty,
its depths clear and luminous.
Its giving is benevolent—
All things receive water and flourish;
it fills the void, never the full.
Its speech is trustworthy—
Water’s inner reflection reveals truth,
its form never betraying its essence.
Its governance is harmonious—
It cleanses all without exception.
Its deeds are accomplished—
It adapts to square or round,
bending or straightening as needed.
Its movement is timely—
It disperses in summer, congeals in winter,
acting in accordance with the seasons.
Only because it does not contend,
it incurs no blame.
Thus, the world finds no fault with water.

Wang Fusi says:
The Sage’s virtue, like water, nears the Dao—
Humans abhor the lowly,
yet water, dwelling there, nearly attains the Dao.
The Dao lacks what water has,
thus it is called *nearly*.

Water’s dwelling in the lowly extends to its virtue of *no blame*—
This shows that water conforms to this Dao.

Emperor Xuanzong says:
The Sage’s virtue, like water—
This illustrates the Sage’s supreme virtue.
Thus, water’s nature is used as the analogy nearing the Dao.
**Commentary:**
*Supreme virtue* refers to the Sage’s conduct.
*Like water* is metaphor.
The Sage’s actions embody water’s virtues,
all detailed below, each containing a deeper meaning.

Water’s virtue benefits all, even where others abhor—
**Commentary:**
Water is sweet and deep,
spreading everywhere,
nourishing what it touches—
those who receive its blessings grow,
thus it is called *beneficial*.
This is its first ability.

No thing is softer than water,
yet it can be modeled—
clear, it reflects truth;
flowing, it fills valleys,
carrying all in its current—
it brings harmony where others seek it,
yet never contends.
This is its second ability.

Others shun the lowly and impure,
yet water accepts it,
dwelling in filth without complaint.
This is its third ability.
Thus it nearly attains the Dao.

*Near* means *close*.
**Commentary:**
Its benefiting all is manifest,
its not contending shows gentleness,
its dwelling in filth demonstrates tolerance—
these are water’s three abilities.
Only the Sage consistently embodies them,
thus his conduct nears the Dao without straying far.
Hence, it is said *close*.

It dwells in the lowly—
The Sage’s person is gentle and yielding,
like water’s flowing downward,
nourishing all.
Earth’s nature is lowly,
yet water favors descending there.
**Commentary:**
The Sage’s dwelling is beneficial,
like water’s flowing on earth—
the more it benefits, the greater its virtue.
Earth’s virtue lies in its lowliness,
and water descends naturally.
This mirrors the Sage’s humility,
nearing the Dao’s gentle nature,
thus it is said *dwelling in the lowly*.

Its heart is deep—
The Sage’s mind is profound and still,
like water’s resting in springs.
**Commentary:**
The Sage’s mind excels in tranquility,
like water’s nature—
calm, it becomes clear;
at ease, it attains insight.
*Springs* symbolize deep stillness.
Thus it is said *heart is deep*.

Its giving is benevolent—
His generosity aligns with supreme benevolence,
like water’s nourishing all things.

**Commentary:**
The Supreme Benevolence of boundless aid
always gives to others,
and its generous deeds align with virtuous conduct,
like water nourishing all—
without favor or aversion.
Thus it is said: *giving is transformative*.

**On truthful speech:**
Words must be sincere and true,
like water flowing through perilous paths—
never failing in its constancy.
**Commentary:**
The Superior Person’s speech is ever true,
guiding the common folk,
truthful without deceit,
like springs that flow—
how could they differ in their steadfastness?
Thus it is said: *speech is truthful*.

**On skillful governance:**
To govern well is to regulate,
like water cleansing all things,
making them pure and cool.
**Commentary:**
Governance means rectification.
The Superior Person, in all actions,
acts without contrivance,
rectifies appearance to enlighten beings—
beings follow what is rectified,
and rectification brings order.
What could be better than this?
Like water’s nature, cleansing all things,
making them pure.
Thus it is said: *governance is skillful*.

**On capable action:**
In all undertakings, one adapts with ease,
like water’s nature—
square in a square vessel, round in a round one,
never hindered by form.
**Commentary:**
The Superior Person is all-encompassing,
unobstructed by things.
Whatever moves or acts,
all matters are traversed—
traversed, thus capable.
This is clarity and insight.
Like water’s nature—
when it flows as rivers,
when dammed, it becomes earth;
floating boats, embracing emptiness—
what it cannot do?
This is capability.
Thus it is said: *action is capable*.

**On timely response:**
Things move and one responds,
never missing the moment.
Like water’s thawing in spring and freezing in winter.
**Commentary:**
The Superior Person’s heart
is like an empty valley,
a mirror’s reflection—
when things stir, it responds.
Like water’s nature—
thawing in spring, freezing in winter,
rising and falling with the seasons.
Thus it is said: *response is timely*.

**On non-contention:**
Only the non-contending
has no blame.
The Superior Person, with a vacant heart,
follows things naturally,
like water—
when dammed, it flows elsewhere.
It never opposes things,
thus there is no blame.
**Commentary:**
Blame means fault.
The Superior Person’s conduct
harms no being,
vacant-hearted and complete,
never competing—
waves ebb and flow,
yielding thus,
never opposing things,
so there is no blame.
Du Guangting says:
*The Superior is like water.*
The Superior cultivates the Dao and refines the heart,
adapting to changes with the times,
moving freely to benefit beings.
The Master Lao wished to reveal the Superior’s virtue
to encourage later learners,
comparing water to the Dao,
thus using water as an analogy.
The Superior’s goodness
forgets its own goodness,
like water not boasting of its deeds—
water’s deeds are greater when unboasted,
virtue shines brighter when unvaunted.
Great and bright,
this is the highest goodness.

From the sovereign on high
to the recluse in the rocks,
if one is like water,
then the Dao is attained.
The analogy uses water as metaphor,
the Dao as principle,
and the Superior Person as its practitioner.

Water excels in benefiting what others despise.
Sweetness is water’s flavor.
Depth is water’s essence.
Water is the mother of *qi*,
ruling the North,
its virtue is to nourish below.
Its color is black,
its nature is wisdom,
its taste is salty,
its number is six.
The North is the beginning of Yang virtue,
the end of Yin *qi*.
Its generative number is one,
matching the Dao.
The Dao is also one—
the one without a one,
water is also one—
the one with a one.
The one without a one is the Dao’s essence,
the one with a one is the Dao’s function.
Thus, water is the Dao’s function.
All things rely on its nourishment to flourish,
and because it nourishes,
it gives rise to all things,
thus it ranks first among the three capabilities.

Gentleness is water’s virtue.
*The Dao De Jing*, Chapter 41, says:
*Nothing in the world is softer than water,*
*yet it overcomes the hardest things.*
Again, water’s virtue is emphasized to encourage embracing gentleness.

Water, when level, does not flow;
law follows equanimity as its foundation,
thus it can be emulated.
Water’s stillness reflects things.
Hence it is said:
*No one mirrors themselves in flowing water,*
*but in still water.*
Because it is clear and tranquil.
Water’s nature is level—
when encountering unevenness, it passes;
when meeting marshes, it stops.
East, west, south, north—
it follows where it is led,
never contending with others,
nothing it cannot traverse.
Comparing all virtues,
it is said its generative function is unmatched,
thus it ranks second among the three capabilities.

Human nature follows convention for the many,
but few are humble and yielding.
Most love high positions,
fearing lowly ones.
Only water
dwells low without contention,
resides in filth without shame.
Compared to the previous virtues,
this one surpasses them,
thus it ranks third among the three capabilities.
Thus it nears the Dao.

If the ruler embodies the virtue of boundless aid,
holds a humble and yielding heart,
and practices containing impurity,
then the world will be at peace.
For those cultivating the self,
their efforts extend to all things—
gentleness governs nature,
dwelling in filth to follow the common,
abandoning traces while humbly shining,
then immortality may be hoped for.

**On dwelling in the lowly:**
This clarifies delighting in humility
as the way to preserve the state and body.
The sky’s purity and lightness
make it use its height,
the earth’s turbidity and thickness
make it rest in lowliness.
*The Book of Changes* says:
*The sky is exalted, the earth is lowly,*
*low and high are arranged.*
Again:
*The earth’s way is low yet ascends.*
Water follows lowliness and dwells beneath,
mirroring the Superior’s humble virtue.

**On a profound heart:**
This clarifies clarity, tranquility, and emptiness
as the method for purifying the self and washing the heart.
*A minister’s heart is like water,*
*a minister’s gate is like a market.*
Is this not so?

**On generous giving:**
This clarifies nourishing all things
as the conduct of universal aid and rescue.
The more one gives to others,
the more one possesses;
the more one gives away,
the more one has.
This is the meaning.

**On truthful speech:**
This clarifies sincerity without deceit
as the eternal and verified teaching.
*Flowing through peril does not lose its truth*—
*The Book of Changes*, the *Kàn* hexagram, says:
*Habitual Kàn—*
*double peril.*

「Water flows yet never overflows,
*it moves through peril without losing its truth.*

**On governing the state and nurturing the people:**
To lead by the Dao/Way, one must first embody it oneself—
speaking only what is true and sincere,
so as to stir the heavens and earth,
and awaken the luminous spirits.
Thus, words of good and evil arise within a single chamber,
yet echo across a thousand leagues—
*this is the utmost truthfulness.*

Confucius said:
*"Remove food and arms, yet let truthfulness remain."*
*How profound his words were!*

**On virtuous governance:**
This clarifies the true and authentic transformation of all things,
as the method to transcend the ordinary and attain the sage’s path.

*One who embodies true virtue and understands all things*—
as in the *Zhuangzi*’s *□Dianzi Fang* chapter:
Dianzi, whose name means "Unselective," attended upon Wei Wenhou.
Wenhou studied with Zixia and befriended Dianzi.
Dianzi often praised the Dao/Way of the *Xigong*,
and Wenhou took the *Xigong* as Dianzi’s teacher.
Dianzi said:
*"No, the *Xigong* is merely a neighbor from my village.
I frequently speak of the Dao/Way correctly,
so the *Xigong* praises me.
My true teacher is Dongguo Shunzi.
He is a man of true virtue—
his outward form reflects humanity,
yet his inner nature aligns with the Dao/Way,
preserving purity and clarity while embracing all things.
Things lack no Dao/Way when he appears,
for his bearing awakens understanding in others,
dissolving all false intentions.
How could I, Unselective, ever compare to him?
This is when things lose their Dao/Way,
and Dongguo Shunzi corrects his bearing,
his heart merging with the Way,
while things behold him and naturally awaken—
false desires utterly vanish.
*This may truly be called*
*the Dao/Way that acts without words,
and transforms without exertion.*
*How profound the true Dao/Way is!*

**On skillful action:**
This clarifies following natural tendencies and adapting to circumstances,
as the method of flexible, responsive, and harmonious conduct.

Water conforms to square or round vessels,
and its flow adjusts to blockages or releases—
thus it can traverse seas and float beneath the heavens,
*expansive and vast.*
A ruler governs by natural order,
delegating tasks to the worthy,
using them without doubt,
each fulfilling their role—
*then governance requires no effort,*
and peace prevails in all things.

**On timely action:**
This clarifies rising and retreating according to the times,
as the precept to uphold the Dao/Way and preserve life.

*Pan*—to disperse—
spring spreads the warmth of yang,
layered ice melts and disperses,
winter brings cold and harshness,
yet flowing waters solidify and freeze—
*water follows the seasons.*

The Way of governing the state,
the method of cultivating oneself,
expands or contracts with the times,
following the nature of things—
*then one attains the utmost principle,*
*then one preserves life.*

**On the virtue of non-contention:**
Only by not contending does one avoid blame.
The virtue of non-contention is the foremost virtue.
Human nature cannot avoid contention,
yet those who contend are many:
*obstinate defiance contends,*
*violence and arrogance contend,*
*anger and rage contend,*
*excess and waste contend,*
*boastfulness and self-aggrandizement contend,*
*love of victory and rivalry contend,*
*disturbance and obstruction contend,*
*greed and ambition contend,*
*courage and cowardice contend,*
*love and hatred contend,*
*selfishness and tyranny contend,*
*favoritism and partiality contend.*

If a king harbors even one of these,
*he will raise armies throughout the land.*
If a feudal lord harbors even one of these,
*their states will clash in war.*

**On the Virtue of Non-Contention in the Common and the Lowly:**

If a high official harbors even one of these [vices],
*he will bring ruin to his household.*
If a commoner harbors even one of these,
*harm will arise within himself.*

All such contention stems from
*lack of thought and reflection,*
*transgressing rites and laws,*
*without fear or reverence,*
*without tolerance or forbearance—*
*thus contention arises.*

Therefore, those who contend over cities
*fill the city with slaughtered men,*
and those who contend over land
*fill the fields with slaughtered men.*
One must examine the roots of contention,
*block its source,*
*and then all will be in harmony.*

The saying goes:
*The virtuous person contends not.*
Again it is said:
*In ugliness, one does not contend.*
The lower scriptures say:
*The Dao of the Sage is to act without contending.*
What fault could there be in the virtue of non-contention?

**The Four Virtues of the Highest Good:**

*The Empty-Hearted*—
*the empty-hearted have no desires.*
*The Flexibly Whole*—
*the flexibly whole bend themselves to preserve others.*
*The Flowing Wave*—
*the flowing wave follows nature’s ease,*
*the decadent and slack—*
*the decadent and slack abandon restraint without hindrance.*

*The Flowing Wave*—
As *Zhuangzi* says in *"The Response of the Emperor"*:
*"Transformation and decay flow like the tides,*
*the affairs of the world surge like waves—*
*nothing remains unchanged."*

*The Yielding-Compliant*—
*the yielding-compliant surrender their heart to the Way.*

**The Three Abilities:**
To embody these four virtues,
to follow these three abilities—
*this is the key to national peace and longevity.*

As *Dao Jun of Song* said:
*The highest good is like water.*

*The Book of Changes* says:
*"The interplay of yin and yang is called the Dao,*
*and what follows it is called virtue."*
*Zhuangzi* says:
*"To separate virtue from the Dao."*

Once virtue is named,
*the essence of the Dao is diminished.*
Yet heaven generates water from the One,
*not yet far from the Dao.*
Deep and void, still and clear—
*this is called the utmost refinement in the world.*

Thus, the highest good is like water.
Water is supremely beneficial,
*nearly approaching the Dao.*

It condenses into rain and dew,
*nourishing all things;*
it freezes into frost and snow,
*forming all treasures;*
it flows as rivers and lakes,
*gathering in pools and marshes.*
Deep springs and vast seas
*draw and store,*
*enriching life and growth—*
*all things rely on it without depletion.*
In benefiting others,
*what is more excellent than this?*

Benefiting all things,
*all things receive its grace,*
*its bestowal,*
*yet it remains in the humble, weak, non-contending place.*
It absorbs filth and dirt,
*without burdening itself with self-regard,*
*thus it is close to the Dao.*

*Ji*—near.

**The Six Virtues of Water:**

*Residing in the good place.*
Flowing through the earth,
*it fills without overflowing.*
*The good heart is deep.*
*The deeper it is measured,*
*the deeper it becomes;*
*the further it is explored,*
*the more distant it grows.*
*The good is kind.*
*It loves all without partiality,*
*gives without choosing.*
*The good word is trustworthy.*
*Avoiding obstacles, it reaches the seas;*
*traversing dangers, it never loses its truth.*
*The good governance is orderly.*
*It purifies the impure,*
*levels the steep,*
*follows nature effortlessly,*
*without scheming in its heart—*
*thus all is governed.*
*The good skill is adaptable.*
*It bends to the land’s curves and straightness,*
*to the vessel’s roundness and angles;*
*it adapts to constant change*
*yet remains ever balanced.*
*The good action is timely.*
*When released, it flows east;*
*when directed, it flows west—*
*it moves without constraint,*
*proper only in its season.*

Only by not contending
*does one avoid blame.*

The Sage embodies the Dao,
*thus preserving the body for enduring life,*
*and benefiting others*
*while dwelling in the non-contending place.*

*Zhuangzi* says:
*"Is it easy to have and yet do nothing with it?"*
*It is easy to do nothing and commit few faults,*
*but difficult to act and yet have no regrets.*
*Once one benefits others through action,*
*to remain blameless becomes difficult.*

The highest good benefits others like water’s nature—
*it benefits without choosing what to benefit,*
*it does not contend with others,*
*and thus none can contend with it,*
*hence no blame arises.*

Thus it is said:
*"Under heaven, nothing is as soft and weak as water,*
*yet in attacking the hard and strong,*
*nothing can surpass it."*

*Wang Anshi* said:
*The highest good is like water.*
*What is called "good" can follow the Dao,*
*yet it cannot exhaust the Dao—*
*thus the person of highest good is like water.*

Water’s nature is to benefit all things,
*all things rely on water to live,*
*yet water’s nature is supremely soft and weak—*
*thus it does not contend.*

People prefer the high and despise the low,
*yet water dwells where people despise.*

**Residing in the good place—**
*The good place is low.*
**The good heart is deep—**
*Deep is still.*
**The good is kind—**
*It gives without seeking return.*
**The good word is trustworthy—**
*Even if bent a thousand times, it flows east.*
**The good governance is orderly—**
*The most yielding overcomes the world’s hardness.*
**The good skill is adaptable—**
*If square, it becomes square; if round, it becomes round.*
**The good action is timely—**
*In spring it rises; in winter it freezes.*

As *Su Yingbin* said:
*The highest good is like water,*
*thus nearly approaching the Dao.*

*The Book of Changes* says:
*"The interplay of yin and yang is called the Dao,*
*and what follows it is called virtue,*
*what fulfills it is called nature."*
*Again it says:*
*"Heaven generates water from the One."*
*Just as the Dao moves to become virtue,*
*so too does qi move to generate water.*
Thus it is said:
*The highest good is like water.*

Both arise from the formless and take form—
*their principles are the same.*
The Dao is everywhere, benefiting all,
*and so too is water.*

Yet once they have taken form,
*they diverge from the Dao.*
Thus it is said:
*"Nearly approaching the Dao."*

Yet nothing can be named as good
*as this—*
*thus it is called the highest good.*

**From Residing in the Good Place to Acting in Due Time:**

*Avoiding the high, seeking the low,*
*never opposing—*
*this is the good place;*
*Empty, still, silent, unfathomable—*
*this is the good depth;*
*Benefiting all things,*
*giving without seeking return—*
*this is the good kindness;*
*Round, it turns; square, it bends;*
*blocked, it stops; released, it flows—*
*this is the good trustworthiness;*
*Purifying all filth,*
*leveling high and low—*
*this is the good governance;*
*Encountering things, it takes their form,*
*yet does not cling to one—*
*this is the good skill;*
*In winter it freezes, in spring it thaws,*
*in drought it recedes, in flood it swells—*
*this is the good timing.*

Only by not contending
*does one avoid blame.*

Even if one has virtue,
*they are not free from human censure—*
*for they contend.*

**The Virtue of Water: The Supreme Good**

Water alone does not contend,
and thus it encompasses the seven virtues without blame.

**Lǚ Jìfǔ said:**
*The Supreme Good is like water.*

The interplay of yin and yang—this is the Dao.
What follows is virtue.

To call it "following" is already to depart from the Dao,
and thus it is no longer the body of the Dao itself.
The Supreme Good is the Dao’s own virtue.

Not all under heaven know virtue as virtue,
and so it is like water.

Water’s virtue is in its utility—
it nearly attains the Dao.

For water benefits all things without contending,
dwelling where others abhor.

And so the Supreme Good does likewise—
yet this is still not the Dao itself,
but nearly so.

**Residing in the Good Place.**
The rivers and seas rule over all valleys
because they are low.
Thus, to dwell is to be in the Good Place.

**The Heart as the Good Depth.**
The stillness of stagnant water is a depth,
the flow of moving water is a depth,
and the discernment of the *guīhuáng* is a depth.
Thus, the heart is the Good Depth.

**Giving is Good Kindness, Speech is Good Trustworthiness.**
It overflows without filling,
it pours without exhausting—
thus, to give is Good Kindness.

It ventures upon dangers without failing in trust—
thus, speech is Good Trustworthiness.

**Governance is Good Governance.**
Its branches become rivers and valleys,
its gathering becomes the seas—
sufficient for governance, it is Good Governance.

**Action is Good Skill.**
Good governance: nothing is softer or weaker than water,
yet nothing surpasses it in overcoming the firm and strong.
Thus, in action, it is Good Skill.

**Movement is Good Timing.**
Sources gush ceaselessly, day and night,
filling the basin before advancing.
Only by not contending
does one avoid blame.

In essence, to emerge without contending
and to take dwelling as foundation—
thus it is said:
*Only by not contending*
*does one take first place under heaven.*

**Wáng Yuànzé said:**
*The Supreme Good is like water.*
Water is the first of the Five Phases,
emerging from emptiness into substance.
Not far from the Dao, its nature is closest to it.

For when one departs from the Dao, virtue is established,
and the Supreme Good is like water—
a natural principle of things.

Water’s virtue is in its utility—
it nearly attains the Dao.

Humans have two hearts—fire—
fire ascends and shines,
and thus they love to contend.
Only when the will aligns with the Dao
can one transcend things without the heart overcoming them.

**Residing in the Good Place.**
Descending and flowing.

**The Heart as the Good Depth.**
Deep, still, and level—
internally bright, externally obscured.

**Governance is Good Governance.**
Following nature rather than emotion,
accumulating softness to bear great weight.

**Action is Good Skill.**
Adapting to change—
thus, nothing is beyond its ability.

**Movement is Good Timing.**
If obstructed, it stops;
if released, it flows.
It does not move before things,
yet it does not lose its timing.

Only by not contending
does one avoid blame.

Water’s unity is unassailable by things,
and thus it encompasses these virtues.

For it has virtue toward things
while always descending before them—
this is why it has virtue.

If one were to willfully seek virtue,
they could not fulfill it.

Thus, the text concludes by reiterating this.

**Liú Shēnpíng said:**
*The Supreme Good is like water.*
Emerging from non-being into being,
dwelling in what is despised without contending,
yet benefiting things—
water’s use here is nearest to the Supreme Good.

When the heart embodies this, its name is established,
and so it is said to be *like* water.

**Giving is Good Kindness, Governance is Good Governance.**
Yet water itself has no governance—
why then speak of trustworthiness and governance?

Because in discussing the virtuous person as water,
we extend governance to the virtuous person as well.

**Movement is Good Timing.**
Virtue inheres in water,
and exhausts itself in my own goodness.

Goodness is goodness—
thus, to dwell is to rest in the Good Place,
the heart to abide in the Good Depth,
giving to balance Good Kindness,
speech to uphold Good Trustworthiness,
action to deploy Good Skill,
movement to follow Good Timing.

From *Záshuō*:
*Movement is Good Timing*—
for it moves in accordance with time,
and this is the goodness of movement.

The *Shū* also says:
*"Consider well before acting,
and act only in its proper time."*

The *Shī* praises Nán Zhòng’s thin assault on the Western Róng,
yet speaks of the chirping grass insects and the leaping *fúzhōng*—
for their movement follows its response.

If one does not move in accordance with time,
how could one attain this?

**Liú Jùjì said:**
*The Supreme Good is like water.*

The *Yì* says: *"What follows the Dao is virtue."*
The *Zhuāngzǐ* says: *"To depart from the Dao is to establish virtue."*
Both mean that from the Dao downward,
none are closer to virtue than this.

Virtue without its own virtue—
this is the Supreme Good,
like the Supreme Virtue’s goodness.

Water’s virtue is in its utility—
it nearly attains the Dao.

The Dao generates Oneness,
Oneness generates Water—
thus, water is near the Dao.

Water’s virtue is in its moistening—
this is called *utility*.
Good timing is called *not contending*.
Descending is called *dwelling in what is despised*.

To benefit others without boasting
is like water’s utility without contending.

To place oneself below others
is like water dwelling where others abhor.

The Dao also benefits all things without contending,
dwelling where others abhor—
and water is like this.

If water is like the Dao,
then the Supreme Good is like water.

This is why it is near the Dao.

**Residing in the Good Place.**
Virtue takes dwelling in lowliness as its place,
water takes descending as its place—
in virtue, it attains water’s place,
and so it is said: *Residing in the Good Place.*

**The Heart as the Good Depth.**
Virtue takes stillness as its heart,
water takes depth and stillness as its depth—
in virtue, it attains water’s depth,
and so it is said: *The Heart as the Good Depth.*

**Giving is Good Kindness, Speech is Good Trustworthiness.**
Virtue takes teaching others as giving,
water takes benefiting things as kindness—
in virtue, it attains water’s kindness,
and so it is said: *Giving is Good Kindness.*

Virtue takes honesty as speech,
water takes venturing upon dangers without failing in trust—
in water, it attains water’s trustworthiness,
and so it is said: *Speech is Good Trustworthiness.*

**Governance is Good Governance.**
Virtue takes rectifying oneself and others as governance,
water takes stirring and separating the pure and turbid as governance—
in virtue, it attains water’s governance,
and so it is said: *Governance is Good Governance.*

**Action is Good Skill.**
Virtue takes harmony as action,
water takes rounding and squaring without obstruction as skill—
in virtue, it attains water’s skill,
and so it is said: *Action is Good Skill.*

**Movement is Good Timing.**
Water takes winter congealing and spring thawing as timing,
in virtue attains water’s timing,
and so it is said: *Movement is Good Timing.*

Only the non-contending is without blame.
It is said that the highest virtue should be like water,
for non-contending is the highest virtue.

To make non-contending advantageous,
one can thus embrace these seven virtues
and be aided by Heaven and assisted by humankind.
What fault could there be?

The previous chapter spoke of the Sage’s matters beyond the body,
and since the six virtues do not contend,
they are followed by the six virtues.

Liu Ji said: *"The highest virtue is like water, hence without blame."*
The *Yijing* says: *"Those who follow the Way are virtuous."*
*Zhuangzi* also says: *"To depart from the Way is to be virtuous."*
All say that from the Dao downward, none approach virtue as closely.

Heaven’s One generates water,
yet it is not far from the Way,
so the highest virtue is like water.

Water’s virtue benefits all things—
though supremely yielding and weak,
it does not contend.
It dwells where people dislike,
thus nearly attaining the Way.

Those who dwell in good land
place themselves beneath others.
Those whose hearts are virtuous depths
are clear through stillness.
Those who give with virtue are benevolent,
benefiting others without seeking return.
Those whose speech is virtuous are trustworthy,
venturing upon dangers without failing in trust.

Next, it flows; when contained, it stops—
virtue’s governance is good governance.
Filling basins and advancing,
a thousand turns yet it flows east—
virtue’s skill is good skill.
Source springs, ceaseless day and night—
movement is good timing.

Embracing these seven virtues without contending with things,
there is no blame.
This is how it nearly attains the Way.

Only the Way gathers in emptiness while water flows downward,
naturally without the burden of excess,
so it is followed by *"Hold and it will be full."*

Zhao Shizhen said: *"First, the analogy of two things: one, yielding succession to the Way.
The highest virtue is like water—
as the previous chapter says, it is not without private intent,
yet it accomplishes its private intent.
It clarifies how Heaven, Earth, and the Sage
achieve public good through private means.
He who can achieve public good through private means
truly understands the mechanisms of Heaven and humankind,
and goes nowhere without fitting in.
This is the highest virtue.
Thus it is said: *The highest virtue is like water.*

For benevolence is the root of virtue,
righteousness is its foundation,
rites are its adornment,
trust is its depth,
wisdom is its refinement.
Each has its virtue, yet none exhausts virtue.
Only water’s virtue encompasses all seven,
so it is called the highest virtue.
Virtue is all-encompassing.
All-encompassing means fully prepared—
this is why it is the highest virtue.
Thus, *the highest virtue is like water.*

The commentary cites *Zhuangzi*: *"To depart from the Way is to be virtuous."*
When virtue is named, the body of the Way is diminished,
yet Heaven’s One generates water,
and departing from the Way is not far.
This again reveals the meaning of the highest virtue.

**Two, directly pointing to water’s virtue.**
Water’s virtue benefits all—
thus it nearly attains the Way.
Previously, virtue was compared to water;
now water’s virtue is spoken of directly.

The Five Phases: Metal generates Water.
Where Metal is generated, Water inherits its form and precedes it,
thus not departing from its mother.
Yet Water is born from *Kan* (the abyss),
*Kan* resides in the *zi* position,
the Yellow Palace nurtures its qi—
this is its proper place.
The lands it encompasses
are where the divine response resides within.
*The Hongfan* says: Heaven’s One generates Water,
Earth’s Two generates Fire,
Fire is born from Water’s essence—*jingyi*.
The divine is in the essence,
the divine response follows as the second,
three Yangs are born from Water,
Water descends while Wind ascends.
Three Yins are born from Wind,
Wind ascends while Water descends.
Yin and Yang merge in virtue,
divine responses interact and apply—
though one Yin and one Yang,
one Wind and one Water,
their origin is Heaven’s One as the root,
so Water rises as vapor to become clouds,
clouds transform into rain,
all things thrive from Water and are born.
Water’s benefit is for all under Heaven,
thus it is said: *Water’s virtue benefits all things,*
and it does not contend.
Again, one phrase cannot exhaust its virtue,
so it is restated.

Non-contending is Water’s yielding nature.
Yielding is顺 (*shùn*),顺 is not opposing things,
thus it communicates with all.
*Mencius* says: *"Direct it east, it flows east;
direct it west, it flows west.
Draw it, and it reaches—*
all this is the work of yielding.
Yet Water’s nature is to descend,
while human inclination favors ascent.
Those who favor ascent dislike descent,
and disliking descent is the common inclination.
Descending is to dwell in lowliness—
lowliness is the virtue of the highest.
He who cannot dwell in lowliness will contend,
contending means to precede others,
preceding others means he cannot transcend his body.
Transcending the body means he can be humble and modest—
this aligns with what was said before.
Thus it is said: *It dwells where people dislike,*
hence it nearly attains the Way.
*Near* means *close*.
The commentary says: *The Yijing* says: *"One Yin, one Yang—this is the Way;
those who follow it are virtuous."*
Thus it is known that none approach the Way as closely as virtue.
Yet the Way is vast, seeming unworthy,
and the world dares not submit to it—
subtle, beyond grasp,
no thing can compare.
Only Water’s lowliness
can nearly approach it.

Next, the seven virtues are elaborated:

**One, the virtue of harmonizing.**
Dwelling in good land—
Water and Earth together encompass,
yet when divided, Earth is still while Water moves.
Earth’s nature restrains Water,
but when Water overflows, Earth builds dikes.
Earth cultivates grains,
Water irrigates—
thus Earth succeeds through Water.
Initially, they share one breath—
brothers.
After division, they are husband and wife.
If not restrained, the six would not generate,
and harmony would not produce creation.
Thus Water moves upon the land—
Water’s benefit lies in the land.
Land is lowliness,
Water is descent.
Water and Earth share virtue,
and cannot be separated for an instant—
this is why they harmonize virtues.
Harmonizing virtues returns to their origin.
Unlike the Way,
they do not differ and do not conspire against each other.
Thus, level land levels Water and Earth,
and it is known that Water dwells in good land.

**御注曰:**
Dwelling upon the land, it flows in the center yet never overflows.
**Two,** its essence is clarity and stillness—
its heart is profoundly serene.

Those with nature possess a heart;
those without feeling lack a heart—
Water has no feeling,
so how could it have a heart?
The *Classic* speaks of a heart
only by analogy to human mind in Water.

The heart is the **Dao/Way**.
The **Dao/Way** arises from the heart;
when the heart is still, all forms perish—
thus its depths are boundless,
unseen and unfathomable.
Yet when the heart stirs and spirit awakens,
the **Dao/Way** scatters as things—
how could it fully manifest its use?

"Serene" means deep—
also "serene" means void.
The heart’s emptiness holds the principle of profound stillness,
so the deeper it is measured,
the farther it extends.
Zhuangzi said: *"Serene and still."*
Does this not illuminate Water’s heart?

When unmoved, it is clear;
when undisturbed, it is level—
here, even eyebrows and mustaches are revealed.
The heavy and turbid settle below,
the pure and bright rise above—
all things rest here.
These are the meanings of profound stillness.

**Three,** its virtue is to nurture life—
its excellence is benevolence.
Those with hearts give without favor;
those without hearts distribute evenly—
Water’s impartiality
reaches the utmost benevolence.
Water makes no choice,
yet virtue flows universally.
The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"Kàn has sincerity—its heart is flourishing."*
With one *yang* dwelling between two *yin*,
if one cannot cultivate virtue and refine conduct
to depart from peril,
how could one show unceasing sincerity?
When in Kàn, one *yang* returns—
returning to reveal the heart of Heaven and Earth.
Heaven and Earth’s heart originates in nurturing life;
returning, it ceases.
Returning and ceasing,
it turns toward life.
The heart of universal love is the sage’s mind.
Without embodying the **Dao/Way**,
benevolence remains constrained—
like a drought’s meager dew,
how could it compare to Heaven’s timely rains?
Thus, even Yao and Shun found it laborious
to broadly bestow and aid the people.
Yet Water’s transformation,
sharing virtue with the **Dao/Way**,
is universally loving, impartial,
and gives without choice—
what could it not encompass?
Thus it is said: *"Its excellence is benevolence."*

**Four,** it has a central master—
speaking of faithfulness.
Roots and stems are the origin of things;
nature and life are what the **Dao/Way** generates.
Tracing its source,
following its inherent nature,
it does not deviate from principle.
The Five Phases attribute wisdom to Water,
faithfulness to Earth.
How does Water speak of faithfulness?
Observe *Fù*—seven days return,
*qi* transmits to *Zhōngfú* (faithfulness).
Kàn in *Fù* obtains *Zhōngfú* naturally—
this is why it is said to master faithfulness.
The *Tai Xuan* states:
One *yang* rides upon unity,
all things draw form from the center—
Water embodies *Zhōngfú*,
the central *yang qi* subtly illuminates the Yellow Palace—
faithfulness is never absent from the center.
Truly, the primal spirit’s subtlety lies in one *qi*,
the origin of myriad threads begins with wisdom—
the source of faithfulness obtains wisdom,
unifying speech and wisdom, action and faithfulness,
without losing harmony with things.
Wisdom does not inherently master faithfulness—
in affairs, hesitation breeds regret;
faithfulness is not wisdom in action—
in nature, it stagnates and falters.
Thus, the essence resides within,
manifestation lies without—
ultimate speech transcends speech,
great faithfulness requires no oaths,
so beginning and end are trustworthy,
not hollow and empty,
yet vast in reception.
Thus, it is known:
If one speaks without faithfulness in action,
one loses its root.
The *Classic of Changes* says:
*"Moving through peril without losing faithfulness"—
this is the reason.

**Five,** it follows principle in action—
governance excels in order.
The Great **Dao/Way** takes rationality as master;
governance precedes literature.
Since Heaven and Earth came to be,
no ruler over all things
has failed to exhaust principle and nature
yet still transformed the people.
The Three Sovereigns governed through spiritual transformation of the **Dao/Way**,
the Five Emperors ruled with benevolence aligned with Heaven—
and the world spoke of governance.
Yet who knows its root is as yielding as Water,
encountering nothing yet achieving transformation?
Those who arrogantly establish their own virtue
and disrupt the Great Constant
simply do not know the foundation of governance—
how could they avoid hardship and scarcity?
Water’s nature seeks lowliness and moisture,
flows through the earth,
bends a thousand times yet flows east,
avoids obstacles and reaches the sea—
this is Water’s principle.
Governance’s foundation in human nature
is like irrigation and cultivation—
movement and growth depend on it for life;
like rain and dew,
withering things rely on it for nourishment—
this is Water’s function.
Governance’s origin in sustaining life
is like cleansing filth and replacing it with purity,
receiving all impurities and replacing them with clarity—
this is Water’s virtue.
Governance’s excellence in guiding customs
is like dikes that can be extended,
yet rivers cannot be violated,
barriers that can be built,
yet torrents cannot be resisted—
this is Water’s power.
Governance conquers the world with yielding **Dao/Way**,
like springs flowing ceaselessly,
their currents vast and boundless—
the more drawn, the clearer,
the more issued, the fresher—
this is Water’s root.
Governance renews the world daily,
like Water’s inherent qualities—
all these it possesses,
thus its excellence in governance is clear.
Ah!
Nothing but Water.
Waves surge yet are not evil,
stillness is profound yet not beautiful—
though turbulent, it never loses its goodness;
purified, it is not stagnant;
stirred, it is not reckless;
raging, it never loses its longevity.
The Supreme Good says: *"The highest excellence is like Water."*
The sage embodies this for governance—
is this not universal wisdom?

**Six,** it adapts to the vessel’s round or square—
affairs excel in capability.
Effortless action yields few errors;
action with purpose yields no calamity is difficult.
Under Heaven, no affair remains still and unmoving.
When it moves,
responding to make it appropriate—
none but the wise and insightful
can decisively judge it.

**Water’s Nature—**
From Heaven’s single source it issues forth,
a ceaseless trickle,
until it fills the basin and then advances,
spreading across the Four Seas.
Observe it in the Two Yin*—
it can navigate peril;
one Yang* abides at its center—
its spirit flows freely.
Though it rests in Yin,
though it sinks into danger,
it never strays from peril—
flowing yet never full,
dwelling yet emerging,
its applications are vast.

Yet it never contends with things,
adapting to the land’s curves and straights—
not crooked for its own sake,
nor rigid without restraint.
It conforms to the vessel’s shape—
square without rigidity,
round without fixed form.
It responds to the myriad transformations of things
yet never loses its constancy;
it fits the timing of use
yet never falters in sincerity—
truly, it has no power
yet lacks no capability.

The Supreme Good’s work
is most evident here.

**Seven,** its flow and congealing have constancy.
Its movement is timely.
Under Heaven’s affairs,
the virtuous observe them for advance and retreat,
lying in the interplay of emergence and withdrawal.

Emerging at its proper time,
the sage acts and all things witness;
retiring by the Dao/Way,
the hidden dragon* yields to the wind* and frets in obscurity.
When one should emerge yet withdraws,
rolling up like a scroll—
this is the way of the unvirtuous.
When one should retire yet emerges,
forcing action—
this is the way of the unwise.

Knowing the Dao/Way of advance and retreat,
never losing its proper time,
then movement is auspicious.

*The *Book of Documents* says:
*"Consider well and act,
act only when the time is ripe."*

As for Water’s movement—
when Yang releases it, it floats;
when Yin congeals it, it becomes ice.
Within one body, it holds Yang within and Yin without;
in spring and winter, it has motion and stillness.
Thus, those who move with adaptability
respond to the *Yù* timing*—auspicious;
those who move with clarity
respond to the *Fēng* timing*—auspicious;
those who move with daring
respond to the *Jiě* timing*—auspicious;
those who move with strength
respond to the *Dàzhuàng* timing*—auspicious.

The ancients hid their talents within,
awaiting the proper time;
advanced their virtue and cultivated their affairs,
seeking to grasp the moment;
refined their conduct and guarded their actions,
waiting for the right season;
understood the fitting approach,
desiring to settle in harmony;
withdrew into obscurity and rested in seclusion,
following the times.

By the times’ unfolding,
even Heaven does not resist—
as for those skilled in nurturing life,
they press forward and then respond;
those who master the art of interaction,
advance and retreat at the proper moments.

If one dwells in the world yet knows not emergence and withdrawal,
pursues the True yet fails to recognize floating and sinking—
how then can one attain the meaning of timely action?

**Later, congealing forms two principles:**
**One,** the summation of yielding and adaptability.
Truly, non-contention is Water’s nature;
inherent in gentleness and weakness is Water’s virtue/power.
In non-contention’s excellence,
the advantage of non-contention is seen in the Seven Affairs.
In governing one’s self,
it does not use strength to conquer others.
In dwelling within one’s self,
it fits just what is needed to guard with gentleness—
if it can be assailed,
if it can be scorned,
then those who endure slander are drowned,
those who endure impurity are sullied.
Yet the patient endure scorn,
the clear grow slowly from turbid—
none can ultimately overcome its gentleness.

Can Water’s force, descending to the low,
become what all people despise?
Yet it never knows to dwell low while serving high?
Can Water’s nature, gentle and weak,
be overcome by the strong?
Yet it never knows to gather in gentleness
and use it—then it becomes strong.

When it is nurtured,
it flows as a trickle,
yet when it surges,
none can restrain its non-contention—
the Dao/Way few can wield it.

**Two,** without the breath of human Dao/Way,
there is no blame.
The strong oppress the weak,
the many bully the few—
all take upon themselves the fault of their strength.
Yet the gentle Dao/Way moves with harmony,
and none find fault in it.

As *Shào Ruò* said:
*"The Supreme Good is like Water—
thus there is no blame."*

All people love contention,
yet Laozi sets non-contention as the Supreme Good,
using Water as an analogy—
Water has no desire of its own,
yet benefits all things without contention,
dwelling where all people despise it.

By Water’s virtue/power,
it nearly attains the Dao/Way.
If one acts without desire,
then non-contention is auspicious;
dwelling without desire,
then stillness is auspicious;
with others without desire,
then benevolence is auspicious;
speaking without desire,
then sincerity is auspicious;
governing without desire,
then administration is auspicious;
doing without desire,
then capability is auspicious;
moving without desire,
then timing is auspicious.

Truly, without desire,
non-contention is auspicious—
thus there is no blame.

As *Wáng Zhìrán* said:
*"The Supreme Good is like Water—
thus there is no blame."*

The Supreme Ultimate generates the Two Principles*,
the Two Principles generate the Four Symbols*,
the Four Symbols generate the Five Phases*,
and the Five Phases’ transformations are vast.

In Heaven, they become the Five Stars*;
on Earth, they become the Five Mountains*;
in humans, they are called the Five Constants*;
in the body, they are the Five Viscera*.
Applied to colors, they are the Five Hues*;
applied to music, they are the Five Tones*;
the tongue savors them as the Five Flavors*;
the nose perceives them as the Five Fragrances*—
each reaching its full use,
called the Five Talents*.

Mutually generating and mutually restraining,
alternately waxing and waning,
yet benefiting all things without contention,
dwelling where all people despise it without refusal—
its functions are beyond naming,
thus those who nearly attain the Dao/Way,
only Water can do so.

Why?
Water’s nature can be both gentle and strong,
both round and square,
both crooked and straight,
both short and long—
melting into rivers,
congealing into ice,
gathering as seas,
dispersing as clouds.
All myriad things draw from it to live,
all treasures obtain it to form.
Its source is boundless,
its flow ceaseless—
Heaven’s first creation,
not far from the Dao/Way.

Having marked the name of the Supreme Good,
which of all myriad things is better than this?
Thus it is said: *"Under Heaven, none are gentler and weaker than Water,
yet none are better at overcoming the firm and strong."*
Its non-contention and victory are such—
as for its flowing, dispersing, and shifting,
it chooses no place yet finds rest;
in the level, it measures and applies;
it receives filth and absorbs stains,
full yet never overflowing—
this is what is called *"dwelling in auspicious places."*

The Sage who dwells in stillness
marks no reflection in flowing waters,
yet mirrors all in stillness—
stillness, then clarity,
returning to the origin, pure and true.
None can surpass the Supreme Void—
this is called *"the heart’s deep virtue."*

To love universally without favor,
to know all yet never exhaust—
to take virtue as kindness,
is it not to make oneself small?
This is called *"the benevolent in harmony."*

Straight speech, though reversed,
is plain as water, tasteless yet profound.
Unsummoned, it gathers;
uninvited, it arrives—
this is called *"speech’s true faith."*

To curb the excesses of Zeng and Shi,
to silence Yang and Mo’s mouths—
if all hold such wisdom, Heaven’s confusion ceases;
if all embody such virtue, Heaven’s misguidance ends.
This is called *"governance’s perfect order."*

Abandon the wise, discard cleverness—
great thieves then desist.
Abandon artifice, discard profit—
the people’s gain is a hundredfold.
Acting with the times, all undertakings succeed—
this is called *"the adept in action."*

Spring’s thaw, winter’s freeze—
the seasons’ natural course;
exploiting terrain for benefit—
the way of forces.
Dammed, it stops; released, it flows.
Guide the people with the times,
and movement aligns with what is fitting—
this is called *"action’s timely flow."*

To dwell well is to rest in ease,
to nurture the heart is to dwell in depth and stillness,
to act benevolently is to give without reserve,
to speak truly is to stand firm in faith,
to govern wisely is to bring order and stability,
to act skillfully is to exhaust one’s capacity,
to move rightly is to follow the seasons’ lead—
this is how the Sage embodies and practices them.

To govern the world and state,
in sorrow share the people’s sorrow,
in joy share the people’s joy.
To act without action, few desires—easy;
to act with action, yet incur no blame—difficult.
If one can embody Water’s supreme utility,
and follow Water’s nature,
benefiting myriad ages without knowing how—
to profit others without contention,
while none can contend with it—
then there is no blame.

Huang Maozai said:
*"The Supreme Good, like Water, thus incurs no blame."*

Water has seven grades of goodness:
The highest—
to benefit others without contention,
to dwell where others abhor—
this is the Supreme Good.
If one embodies this, one nears the Dao.

Its lesser grades, sevenfold:
To dwell in auspicious places—
to pool as marshes;
to nurture a deep heart—
stillness can reflect;
to act benevolently—
its nourishing reach is vast;
to speak truly—
its voice, once stirred, never ceases;
to govern wisely—
it can cleanse filth and reveal essence;
to act skillfully—
it shapes square and round as needed;
to move with the times—
freezing in winter, thawing in spring.

Though these seven may make a good person,
none surpass the non-contention of Water—
non-contention, thus no blame.

Program Tai said:
*"The Supreme Good, like Water, thus does not contend."*

All things under Heaven that benefit others—
if I take them alone, another must be deprived,
and my gain is their loss.
Contention begins here.

Water’s virtue:
it does not seek to benefit others,
yet does not refuse to do so.
It can boil, irrigate, cleanse, or bear—
acting only when the time is right,
so benefit arises without harm elsewhere—
no contention exists.

The Supreme Good is the good beyond good.
To dwell among the people is to near the Dao.
Before movement, it is non-being;
in its manifestation over all things, it is emptiness.
When it meets events and reveals itself,
it does not seek fullness,
but is moist, weak, lowly, and yielding.
Though not yet the Dao,
when used with force,
it does not enter excess—
thus it attains emptiness and tends toward non-being.
This is the closest approach to the Dao.

Though some know the benefit of humility and weakness,
private pride cannot be overcome—
how could one willingly bend, endure humiliation,
and walk the path of humility and weakness?

Only Water is good at yielding without contention,
receiving filth without refusal,
and in human affairs,
all that is deemed base or shameful—
it endures and contains them.
Though not yet the Dao,
its inner emptiness and selflessness
are the essential path for those seeking it.

**Dwelling in auspicious places:**
*"Residence"* refers to where it gathers—
low and sunken is its dwelling,
thus great rivers flow downward—
hence, *"auspicious places."*

**The heart’s deep virtue:**
Never ceasing to move yet profoundly still—
this is its heart.

**Benevolent harmony:**
Its nourishment reaches everywhere without limit.

**True speech:**
In matters, some should speak yet remain silent,
some should be magnified yet are diminished,
some should be made plain yet are exaggerated—
these are not as they should be.
Water’s still pools make no sound,
yet the world calls them *"profound silence."*
When stirred, it makes noise—
great agitation brings great sound,
small agitation brings small sound—
each encounter is thus—
this is called *"faith."*

**Perfect order:**
*"Governance"* corrects what is incorrect.
Once cleansed, external filth is gone,
and the original nature is revealed—
this is its order.

**Adept in action:**
Its balanced levelness, its inner clarity—
its skill is revealed in action.

**Timely movement:**
When blocked, it stops;
when released, it flows.
In cold, it freezes;
in thaw, it descends—
it acts as circumstances demand.

Only because it does not contend
is there no blame.
Responding without initiating,
acting where there is none—
though its utility reaches others,
it does not take from them,
so none can harm what it does—
thus the seven goods are not merely Water’s talents.
Since it does not contend,
none blame it,
and its Supreme Good is easily achieved.

**Discourse on Eighty-One Chapters: Sixfold Elucidation of the Benefits of Non-Contention**

First, it is said:
*"He who does not vaunt himself has merit,
He who does not boast endures long.
Only because he does not contend,
the world cannot contend with him."*
This is the first.

Second:
*"To place oneself above others yet serve them,
To precede others yet follow them—
because he does not contend,
the world cannot contend with him."*
This is the second.

Third:
*"The Way of Heaven acts without contention yet achieves victory."*

Fourth:
*"The Sage’s Way acts without contention."*

Fifth:
*"To wage war without force,
To win without claiming victory—
this is the virtue of non-contention."*

Sixth:
*"Thus, the sixfold non-contention incurs no blame."*

Now, what is called *contention* is not necessarily war or battle.
When two opposing forces refuse to yield—
this is contention.
Though Heaven’s yin and yang are most subtle and ungraspable,
they still contend at the winter and summer solstices—
for the departing force has not withdrawn,
while the incoming force presses forward.
This is called contention.
Thus, contention is when opposing forces arise and neither yields.

But those who grasp the Dao are otherwise.
Knowing to embrace the feminine while guarding the masculine,
they act yet do not act.
Their abilities could benefit others, yet they withhold them;
their wisdom could overshadow the world, yet they conceal it.
They never seek to lead the world first—
how then could there be contention?

Indeed, Liezi spoke of the Dao of perpetual victory and perpetual defeat:
*"The ancients spoke of strength—
those who do not yet surpass me,
when they surpass me, are in peril.
To surpass me and yet be in peril—
this is one who loves victory and must meet his match,
and thus must surely be defeated."*

Again, he said:
*"The gentle one—
those who act first perish,
while those who do not contend face no peril.
Thus, their victory is certain."*

Pushing this logic to its extreme:
Even if two armies clash and I win,
it may still be called non-contention.
I wait in gentleness until the moment of collapse,
then strike—
and this too is non-contention.
Thus is the Dao of perpetual victory.

Yet this is perpetual victory from my perspective alone.
I advance when advantageous,
and withdraw when not—
prioritizing self-cultivation over benefiting others.
Though Laozi’s words are profound,
his approach preserves the self at all costs,
only acting when peril is absent.
Otherwise, he refrains.

Indeed, many ancient scholars were like this.
Morning Gate mocked Confucius:
*"Is this not knowing the impossible yet doing it?"*
The man with the basket also said:
*"How vulgar! Stubborn and unrecognized—
this is enough!"*
These two, though concerned with the world,
when they found none to align with them,
simply let things be.

All such doubts belong to the Daoist path,
those unwilling to take action.

But Confucius was otherwise.
Hearing the basket-man’s words, he sighed:
*"Ah, the end is indeed difficult!"*
Though loving one’s life while neglecting the world
was not beyond Confucius,
he prioritized saving the world—
approaching what must be approached,
never shirking what must be done.
Thus, the Five Approaches, the Five Withdrawals,
and the seventy-two visits—
all bore the world upon his shoulders.

Though Laozi’s view was not without merit,
Confucius endured what he could not.
If measured by self-preservation,
misfortune and disgrace could not touch him.
Thus, he was spared the fate of being hacked to pieces or felled like wood.

Zhan Qiupu said:
