there may be soul without vital essence,
or vital essence without soul—
the person is no longer a person and dies.

*Laozi* thus sets forth analogies,
speaking of the five matters of soul and vital essence embracing unity.
An infant is pure, unified, soft, and good—
its *qi* is concentrated, its softness extreme.
*Extreme* means *ultimate.*»

Thus, one may make the soul and vital essence unite without separation—
this is *purity and firmness*.

To purify flaws and remove defilements, to gaze into the profound and obscure,
is to seek out faults and blemishes.
But if one purifies and gazes without seeking faults,
then the soul and vital essence may unite without separation—
this is *non-attachment*.

To love the people and govern the state while acting through *wuwei* (non-action),
then clarity and stillness arise naturally,
and the soul and vital essence may unite without separation—
this is *purity and clarity*.

The opening and closing of the *Heavenly Gate*,
through which *Heavenly Principle* emerges—
when *yin* and *yang* interact in harmony,
when *male* and *female* resonate together,
with principle present yet the mind absent,
then the soul and vital essence unite without separation—
this is *desirelessness*.

To be bright and far-reaching yet appear as if without knowledge or awareness,
then one conceals brilliance in obscurity,
and the soul and vital essence may unite without separation—
this is *concealing brilliance*.

In essence, *purity and firmness*, *non-attachment*, *purity and clarity*,
*desirelessness*, and *concealing brilliance*—
these five make the soul and vital essence naturally embrace unity.
When the soul and vital essence embrace unity,
they become the source of *generative life*.

*Heaven’s Dao* takes nurturing all things as its intent,
yet especially cherishes humanity.
To give birth and nourish is *Heaven’s Dao*,
yet if the soul and vital essence separate,
life cannot endure.
*Laozi* teaches these five matters to humanity,
while *Heaven and Earth’s* benevolent generation is boundless.
Yet *Heaven’s Dao* gives birth without possessing—
how could it claim credit for its generative power?
It acts without relying—
how could it boast of its deeds?
Though it stands as sovereign over all things,
it harbors no masterful intent—
this is called the *mysterious virtue*.

To take the unity of soul and vital essence as the root of generative life,
and to possess without claiming, act without relying, govern without dominating,
is to have no room for the mind.
The grace of giving birth and nourishing
is shared equally by *Heaven* and the *Sage*—
thus speaks *Ben Yi An*, the recluse of the *One Root Lodge*:
*"From ‘carrying the vital essence and soul’ to this point is called the *Mysterious Virtue*."*

The meaning of *soul* and *vital essence* has been thoroughly expounded by earlier scholars.
In my view, regarding the *Rites’* sacrificial rites, *Confucius* said:
*"The vital essence is the flourishing of the spirit."*
*Zheng Xuan* annotated:
*"The vital essence is the luminous clarity of the ears and eyes."*
This is the most concise explanation.
*Zhu Xi* said that *vital essence* (*ying*) is akin to *ying* (glowing),
meaning radiant brilliance—
thus, *vital essence* and *soul* are the spiritual essence of the form.
Human form gives rise to spirit,
and the luminous clarity of the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth
all originate from *One Nature*—
what the *Buddhist School* calls *Elemental Essence*.
It divides into the six harmonized faculties from a single clarity—
yet because it is drawn by external things,
it drifts and forgets its return,
thus the form decays externally while awareness falters internally,
and suddenly, death comes.
The soul ascends, the vital essence descends—
they can no longer reunite.
To die without forgetting is difficult indeed.

Thus, the enlightened one gathers vision and returns hearing,
reverses light to illuminate the source,
and restores the origin of *One Nature*.
*"Carrying"* means dwelling steadfast without scattering.
*"Embracing"* means preserving unity without loss.
*One* refers to *Nature*—
what the *Buddhist School* calls *Returning the Flow to Wholeness*,
where the six faculties do not act,
and clarity does not follow the roots—
this is *illuminating the root and emitting light*.
To illuminate the root and emit light is to *carry the vital essence and soul*.
To return the flow to wholeness is to *embrace unity without separation*.
This is the essential path to *restoring Nature and embodying form*—
not merely the true cultivation of refining form and spirit for longevity and sharp vision.

*Specialization* means *unmixed*.
*Extreme* means *ultimate*.
An infant, untempted by knowledge or thought to disturb its *qi*,
thus its *qi* is *specialized*.
Unburdened by competition between self and other to harm its softness,
thus its softness is *extreme*.
Though humans may strive to maintain gentle *qi*,
they can manage it temporarily but not perpetually—
only as an infant is it truly *extreme*.
These two aspects both return to the beginning of life,
and only through purification and profound contemplation
does the divine attain its ultimate function.
For purification removes dust and defilement—
truly, the original clarity emerges from this.
If even a speck of external filth remains unexhausted,
then wisdom is obscured;
if even a hair’s breadth of imperfection lingers,
only purification can resolve it—
until the mind and eyes become luminously clear,
then one perceives all things with penetrating vision.
The pure remain pure,
the impure become pure—
no selection, no perception of flaws—
this is *ultimate*.

Having perfected self-cultivation thus,
one extends it to govern the world and respond to affairs,
loving the people and ruling the state—
this is the norm.
The opening and closing of the *Heavenly Gate*—
this is its transformation.
As the *Yijing* says:
*"One closing, one opening—this is called transformation."*
To be *female* is to be harmonious without initiating,
to follow without leading—
in its constancy, there is no trace of action.
In its response to change, there is no intent to precede things.
For there is neither anticipation nor resistance—
one simply abides in natural ease.

To be bright and far-reaching yet appear without knowledge,
this is called *"wise and insightful, yet guarded by simplicity."*
To give birth and nourish is *virtue*.
To give birth without possessing,
to act without relying,
to lead without dominating—
this is *virtue* without the mind of *virtue*—
this is the *mysterious virtue* of *virtue*.

*Laozi’s* this chapter #2
encompasses the *Dao* of governing the body and the state.

*Lu Yu* of *Shi Yi* says:
*"‘Carrying’ originates from *Heaven*—
the beginning of the discourse."*
*Shi Tan* says:
*"Carrying the vital essence and soul, embracing unity—
how could they separate?"*
*Vital essence*, in ancient annotations, is taken as *soul*.
For the *soul* is the moon’s luminosity,
the *vital essence* is the moon’s shadow.
The moon receives sunlight to become luminous,
the shadow must carry the luminosity to live without dying.
*Embracing unity* means the vital essence and soul merge as one,
never separating.
To specialize *qi* and achieve ultimate softness,
one must be like an infant.
Humans are endowed with form and *qi* to live,
yet when *yang qi* flourishes uncontrollably,
it cannot be self-regulated and inevitably drifts,
losing its true essence.
Only by specializing and guarding one’s *qi*,
making it soft as an infant—
though it may move, it does not know the union of *male* and *female*—
is this well done.
This aligns with the later text:
*"The depth of virtue is compared to that of an infant."*

To purify and gaze profoundly,
one must be without blemish.
The ancients said:
*"The mind perceives all things,
easily moved by external influences—
thus, one must purify external desires,
leaving no trace of flaw or defect."*

「To cherish the people and govern the state,
one must attain *wuwei* [無為].

The ancient commentary states:
*"For those who cultivate the body, cherishing the *qi* ensures bodily integrity;
for those who govern the people, cherishing the people ensures the state’s security."
This encompasses both meanings.

To attain *wuwei* in terms of cultivating the body,
it means the *Way* [道] is applied without excessive effort—
as seen in the previous chapter.
In terms of governing the people,
it is the *Way* of *"governing through non-action"* [無為而治].

However, the *Master of the Yellow River* [河上公] rendered it as *"without knowing"* [無知],
which aligns with the following passage.
Yet, *"without knowing"* [無知] should be interpreted as *"without acting"* [無為].
The *Heavenly Gate* [天門] opens and closes,
yet remains *without female* [無雌]—i.e., *without clinging to passivity*.
As *Program Tai* [程泰] explains:
*"Zhuangzi* [莊子] designated the realm of birth and death,
the emergence and disappearance of all things,
as the *Heavenly Gate* [天門].
*Female* [雌] here signifies tranquil stillness and yielding weakness—
one who embodies *female* [雌] does not boast of their power,
though *yin* and *yang* [陰陽] may give rise to all things.
This reflects the principle of *"giving birth without possession"* [生而不有].

To be *bright and all-pervading* [明白四達] yet *without knowing* [無知],
this heart, though aware of all things,
never seeks to grasp that knowledge—
the *Way* of *"without thinking yet knowing"* [不思而得],
*"without deliberation yet aware"* [不虑而知].

To bring forth and nurture all things,
to give birth without possession,
to act without claiming merit,
to grow without controlling—
this is called *mysterious virtue* [玄德].

The preceding passages on *loading the Vital Essence* [載營], *specializing and softening the *qi*** [專氣致柔],
and *purifying and profound vision* [涤除玄覽]
focus solely on cultivating the body.

*Cherishing the people and governing the state* [愛民治國],
*the Heavenly Gate opening and closing* [天門開闔],
and *brightness and all-pervasiveness* [明白四達]
extend these principles to all things.

This passage summarizes the three preceding lines:
*"To bring forth and nurture all things,
each attains their place naturally,
yet none know the reason why—
this is called *mysterious virtue* [玄德].*
This aligns with the saying:
*"The common people do not know the power of the Sovereign"* [百姓不知帝力].

*Mysterious Virtue* [玄德] *of the Daoist and Moral Classic* [道德真經] *Volume 16 concludes.*

#1 *Lost in the Way* [失之道哉]: Likely a miscopy, intended as *"The Way of Heaven* [天之道哉]".

**Annotations on the *Daoist and Moral Classic* [道德真经]
Compiled by Sūnyǒng Guānshì Liú Wéiyǒng
Verified by Former Imperial Scholar and Treasury Clerk, *Gūnmì Yùan* Editor **Dīng Yìdōng**

**Thirty-Spoke Chapter [三十辐章]**
*Critical Notes:*
The *Riverbank Master* [河上公] composed the *"Chapter of the Useful in Non-Use"* [无用章],
while *Zhào Shí’ān* authored the *"Hidden and Manifest Illuminating Meaning"* [隐显玄彰义章].

**Emperor Xuānzōng’s Commentary [唐明皇疏]:**
The preceding chapter expounds nurturing the spirit and cherishing *qi*, unadulterated—thus without blemish.
This chapter elucidates the utility of *non-use* and the efficacy of *use*, their mutual reliance establishing function.
Thus, *Heaven* [乾] and *Earth* [坤] are the profound essence of the *Great Transformation* [大易],
and the *yoke and axle* [辕厢] embody the substance of *non-use*.
They are likened to *vehicles, vessels, and chambers*—
their efficacy lies in the interplay of *having* and *non-having*.

**Du Guāngtíng’s Explanation:**
Cherishing *qi* and nurturing the spirit upholds *tranquility*.
The utility of *non-use* and the efficacy of *use* lie in their mutual reliance—
taking from what exists while leveraging what is absent.

The three—*vehicles, vessels, and chambers*—
all borrow their *having* to exploit their *non-having* for function.
*Vehicles* convey, *vessels* contain, *chambers* shelter—
the mind relies on external *having* while harnessing internal *non-having*,
thus accomplishing the efficacy of *use*.

*Heaven* and *Earth* are the foundation of the *Great Transformation* [大易],
as stated in the *"Systematic Transmission"* [□系辞].
The *Great Transformation*’s establishment originates from *Heaven* and *Earth*.
Without *Heaven* and *Earth*, the *Dao* would have no foundation.
Thus, *Heaven* and *Earth* are the root and repository of the *Dao*,
like rivers and granaries storing its depths.
Hence, it is said: *"When *Heaven* and *Earth* align, the *Great Transformation* stands within."*

If *Heaven* and *Earth* are destroyed, the *Great Transformation* cannot manifest.
This is akin to the *wheel-hub* and *yoke-axle*—
if the *yoke-axle* is ruined, the *vehicle* cannot exist.
To illustrate the principle of *utility*, three analogies are given.

For governing the realm: if the people perish, the state collapses;
if the people scatter, the state falters.
For cultivating the self: if the spirit departs, life ends;
if the spirit dissipates, the body perishes.
The *Dao* of *utility* truly depends on mutual reliance.

**Zhāng Chōngyìng’s Interpretation:**
*Non-use* is *emptiness*—
if *qi* were not empty, it could not circulate and transform into spirit.
Thus, it is called *"non-use."*

Thirty spokes converge at one hub—
its *emptiness* yields the *vehicle*’s function.
*Clay molded into vessels*—
its *emptiness* yields the *vessel*’s function.
*Doors and windows carved for chambers*—
its *emptiness* yields the *chamber*’s function.
Thus, *having* provides *utility*, while *non-having* enables *use*.

**Riverbank Master’s Explanation:**
Thirty spokes converge at one hub—
ancient *vehicles* had thirty spokes, following the lunar cycle’s count.
They converge at the hub because its *emptiness* allows them to unite.
For cultivating the self, one must purge emotions and desires,
leaving the five *zàng*-organs empty—
thus the spirit returns.
For governing the state, few leaders unite many subjects,
making the strong serve the weak.
When *emptiness* prevails, the *vehicle*’s function emerges.
*Emptiness* means *void*—
the hub’s void allows movement;
the *zàng*-organs’ void permits bearing burdens.

*Clay molded into vessels*—
*Bié* (harmonizing) and *zhì* (earth) form drinking and eating utensils.
Their *emptiness* yields their function—
the vessel’s void allows containment.

*Doors and windows carved for chambers*—
referring to constructed dwellings.
Their *emptiness* yields their function—
doors and windows’ void permits entry and exit;
the chamber’s void permits residence.
Thus, *having* provides *utility*—
benefiting form and function,
fearing the vessel’s collapse or the body’s decay.
*Non-having* enables *use*—
only the void can contain all things.
Thus, *"emptiness governs the formed."*

The *Dao* is *emptiness*.
**Wáng Fǔsì’s Statement:**
From *thirty spokes* to the *vehicle*’s function—
the hub’s *emptiness* unifies the spokes,
allowing the solid to govern the many.
From *clay molded into vessels* to *non-having* as *use*—
wood and clay form walls,
yet all rely on *emptiness* for function.
Thus, *non-having* is the foundation of *having*’s *utility*.

**Emperor Xuānzōng’s Further Explanation:**
From *thirty spokes* to the *vehicle*’s function—
this demonstrates how *having* and *non-having*’s efficacy relies on mutual support.
Thirty spokes converge at one hub,
illustrating how the few govern the many.
The *yoke-axle*’s *having* forms the *vehicle*,
while the *vehicle*’s *emptiness* enables movement.
Without the *yoke-axle*’s *having*, there would be no *vehicle* to utilize.
If the *vehicle* were not empty, the *yoke-axle*’s *having* would be useless.

**Commentary:**
Thirty spokes pierce one hub—
the few govern the many.
When empty, the *vehicle*’s movement is realized—
*non-having* benefits *having*.
What is the *Dao*?
It is the ultimate *emptiness*, the ultimate *oneness*.
Thus, it moves and nurtures all things,
commanding myriad materials,
making ten thousand distinctions coalesce—
all from a single *image*.
All orifices resonate as one sound when struck—
the origin of all underheaven’s movement and transformation
never departs from ultimate *emptiness* and *oneness*.

Even in *vehicles*:
the *yoke-axle* has substance, while the *vehicle*’s interior is empty.
The *vehicle*’s emptiness allows movement.
Without the *yoke-axle*’s substance, the *vehicle*’s function ceases.
If the *vehicle* were not empty, the *yoke-axle*’s parts would be discarded.

Thus, when *Heaven* and *Earth* align, the *Great Transformation*’s efficacy is manifest;
when ten thousand transformations flow, the *Dao*’s utility shines.
Hence, through coarse analogies of *non-use*,
the utility of ultimate *emptiness* is illuminated.

*Clay molded into vessels*—
when empty, they serve their function.
*Bié* (harmonizing) and *zhì* (earth)—
potters blend earth to form *wǎ* (vessels).
**Commentary:**
*Bié* means *harmonizing*; *zhì* is *adhesive clay*.
The annotation cites the *Shàngshū*: *"Molding earth is called *táo*."*

「This speaks of the potter shaping and blending adhesive clay, then firing it to become vessels—
it is the inner void that allows them to hold and receive things.

Carving doors and windows yields the function of a dwelling.
Ancients dug caves for shelter, also opening doors and windows,
hence the phrase *"carve thus"* (凿尔).
**Commentary:**
*Carve* (凿) means *to excavate*.
Windows (牖) are side chambers or openings near doors.
The ancients dwelled in caves, so the *Shijing* says:
*"The potter digs and covers the cave,"*
meaning he excavates the earth within the cave and covers it above—
thus *"carve thus"* (凿尔).

Later sages replaced this with official halls,
taking their inner void as the means for people to dwell.
*Zhuangzi* says:
*"If a dwelling has no void, mother-in-law and sister-in-law will jostle for passage,"*
meaning they will fight over narrow paths.
*The Erya* states:
*"The hall is called a dwelling."*
Thus, having form is for utility,
while emptiness is for discarding.
Having form profits from emptiness,
using emptiness for profit;
emptiness relies on form,
using form for function.

What transcends form is called *Dao*,
what is beneath form is called *instrument*.
To reveal the *Dao*’s function,
it is clarified through form and substance.
Thus, by borrowing the coarse utility of having form to illustrate
the subtle function of ultimate emptiness—

**Commentary:**
The profit of having form lies in its utility,
while utility itself depends on emptiness,
so having form profits from emptiness.
The function of emptiness relies on form,
while form itself depends on having substance,
so emptiness profits from having form.

The phrase *"what transcends form is called Dao, what is beneath form is called instrument"*—
this is the language of the *Yijing*’s *Xìcí Shū*.

**Commentary:**
From emptiness, it is called *Dao*;
when touching upon substance, it is called *instrument*.
To clarify the *Dao*’s function,
one must approximate it through form and instrument.
Though it borrows analogies from the three transformations,
ultimately, it relies on emptiness for one principle.

*Du Guangting* says:
*"Thirty spokes converge to form the wheel’s function.
The hub gathers all spokes to complete the wheel,
the carriage gathers all materials to fulfill its purpose.
What it uses is the carriage’s hollow interior—
its emptiness.
Without the hub and spokes,
the carriage cannot be formed.
Now that the carriage is formed,
it empties its core to carry loads,
illustrating how a sovereign internally relies on ministers’ counsel
and externally delegates the aid of feudal lords
to establish his realm—
as the thirty spokes converge into one hub.
Once the realm is established,
if he can empty his heart to embody the *Dao*,
then all under Heaven transforms harmoniously,
like the carriage’s hollow space.
Man’s body,
externally depends on the hundred limbs’ arrangement,
internally relies on the five *qi*’s balance—
like the spokes converging to form a person.
Once the body is complete,
if he can empty his heart to embody the *Dao*,
then the primal harmony subtly operates,
and longevity is achieved.
This reveals how having and emptiness mutually profit and rely upon each other.

The *Dao*’s true singularity—
no color, no sound—
all types and materials depend on it to manifest.
The moving are the five spirits (灵), fur and feathers (毛羽), scales and shells (鳞甲), and winged insects (羽虫);
the growing are grasses and trees (草木).
*Types* (类) refer to *forms*,
*materials* (材) to *substance*.
Though moving and growing forms and substances differ by myriad measures,
it is the *Dao* that nurtures and gives rise to them all.
The *Dao* is but one essence.

The scripture says:
*"In the vague and indistinct, there is an image,"*
meaning this true, pure singularity
gives birth to all forms and substances.
Though few in essence,
it is the source from which the myriad arise.

The myriad orifices—
*Zhuangzi*’s *"Qíwù Piān"* says:
*The southern gate’s Zǐ Qí said to Zǐ Yóu:*
*"The Great Block exhales *qi*—
its name is wind.
When it does not act, it is still;
when it acts, then all orifices roar and howl.
The orifices of a great tree, a hundred spans around,
resemble a nose, a mouth, ears, and a window.
When it is agitated, it makes sounds—
*whoosh*, *hiss*, *shout*, *inhale*, *wail*, *roar*.
A gentle breeze harmonizes the small orifices,
while a gusting wind harmonizes the great ones.
Thus, though the sounds of all orifices differ vastly in scale,
what stirs them is but one wind."*

Observing all under Heaven’s movement and function—
the *Yijing*’s *Xìcí* says:
*"The sage perceives the movement of all under Heaven,"*
meaning the sage possesses subtlety and mystery
to see the myriad transformations of all things,
and knows that all things’ generation and growth
derive from the pure, singular, subtle *Dao*.

Thus, it is said:
*"It never departs from ultimate emptiness and singularity."*

This further elucidates:
*"When Heaven and Earth align, the *Great Transformation*’s efficacy is manifest,"*
and illustrates how the *yoke-axle*’s substance
completes the carriage’s emptiness.

All transformations flow and function through the *Dao*’s utility.
Without the myriad transformations,
the *Dao*’s function would not be revealed—
just as the *yoke-axle* serves the carriage’s purpose,
and Heaven and Earth contain the *Yijing*’s essence.

The carriage is a common instrument,
easily seen by all.
Using it as an analogy to illustrate the subtle *Dao*,
hence it is called a *coarse analogy*.

The potter shapes clay into vessels—
when empty, they serve their purpose.
Blending earth to form vessels
also reveals how substance relies on emptiness for function.

All so-called *instruments* and *functions*,
though their forms differ by myriad measures—
large, small, square, round—
some refined, some crude,
some cheap, some precious—
their true function lies in the vessels’ inner emptiness.

The phrase *"the potter shapes clay"* (范土曰陶) is from the *Shàngshū*.
When *Shun* tilled the *Lìshān* fields,
he farmed at *Lìshān* and pottered at the *Hé*’s banks—
this is the reference.
*The Liexian Zhuan* says:
*"The potter and his disciples, Master Mén,
were all ancient potters.
They mastered the transformation of the five colors of fire
and ascended to Heaven."*

*Carving doors and windows* (凿户牖) yields the function of a dwelling.
Before dwellings existed,
the potter shaped the earth and covered it,
dug the soil and hollowed it out—
when father, son, husband, and wife dwell together, it is called a *family*.
Before there were sleeping halls or ancestral temples,
nor were there *families* or *dwellings*—
*covering* (复) means covering above the ground,
*excavating* (凿) the earth below—
all like the potter’s work.
The potter’s craft is today’s tile kilns.

The *Yijing*’s *Xìcí* says:
*"In ancient times, they dwelled in caves and lived in the wilds;
later sages replaced this with official halls."
This is derived from the *Dà Zhuàng* hexagram,
which governs the construction of halls and dwellings
during the era of cave-dwelling and wild living—
hence it is called *Dà Zhuàng*.
The *Yijing* speaks of the ancients,
meaning before halls and dwellings were built,
they only had summer nests and winter caves—
thus, halls and dwellings were created to replace them,
not that later things superseded earlier ones.»

Thus it is said, *"upper antiquity"*—
that is, the time between **Fuxi** and **Huangdi**.

*The Zhuangzi* ["Thieves and Zhi"] says that the Master spoke of the ancients,
who in summer nested in trees and in winter gathered acorns—
just as it is written.
Within the nests and caves, they took the empty spaces for dwelling.
Now, the halls and dwellings we construct also take their emptiness for habitation—
hence it is said: *"When there is no use for rooms, then there is room for use."*

*"Mothers-in-law and daughters-in-law treading each other’s paths"*—
*shè* (蹊) means a path or way,
*bó* (勃) means anger or resentment.
As in *The Zhuangzi* ["External Things"], it says:
*"When the room is not empty, paths are narrow and confined,
then mothers-in-law and daughters-in-law quarrel over the way they walk."*
A daughter-in-law should yield to her mother-in-law in harmony,
as filial piety and respect demand.
Yet now they quarrel and rage over the path—
this is because the room is narrow and confined,
with no space for private movement,
so they clash and fight instead.
This is called: *"When rooms are narrow and not empty,
mothers-in-law and daughters-in-law quarrel over the path."*

When the heart is clogged and not empty,
then desires and cravings assail it in turn.
*The Er Ya* says:
*"Palaces are called *shì* (室), and rooms are called *gōng* (宫).*
Their sizes differ in construction."
Now, rites have been diminished and reduced—
the dwelling of the sage is called a *gōng* (palace),
while common dwellings are called *jiāshè* (houses), *wūyǔ* (halls), *tángshì* (chambers and rooms), etc.
As the *Lunyu* commentary by **Huang Kan** explains:
*"Within the hall, partitions divide it into inner and outer spaces,
separating it into rooms."*
Thus, Confucius’ disciples were said to have *"ascended the hall"* or *"entered the room."*
So the *táng* (hall) is the general term,
while *shì* (room) is within it, further distinguished.

Thus, *having* is for utility,
while *not having* is for function.
The *Dao* is without form—
it relies on *having* to manifest its efficacy;
without *having*, the *Dao*’s work would not be displayed.
Things are with form—
they rely on the *Dao* to reveal their nature;
without the *Dao*, things would not arise.

Things cannot form and complete themselves without the *Dao*,
and the *Dao* cannot display its function without things—
just as with chariots, tools, and rooms:
all take emptiness to benefit form,
and rely on form to serve emptiness.

That which is above form is the origin of the *Dao*,
dwelling in clarity and emptiness, doing nothing.
That which is below form is the function of the *Dao*,
receiving substance and taking shape below.

The *Dao*’s function is displayed through things,
and things receive form, so they are called *qì* (instruments).
*Qì* are the category of things with form.
The sage follows the *Dao*’s function,
crafting them into instruments:
drawing trigrams and observing symbols,
establishing writing,
hollowing wood for boats,
carving wood for oars,
cutting wood for pestles,
dug earth for mortars,
bending wood for bows,
carving wood for arrows,
constructing halls and dwellings,
knotting nets,
harnessing oxen and riding horses,
carrying burdens and traveling far,
casting metal for weapons,
raising poles for flags,
hewing wood for plows,
twisting wood for plowshares—
each of these, used to benefit the world,
are all divisions of the *Dao*’s function as instruments.

This is what the *Yijing* ["Systematic Commentary"] refers to:
*"The Dao is the name of the formless,
form is the function of the having.
All things arise from the non-being,
all forms are established by the Dao.
First the Dao, then form—
the Dao is above form,
form is below the Dao.
Thus, that which is above form is called the Dao,
and that which is below form is called instruments.
Though form stands at the boundary of Dao and instruments,
it is above instruments, not the Dao itself.
Since it has form and substance to serve as instruments,
it is called ‘that which is below form’—instruments.
The Dao is non-being,
form is being.
Being has limits,
non-being endures forever.
Those who cultivate the Dao
must externally fortify their form to treasure their being,
internally preserve their spirit to venerate their non-being.
Gradually attuning to the subtle non-being,
they align with the Dao,
and thus attain longevity."*

The *Dao* of the utmost unity and non-being,
things have symbols and forms as instruments.
To clarify the *Dao* through instruments,
it again borrows metaphors from chariots, tools, and rooms—
threefold reversals.
Their use in non-being is all of one principle.

When the sage governs the world,
he sets rewards and punishments,
establishes laws and decrees,
issues teachings and clarifies hierarchy—
these are all *having*.
Yet if he governs in silence and stillness,
emptily and calmly guiding people,
without speaking to transform them,
all things regulate themselves—
even with rewards and punishments,
institutions, teachings, and distinctions of rank,
if they are not used,
it can still be said to *"borrow having to employ non-being."*
This is the utmost principle.

In cultivating oneself,
one follows the classics to awaken to reason,
then through enlightenment forgets words,
penetrating the subtle gate—
not clinging to teachings—
is this not the same meaning?

**Song Dao Jun** said:
*"Thirty spokes converge at the hub’s function of non-being.
Having and non-being are in harmony,
utility enters and exits—
this is called the utmost spirit.
Having and non-being differ in appearance,
their substance lies in having,
their function in non-being.
The operation of yin and yang,
the principle of all things.
The chariot’s use is in movement,
the instrument’s use is in containment,
the room’s use is in emptiness.
Mysterious function arises from utmost non-being,
transformation and change are hidden in no burden.
Like a mirror with no image,
it reflects things to display light.
The sage’s use of the heart
ever resolves this truth.
Thus, having is for utility,
non-being is for function—
having is solid,
non-being is empty.
Solidity can embody form, appearance, sound, and color,
possessing substance.
Emptiness can move, measure, and respond without exhaustion.
Between heaven and earth,
the *Dao* manifests through instruments,
so non-being does not abandon having;
instruments rely on the *Dao*’s subtlety,
so having must return to non-being.
Wood bends and water moistens,
fire blazes and metal hardens,
earth balances and grains flourish—
this is *having*, on which people depend for benefit.
The heavens move in their course,
the earth settles in its place,
the four seasons proceed in their order,
all things flourish—
who is their master?
This is *non-being*, though the world does not perceive its traces.
Thus, having is never exhausted,
and having and non-being generate each other."*

**Laozi** expounds these three principles clearly.
**Wang Anshi** said:
*"Thirty spokes converge at the hub’s function of non-being."*

The *Dao* has beginnings and endings.
The beginning is the source from which all things arise,
the ending is the means by which all things are completed.
The beginning emerges through natural spontaneity,
unassisted by human effort,
yet it is the source from which all things arise.
The ending involves form and function,
thus it relies on human effort
before all things can be completed.

When the beginning requires no human effort
yet all things arise from it,
then people may remain silent,
doing nothing.
But when the ending depends on human effort,
then sages must speak,
must act.
Thus, the sages of old,
who governed above and took all things as their responsibility,
employed four methods—ritual, music, punishment, and governance—
these are the means by which all things are completed.
Therefore, sages focus only on refining
the methods that complete all things,
not speaking of those that give rise to them,
for birth comes from natural spontaneity,
which cannot be altered by human effort.

Laozi alone is different.
He believes that whatever involves form and function
is unworthy of mention,
unworthy of action.
Thus, he largely rejects ritual, music, punishment, and governance,
and only speaks of the *Dao*.
This is a failure to discern the Way’s principles,
yet he seeks lofty heights—
an excess of ambition.
What part of the *Dao* does he truly grasp?
Only when form and function are involved
must one depend on human speech,
on human action.
His text says:
*"Thirty spokes meet at the hub,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing.*
The hub’s usefulness is found
where the wheel has no substance.
Yet a craftsman’s carving and shaping
never reaches that emptiness.
For emptiness comes from natural spontaneity,
and human effort cannot alter it.
Those who craft wheels today
know how to shape the hub and spokes,
but never touch the emptiness.
Yet wheels are completed—
the hub and spokes are present,
and thus their use is realized.
If one knows emptiness as the source of use
yet neglects the hub and spokes,
one is already distant from wisdom.
Now, if one knows emptiness as the source of wheel-use,
and emptiness as the source of world-use,
yet does not know how to employ it,
then one is near to folly.

Su Yingbin said:
*"Thirty spokes meet at the hub,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing.*
Exhausting wisdom and resources to create instruments,
yet their true use lies in the emptiness within them.
If there is no emptiness, there is no use for emptiness to achieve.
If there is no instrument, there is no benefit to apply.
Thus, sages always observe emptiness to grasp its subtlety,
and always observe instruments to perceive their boundaries.
Knowing these two as one,
yet inseparable,
then one has reached the utmost.

Lü Jipu said:
*"Thirty spokes meet at the hub,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing.*
The wheel’s hub turns, the spokes point straight—
these are the components that form the wheel.
Thirty spokes symbolize the moon’s phases.
*Bing* (埏) is harmony, *zhi* (埴) is gathering.
The craftsman hollows doors and windows to make a room,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing.
The room is where I dwell.
When riding, I observe the wheel;
when using, I observe the instrument;
when residing, I observe the room—
yet their true use is always found in emptiness.
The principle is not far removed.
But as for the body—
how do I know its use?
Thus, I rely on form for benefit,
and emptiness for use.
If I depend solely on form for use,
and emptiness for benefit,
then what is called benefit
is also discarded and unused.
If I depend on emptiness for use,
and form for benefit,
then what is called use
is also harmful and not beneficial.
Thus, sages act within yet never possess,
acting without yet never abandoning.
This is how emptiness becomes use,
and form becomes benefit.
Therefore, it is said:
*Refine the essence to enter the divine,*
to achieve use;
*benefit and use secure the body,*
to elevate virtue.

Lü Nongshi said:
*"Thirty spokes meet at the hub,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing.*
Form and emptiness rely on each other,
and cannot be considered in isolation.
Thus, without emptiness, one cannot employ form,
and without form, one cannot perceive emptiness.
If one uses form for benefit,
it may lead to stagnation,
but if one uses emptiness for use,
its application is boundless.

Wang Yuanzé said:
*"Thirty spokes meet at the hub,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing.*
These three things—
the wheel, the vessel, and the room—
either move, or store, or dwell,
yet all derive their use from emptiness.
Emptiness is merely the opposite of form,
and form gives rise to emptiness.
Within emptiness,
there is a boundless subtle use,
a subtle function akin to greatness.
Form possesses substance and shape,
yet cannot respond to boundless needs.
Thus, one must rely on form for benefit,
benefit being the realm of the *yin*.
Although this is the theory of form and emptiness,
pushed to its extreme,
emptiness cannot exist apart from form.
Form is also true emptiness,
and neither form nor emptiness—
this is the true subtle mystery.
Liu Zhongping said:
*"Thirty spokes meet at the hub,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing.*
I rely on form for benefit,
and emptiness for use.
The sage’s approach to the world is likewise.
By observing all its benefits,
one can then know its boundless use."*

「The potter blends earth and shapes vessels,
then fires them—
all these tools, carriages, and dwellings
are but means to serve the *yin* benefit of form.

Yet the usefulness of carriages lies in both form and emptiness,
the benefit of dwellings in their vastness,
while vessels, though few and slight in benefit,
still cannot be formed without relying on matter.

For all that serves a benefit—
whether much or little,
whether great or small—
arises from form alone.

Thirty spokes converge at the hub,
yet its purpose is but the wheel.
Though its benefits are manifold,
the hub’s core and the spokes’ alignment
are not yet accounted for.

Thus, the *Zhou Officials* states:
*"A single vessel with two gatherings—
the wheel is the most complex."*

In ancient times, dwellings were dug from the earth,
doors carved for entry and exit,
windows pierced for ventilation.
These structures, shaped by *yin* and *yang*,
established the order of rulers and subjects,
parents and children,
ancestral temples,
courtly assemblies,
and resting places—
all hidden within completion,
yet their benefits were vast indeed.

Hence, the *I Ching* says:
*"Later sages refined the world with roofs and walls,*
taking inspiration from *Great Strength* (*Tai Zhuang*)."
Vessels like pots and jars belong to this category.

Yet even among these,
few are prized,
many are merely functional,
the round follows the compass,
the square the ruler,
the curved the hook,
the straight the plumb line—
none without benefit from form,
though their true use lies in the realm of emptiness.

The Master Lao expounds upon this,
to reveal that though emptiness depends on form to manifest its use,
one cannot discard emptiness for the sake of benefit alone.

Thus, when form decays,
emptiness remains.
The principle of benefit and use:
united, they are one;
separated, they are two.

Benefit and use are not the same—
benefit is the realm of *yin*,
while use is rooted in emptiness.
The wheel’s benefit lies in its form,
the vessel’s in its blending and shaping,
the dwelling’s in its doors and windows—
yet their true use resides in emptiness.

This is why the sage *Mencius* said:
*"The ancient ways took benefit as their foundation,
and the Great Yu’s drainage of waters
was but the removal of what was not needed.*
Here, the use of emptiness is revealed.

The prior chapter spoke of *Mysterious Virtue* (*Xuande*),
yet *Mysterious Virtue* is relative to emptiness—
thus, it follows with the wheel’s thirty spokes converging at the hub.

Liu Ji said:
*"Thirty spokes meet at the hub,
yet its usefulness lies in the space where there is nothing."*

Exalted Master Bian Que taught:
*"Within the human body are five *zang* organs,
where the True Qi converges.*
Each of the five *zang* is governed by six *qi*,
thus the origin of the thirty-six convergence lies in them—
just as the wheel’s thirty spokes.
Flowing without ceasing,
they unite at the single hub,
like the thirty spokes converging at the hub.

The sage understands the pivot of transformation,
using form as its physical manifestation,
the body as a furnace,
the Three Palaces as tripods,
and refining within the void—
as boundless as the carriage one rides,
the vessels one employs,
and the dwelling one inhabits.
Form serves as the vessel,
emptiness as the use.
Thus, form is for benefit,
emptiness for use.

The ignorant of this age
hear only of the Dao of abandoning the body,
yet fail to grasp the subtlety of entering it.
This is why the Master Lao
uses the wheel, vessels, and dwellings
as detailed analogies.

It is like the *Qian* and *Kun* forming ranks,
yet the *I Ching* stands within them—
when *Qian* and *Kun* perish,
the *I Ching* cannot be seen;
when form decays,
the spirit cannot be preserved—
this is why form and spirit must both be refined.

The sage uses form as its vessel,
emptiness as its spirit,
entering form to reach emptiness,
and employing the false to attain the true.

How could mere appearance, name, or sound
be sufficient to grasp its essence?
Thus, it follows with the five colors.

Zhao Shizhen said:
*"First, it illustrates the principle that emptiness is the root of use:
One, to elucidate the *Qian* and *Kun* cycle of return.
Thirty spokes converge at the hub—
when emptiness is present,
the wheel’s use emerges.
The Dao, though void, manifests as use;
its function unseen,
it relies on substance to reveal itself.
Things, though solid, depend on voidness for their benefit;
their emptiness unseen,
they borrow the void for their capacity.
One vessel, one use—
mutually clarifying,
one and emptiness alone can truly manifest.
The use of emptiness is clear in principle,
the function of the void is unfathomable in Dao.
Thus, one knows that substance alone cannot serve as use,
while voidness harmonizes with all things.
Using three objects to display the mechanism,
testing two aspects to glimpse the one—
the alchemical method follows the lunar cycle,
advancing and receding in thirty days,
then naturally waxing and waning.

One is the hub—
though it has form, it is not used.
Thirty are the spokes—
the count of the moon’s phases,
all revolving around this principle.

To employ emptiness in guiding form—
without the hub,
the spokes have no place to rest,
just as the Dao governs time—
without the days,
the moon would not arise.
The *yin* void depends on substance to borrow,
its eclipses and waxings shaped by the interplay of light and dark.
The *yang* substance contains the void,
nurturing the *yin* like a toad,
and gestating the *moon* within the *yin* like a hare in shadow.

This is how the alchemist
takes the *Qian* and *Kun* cycle of return,
and clarifies the benefits of form and emptiness.

The Dao originally has no image,
yet alchemy arises naturally.
The hub and spokes illustrate the thirty-six principles,
and the text expounds on form and emptiness
as the foundation of benefit and use—
thus, the adept of the Way
responds to all things through emptiness,
while substance obstructs and does not flow.

Hence, emptiness is for benefit,
form is for use.

The spokes and the hub
comprise the wheel’s complete structure.
The spokes’ use lies in the hub—
voidness guides all things,
as if the hub were solid and the spokes hollow—
where would they rest?

Again, it is said:
*"The wheel is beneath the house."*
When emptiness is present,
it refers to the void within the hub.
With solid spokes and an empty hub,
the wheel’s use emerges.
When it moves without end,
then the wheel’s benefit is truly stored.

Thus, form is for benefit,
emptiness for use.

Two, it points to blending and shaping.
Blending and shaping create vessels—
when emptiness is present,
the vessel’s use emerges.
Blending and shaping mean
mixing clay and kneading earth to form vessels—
today’s pots and jars are examples.
Their emptiness is used—
when they can be filled,
that is the vessel’s benefit.

Heaven and Earth arise from the void,
yet generate all things.
The Great Dao, though void,
encompasses Heaven, Earth, and humanity,
and with a void heart
responds to all existence.
Blending and shaping use emptiness within
to receive all things—
thus, one knows that blending and shaping
are the benefit of form,
while emptiness within
is the use of emptiness.»

---

Having first clarified the meaning of the wheel’s hub and spokes,
now further elucidating the principle of blending and shaping,
for indeed the interplay of form and emptiness exhausts the Dao’s full function—
its meaning profound and subtle, not easily comprehended.
This is the very nature of reality aligned with the Way of Heaven.

Thus, it further illustrates the principle of doors and windows.

**Three: The Principle of Doors and Windows.**
Carve doors and windows to make a hall—
its emptiness is the void #1,
yet it yields the use of a chamber.
Barriers block the light,
but emptiness allows all things to be contained.
In all cases, one takes emptiness within for use.

Half a door becomes a door,
crossed wood becomes a window.
Doors function by opening and closing,
windows serve by revealing light.
If doors and windows were not carved,
how would halls and chambers exist?
Removing obstructions creates emptiness,
and chambers take this emptiness for dwelling—
thus, doors and windows are for benefit,
while chambers are for use.
For doors and windows provide the use of chambers,
and only then can chambers be complete.

Yet it does not end with these three—
taking emptiness for use applies to all things.
Grain stores are empty yet receive,
flutes and keys are empty yet sound,
vessels are empty yet hold,
boats are hollow yet carry.

The Most High points to these three,
and the rest may be inferred.
Later, it clarifies the uses of form and emptiness.
Thus, form is for benefit,
emptiness is for use.
Using vessels to manifest the Dao,
the Dao is then clearly seen within vessels.
Using emptiness as function,
function is then not found in solidity.

Yet vessels cannot be destroyed—
if vessels are destroyed, their use cannot be made clear.
Borrowing things to make statements,
without things, words have no foundation—
thus, the wheel’s emptiness fulfills its function of transport,
taking the creative vigor of *Qian* to generate all things as its model.
Blending and shaping have emptiness within for use,
taking the receptive emptiness of *Kun* to contain all things as its model.
Doors and windows have chambers for use,
comparing the emptiness of the heart to supply all affairs as its model.
Thus, one knows emptiness itself has efficacy,
the Dao is revealed through vessels—
who would say the void is useless?
They do not know that daily use lies in emptiness.

To say only form and appearance are true,
yet not know that form and appearance obscure their use.

Zhuangzi said:
*"The void is not destroyed, all things are real."*
Benefit and use are both illuminated.

*The System of Changes* says:
*"If *Qian* and *Kun* are destroyed, there will be no way to see the *Yi*."*
When emptiness and reality illuminate each other,
only then does one know the pivot begins,
obtaining the central harmony
to respond to the boundless.

Shao Ruoyu said:
*"Thirty spokes converge at one hub—
emptiness is their use."*

Laozi, using the wheel, chambers, and vessels,
illustrates the principles of things—
form and emptiness, benefit and use.
Borrowing form for benefit,
within emptiness, the wondrous and inexhaustible use is revealed.

Take the wheel, for instance—
today’s eighteen spokes, ancient thirty,
all converging at one hub to form a wheel.
Borrowing the wheel for its tangible benefit,
within its emptiness lies the wondrous function—
in its rotation, one knows emptiness is the wheel’s use.

Blending and shaping kneads clay to make vessels,
borrowing vessels for their tangible benefit,
within their emptiness lies the wondrous use—
in their capacity to hold and store.
Thus, one knows emptiness is the vessel’s use.

Ancient dwellings were dug from earth,
doors were carved for entry and exit,
windows for viewing the outside—
only then were the institutions of rulers, ministers, parents, children,
ancestral temples, and feasts established as chambers.
Borrowing chambers for their tangible benefit,
within their emptiness lies the wondrous function—
in their capacity for dwelling.
Thus, one knows emptiness is the chamber’s use.

Therefore, form is taken for benefit,
emptiness for wondrous use—
thus, borrowing the phantom body for benefit,
the heart of no-mind for use.
This teaches the student to embody the logic of form and emptiness,
to grasp the Dao’s benefit and use.

Wang Zhiran said:
*"Thirty spokes converge at one hub—
emptiness is their use."*

Mankind, born into the cosmos,
faces urgent daily needs—
three things the body cannot do without:
vehicles, tools, and dwellings.
Form is for benefit,
emptiness is for use.
If benefit and use are not properly aligned,
they become grave afflictions for the living.

Those who do not understand must first consider what suits them,
then determine the right course.

As for vehicles, from the Son of Heaven to commoners,
each has their due.
The Son of Heaven’s chariots are called "ten thousand,"*
lords "thousand,"*
ministers "hundred,"*
while commoners ride single-horse carts at most.
Few is not lacking,
but excess is sure to transgress propriety—
adding ornate decorations, embroidered reins,
yet not calling it deceitful or disrupting norms—what else could it be?
Thus, the ancients valued simplicity,
and even riding or walking followed ritual.
Hence, the Master walked when the Master walked,
ran when the Master ran—
the gentleman’s daily conduct never strayed from essentials.

Some fed horses and oiled chariots,
yet still seemed excessive in their extravagance,
deviating from the Sage’s pure and unadorned way of governing past and present.
To the point of hunting excursions,
breaking axles, wheels left unfinished—
how could such recklessness be fitting?

As for blending and shaping,
it refers to molding clay and crafting pottery.
The ancients used what was sufficient,
discarded what was spent—
no hoarding, no waste.
The people found joy in food and drink alone.
How could they know the quality of their tools?

In recent times, however,
strange novelties are prized,
wealth and ease sought above all—
none can match the age’s indulgence.
Yet even the sun’s warmth is not valued for its rarity,
only for its comfort to body and mouth—
people fail to heed the gradual loss.

The *Classic* says:
*"Carve doors and windows to make a chamber."*
This refers to ancient dwellings in trees and caves—
initially to avoid cold and heat,
to shelter from wind and rain.
Yet Emperor Yao built a three-step earthen platform,
thatched roof untrimmed,
and the people found contentment in their homes,
joy in their customs—
thus the land was in great harmony.

The Five Hegemons were not far removed from antiquity,
yet their carved beams and towering eaves,
their rafters reaching like clouds—
they still found their dwellings too narrow,
ashamed that their earthworks were not yet grand.
The hues of ochre and white left no craft unexploited,
while the five granaries grew empty and tranquil without their knowing.
Truly, they could not observe themselves through themselves,
their households through their households,
their villages through their villages,
their states through their states,
the world through the world—
lest they be lashed for their past mistakes.

Alas! All know the use of what is *useful*,
yet none grasp the use of what is *useless*.
Being and non-being, emptiness and substance,
mutually lend each other form.
When empty, no trace is seen;
when traced, it arises from what is.
Speaking of non-being, how could one know
the source of traces?

Thus Laozi expounded these three principles
to illuminate the ultimate of being and non-being, utility and use.

A chariot excels in bearing,
a vessel in containing,
a dwelling in sheltering—
all shaped forms are but *being*.
Lose it to non-being, and it cannot serve its purpose.
Lose it to being, and it cannot bring benefit.
Thus, non-being and being, utility and use—
even the ancient sages took them as models.
Students must not deceive themselves.

Program Tai said:
*"Thirty spokes converge at a single nave—
its use lies in the void.*
The function of storage is the chariot’s purpose.
When spokes and nave are complete,
only then can it bear and carry.
Yet a chariot without spokes and nave
lacks a foundation to reveal its function.
But examining its principle,
the grinding of earth and the turning of wheels
lie beyond all material substance—
thus, the chariot’s function belongs to non-being,
not to being.

That a vessel can contain,
that a dwelling can be inhabited—
their use does not depend on being,
but arises from non-being.
The principle is one.
Thus Laozi spoke metaphorically
to show the worth of non-being.
Indeed, it is so.

Therefore, the chariot-maker first prepares spokes and nave
as its foundation,
yet expects its function to lie beyond spokes and nave—
in the realm of non-being.
What is called *being* is sought to achieve it;
what is called *non-being* is sought to transcend it.

「This meaning is indeed a metaphor for Daoist learning—
the more one cultivates the Way, the greater the loss of rigid attachments,
and its principle rests solely in the interplay of form and emptiness.

Those who doubt Laozi’s teachings in the world
do so because they believe his "non-being" lacks substance,
and thus cannot govern—
they fail to grasp that Laozi’s "non-being"
aims to transcend "being" in order to utilize it,
not to negate all form and function utterly from beginning to end.

The essence lies in the balance of intent and totality.

The words of King Linchuan [Wang Bi] state:
*"The chariot-maker knows to govern its spokes and nave,
yet never seeks to grasp ‘non-being’—
yet ‘non-being’ arises as its very function once spokes and nave are complete."*

If one were to discard the spokes and nave from the chariot,
or abandon rites, music, punishments, and governance in the world,
and seek "non-being" as their sole function,
then such reasoning is close to folly.
This is a misinterpretation of Laozi’s intent.

Laozi’s teachings seek to fulfill the utility of rites and laws,
while transcending them to achieve true function.
His words on "being" and "non-being"
are akin to "gain" and "loss."

To "gain" is to seek what one does not yet possess;
to "loss" is to transform what one already has.
This is his application of chariot principles to human affairs.

When one seeks "being," it means accumulating trust and goodness
to fill oneself,
and to make them substantial and grand.
When one seeks "non-being," it means taking what is already full and transforming it,
so that its traces vanish yet its function remains.
The phrases "being" and "non-being"
refer to the realm where human effort is applied.

Yet King Linchuan’s theory equates "being" and "non-being"
to their completion,
as if Laozi did not know that a chariot without wheels
cannot be drawn or pushed.
Indeed, Laozi’s words are subtle and difficult to fathom—
though King Linchuan most cherished his text,
he still erred in following the words while losing their meaning.
The calamity of the Western Jin [dynasty] stemmed precisely from this.

They took Laozi’s metaphorical language to belittle rites and laws,
attaching themselves to the realm of discarding benevolence and righteousness.
Hearing of Laozi’s reverence for *wuwei* [non-action],
they hoped to govern without spokes and nave,
as if a chariot could move itself.
They failed to understand that within metaphorical language lies true principle,
and that *wuwei* [non-action] itself contains *wu buwei* [no non-action].

He merely sought to employ the spokes and nave
to manifest the function of "non-being,"
yet never abandoned them to neglect their "being."
Laozi’s teachings began to take effect in governance
from the Han dynasty onward.
When Cao Can [曹参] served Emperor Xuan [孝思],
and Emperor Wen [文帝] succeeded Emperor Gao [高帝],
they achieved harmony through *qingjing* [tranquility and simplicity],
and purity through *yuandu* [primordial stillness],
though they did not fully transform "being" into "non-being,"
they could still be said to have transcended form and substance
to gather emptiness.

Yet their *qingjing* and *yuandu*
were not equivalent to abandoning all governance.
The foundational laws of Emperor Gao were still in place,
and Xiao He’s [萧何] institutions remained.
Thus, the spokes and nave were already prepared in advance.
Hence, Cao Can and Emperor Wen could rely on their utility,
achieving stillness when they wished and silence when they desired.

If one were to discard Emperor Gao’s laws
and Xiao He’s regulations entirely,
leaving all to indifference,
then the Western Jin would have already perished.

Huang Maocai [黄茂材] said:
*"Thirty spokes converge at the hub to serve the function of ‘non-being.’
There is ‘being’ within ‘being,’ and ‘being’ within ‘non-being.’
‘Being’ within ‘non-being’ has boundless function;
‘being’ within ‘being’ offers great benefit.
The spokes and nave form the chariot,
clay and mud shape the vessel,
doors and windows create the dwelling—
these are ‘being’ within ‘being,’
upon which people depend for extensive utility.
Though there may be no chariot, its function remains;
though there may be no vessel, its function remains;
though there may be no dwelling, its function remains—
this is ‘being’ within ‘non-being.’
The enlightened and accomplished rely on its boundless function.
Today, texts like *The Parameters of the Same* [*参同契*] and *The Yellow Court Scripture* [*黄庭经*]
abound with such sayings,
for they have their origins.

Zhan Qiupu [詹秋圃] said:
*"In ancient times, ten spokes converged at a single hub
to serve the function of ‘non-being.’
The chapter ‘On Non-Action’ [无用] within *On Non-Action* [无用]
still contains practical application.
Though a chariot with thirty spokes revolves harmoniously around one hub,
even at the dawn of creation when there was no chariot,
its function of bearing loads was already inherent—
it cannot be discarded.
Though clay and mud are molded into vessels,
even at the beginning when there were no vessels,
their function as containers was already present—
it cannot be omitted.
Again, when doors, windows, and openings are carved to form dwellings,
even at the time when there were no dwellings,
their function as shelter was already there—
how much more so must one have refuge and rest!
These three [chariot, vessel, dwelling]
derive their utility from earth and wood,
yet their practical functions are ever-present.
From ‘non-being’ to ‘being,’
‘non-being’ is merely a means to harness utility for greater utility—
this is the function of ‘non-being.’

Zhang Chongying [张冲应] replied:
*"Thirty spokes converge at the hub to serve the function of ‘non-being.’
The heavens possess the Six Qi [六气], the earth the Five Phases [五行].
The Six Qi are yin, yang, wind, rain, darkness, and brightness.
The Five Phases are water, wood, fire, earth, and metal.
When heaven and earth first divided,
water came first,
and when humans first took form,
water was their foundation.
Water governs the kidneys, the root of life.
In the earth, the number six generates wood,
wood governs the liver, the abode of the soul.
In the earth, the number eight generates fire,
fire governs the heart, the chamber of the spirit.
In the earth, the number two generates soil,
soil governs the spleen, the seat of intent.
In the earth, the number ten generates metal,
metal governs the lungs, the repository of the vital breath.
In the earth, the number four regenerates water.
The Five Phases in the earth, in their cyclic generation,
comprise thirty in total.
This is the *qi* [vital force] of the body,
which moves and operates in accordance with it—
without contradiction.
Thus it is said: ‘Thirty spokes converge at one hub,’
meaning that humans are confined within the earth’s framework,
and the Five Phases, following the earth’s thirtyfold cycle,
operate to ensure the Six Qi flow harmoniously—
just as thirty spokes enable the hub’s rotation.
Others might say that the Five Phases generate in cycles,
and the Six Qi harmonize in balance,
and that five and six combine to form thirty.
The *qi* [vital force] moves itself—
all are one explanation.
Yet the hub’s value lies in its rotation,
and it cannot rotate if its core is hollowed out.
»*

The Five Phases’ thirtyfold cycle does not generate through emptiness—
then how would the Six *Qi* move and circulate?
The hub moves through emptiness,
and thus the chariot, through the hub’s rotation, can bear loads and serve its purpose;
the *qi* moves through emptiness,
and thus the body, through the *qi*’s circulation, can nourish and serve its purpose.
Hence, from non-being arises being,
and being is what is put to use.

As for earth forming vessels,
if it does not blend water, wood, fire, and metal in empty harmony,
it cannot contain its contents.
Carving doors and windows to make a dwelling,
if its halls are not left empty,
it cannot house its inhabitants.
Thus it is said:
When its emptiness is right, there is the chariot’s function;
when its emptiness is right, there is the vessel’s function;
when its emptiness is right, there is the chamber’s function.
*"Right"* means aligning with their natural state.
The chariot can bear things,
the vessel can hold things,
the chamber can contain people—
these are the uses of being for utility.
Being is used for utility,
yet it arises from the operation of emptiness.

The chariot, vessel, and chamber—
their utility through emptiness is thus,
and how much more so for humans,
who receive the Five Phases,
circulate the Six *Qi*,
and transform into spirit?

This chapter is Laozi’s exposition of the fallen earthly form,
to elucidate its meaning.

Zhang Lingying says:
In the human body, the essence above is like the spokes,
the *qi* like the hub.
The *qi* issues from non-being,
propelling the essence-spokes,
the essence condenses into being,
and together they revolve.
When the *qi* ascends, the essence descends;
when the essence ascends, the *qi* circulates.
They nourish each other without ceasing—
yet the *qi* cannot be diminished by a single measure,
nor the essence wasted by a single measure.
So long as non-being and being interact,
understanding the spokes and hub’s function—
what difficulty is there in longevity?
For essence belongs to yin,
following the earth’s thirtyfold cycle as thirty spokes.
The *qi* belongs to yang,
following heaven’s twofold cycle—
fifteen as one hub.
Without the hub, how can the spokes turn?
Without the *qi*, how can the essence move?
Such is their function.

Bai Yuxian says:
Thirty spokes—
like thirty days.
Shared by one hub—
one month is thus.
When its emptiness is right—
months wax and wane.
The chariot’s use—
even in small months, a month is complete.
Earthen vessels—
yin and yang interact, completing transformation.
When its emptiness is right—
heaven and earth lack no function,
sages lack no ability.
The vessel’s use—
though sometimes insufficient, heaven’s work is seen.
Carving doors and windows for a chamber—
ten thousand forms gathered in one net,
aligned with the celestial unity.
When its emptiness is right—
spirit does not guard its dwelling,
the five senses lose their watch.
The chamber’s use—
sages and fools share the same nature,
their wills turn inward to the external.
Thus being is used for utility—
obtaining one’s parents’ body for function.
Emptiness is used for utility—
preserving the original, undivided nature,
neither inner nor outer.

Liao Cuiran says:
Thirty spokes—
like the sun and moon as a jade disk,
one month completing a heavenly revolution.
Shared by one hub—
like the body’s primordial *qi*,
also revolving once a month.
When its emptiness is right—
unified by the One.

「The use of a carriage—
it may serve as my conveyance.
Molding clay to make a vessel—
with the *qi* of Yellow Court refining the soul and spirit,
refined by water and fire to form its substance.
When its emptiness is right—
the Dao governs its use.
The use of a vessel—
it may serve as my grand vessel.
Carving doors and windows for a chamber—
clearing paths for rear gates, for ease with water and fire.
Opening windows at the *chǐ zhái* [measure of land], to commune with the divine.
When its emptiness is right—
it is used as a comparison.

The use of a chamber—
it may serve as my divine abode.
Thus, the use of being is for advantage—
the *Tàishàng* [Supreme Venerable] speaks of its details.
The use of emptiness is for function—
no need for heavy labor, no burden of annotations,
two hands freely bestowed.

Chen Bìxū says:
From the thirty spokes to the use of a carriage—
this illustrates the interplay of *you* [being] and *wú* [emptiness],
mutually supporting each other.

The *Zhōulǐ* [Rites of Zhou] *Kāogōngjì* [Record of Crafts] states:
The carriage cover is round to symbolize heaven,
the carriage frame is square to follow earth.
Thirty spokes represent the count of one month.
The moon hangs in heaven, flowing endlessly.
The carriage wheels roll on earth, turning without bound.
Thus, ancient carriages symbolized the moon.
Moreover, thirty days compose one month,
just as thirty spokes unite at one hub.

When the hub’s center is empty—
the wheels can turn,
when the carriage’s interior is empty—
people can ride upon it.
Thus, its emptiness holds the use of turning and bearing.

Yán Jūnping says:
In the age of great antiquity, the sage ruled the people,
following the natural course of heaven and earth,
without contrivance of cleverness.
Drinking, they used gourds;
eating, they used their hands.
All things were equal, with no high or low.

When kings began to act with purpose,
they imposed heavy burdens and laborious tasks,
until the people were utterly exhausted.
The demands of the ruler were insatiable,
tribute came from afar,
men and women laden with burdens,
unable to bear the weight.

Thus, the wise crafted the wheel hub,
harnessed horses and oxen,
bore heavy loads and reached distant places,
easing the people’s toil.

Later generations followed suit,
and craftsmanship grew ever more intricate—
painted hubs and vermilion wheels,
adorned with gold and silver,
and embellished with jade pendants.
The cost of one carriage
could impoverish a household.

Hence, the *Lǎozǐ* [Old Master] lamented the harm of artificial creation to *moral virtue*,
and illuminated how doing good breeds disorder.

Thus, he expounds on the three matters of carriage, vessel, and chamber,
to explain how *you* and *wú* mutually support their uses,
and offers warning accordingly.

Molding clay to make a vessel—
when its emptiness is right,
it holds the use of a vessel.
*Cóng* [molding] is harmony.
*Zhí* [clay] is sticky earth.
The craftsman blends harmony with sticky earth,
shapes it into vessels,
and takes the emptiness within them—
this is the use of containing all things.

Yán Jūnping says:
In times when *moral virtue* and the Dao decline,
worries assail the inner self,
while yin and yang harm the outer.
The people grow weak and emaciated,
plagued by sickness.
Thus, water and fire arise together,
the five flavors form in confusion,
raw and cooked are not distinguished,
dryness and dampness are not separated.
Hence, the wise mold earth into vessels,
to cook sour and salty foods,
and so reach the point of field hunting and decadent excess,
ravaging all living beings,
hollowing wombs and slaughtering grains,
to gratify the ruler’s desires,
and carving jade into ornaments,
for cups and basins.
Ah! From simple vessels to such extravagance.

Carving doors and windows for a chamber—
when its emptiness is right,
it holds the use of a chamber.
*Záo* [carving] is piercing.
The half-door is called *hù*,
the window beside the door is called *yǒu*.
Door, window, half-door, and side-window—
all are general terms.
In ancient times, dwellings were dug-out caves,
piercing the earth within the hole to cover it above.
Making doors and windows was for habitation,
and taking the emptiness within—
this is the use of resting, entering, and exiting.

Yán Jūnping says:
Once the human heart changes,
all things harbor resentment,
serpents and insects rise,
poisons and calamities multiply,
beasts and wild animals harm the people.
Thus, caves and holes are insufficient
to ward off calamities,
to preserve life,
or to complete one’s natural years.
Hence, the wise build dwellings—
roofs above, eaves below,
piercing windows for observation,
fortifying gates and closing them tight,
opening and shutting with swift ease,
so that wasps and insects cannot enter,
beasts and wild animals cannot approach.
Later, this led to ornate pavilions and perilous towers,
the *Āfáng* [Hall of Ease] palaces,
great gates guarding strategic passes,
and building walls for defense.
Soldiers grow weary and exhausted,
and countless die in the process.
Yet what was once deemed governance
later became seen as chaos—
this is the fault of *you* and *wú* mutually supporting their uses.
It lies in the hands of the people.

Thus, the use of *you* is for advantage,
while the function of *wú* is for use.
This clarifies the three matters above,
showing how *you* and *wú* mutually support each other,
and neither can be neglected.

The use of *you* is for advantage,
while the function of *wú* is for utility.
The advantage of *you* lies in its outward form,
which relies on windows and openings to manifest.
The utility of *wú* lies in its inward void,
which depends on vessels and forms to fulfill its purpose.
Thus, *wú* relies on *you* for advantage,
while *you* relies on *wú* for utility.

*Wú* aligns with the Dao,
while *you* forms the vessel.
The Dao, though formless,
must rely on *you* to display its power.
If *you* were absent, how could the Dao’s power be shown?

The vessel, though formed,
must rely on *wú* to complete its use.
If *wú* were lost, how could the vessel’s function be fulfilled?

Thus, vessels without the Dao cannot be applied,
and the Dao without vessels cannot display its power—
just as the hub has spokes,
the vessel contains things,
and the chamber holds people.
All depend on *wú* to benefit *you*,
and *you* to utilize *wú*.

Furthermore, governing the body—
the spirit is the advantage for sustaining life,
the void is the function for gathering the spirit.
Thus, *wú* can govern and apply,
while *you* can benefit and serve.

Benefiting things lies in *you*,
while governing and applying lies in *wú*.
For *wú* is the state of emptiness and tranquility.»

The *you* is what is called **divine luminosity**.
Divine luminosity is the wondrous *you*,
while the void and tranquility is the utmost *wú*.

The wondrous *you*’s virtue lies in its benefit,
and that benefit is in sustaining life.
The utmost *wú*’s function is in its application,
and that application is in gathering the divine luminosity.
Indeed, the virtue of sustaining life and gathering the divine luminosity
do not exceed the realm of wondrous *you* and utmost *wú*.

Thus, it is said that *you* is used for its virtue,
and *wú* is used for its function.

Xie Tuonan remarked:
*"The thirty spokes converge to fulfill their function.*
The wheel’s turning depends on the hub.
The thirty spokes unite at one hub,
symbolizing the thirty days that constitute a month.

Things in their solidity rely on the void to move,
the spokes gather at the hub,
the hub turns within the void.
Thus, when it is merely *you*,
it is insufficient to show the wheel’s function,
but *wú* is the very means by which the wheel’s function is realized.

*Molding clay to form vessels is the ultimate function of *you*.*
*Molding* refers to pottery,
*clay* refers to earth.
Pottery shapes clay into vessels—useful things.
Yet vessels receive objects through their inner void.
Thus, when it is merely *you*,
it is insufficient to show the vessel’s function,
but *wú* is the very means by which the vessel’s function is realized.

*Carving doors and windows is the ultimate function of *you*.*
The *chamber* is where people dwell,
*doors and windows* are the means of entry and exit.
The chamber’s inner void makes it habitable,
the door’s inner void makes it passable.
When it is merely *you*,
it is insufficient to show the chamber’s function,
but *wú* is the very means by which the chamber’s function is realized.

Thus, *you* is the ultimate means of function.
Without spokes, one cannot make a wheel;
without clay, one cannot make a vessel;
without doors and windows, one cannot make a chamber.
Therefore, *you* is what brings virtue to the world,
while *wú* is what brings function to the world.
The solid relies on the void to contain,
the *you* relies on the *wú* to move—
this is the principle.

Indeed, I have discussed it:
The *you* above form is called the **Dao/Way**,
the *you* below form is called **vessel**.
The vessel takes shape through *you*,
the Dao/Way is concealed within *wú*,
so *you* cannot move *you*,
while *wú* is the very means by which *you*’s function is realized.

And so it is with humanity.
The movement of the limbs is like the wheel’s spokes,
the arrangement of the chest and heart is like the chamber’s structure.
If there were merely solid things and *you*,
would that not be called a vessel?
But the **soul’s platform** is void within,
the means by which it contains all within and moves all without,
and responds to limitless functions—
this is the case.

Otherwise, it would be but a rigid mass,
what use would it be?

Lin Yongzhai said:
*"The thirty spokes converge at one hub—
the utmost *wú* is what fulfills their function.*
The hub is the axle that holds the wheel,
the spokes are the ribs of the wheel.
Only because the hub is void within can the wheel move.

*Molding clay to form vessels*—
pottery’s vessels are void within, thus can they be shaped.
*Doors and windows*—
the luminous passages in the chamber.
These three examples all illustrate the void’s role in function.
Thus, it is said that *you* is used for its virtue,
and *wú* is used for its function.

Wheels, vessels, and chambers—
all are the virtues of solid *you*,
yet their very nature as wheels, chambers, and vessels
depends on the void’s function within.
With this, the single character *wú* is wonderfully depicted.

Fan Yingyuan said:
*"The thirty spokes converge—
this is the utmost *you* that fulfills the wheel’s function.*
The spokes are the wheel’s rim.
The *Shuowen Jiezi* states:
*The wheel is the rim;
the hub is where the spokes gather.*
This single character *wú* is a perfect verse,
illustrating how things reveal the Dao’s boundless function.
Ancient artisans crafted vessels by following natural forms.
The wheel’s spokes numbered thirty,
symbolizing a month’s days.
The hub’s void and passage allow the wheel to turn.
Thus, the thirty spokes gathering at one hub—
when the void is present, the wheel’s function is realized.

*Molding clay to form vessels*—
this is the utmost *you* that fulfills the chamber’s function.
*Molding* refers to blending,
*clay* is sticky earth, as in the *Shuowen Jiezi*.
It means blending sticky earth to form vessels.
Half a door is called a *door*,
intersecting wood is called a *window*.
If vessels are void within, they can hold objects;
if chambers are void within, they can shelter people.
Thus, when the void is present,
the vessel’s and chamber’s functions are realized.

Zhuangzi said:
*'If a chamber lacks emptiness and void,*
*then mothers-in-law and daughters-in-law will jostle within.*
*'If the heart lacks boundless freedom,*
*then the six senses will vie for dominance.*
This too uses things to illustrate the heart’s void and passage in function.
Thus, it is said that *you* is used for its virtue,
and *wú* is used for its function.

Therefore, all solid *you* is used for its virtue,
while all void *wú* is used for its function.
It is not only wheels, vessels, and chambers that are so.
How can this be verified?
My body has form,
yet within it, there are formless *wú* that fulfill its function.
It is not merely my body—
all things in heaven and earth are the same.

Xue Yongqi said:
*"The thirty spokes converge at one hub—
the utmost *wú* is what fulfills their function.*
These three examples show *you* and *wú* mutually relying on each other for function.

Chu Boixiu said:
*"The thirty spokes converge at one hub—
the utmost *wú* is what fulfills their function.*
The hub and spokes form the wheel,
the void within carries objects.
Molding clay forms vessels,
the void within stores objects.
Carving doors and windows forms chambers,
the void within shelters people.
Their mutual reliance on *you* and *wú* for function is evident.

*You* is the vessel—
artificial, thus subject to creation and destruction.
*Wú* is the Dao—
natural, thus without end.
Take the human body:
The head, eyes, hands, and feet are all solid *you*,
yet they all depend on the formless *wú* within to move.
Seeing, hearing, grasping, walking,
speaking, and acting—
all require the *wú* to function,
so vast is the *wú*’s role.

When life ends,
the body lies still in the great chamber,
the head, eyes, hands, and feet remain intact,
yet the *wú* no longer moves them—
no different from a wooden puppet—
because the divine luminosity has departed,
while the earthly frame remains.

However, *you* and *wú* mutually rely on each other,
and neither can be neglected.
If one were to take a mortal body
to cultivate the **sage’s fruit**,
by obstructing it to achieve utter void,
what harm would there be?

In general, *you* is finite,
*wú* is infinite—
this is why they differ in virtue and function.

The chapter expounds only the single character **無** (*wú*).
It is because of **無** (*wú*) that function is possible.
All things under heaven take form to achieve the work of vehicles and dwellings,
yet rely on **無** (*wú*) for their essence and **有** (*yǒu*) for their utility—
then they are not confined merely to vehicles and dwellings alone.

Zhuangzi says: *"Obtain its central pivot to respond to the boundless."*
All are skilled in establishing metaphors.
Some interpret the thirty spokes as corresponding to the number of days in a month,
a later passage finding it forced and awkward.

Others take **無有** (*wúyǒu*) as *"not yet having"* and cite the *Yì* [□] *Xìyǔ* [系辞] on the advantage of boats and oars,
taken from the *Hàn* [涣] hexagram,
and *"riding oxen, mounting horses,"*
taken from the *Suí* [随] hexagram,
as proof—
saying that even before these implements existed,
their functional principle was already present.
This is another view.

Niu Miao’s *Transmission* states: *"The thirty spokes yield the use of a chariot."*
A single chariot has thirty spokes,
and a month has thirty days.
When it speaks of the chariot hub,
it refers to the sun and moon.
If spoken of in terms of **道** (*Dào*),
then before the Great Primordium (*Dàpuǎo*) had yet divided,
before heaven and earth had roots,
before the sun and moon shone,
there was originally no use of sun and moon.

In terms of implements and utility,
the Age of Great Simplicity (*Shànggǔ Chúnpǔ*)
was pure and unknowing,
with no use of chariot hubs for turning or transporting.
It was only from the Yellow Emperor onward,
observing the revolving of the wild grass (*péng*),
that he fashioned the chariot
to bear heavy loads and reach distant places.
Later generations, indulgent in luxury,
adorned it with gold and jade,
and painted its hubs with vermilion and cinnabar.
The Most High Sage (*Tàishàng*)
witnessed the customs growing extravagant,
the purity of antiquity fading,
and thus composed this sigh:
*"When there was yet no chariot,
its use was already present."*

Molding clay to make vessels,
when there was yet no vessel,
its use was already present.
*"Molding"* means blending,
*"clay"* refers to earth—
it speaks of blending earth to make vessels.
Vessels (*qìng*) are the tripod vessels.
Ancient people took heaven and earth as the divine tripod vessel,
and the sun and moon as its windows and doors.

If spoken of in terms of **道** (*Dào*),
then before the Great Polarity (*Tàijí*) had yet been distinguished,
