there was originally no heaven and earth, no sun and moon—
that was **道** (*Dào*).

In terms of dwellings,
the Age of Great Simplicity had no palaces,
summer dwellings were boats and nests,
winter dwellings were caves and burrows.
Later sages transformed them into palaces,
with lofty beams and eaves to shelter against wind and rain.
From the Middle Ages onward,
customs grew refined yet decadent,
luxury and extravagance flourished,
palaces sprawled in intricate layers,
towers soared in dizzying heights,
emotions ran wild, desires unbounded,
pushing excess to its utmost.
The Most High Sage lamented the decline of the age,
and thus sighed:
*"When there was yet no dwelling,
its use was already present."*

Thus, **有** (*yǒu*) is relied upon for utility,
while **無** (*wú*) is relied upon for function.
**有** (*yǒu*) refers to the sun and moon
turning and moving to bring forth cold and heat,
to heaven and earth as the divine tripod vessel
to refine and transform all things,
to the divine dwelling under heaven
to shelter and nourish all beings,
to the chariot hub bearing and transporting
to facilitate its turning,
to vessels and utensils
to aid in drinking and eating,
to dwellings and windows
to replace nests and caves.

All these are the sages’ preparation of things and realization of utility
to benefit the world.
Thus it is said: *"**有** (*yǒu*) is relied upon for utility."*

**無** (*wú*) is relied upon for function,
meaning when heaven and earth and all things were yet **無** (*wú*),
only **道** (*Dào*) was empty and boundless.
It is because of this emptiness and boundlessness that function is realized,
and thus it is said: *"**無** (*wú*) is relied upon for function."*

The **休休庵** (*Xiūxiū’ān*) commentary states:
*"From the thirty spokes to **無** (*wú*) relied upon for function."*
Awakening to the Great Dao is called *"obtaining the body."*
One must also obtain function.
Obtaining the body but not function is called *"dead matter."*
Obtaining function but not the body is called *"playing with affairs."*
Recognizing **德** (*virtue/power*) and **道** (*Dào*),
body and function complete,
is called a *"sage of insight."*

The **Old Master** (*Lǎozi*) uniquely uses the metaphors of chariot-making and window-carving
to illustrate **無** (*wú*)’s wondrous function,
benefiting and saving the world.
Thus all deeds of those who follow the **道** (*Dào*) are beneficial.

In the world, what is **無** (*wú*) is obtained for use,
abandoning **道** (*Dào*) and **德** (*virtue/power*),
how then could one complete the human world?

Yang Zhìrén says:
*"From the thirty spokes to **無** (*wú*) relied upon for function."*
It refers to the chariot wheel.
The thirty spokes follow the pattern of a month’s days.
The wheel is the mechanism,
the turning is its function.
Heaven uses the Big Dipper as its mechanism,
humans use the mind as theirs,
gathering the original spirit as spokes around the central palace,
letting the true **氣** (*qi*) flow and move through the body,
revolving and transforming creation,
concentrating the Five Phases,
harmonizing the Four Symbols—
all are the uses of the chariot.

*"Molding clay"* refers to the potter’s wheel,
a metaphor for the same mechanism.
Without this wheel, how could vessels be made?
If humans vary their mechanisms at the central pass,
the **栲子** (*kēngzi*) will turn everywhere without obstruction.

*"Windows and doors"* are apertures.
It is like the birth of **混沌** (*Hùndùn*),
a formless mass.
If one were to carve an aperture daily,
by the seventh day **混沌** (*Hùndùn*) would die.
Humans have seven apertures;
retracting vision inward brings life,
letting it loose outward brings death.

Thus the doctrine of **有** (*yǒu*) and **無** (*wú*) is spoken of by humans.
If one applies **無** (*wú*) to all things,
**無** (*wú*) generates **有** (*yǒu*),
and obtains its function.

**無** (*wú*) within **有** (*yǒu*) harmonizes wonderfully with the Primordial.
Yet when it speaks of **有** (*yǒu*),
it means **無** (*wú*)’s defects.

To possess a single eye within the realm of **有** (*yǒu*) and **無** (*wú*)—
only then is one truly at the core of the matter.

**無** (*wú*) is the means by which all things function.
Zhuangzi said:
*"Does Heaven move itself?
Does Earth settle itself?
Do the sun and moon vie for their places?
Who directs this?
Who holds the reins?
Who remains in stillness?
When pushed into motion—
is it because of some inherent mechanism?
Or because it is bound by necessity?
Or because it moves and cannot stop itself?"*

Qingzhong further explained:
*"The thirty spokes converge at the void for their function.
All things under Heaven do not arise from **有** (*yǒu*) alone,
but from **無** (*wú*).
When at **無** (*wú*), read it as a single phrase.
At the time of the thirty spokes,
there is yet no utility of the chariot.
Yet the chariot’s function already resides within.
Thus it is said: ‘the function of the chariot.’
When shaping clay into vessels,
there is yet no utility of the utensil.
Yet the utensil’s function already resides within.
Thus it is said: ‘the function of the utensil.’
When carving doors and windows,
there is yet no utility of the dwelling.
Yet the dwelling’s function already resides within.
Thus it is said: ‘the function of the dwelling.’*

According to the *Zhou Li* [*考工记*]:
*"The chariot’s canopy is round to emulate Heaven,
the carriage’s base is square to emulate Earth,
and the thirty spokes symbolize the phases of the moon.
The **毂** (*gǔ*) is the central axle of the chariot,
where the spokes converge to form the wheel.
**埏** (*kēng*) means to blend,
**埴** (*zhí*) is clay.
The potter turns and shapes to create vessels.
**凿** (*záo*) means to pierce.
Half a door is called a **户** (*hù*),
windows beside the door are called **牖** (*yǒu*).
Another interpretation: **無** (*wú*) is emptiness, is void.
When the **毂** (*gǔ*) is hollow and empty,
the wheel can turn;
when the chariot is hollow and empty,
it can carry people.
Thus, where there is emptiness and void,
there is the function of movement and bearing.
When shaping vessels, the exterior is solid while the interior is hollow.
Where the vessel’s emptiness resides,
there is the function of containing things.
In ancient times, people lived in caves,
dug out earth to cover their dwellings,
and thus created the design of doors and windows.
Where the dwelling’s emptiness resides,
there is the function of habitation and passage.
Thus, **有** (*yǒu*) is used for utility,
and **無** (*wú*) is used for function.
The utility of vessels lies in their form,
while the function of **無** (*wú*) lies in the void.
For vessels to be useful,
their utility must manifest outwardly,
relying on emptiness for function.
For emptiness to serve its purpose,
it must be hollow within,
borrowing the vessel’s utility to fulfill it.
Thus, **無** (*wú*) depends on **有** (*yǒu*) for utility,
while **有** (*yǒu*) relies on **無** (*wú*) for function.
**無** (*wú*) speaks of the Dao beyond form,
while **有** (*yǒu*) speaks of shaped vessels.
The Dao is not revealed without vessels,
and vessels are incomplete without the Dao.
The interdependence of Dao and vessels
cannot be separated—one cannot be discarded for the other.

Another interpretation:
Bian Que said that within the human body are the five viscera,
where true *qi* converges.
Each viscera governs six *qi*,
thus forming the thirtyfold convergence—
like the thirty spokes of a chariot.
Flowing ceaselessly, they communicate through a single pivot,
just as the thirty spokes unite at the **毂** (*gǔ*).
The sage understands the pivot of transformation,
using **有** (*yǒu*) as form and substance,
the body as the furnace,
the Three Palaces as the tripod,
crafting creation within the void of indistinctness.
Like the chariot one rides,
the vessels one uses,
the dwelling one inhabits—
these exist as **有** (*yǒu*) in form,
yet as **無** (*wú*) in function.
Thus, **有** (*yǒu*) is for utility,
and **無** (*wú*) is for function.
As Wei Boyang’s *Parametric Concordance* states:
*"Use **無** (*wú*) to govern **有** (*yǒu*);*
*the function of vessels lies in emptiness."*
All these interpretations hold merit;
let them remain for those who seek enlightenment.

Xu Liuyu said:
*"The thirty spokes converge at the **毂** (*gǔ*) for their function.
This passage speaks of the sage’s insight:
the thirty spokes unite at the **毂** (*gǔ*).
Observing things to understand the body’s Dao—
this is not merely about words.
The principles of chariots, dwellings, and vessels
have been thoroughly discussed by the ancients.
This need not be repeated.
Yet the Dao of observing things to know the body
is seldom spoken of.
Consider this: the head, eyes, ears, nose, mouth,
body, hands, and feet—
all compose the self,
each with its own governance.
Though they form a single mass,
movement, speech, and laughter all originate from within.
Yet when seeking the ‘self’ (*wú*),
there is no precise location to point to.
Is it not the self without position,
enabling the body’s numbered functions?
This is what the text means by:
**‘有** (*yǒu*) **is for utility, 無** (*wú*) **is for function.’**
Readers should ponder this deeply.

Chai Yuangao said:
*"The thirty spokes converge at the **毂** (*gǔ*).
The spokes are the wheel’s boards,
the **毂** (*gǔ*) is what pierces through them.
The **毂** (*gǔ*) is the body,
the spokes are the function.
Like the heart governing all laws.
When at **無** (*wú*), there is the chariot’s function.
When there is no chariot,
who reveals the marvel of spokes and **毂** (*gǔ*)?
When shaping clay into vessels,
who reveals the marvel of dug-out dwellings?
Thus, **有** (*yǒu*) is for utility,
and **無** (*wú*) is for function.
When **有** (*yǒu*) manifests, its benefits are clear;
when **無** (*wú*) manifests, its marvels are revealed.
The heart as body, utility as function."

Su Jingjing said:
*"From ‘the thirty spokes converge at the **毂** (*gǔ*)’ to ‘for their function,’
this passage embodies Laozi’s intent—
**無** (*wú*) alone.
The **毂** (*gǔ*) is the chariot’s central axle,
the spokes are the wheel’s ribs.
Only because the **毂** (*gǔ*) is hollow within
can it contain the axle to push the wheel,
thus yielding the chariot’s function.
**埏埴** (*kēngzhí*) are the potter’s vessels—
the turning wheel.
Only because the wheel is hollow and round can it rotate,
thus yielding the vessel’s function.
Piercing doors as windows,
then the dwelling is illuminated.
Only because the windows are hollow
does the dwelling’s function emerge.
The hollowness of the **毂** (*gǔ*), the wheel, and the windows—
all are **無** (*wú*).
These three, though void in substance,
give rise to function.
Thus, the existence of chariots, vessels, and dwellings
all arise from **無** (*wú*)."*

「This too carries the meaning of *things arising from the void*.
Master Ben-yī of the One Hut said:
*"Thirty spokes converge to serve their function.*
Things are *having* (*yǒu*).
That which enables their function is *void* (*wú*).
To wield *having* for the sake of *having* is merely to let things contend with things.
Thus, if *void* lacks *having*, it has no foundation;
if *having* lacks *void*, it has no master.
It is not only chariots, dwellings, and vessels that follow this.
Speaking of the world, things are its boundaries, while the Dao is its mystery.
Speaking of a single person, the body is its substance, while the mind is its void.
Yet *void* profits *having*, and *having* serves *void*—
these two are never truly separate.
Thus, there are no things outside the Dao,
nor a body outside the mind.

This is the *utilitarian* function of *void*,
not the *substantial* function of *void*.
If we speak in terms of substance and function,
then *void* is the substance, while *having* is the function.

Stone Pool [commentary] states:
*"Thirty spokes unite at one hub,
yet it is their void that yields the chariot’s function.
The potter’s wheel shapes vessels,
yet it is their void that yields the vessel’s function.
Piercing doors as windows for a dwelling—
yet it is their void that yields the dwelling’s function.
Thus, *having* brings profit,
while *void* brings function.

The thirty spokes unite at one hub
to form the chariot.
Yet the axle’s resting place must be hollow within,
only then can it move.
If the chariot were solid and not hollow,
what use would the hub serve?
The potter’s wheel shapes vessels,
yet the clay must be hollowed to form its handles and lids,
only then can the vessel be complete.
If the potter’s wheel did not rely on void for function,
how could the vessel ever be made?
Piercing doors as windows for a dwelling—
yet it must allow light and passage,
only then can one dwell and reside.
If it were not hollow and open,
what use would the dwelling have?
Thus, *having* brings profit,
while *void* brings function.

That which brings profit through *having* are chariots, vessels, and dwellings.
That which brings function through *void* all depend on emptiness.
To illustrate for humanity,
one must have a void mind to receive the Dao—
the Dao gathers in the void.

Some say that vessels must be hollow to contain,
and dwellings must be hollow to inhabit—
yet this is the very *void* of the potter’s wheel, doors, and windows.
Others say that before these chariots, vessels, and dwellings existed,
their functions already existed—
yet this may not be Laozi’s intent.

*Complete Commentary on the True Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue*, Volume Seventeen, ends here.
#1 *Tang qí wú* ["*Tang*" likely should be "*Dāng*"].」
